Bestial fur covers your body, your facial features become feral, and you gain the following benefits:

  • Your walking speed increases by 10 feet.
  • You gain &Reference[rule=darkvision] with a range of 120 feet.
  • You make Strength-based attack rolls with advantage.
  • Your melee weapon attacks deal an extra [[/damage 1d6 type=force]] damage on a hit.

Great Tree

Your skin appears barky, leaves sprout from your hair, and you gain the following benefits:

  • You gain 10 temporary hit points.
  • You make Constitution saving throws with advantage.
  • You make Dexterity- and Wisdom-based attack rolls with advantage.
  • While you are on the ground, the ground within 15 feet of you is &Reference[rule=difficultterrain]{difficult terrain} for your enemies.

Shalkoc Zornax.name: Torch
Shalkoc Zornax.description: A torch burns for 1 hour, providing bright light in a 20-foot radius and dim light for an additional 20 feet. If you make a melee attack with a burning torch and hit, it deals 1 fire damage.

buildings.effectText: +1d4 bonus to Downtime Activity: Research checks
buildings.flavorText: Within its halls of thought, scholars question the old ways and craft the new, the academy's influence rippling through the city as it births both wisdom and unrest.
grants: +1d4 bonus to Downtime Activity: Research checks
buildings.name: Academy

buildings.effectText: Enables travel and trade via airships.
buildings.flavorText: A bustling hub of towering scaffolds and massive mooring lines, the dockyard is where skyships are built, loaded, and launched. Merchants and smugglers alike strike deals beneath the towering hulls, while city officials struggle to keep control of what goes in and out.
grants: Enables travel and trade via airships.
buildings.name: Airship Dockyard

buildings.effectText: Downtime Activity: Training (Alchemist's Tools); +1 bonus to skill checks using Alchemist's Tools while in the laboratory;
buildings.flavorText: A modest workshop of bubbling flasks and pungent fumes, the alchemist's laboratory is a sanctuary for discovery, where one mind's quiet pursuit of knowledge might yield wonders.
grants: Downtime Activity: Training (Alchemist's Tools); +1 bonus to skill checks using Alchemist's Tools while in the laboratory;
buildings.name: Alchemist's Laboratory

buildings.flavorText: Here, within halls lined with models and plans, architects refine construction methods, making ambitious projects achievable with less effort.
buildings.name: Architect’s Guild

buildings.flavorText: Inside the barracks, the clamor of armor and weapons is constant, a reassuring sound for some and a reminder of authority's ever-watchful presence for others.
buildings.name: Barracks

buildings.effectText: Trader (Illicit goods); (optional) Increase available items for Downtime Activity: Buying a Magic Item by 1d4 but increase purchase price for all offered items 1d4 x 25%
buildings.flavorText: Hidden behind unmarked doors and veiled glances, the black market thrives in defiance of law and morality, a realm where rare and illicit goods, services, and secrets are only a matter of coin.
grants: Trader (Illicit goods); (optional) Increase available items for Downtime Activity: Buying a Magic Item by 1d4 but increase purchase price for all offered items 1d4 x 25%
buildings.name: Black Market

buildings.effectText: Trader (Herbs); Gold cost of Downtime Activity: Brewing Healing Potions is reduced by 20%
buildings.flavorText: Nestled in vibrant greenery, the botanical garden blends nature and science, its carefully tended plants offering rare resources to those who know how to harvest their potential.
grants: Trader (Herbs); Gold cost of Downtime Activity: Brewing Healing Potions is reduced by 20%
buildings.name: Botanical Garden

buildings.effectText: Downtime Activity: Training (Disguise Kit);
buildings.flavorText: Whispers of discontent fill the streets as the brothel flourishes, a gilded cage where the powerful indulge while the common folk see their dignity sold one night at a time.
buildings.name: Brothel

buildings.effectText: Downtime Activity: Training (Carpenter's Tools); +1 bonus to skill checks using Carpenter's Tools while in the workshop;
buildings.flavorText: From dawn to dusk, the hum of saws and the scent of fresh timber define the carpenter's workshop, a place where craftsmanship turns rough wood into everything from simple furniture to the grand beams of the city's halls
grants: Downtime Activity: Training (Carpenter's Tools); +1 bonus to skill checks using Carpenter's Tools while in the workshop;
buildings.name: Carpenter's Workshop

buildings.effectText: While the city follows the deity's edicts, the deity grants a realm effect to the city.
buildings.flavorText: Towering over the city as a fortress of faith, the cathedral is both a place of worship and a symbol of divine protection. Few dare challenge a city under the watchful gaze of its patron deity.
grants: While the city follows the deity's edicts, the deity grants a realm effect to the city.
buildings.name: Cathedral

buildings.effectText: The city's authority is doubled for defense against sieges.
buildings.flavorText: A city well-defended is a city that endures. The walls ensure safety, though merchants grumble at the restricted flow of goods.
grants: The city's authority is doubled for defense against sieges.
buildings.name: City Walls

buildings.flavorText: A hive of hammering, shouting, and relentless movement, the construction yard turns raw resources into grand visions, though its clamor often drowns out the city's quieter joys.
buildings.name: Construction Yard

buildings.flavorText: Fair trials, strict rulings—this is where disputes are settled and criminals face judgment. It keeps the city in order, even if it stifles progress.
buildings.name: Courthouse

buildings.effectText: Trader (Bugman's Ale) ; Downtime Activity: Training (Brewer's Supplies); +1 bonus to skill checks using Brewer's Supplies while in the brewery;
buildings.flavorText: The air around the Dwarven Brewery is always thick with the smell of brewing ale. It is a place where dwarven tradition meets celebration, its warm hearth a beacon on cold nights.
grants: Trader (Bugman's Ale) ; Downtime Activity: Training (Brewer's Supplies); +1 bonus to skill checks using Brewer's Supplies while in the brewery;
buildings.name: Dwarven Brewery

buildings.effectText: Trader (gadgets & bombs); Downtime Activity: Training (Tinker's Tools); +1 bonus to skill checks using Tinker's Tools while in the workshop;
buildings.flavorText: A noisy, chaotic space where problems are solved with gears, levers, and the occasional explosion. Some see it as the future—others see it as a disaster waiting to happen.
grants: Trader (gadgets & bombs); Downtime Activity: Training (Tinker's Tools); +1 bonus to skill checks using Tinker's Tools while in the workshop;
buildings.name: Engineer's Workshop

buildings.flavorText: Nestled amidst open fields, the farm is a lifeline for the town, producing fresh crops and bringing families together in shared labor and celebration of the land.
buildings.name: Farm

buildings.effectText: Downtime Activity: Pit Fighting & Magical Dueling
buildings.flavorText: The fighting pit draws crowds and coin alike, but some fear its focus on bloodsport dulls the town's desire for anything more meaningful.
grants: Downtime Activity: Pit Fighting & Magical Dueling
buildings.name: Fighting Pit

buildings.flavorText: Few things enforce authority like the sight of a hanging body. The gallows keep the city in line, though the weight of fear dampens ambition and sows unease among the people.
buildings.name: Gallows

buildings.effectText: Downtime Activity: Training (Glassblower's Tools); +1 bonus to skill checks using Glassblower's Tools while in the glasshouse;
buildings.flavorText: From humble drinking vessels to intricate lenses, the Glasshouse provides the city with objects of both utility and exquisite beauty.
grants: Downtime Activity: Training (Glassblower's Tools); +1 bonus to skill checks using Glassblower's Tools while in the glasshouse;
buildings.name: Glasshouse

buildings.effectText: Trader (Spices);
buildings.flavorText: Glim Billowdwaddle's bustling emporium draws spice merchants and food enthusiasts alike, though its extravagance has stirred resentment among the common folk.
buildings.name: Glim's Emporium of Exotic Flavours

buildings.effectText: Downtime Activity: Training (Instrument (Bagpipes, Drum, Horn), Language (Goblin));
buildings.flavorText: Chaotic, noisy, and endlessly inventive, the goblin quarters overflow with peculiar contraptions and questionable experiments, their ingenuity both a marvel and a menace.
grants: Downtime Activity: Training (Instrument (Bagpipes, Drum, Horn), Language (Goblin));
buildings.name: Goblin Quarters

buildings.flavorText: A towering symbol of plenty, the granary secures the fruits of the harvest, ensuring that even in scarcity, no family need go without.
buildings.name: Granary

buildings.flavorText: The graveyard stands as a solemn reminder of lives past, a quiet place of reflection that fosters unity among the living through shared grief and memory.
buildings.name: Graveyard

buildings.flavorText: A humble sanctuary for the destitute, where kindness outweighs profit, though not without resentment from those who see generosity as wasteful.
buildings.name: Homeless Shelter

buildings.effectText: Downtime Activity: Training (Dice Set, Playing Cards Set);
buildings.flavorText: A haven for locals and travellers alike, the inn stands as a cornerstone of the community, a place where the weary find respite and the curious find intrigue.
grants: Downtime Activity: Training (Dice Set, Playing Cards Set);
buildings.name: Inn

buildings.effectText: Downtime Activity: Training (Thieves' Tools)
buildings.flavorText: Behind its barred windows, the jail holds those who defy the law, its presence a quiet warning to any who might challenge the town's authority.
buildings.name: Jail

buildings.effectText: Downtime Activity: Training (Calligrapher's Supplies); +1 bonus to skill checks using Calligrapher's Supplies while in the library;
buildings.flavorText: The library stands as a testament to the value of knowledge, where every book and tome represents a step toward a brighter, more enlightened future.
grants: Downtime Activity: Training (Calligrapher's Supplies); +1 bonus to skill checks using Calligrapher's Supplies while in the library;
buildings.name: Library

buildings.effectText: Trader (basic goods)
buildings.flavorText: Vendors call out their wares, children weave through the crowds, and deals are struck with firm handshakes. The old ways of trade and barter hold strong in this lively square.
buildings.name: Market Square

buildings.effectText: Trader (Holy Water, Restorative Potions);
buildings.flavorText: Within these walls, monks devote themselves to prayer and labor, their careful craftsmanship supporting both their faith and the city beyond.
buildings.name: Monastery

buildings.effectText: +1 bonus to Charisma (Persuasion) and Charisma (Intimidation) checks against nobles and high-ranking officials from other factions.
buildings.flavorText: A symbol of the town's might and wealth, the monument inspires awe in some but frustration in others, who see it as an unnecessary display of vanity.
grants: +1 bonus to Charisma (Persuasion) and Charisma (Intimidation) checks against nobles and high-ranking officials from other factions.
buildings.name: Monument

buildings.effectText: Prevents planar travel in a 10 mile radius sphere. Can be activated and deactivated as an action.
buildings.flavorText: Built around the Nullstone Monolith, the nexus sacrifices innovation and trade to create a sanctuary impervious to magical intrusion.
grants: Prevents planar travel in a 10 mile radius sphere. Can be activated and deactivated as an action.
buildings.name: Nexus of Binding

buildings.flavorText: A place of refuge for those without families, the orphanage provides care for the town's lost children, though some of the guilds' members bemoan the loss of cheap labor.

pages.name: The Structure of the Planes
pages.content:
A plane is a vast dimension with various physical traits, such as gravity and chronology, and metaphysical traits, such as alignment and quintessential composition. Each plane in the Great Beyond represents a separate, concurrent, encapsulated universe that exists independently of each other, although most have connections linking them together. The Great Beyond is a term that encompasses all the planes of existence that make up the known multiverse.

Each plane is effectively a standalone infinite universe, differentiating them from demiplanes, which are finite and measurable. Planes are also often traversable via means of planar travel, while demiplanes are sometimes subject to more restrictive access.

Planes might be subdivided into layers, each having their own physical properties similar to distinct planes. These layered planes are interconnected through physical connections, gates, or fluid edges. Layers are usually traversed in a specific order most often visualized as a stack, with connections to other external planes occurring on the top or bottom layers. The levels of Hell represent the most prominently known example of layered planes in the Great Beyond.

The Inner Planes

The term Inner Planes refers to the planes created directly from the collision of positive and negative energy. This includes the Ethereal Sea, the Material Plane and its two reflections inside it, and the Elemental Planes surrounding it. The Inner Planes are considered to be of true neutral alignment.

The Etherial Sea

This transitive plane is created by the collision and subsequent intermingling of the fundamental forces of Positive Energy and Negative Energy. This collision and intermingling is considered to be the very mechanism behind creation itself, as evidenced by the fact that new souls are only created on the planes wholly contained within the Ethereal Sea - the Material Plane and, to a lesser extent, the Feywild and the Shadowfell.

The Material Plane

Also known as the Prime Material, Wellspring of Souls, Fulcrum of Existence, or simply as the mortal world, this inner plane lies at the very center of the Ethereal Sea, where positive and negative energy are evenly distributed. As such, most souls that ever sprung into existence were born on the material plane.

Feywild

The Feywild is the material plane's positive twin, barely touched by negative energy. This makes everything on this inner plane much more intense compared to the neutral material plane. Life flourishes, colors are more vibrant, emotions are unrestrained, change is faster and more chaotic. Travellers from the material plane have often described their experiences in the Feywild as "dreamlike" but the plane's connection to dreams is still widely debated amongst scholars. While some believe that the soul of a dreaming creature temporarily shifts into the Feywild, others think that it's visitors from this plane that bring dreams with them.

Shadowfell

The counterpart to the Feywild, this inner plane and twin of the material plane is primarily influenced by negative energy. It's marked by a bleak and gloomy atmosphere that dulls emotions and fades colors to nothing but shades of grey. Death and shadows shroud the plane and the few that visit it and return recount an oppressive feeling of emptiness and depression. Nightmares are also often associated with the Shadowfell, most scholars however think those, just like other dreams, stem from the Feywild.

The Elemental Planes

The four elemental planes of Water, Air, Fire, and Earth surround and border the Ethereal Sea. They are believed to be formed from the excess of the positive and negative energies flowing into the Ethereal Sea fail to coalesce into mortal souls. Instead this energy floats onto the shore of one of the elemental planes and becomes part of it.

Elementals, the creatures native to these planes, are not born but rather manifest from the essence of the plane itself and return to it when they die. As such, elementals represent an form of life and death that's wholly different and disconnected from that of souls.

Each elemental plane is a representation of its element in all the different forms that element can take. The borders between two elemental planes are not clearly defined and it is thus often advised to imagine the elemental planes as one continuous band.

One notable feature of the Elemental Planes is that their inner border also marks the farthest extent of the Ethereal Sea and thus of travel through the Ethereal Sea.

The Outer Planes

The Outer Planes lie beyond the Elemental Planes, suspended within the boundless Astral Sea. These are layered realms with each layer possessing its own unique characteristics, appearing as distinct worlds stacked one upon the other, interconnected through specific pathways, portals, or shifting borders. Access to inner layers is often restricted or requires specific, often arduous, means of passage, with planar travelers commonly arriving upon the outermost or "first" layer of any given plane.

The Outer Planes are also the dominions of gods and other ascended beings, who carve their own realms from the fabric of these planes. These domains range from modest domains to spanning across multiple entire layers. These domains are reflections of divine will, where the deity's power is near absolute and the rules of reality are based solely to reflect their ideals.

Fundamentally different from the neutral Inner Planes, the Outer Planes are intrinsically tied to the concepts of alignment, belief, and the ultimate fate of mortal souls. Out of the nine traditional alignments, all but true neutral are embodied by an Outer Plane - their respective moral and ethical philosophies distilled into physical and metaphysical realities. They are often categorized into Upper and Lower Planes based on their alignment on the good/evil axis.

The River of Souls & Pharasma’s Judgment

The ultimate fate of a mortal soul is intrinsically tied to Pharasma and to the Outer Planes. Little is truly understood of Pharasma herself and her motivations appear singularly focused on the sanctity and preservation of souls. Indeed, she is known to grant divine power only to those who dedicate themselves to protecting mortal souls from destruction.

Upon death, a mortal's soul is drawn into the River of Souls, a metaphysical current that lies beyond a veil only the souls of perished mortals can cross. Its place within the known cosmology still remains a mystery to scholars. This river culminates at the Spire of Eternity, Pharasma's domain. It is here that the soul undergoes judgment, and is sent to its finaly destination.

Souls judged to be True Neutral are typically exceptions to this journey's end, often being destined for rebirth upon the Material Plane or one of its reflections. However, souls bearing any other alignment are sent to the Outer Plane where the soul will find its kin. Pharasma's judgment is thus understood not as a system of reward or punishment for deeds committed in life, but rather as an impartial assessment of the soul's true belonging.

Upon reaching their destined planes, souls undergo a profound metamorphosis. They become an integral part of that plane's very essence and are often reshaped or reborn into new forms of existence known as Outsiders. Consequently, each Outer Plane can be viewed as the collective, distilled essence of all mortal souls of its corresponding alignment that have ever existed, a vast reservoir of aligned energy given form.

These beings, known as Outsiders—a term encompassing entities such as angels, demons, devils, archons, and inevitables, among others—are native inhabitants of their respective planes. They typically retain no specific memory of their previous mortal existence, instead becoming pure embodiments of their plane's alignment. When an Outsider is slain outside its native plane, its essence is not destroyed but is instead drawn back to its home plane, where it will eventually reform, sometimes retaining its personality and memories. The true destruction of an Outsider's soul is widely believed to be possible only if its soul is destroyed upon its native plane of existence.

The Upper Planes

Heaven (Lawful Good)

Also known as the Seven Heavens, this plane goodness shaped by law and justice tempered with mercy. Even though it and each of its layers are infinitely large, it appears to visitors as a gigantic single mountain with a flat summit. Planar travel is only possible from and to the city named Heaven's Shore (also known colloquially as "Heathen Shore") on the bottommost layer, Threshold, and Archons and other celestials visitors keep a close eye on visitors to ensure none of the plane's strong laws are broken.

Nirvana (Neutral Good)

This plane, also sometimes called the Sanctuary of Enlightenment, embodies concept of pure good without being overly restricted by law nor dissipated by the randomness of chaos. Its natives are the contemplative and wise celestials, often taking the shape of animals or angels, who guide spirits to enlightenment and unity with the plane and with themselves

Elysium (Chaotic Good)

Colloquially known as the Dreamers' Dream, it represents the ultimate expression of wild freedom and compassion. Home to the wild and freedom loving azata, it is a place of uninhibited love, art, and expression. The beauty of its untouched wilderness is almost overwhelming, ranging from wild forests to foam-peaked seas, to impossibly high mountains, interspersed with hard-to-reach green valleys, the landscape embodying the lovely and peaceful, and the passionate and wild, all at the same time. None of the normal trappings of civilization can be found here; the natives prefer to live in small groups and gather for larger meetings only occasionally. To outsiders, the untamed and dangerous wilds can seem harsh and uninviting, but the initiated understand its true nature: Elysium is a place promoting selfless cooperation combined with self-sufficiency and the complete lack of external authority.

The Medial Planes

Mechanus (Lawful Neutral)

This Outer Plane, its singular layer also known as Axis, is the plane of absolute, perfect, and impersonal order. Some theories hold that its continent-sized gears make up the clockwork of time throughout the cosmos and that time itself would stop if the gears ceased their turning. Everything here exists to fit into the greater scheme of things, and each individual's purpose is to fill a role like a gear in a machine. Passion, fantasy, and illusion do not exist, except for what might be brought in by visitors and would not be well received by the Modrons, Inevitables, and Aeons home to this plane.

Limbo (Chaotic Neutral)

Collectively referred to as the Maelstrom, this plane is supreme chaos, an ever-changing storm of elemental matter, color, thought, and energy. Even though it is easy to shape with nothing but a thought, dampening the chaos down to livable levels and producing a safe environment, it only takes a single moment of distraction for any creations fall apart again. Demigods and other powerful beings do not have this burden and can create realms that survive even if they left Limbo. As such, Limbo has become the chosen home of a vast variety of beings not native to the plane.

The Lower Planes

Hell (Lawful Evil)

The Nine Hells, sometimes referred to as the Pit, is the ultimate expression of evil order in the Great Beyond. A plane of sinister wickedness and institutional cruelty, the devils native to it are organized into a strict caste system with a very rigid chain of command. As well as "hellish", the adjective to describe Hell is "infernal". All nine layers of Hell are the domain of Asmodeus, and each one is overseen by one of his lieutenants, the dreaded Archdevils. Planar travel is only possible from and to the topmost layer, Avernus, and a traveler must pass through each layer in order to arrive at the next lower one.

Hades (Neutral Evil)

Also known as Gehenna or Abaddon, this plane is a wasteland of infinite and apocalyptic proportions and home to the fiends known as Yugoloths or Daemons. It is dominated by the citadels of the Apocalypse Riders but includes vast stretches of uninhabited wastelands, and smaller holdings of minor warlords and vassals. It lies unnaturally quiet, like a land depopulated by war or plague, and is covered in a cold, black mist. The air feels heavy and rotten, and what little light exists is provided by a strange, sun-like object in permanent eclipse.

Abyss (Chaotic Evil)

The infinite layers of the Abyss, or the Outer Rifts as it's sometimes referred to, are the home of demons and the embodiment of evil unfettered by law. These realms are pockets in which the fabric of the Outer Rifts has slowed its relentless, changing insanity to a near-reality pace. These places are often ruled by a demon lord, either thanks to the lord's own power over the area, or simply because demon lords are attracted to a place to build a fortress and armies. Some Abyssal realms have remained relatively unchanged for aeons and are designated as anchored realms, or anchor realms.

The Astral Sea

This transitive plane is often imagined as an ocean of aether, in which all other known planes of existence are suspended. The Astral can be reached from almost any point on an inner plane, elemental plane, or first layer of any outer plane. Most of the Astral Sea is a vast, empty expanse, with swirling clouds of white and gray illuminated by motes of light. Visitors occasionally stumble upon the corpse of a dead god or chunks of matter, broken off from their original plane, drifting forever in the silvery void. The Astral has no gravity but objects do retain their mass so one could throw small items or push off from large objects to move in the weightless environment. The pull of gravity can however be felt on floating objects of sufficient size or where created by a magical field. Creatures on the Astral Plane don't age naturally. For this reason, some creatures that live on the Astral Plane establish outposts on other planes, often the Material Plane, so their children can grow to maturity.

The Void

Also called the Far Realm, this term refers to whatever lies beyond the largely understood cosmology of the multiverse. Very little is known about the Void, as research into it has driven even gods to madness, and scholars generally do not consider it to be part of the Great Beyond. The only thing that's understood about this plane is that it lies beyond the Astral Sea and it's been theorized that the Astral Sea, and with it all other known planes of existence, are nothing but a bubble within the Void.

Demiplanes and Extradimensional Spaces

Sometimes also referred to as False Planes, these finite pockets within an infinite true plane (most often the Astral Plane), are extradimensional spaces come into being by a variety of means. Some are created by spells while others are natural folds of reality pinched off from the rest of the multiverse. While planes are also often traversable via means of planar travel, access to demiplanes is generally much restrictive. Theoretically, a Plane Shift spell can carry travelers to a demiplane, but the proper frequency required for the tuning fork can be extremely hard to acquire. The Gate spell is more reliable, assuming the caster knows of the demiplane.

pages.name: Draconic Aspects and their Kin - A Study
pages.content:
A Survey of the Draconic Age

The history of the Material Plane is marked by epochs of great power and sweeping change, yet none is so foundational to the modern world, nor so tragically truncated, as the Draconic Age. This era, which concluded with an abruptness that still confounds historians some four millennia later, was defined by the presence of Dragons—beings of immense power who were not merely inhabitants of the world, but are believed to have been an inexorable part of its fundamental nature.

The end of the Draconic Age was nothing less than absolute. The historical record is starkly clear: in a period of astonishing brevity, the entire species of dragonkind vanished from the plane. This disappearance is immediately preceded in the few surviving chronicles of the time by mentions of a period of immense, plane-wide turmoil, an event known to us only by a single name: The Convergence. The exact nature of this cataclysm remains one of the greatest unanswered questions of our time.

The consequences of this vanishing were swift and catastrophic. The vast and powerful Dragonborn empiresm civilizations built upon draconic patronage and philosophy, crumbled into ruin within a few short centuries, their source of power, guidance, and authority irrevocably severed.

In the millennia of study since, scholars have sought to understand the nature of the beings who held such sway over the world. Lacking living subjects, research has relied upon the painstaking analysis of ancient texts, archaeological evidence, and the interpretation of the enduring myths. From this vast body of work, a standard analytical framework has emerged. Modern historiography categorizes dragonkind into two broad philosophical kin: the Chromatic and the Metallic. This division is not believed to be one the dragons used themselves, but rather represents a useful paradigm for understanding their two fundamentally different, and often conflicting, approaches to their role as guardians of the Material Plane.

The Progenitor Myth

The genesis of dragonkind, as understood from the synthesis of numerous ancient records, is inseparable from the very fabric of the Material Plane. It is a tale not of evolutionary ascent or divine creation by an external power, but of a singular, cataclysmic event that fundamentally altered the nature of the world.

The widely held narrative posits that in a primordial age, the world was governed by two native deities, Bahamut and Tiamat. Unlike the gods of the Outer Planes, these twin progenitors are believed to have been born of the Material Plane itself, their existence a direct manifestation of its nascent, chaotic energies, not unlike that of the Elemental Planes. Their story is one of antithetical natures locked in an eternal conflict that ultimately culminated in their mutual annihilation. In their final, violent moments, their divine essence, their very blood, is said to have poured forth, mingling and from it, the first ten dragons, the great Aspects, arose.

While this origin story is pieced together from countless sources, from Dragonborn doctrinal texts to carvings on cyclopean ruins, its most eloquent and well-preserved articulation is found in the artifact known as the Redwind Sands Fragment. Discovered in the last century, this tablet has become a cornerstone of modern draconic studies. It reads:

From plane's own core, the gods are born,
their being shaped, their fate is sworn.

Tiamat and Bahamut, twins gods of old,
in hatred's grip, their conflict bold.

Their clash laid waste, no corner spared,
the plane engulfed, a realm ensnared.

Their last embrace, their breaths entwined,
life sparked anew, from death combined.

Hate's demise, a sacred birth,
ten Aspects rose, from ashes' worth.

The analysis of this fragment has dominated scholarly discourse. The opening stanza, "From plane's own core, the gods are born," is of paramount importance, as it supports the theory of native divinity, separating Bahamut and Tiamat from the pantheons of the Outer Planes. The term "twins" is a subject of ongoing debate. While some literalists maintain it implies a familial bond, the prevailing interpretation views it metaphorically, suggesting they were two equal and opposing forces born of a single origin.

It is crucial to distinguish the primordial shaping of the world described in the third stanza from the later cataclysm of The Convergence. The "clash laid waste" is understood not as an event of ending, but of violent creation, the forging of the world as we know it through divine conflict.

The final couplets are the most philosophically significant. The phrases "last embrace" and "Hate's demise" are interpreted by most scholars not as an act of reconciliation, but as the moment their conflict reached its only possible conclusion: a perfect, final equilibrium in mutual destruction. From this union of opposites, destruction and creation, order and chaos, good and evil, a "sacred birth" occurred. This concept is central to all further study: that every dragon, regardless of its philosophical leaning, carries within it the blended, paradoxical essence of both progenitors.

Author's Note: Eyes as Vessels of the Soul

A compelling and well-supported body of theory posits that the very eyes of a dragon were not mere sensory organs but vessels for its very soul. It is believed that one eye housed the good-aligned essence of Bahamut, and the other, the evil-aligned essence of Tiamat. Some speculate this created a constant internal dialogue that defined the dragon’s nature.

This theory is supported by ancient tales of one-eyed dragons, who are invariably depicted as beings of extreme moral alignment. Having lost the counter-balancing perspective, they fall into either unwavering virtue or irredeemable evil.

A significant debate, however, centers on whether this division was consistent. A prominent school of thought posits that Bahamut's essence was always found in the right eye, and Tiamat's in the left. Proponents point to the curious endurance of certain idioms across nearly all languages—phrases such as "doing the right thing" and the "evil eye"—as potential cultural remnants of a time when this anatomical reality was known.

The Chromatic Kin

The first of the two great philosophical divisions within modern draconic studies is the paradigm of the Chromatic Kin. This category encompasses the Black, Blue, Green, Red, and White dragons. The unifying thread among these five is a philosophy of guardianship centered on the primal, foundational, and often immutable truths of existence.

The Chromatic worldview does not concern itself with abstract concepts of societal progress or cultivated ideals. Instead, it holds that the Material Plane is governed by fundamental laws—the reality of physical power, the sanctity of the bloodline, the instinct of the predator, or the core imperative to survive. Their guardianship was one of preserving and enforcing these essential pillars, believing that a world which loses touch with these truths becomes a hollow and fragile artifice, doomed to collapse. Their philosophies are thus expressions of the world as it is, in its most raw and honest form.

Dahak the Black

"Only the strongest survive and prosper, so I must be the strongest of all." —Dahak’s ideal of Might, modern interpretation

For Dahak, it is believed that might was not an abstract concept but the singular, organizing principle of reality. He saw himself as the ultimate embodiment of this truth, a living standard against which all other power could be measured. In his view, a world where the weak were allowed to persist was a world courting disaster. His role as a guardian was therefore to be the ultimate challenger, a constant and unyielding force that would shatter not only external foes but also any power structure not founded on true, demonstrable strength.

The historical impact of this ideal is one of stark duality. On one hand, certain chronicles praise Black Dragons as agents of necessary change, crediting them with shattering corrupt, decaying empires and clearing the way for more vigorous civilizations to rise from the ashes. On the other hand, different records detail the enslavement of entire regions under the heel of a tyrant, where the ideal of might was interpreted as a simple right to dominate. This demonstrates how the same core philosophy could be the source of both violent renewal and brutal oppression.

Ishtar the Blue

"The first cracks in a breaking world are severed ties of blood and it is our duty to prevent and mend them." —Ishtar’s ideal of Family, modern interpretation

Ishtar, it is believed, saw the integrity of the bloodline not as a social construct but as a cosmic law. For her, kinship was the sacred, fundamental architecture of reality. Her guardianship was that of a divine matriarch, ensuring the continuation of lineages and the sanctity of ancestral oaths. She viewed a broken dynasty or a forgotten ancestry as a wound upon the world itself, one which she was divinely obligated to prevent or cauterize, preserving the continuity that allowed life and culture to persist through the ages.

Numerous Dragonborn dynasties chronicled long periods of stability and prosperity, attributing them to the judicious oversight of a Blue Dragon patron who enforced succession and sacred covenants. Conversely, the histories of other realms cite this very ideal as the philosophical basis for periods of intense xenophobia and the creation of rigid, oppressive caste systems. It is clear that the interpretation of "family" could lead to either the steadfast foundation of a society or the construction of an inescapable prison of birthright.

Azag the Green

"Destroying your foes without exposing yourself to danger is an art." —Azag’s ideal of Cunning, modern interpretation

It is held that for Azag, cunning was the highest expression of a primal truth: that the mind is the ultimate weapon. He viewed direct confrontation not as brave, but as a failure of intellect. His philosophy of guardianship was that of the master predator, one who never engaged in a fair fight. To him, the world was a complex web of motivations and secrets, and true protection came from subtly manipulating that web; turning enemies against one another, unraveling plots from the shadows, and achieving victory so completely that the vanquished never even knew they were at war.

The consequences of this philosophy were dictated by the individual dragon's ultimate aim. In some fragmented histories, Green Dragons are revered as unseen guardians who averted wars and toppled conspiracies through masterful intrigue. Yet other accounts describe kingdoms descending into ruinous civil strife, the origins of which are traced to the intricate meddling of a Green Dragon who pursued cunning as an art for its own sake, without a clear protective goal.

Girra the Red

"Fire destroys, but it can also temper when it is applied carefully—if the material tested is strong enough." —Girra’s ideal of Responsibility, modern interpretation

For Girra, the immense power of fire was not a tool to be used, but a fundamental reality to be managed. Her philosophy was born from the conviction that only a being of supreme self-control and wisdom could be entrusted with such force. Her role as a guardian was to be the ultimate steward of power. The accumulation of legendary hoards, therefore, is understood not as an act of greed, but as the sequestration of power, taking it from the hands of the "irresponsible" to be kept under her judicious watch.

The interpretation of this ideal led to the most dramatic of outcomes. Epic poems celebrate Red Dragons who acted as catalysts for greatness, their fiery trials forging heroes and testing the resolve of nations. In these stories, destruction was a tool for tempering. In stark contrast, historical annals document reigns of terror where "Responsibility" was interpreted as a mandate for absolute dominion. These accounts describe cities annihilated for the slightest defiance, illustrating how the philosophy of stewardship could be twisted into a justification for unquestionable and devastating tyranny.

Arali the White

"The universe is harsh and unforgiving, and so am I. I do whatever it takes to survive." —Arali’s ideal of Survival, modern interpretation

Arali, it is theorized, perceived all other philosophies as dangerous delusions built upon a single, non-negotiable truth: existence. For her, survival was the only law that could not be broken. Her guardianship was to be the living embodiment of this law - a constant, chilling reminder of the universe's fundamental indifference. By embodying a pure, cold pragmatism, she was thought to prevent the world from growing too decadent and too far removed from the essential, brutal reality of the struggle to endure.

The application of this stark ideal is a subject of profound scholarly debate. One school of thought posits that the actions of White Dragons, while locally devastating, had a larger ecological or even cosmic purpose, acting as a force of planetary triage that culled the weak to ensure the long-term viability of the whole. A second, equally supported view holds that the ideal was interpreted on a purely individual level. In these accounts, the White Dragon is not a malevolent entity, but a supremely pragmatic predator, whose actions were not driven by cruelty but by a focused and absolute adherence to the law of its own preservation, regardless of the consequences for others.

The Metallic Kin

The second great division within draconic studies is the paradigm of the Metallic Kin, a category encompassing the Brass, Bronze, Copper, Gold, and Silver dragons. The philosophies uniting this group stand in conceptual opposition to their Chromatic counterparts. Where the Chromatics focused on the immutable, primal truths of the world, the Metallics concerned themselves with cultivated ideals—the intellectual and moral concepts that elevate civilization above mere existence.

The Metallic worldview holds that the Material Plane's true strength lies not in its raw state, but in its potential for growth, learning, and betterment. Their ideals of guardianship are thus centered on constructive principles: the gathering of perspectives, the fostering of progress, the creation of beauty, the application of foresight, and the guidance of leadership. Theirs was a philosophy of nurture, of shaping the world not by enforcing what it is, but by striving to guide it toward what it could be.

Nabu the Brass

"Everyone sees things differently, so if you want to know about the world, gather as many different points of view as you can." —Nabu’s ideal of Perspective, modern interpretation

For Nabu, it is believed, ignorance was the greatest threat to the world. He saw conflict, hatred, and prejudice as symptoms of a singular disease: a failure to see the world from another's point of view. His guardianship was that of a master archivist and diplomat. His philosophy dictated that true understanding, and therefore true peace, could only be achieved by collecting and considering the vast multitude of truths held by all creatures. To preserve a story, to facilitate a conversation, was to build a defense against the darkness of misunderstanding.

The legacy of this ideal is one of profound knowledge, though its utility is debated. In many accounts, Brass Dragons are credited with the founding of great libraries and the brokering of seemingly impossible peace accords between ancient enemies, their actions fostering eras of enlightenment and cooperation. However, other records criticize this philosophy for its potential to lead to moral paralysis. In these cases, a Brass Dragon's obsession with gathering all perspectives is thought to have led to inaction in the face of clear injustice, with the dragon choosing to document an atrocity from all sides rather than intervening to stop it.

Erra the Bronze

"Conflict drives evolution. Ever has the spark of war ignited the fires of advancement." —Erra’s ideal of Progress, modern interpretation

Erra, it is thought, viewed peace not as a final goal, but as a dangerous state of stagnation. For her, the universe was defined by change and adaptation, and the primary catalyst for such growth was conflict. Her philosophy of guardianship was not to prevent war, but to ensure it was meaningful. She believed that struggle, whether on the battlefield or in the forge, was the crucible in which new technologies, new strategies, and stronger societies were created. A world without conflict was a world that had ceased to evolve.

The impact of this philosophy was both creative and destructive. On one hand, Bronze Dragons are celebrated in many military histories as patrons of righteous wars and heroic innovation. They are said to have armed besieged kingdoms and taught brilliant strategies, their intervention turning a desperate defense into a catalyst for an entire generation of technological and societal advancement. Conversely, there are darker suggestions that some Bronze Dragons, seeing a region as too peaceful and soft, would covertly instigate conflict to spur "progress," becoming merchants of war who valued advancement over the lives lost to achieve it.

Kabta the Copper

"The ability to create, appreciate, and sustain beauty is the true measure of a creature or civilization." —Kabta’s ideal of Beauty**, modern interpretation

For Kabta, it is held, a world without beauty was a world not worth guarding. Her philosophy posited that survival was merely the foundation, not the purpose, of life. The true measure of any society's worth was its capacity to create and appreciate beauty, be it in art, music, nature, or even elegant humor. Her guardianship was that of a divine muse and conservator. To inspire an artist, protect a pristine wilderness, or bring laughter to the desperate was to defend the very soul of the world against the encroaching gloom of nihilism and despair.

This ideal's manifestations varied greatly in their consequences. In numerous chronicles, Copper Dragons are revered as patrons of the arts, their influence sparking cultural renaissances and their fierceness protecting natural wonders from destruction. They were champions of joy and creativity. Yet, other accounts describe a darker side to this aestheticism. These tales speak of master artisans held in gilded captivity to create art for a dragon's private hoard, or of entire villages being "removed" for being an "eyesore" upon a landscape.

Shamash the Gold

"To ensure the cure isn't worse than the disease, one must weigh the consequences of all potential actions." —Shamash’s ideal of Foresight, modern interpretation

Shamash, it is believed, saw rash action as the greatest danger to a stable world. His entire philosophy was built upon a profound understanding of cause and effect. For him, a well-intentioned act with disastrous, unforeseen consequences was no better than a malicious one. His guardianship was one of immense patience and deep calculation. It involved studying the currents of fate and possibility, and acting only when he could be reasonably certain that the intervention would create a better future, even if that future was centuries away.

In many cases, the influence of a Gold Dragon is thought to have been one of subtle, preventative success, such as a monarch advised against a disastrous war. Their triumphs were often invisible, marked by disasters that never came to pass. The alternative, however, was a form of "benevolent" tyranny. Some accounts suggest Gold Dragons, certain of their foresight, would manipulate societies and remove individuals they deemed future threats, stripping mortals of their free will in the name of a better future that only the dragon could see.

Shakkar the Silver

"The younger races are capable of great things—sometimes they just need a subtle push in the right direction to find their way." —Shakkar’s ideal of Leadership, modern interpretation

For Shakkar, the mortal races were the world's greatest asset, filled with boundless potential for good. He saw them, however, as tragically short-sighted and prone to error. His philosophy of guardianship was that of a paternal mentor. His role was not to rule mortals, but to guide them, to offer the subtle push, the piece of wisdom, or the anonymous aid that would allow them to achieve their best selves and build just, prosperous societies on their own terms.

The legacy of this ideal is one of intimate involvement with mortal affairs. Histories of the most just and enlightened kingdoms frequently mention a mysterious, wise benefactor or a strangely knowledgeable advisor, figures often believed to have been Silver Dragons in disguise. Yet, this very closeness held the potential for a suffocating paternalism. In some cases, the subtle guidance is thought to have become overt manipulation, with the dragon treating kings and heroes like puppets. In these instances, the desire to protect mortals from their own mistakes resulted in denying them their agency, suffocating them under a blanket of well-intentioned control.

pages.name: Divinities - A Working Catalogue
pages.content:
Future Linzi: Turn this chaos into something pretty. Present Me: Stop overthinking! Scribble the weird altar carvings, the drunk priest's rambles, the chills down your spine. We'll make sense of it… eventually.

Nethys

The All-Seeing Eye

Overview

  • Realm. Ahkanefti (Limbo)
  • Alignment True Neutral
  • Areas of Concern. Magic
  • Edicts. Seek out magical power and use it
  • Anathema. Continually pursue mundane paths over magical ones

Notes

Rovagug

The Worldbreaker

Overview

  • Realm. unknown
  • Alignment. Chaotic Evil
  • Areas of Concern. Wrath, Disaster, Destruction
  • Edicts. Destroy all things, free Rovagug from his prison
  • Anathema. Create something new, let material ties restrain you, torture a victim or otherwise delay its destruction

Notes

  • Legends say he's imprisoned in a place called Dead Vault.
  • His followers believe the world is lost already and destroying it would make way for a better one to arise afterwards.

Pazuzu

King of the Wind Demons

Overview

  • Realm. High M'Vania (Abyss)
  • Alignment. Chaotic Evil
  • Areas of Concern. The Sky, Temptation, Winged Creatures
  • Edicts. Tempt others to immoral acts, revel in flight, possess or magically influence others to cause calamities
  • Anathema. Deny a flying creature the ability to fly, abuse Pazuzu's name or call on Pazuzu for help

Notes

  • Worshipped by a variety of evil flying creatures, most notably vrock demons and harpies.

Besmara

The Pirate Queen

Overview

  • Realm. On board her ship, The Seawraith (Maelstrom, through often raiding other planes)
  • Alignment. Chaotic Neutral
  • Areas of Concern. Piracy, Treasure, Storms, Sea Monsters
  • Edicts. Sail the seas, stay loyal to captain and crew, take what you want
  • Anathema. Betray shipmates, forsake piracy, settle on land

Notes

  • Besmara originated as a water spirit who could manipulate monstrous sea creatures, her power grew over centuries as seafarers made sacrifices in her name.

Iomedae

Lady of Valor

Overview

  • Realm. Iomedae's Realm (Heaven)
  • Alignment. Lawful Good
  • Areas of Concern. Honor, Justice, Rulership, Valor
  • Edicts. Be temperate, fight for justice and honor, hold valor in your heart
  • Anathema. Abandon a companion in need, dishonor yourself, refuse a challenge from an equal

Notes

Abadar

Arbiter of Scales and Streets

Overview

  • Realm. Aktun (Mechanus)
  • Alignment. Lawful Neutral
  • Areas of Concern. Cities, Law, Merchants, Wealth
  • Edicts. Civilize frontiers, earn wealth through work and trade, obey laws
  • Anathema. Steal, undermine a law-abiding court

Notes

Yuelral

The Wise

Overview

  • Realm. Yuelral's Domain (Elysium)
  • Alignment. Neutral Good
  • Areas of Concern. Magic, Crystal, Jewelers
  • Edicts. Practice herbalism, use and enchant gems, encourage and teach magicians and jewelers, preserve elven magic and knowledge
  • Anathema. Cut a gem for aesthetic reasons, defile nature, allow the irresponsible use of magic

Notes

  • According to a Shessra, a spellscribe who studied under the goddess's tutelage, spellscribing is an art originally created by Yuelral and only taught to those who've lived in accordance with her principles for centuries and have earned the goddess's trust.
  • Worshipped as the goddess of magic in the elven pantheon

Sarenrae

The Dawnflower, The Cleansing Light, The Healing Flame

Overview

  • Realm. Everlight (Nirvana)
  • Alignment. Neutral Good
  • Areas of Concern. Healing, Honest redemption, The sun
  • Edicts. Destroy irredeemable evil, protect allies, provide aid to the sick and wounded, seek and allow redemption
  • Anathema. Create undead, lie, deny a repentant creature an opportunity for redemption, fail to strike down evil

Notes

  • Patron goddess of the city of Promise

Torag

Dwarffather, The Soul Forger

Overview

  • Realm. Forgeheart (Heaven)
  • Alignment. Lawful Good
  • Areas of Concern. Forge, Protection, Dwarven crafts, Tradition
  • Edicts. Be honorable and forthright, keep your word, respect tradition and the forge, serve your people
  • Anathema. Tell lies or cheat someone, intentionally create inferior works, break tradition, show continued mercy to the enemies of your people when such enemies prove they are undeserving

Notes

Brigh

The Bronze Lady, The Whisperer in Bronze

Overview

  • Realm. Citadel of Resplendent Clockwork (Axis)
  • Alignment. Lawful Neutral
  • Areas of Concern. Clockwork, Invention, Time
  • Edicts. Craft new creations, pay attention to details, share achievements
  • Anathema. Carelessly destroy others' creations or research, enslave intelligent constructs, abuse constructs, refuse to acknowledge or learn from mistakes

Notes

Gyronna

The Angry Hag, Hag Queen

Overview

  • Realm. Muravelara (Abyss)
  • Alignment. Chaotic Evil
  • Areas of Concern. Spite, Hatred, Extortion
  • Edicts. Expose hypocrisy (real or imagined) in others, make other creatures miserable, demand bribes to spare creatures from your torments
  • Anathema. Allow others to slight you without retaliation, seek the approval of society, forgive those who have wronged you

Notes

pages.name: The Birth of the Soul
pages.content:
As commonly understood, souls are created in the Ethereal Sea from the collision of positive and negative energies. These newly created souls, which are yet to find a vessel to manifest in, are called unformed souls - in contrast, souls that have completed this manifestation are known as formed or manifested souls.

Ley Lines

Soon after a soul springs into existence within the roiling Ethereal Sea, it is picked up by a current. These currents, also known as Ley Lines, carry souls from the depths of the Ethereal Sea to the Material Plane.

There they wind through the fabric of the plane, branching off smaller ley lines along the way - not unlike a river and its tributaries if the flow was reversed - as the souls they carry seep into the plane.

Eventually, the ley lines pass through the Material Plane, usually still carrying unformed souls that haven't yet found a vessel, and pour into either the Feywild or the Shadowfell, where souls are dispersed the same way.

Ultimately, the ley lines empty back into the Ethereal Sea, where any remaining unformed souls briefly drift and mingle with newly created ones before inevitably being drawn into a new cycle by another current.

Manifestation

At some point along the way, an unformed soul might find an unborn (or unhatched) mortal vessel. The unformed soul then enters the vessel and becomes a formed soul - a process known as Manifestation which marks a moment of significant transformation for the soul.

It is highly likely that the moment an unformed soul enters its vessel is also the first time it encounters formed souls - namely those of the vessel's parents. This encounter leaves a strong imprint on the unformed soul, causing it to take on a number of characteristics of both parents' souls.

This explains why children inherit various physical and mental traits of both parents and why the children of, for example, two halflings will (almost) always be halflings as well.

Author's Note: It is not yet understood why this inheritance of traits occurs even in creatures thought not to possess souls, such as beasts.

Colored by Emotion

It is thought that a unformed souls pick up on and are 'colored' by the emotions - or lack thereof - of living creatures they pass by along their way through the ley lines. This explains why siblings and even twins generally display differences in personality.

One theory even posits that this process could explain the large natural differences between mortals from the three inner planes. It postulates that souls which manifest in the Feywild are those that have been heavily colored by strong emotions while souls manifesting in the Shadowfell are those that picked up either few emotions or an overwhelming amount of apathy or disinterest along their way.

Impressions of Death

It is well known that ley lines can intersect the River of Souls. Because of this, it is thought that when an unformed soul within such a ley line passes through such an intersection, it might encounter the soul of a recently deceased mortal that's carried by the river.

This would be the unformed soul's first encounter with a formed soul, and is thus leaves a strong impression upon the unformed soul, similar to what happens during manifestation. As such, the unformed soul takes on some of the encountered soul's characteristics - which could explain many reports of reincarnation where magical influence was ruled out.

Such an encounter could however also cause the unformed soul to become tainted with the presence of death. When such a tained soul then finds a vessel and manifests, this presence of death begins to affect the unborn vessel and in some cases even the expecting mother. This unfortunate process is understood to be the reason for stillbirths.

Natural Undead

Undead are commonly viewed as either soulless husks puppeteered by necromantic magic or souls of the deceased that are unable - or unwilling - to enter the river of souls.

Like many other wide-spread beliefs, this one is mostly accurate but fails to paint the full picture as there is another kind of undead which are very rare on the material plane - and unheard of in the Feywild -, but not all that uncommon in the Shadowfell.

Unformed souls can become so heavily tainted by the presence of death that they might mistake a corpse for a vessel. The likelyhood for this confusion to occur is thought to be directly correlated with the corpse's similarity to the physical form of the deceased soul that caused the taint. However there are theories that posit that the corpse's similarity to the memory of a loved one of the deceased soul might be a sufficient medium as well.

An unformed soul that is so heavily tainted might also be able to spontaneously manifest without a vessel. In this case, it would appear as a wandering spirit resembling the deceased soul or the memory of one of its loved ones.

Either way, because these souls manifest directly into undeath and never experienced life, they don't feel the pull of the River of Souls until their undead vessel or the wandering spirit they appear as are destroyed for the first time.

As such, there is a growing number of scholars arguing that these "natural" undead should be thought of as simply another form of mortals. Some fringe groups even go as far as to argue they should be considered as "alive" and prefer to call them "living dead" instead of "undead".

pages.name: Downtime
pages.content:
Downtime Activities

This is is a significantly modified version of the downtime activities rules from Xanathar's Guide to Everything.

Downtime activities are tasks that are performed continuously over the course of one week. These tasks can include buying or creating magic items, pulling off crimes, researching information, or working at a job.

These activities are handled away from the table, in between game sessions. At the end of a session, the characters can collectively decide to spend one or more weeks on downtime activities. A character then selects a downtime activity from among those available to them from the list below.

Resolving Activities

Each downtime activity requires a week to resolve, during which a character spends at least 8 hours of each day engaged with the activity.

Most activities require only a single completion to yield their results. Some longer tasks however may require multiple completions over the course of multiple weeks of downtime. These don't need to be consecutive as each one counts as a separate activity.

Downtime Activities - Earning Money

Artistic Endeavours

Many people are willing to pay vast sums for high-quality entertainment. You can create a painting for an art gallery, play music at a tavern, or act in plays.

Resources

An artistic endeavour requires the necessary tools for the chosen endeavour - an instrument to play music, painter's tools to create a painting, a disguise kit to act in plays, etc.

Resolution

This activity involves a series of skill checks as you work your way up through venues of increasing prestige. You can choose which skill checks you want to make when you choose this activity. The same two checks must be used for all venues.

  • Check 1. Dexterity (Acrobatics), Dexterity (Sleight of Hand), Charisma (Persuasion), or Charisma (Performance)
  • Check 2. Instrument (Cha), Artisan's Tools (Dex/Int/Wis/Cha), or Disguise Kit (Cha/Dex)

The DC of each venue needs to be beaten by at least one of two skill checks to advance to the next venue. You earn the Gold Reward of that venue if you succeed both skill checks, or half as much if you succeed only one. If you fail both skill checks for a venue, you cannot progress and the activity is completed.

LocalCityNobleCountryAbroadPlanar
DC101520253035
Gold Reward10020040080016003200

Crime

Sometimes it pays to be bad. This activity gives a character the chance to make some extra cash, at the risk of arrest.

Resources

A character must spend at least 25 gp gathering information on potential targets before committing the intended crime.

Resolution

The character must make a series of checks, with the DC for all the checks chosen by the character according to the amount of profit sought from the crime.

  • Check 1: Dexterity (Sleight of Hand) or Dexterity (Stealth)
  • Check 2: Charisma (Deception), Intelligence (Investigation), or Wisdom (Perception)
  • Check 3: Disguise Kit (Int/Cha), Forgery Kit (Dex/Wis), or Thieves' Tools (Dex)
Very EasyEasyMediumHardVery HardImpossible
DC101520253035
Loot Value500100020004000800016000

The outcome of the crime depends on how many of the three checks the character succeeds:

  • 0 Successes: The character is caught and jailed. They must pay a fine equal to the profit the crime would have earned and must spend one week in jail for each 2000gp of the fine.
  • 1 Successes: The heist fails but the character escapes.
  • 2 Successes: The heist is a partial success, netting the character half the payout.
  • 3 Successes: The heist is successful and the character earns the full value of the loot.

Fishing

Crikey Mate!

Resources

A character going on a fishing trip must bring a fishing rod or a net, and must spend 10gp on bait.

Resolution

To begin with, a character must first make a series of skill checks to determine the quality of a suitable fishing spot and how long it takes the character to find it. The DC of all checks chosen by the character, based on the type of fish they're trying to catch.

  • Check 1: Water Vehicles (Dex/Wis), Navigation Tools (Wis/Int), or Intelligence (Nature)
  • Check 2: Intelligence (Investigation), Wisdom (Perception), or Dexterity (Stealth)
  • Check 3: Strength (Athletics), Dexterity (Acrobatics), or Wisdom (Animal Handling)

A character who fails all three initial checks is unable to find a suitable fishing spot.

Once a fishing spot is found and the fishing itself can begin, the character must make a number of Wisdom (Survival) checks equal to the number of successful checks to find the spot. Each successful Wisdom (Survival) check increases the total payout of the fishing trip by an amount equal to the Gold Reward of the type of fish caught.

Small FishBig FishExotic Fish
DC152025
Gold Reward50010002000

Gambling

Games of chance are a way to make a fortune—and perhaps a better way to lose one.

Resources

This activity requires a stake, which depends on the chosen establishment and table.

Tavern BackroomGabling DenNoble's ClubPlanar Casino
Stake (gp)10 to 499500 to 49995000 to 1499915000+
DC Modifier+4+8+12+20
Resolution

The character must make a series of checks, with a DC determined at random based on the quality of the competition that the character runs into and the chosen establishment. Part of the risk of gambling is that one never knows who might end up sitting across the table.

The character makes three checks. The checks must be different from the following list Wisdom (Insight), Charisma (Deception), Charisma (Intimidation), Dexterity (Sleight of Hand), and Gaming Set (Dex/Int/Wis/Cha). The DC for each of the checks is 2d10 + DC Modifier of the chosen establishment, with a separate DC generated for each check.

ResultValue
0 successesLose all the money you bet, and accrue a debt equal to that amount.
1 successLose half the money you bet.
2 successesGain the amount you bet plus half again more.
3 successesGain double the amount you bet.

Magical Dueling

The Pit Fighting Arena has expanded its business to also include spellcasting battles. These duels can be dangerous but pay well for those who survive.

Resources

Spellcasting or Pact Magic feature

Resolution

A character must make a series of rolls with a DC determined by the quality of the opposition that the character runs into. To ensure fair and entertaining matches, magic duels are fought against opponents of equal level. The use of performance enhancing items and magic is strictly forbidden.

The character makes a total of three rolls. The DC for each of these rolls is 1d12 + 8 + your proficiency bonus.

  • Check 1: Constitution saving throw as if to maintain concentration on a spell.
  • Check 2: Intelligence (Arcana), Wisdom (Insight), Charisma (Intimidation), or Charisma (Performance)
  • Check 3: A spell attack roll with a spellcasting focus that does not give a bonus to attack rolls.
ResultPayout
0 SuccessesYou earn nothing and gain 1 level of exhaustion
1 Success10gp x your level
2 Successes200gp x your level
3 Successes400gp x your level

Medical Assistance

Finding the necessary herbs, making the perfect potion, and giving the right treatment are difficult tasks under ideal conditions. In war zones and other deadly areas ideal conditions are nowhere to be found - yet that's where this job is needed the most.

Resources

A character who chooses this activity must bring their own Alchemist's Supplies, Herbalism Kit, or Cooking Utensils if they intend to use them.

Resolution

A character who chooses to provide medical assistance must first decide if they want to head to a high-risk area or not. Jobs in high-risk areas are more difficult and personal risk is unavoidable but they pay much better. They must then make a series of checks, the results of which are counted together.

  • Check 1: Intelligence (Nature), Intelligence (Investigation), or Wisdom (Perception)
  • Check 2: Wisdom (Medicine), Alchemist's Supplies (Int/Wis), Herbalism Kit (Int/Wis), Cooking Utensils (Dex/Wis/Int)
  • Check 3: Wisdom (Insight), Charisma (Persuasion), or Wisdom (Animal Handling)

If the total of these checks is less than the Minimum DC, the character cannot choose this activity again for one week, as they are expected to study their mistakes and visit the family of the patient to deliver the bad news.

MinimumGoodPerfectRisk Zone Modifier
DC506070+10
Pay100020004000x2

If the character chose to work in a high-risk area, they must additionally make an Wisdom (Survival) or Dexterity (Stealth) check. The DC for this check is 1d12 + 10. Should they fail this check, they themselves are stuck in a dangerous situation, gain 1 level of exhaustion during their escape and lose one half of their pay.

Pit Fighting

Pit fighting includes boxing, wrestling, and other nonlethal forms of combat in an organized setting with predetermined matches.

Resources

Proficiency with at least one martial weapon

Resolution

A character must make a series of rolls with a DC determined by the quality of the opposition that the character runs into. To ensure fair and entertaining matches, pit fights are fought against opponents of equal level. The use of performance enhancing items, as well as magic in general is strictly forbidden.

The character makes a total of three rolls. The DC for each of these rolls is 1d12 + 8 + your proficiency bonus.

  • Check 1: Constitution check with a bonus equal to the character's largest Hit Die.
  • Check 2: Strength (Athletics), Dexterity (Acrobatics), Wisdom (Insight), Charisma (Intimidation), or Charisma (Performance)
  • Check 3: A weapon attack roll with a weapon that does not give a bonus to attack rolls.
ResultPayout
0 SuccessesYou earn nothing and gain 1 level of exhaustion
1 Success10gp x your level
2 Successes200gp x your level
3 Successes400gp x your level

Private Eye

Many request are available for the cunning and inquisitive: investigating disappearances, solving murders, confirming rumors, or digging up some dirt. People pay a pretty penny for concrete answers.

Resources

Proficiency in Intelligence (Investigation) or succeed on a DC 15 Charisma (Deception) check.

Resolution

When a character chooses this activity, they must choose the difficulty of the case they want to take up.

The character must first roll to determine how many skill checks are required, then roll that many checks. They can choose from Strength (Athletics), Dexerity (Sleight of Hand), Dexterity (Stealth), Intelligence (Arcana), Intelligence (History), Intelligence (Investigation), Intelligence (Religion), Wisdom (Insight), Wisdom (Perception), Charisma (Deception), Charisma (Intimidation), or Charisma (Persuasion). The same skill cannot be chosen twice. The DC for each check is generated separately.

EasyMediumHardImpossible
# of Skills1d2 + 11d4 + 12d42d6
DC1d4 + 122d4 + 133d4 + 144d4 + 15
Base Pay (gp)100200400800

After making all rolls, the character is able to get some answers and earn gold equal to the Base Pay for each successful roll. If all rolls are successful, the case is solved and the total earnings are multiplied by 1.5.

If 3 or more rolls fail however, the character cannot tell right information from wrong anymore and may have added misinformation to the case. They are no longer allowed to work on that case and are not paid.

Tools of the Trade

Businesses are seeking skilled artisans to craft exquisite goods for their stores and enterprises.

Requirements

Proficiency with at least one Artisan Tool.

Resolution

When a character chooses this activity, they must choose who they want to be commissioned by.

PeasantsMerchantsNoblesAristocratsPlanar Entities
DC1015202530
Base Pay (gp)50100200400800

The character must make a series of checks against the DC based on the commissioner.

  • Check 1: Artisan Tool (Str, Dex, Int, Wis)
  • Check 2: Either a different Artisan Tool (Str, Dex, Int, Wis), or the same tool as the first check but with a -5 penalty.
  • Check 3: Dexterity (Sleight of Hand), Intelligence (Arcana), Intelligence (History), Intelligence (Nature), Intelligence (Religion), Wisdom (Perception), or Charisma (Performance)
ResultPayout
0 SuccessesYou earn nothing
1 Success1 x Base Pay

Work

It ain't much, but it's honest work.

Requirements

None

Resolution

To determine how much money a character earns, the character makes an ability check with any Skill, Musical Instrument (Cha), Tools (Dex/Int/Wis/Cha), or Vehicles (Dex/Int/Wis/Cha).
