Sign Signee: Kyrin Niteshade

pages.name: To Deny the Cold
pages.content:
"This way," the wizard said, clutching his book in the folds of his cloak.

The party followed him, hunched against the blizzard; a tall human in plate armour, a dwarf who was missing his right hand, and a Halfling wrapped up so only her brilliant green eyes showed. The wizard, another human muffled in an embroidered purple cloak, led the way with growing excitement. The others did not come close to sharing his sentiment.

"It's too cold," the knight said, holding his shield to protect the Halfling from the biting winds. "Naami won't make it."

"Don't worry about me," she muttered through her scarf.

"That's the spirit! Think of the wonders that await us in the ruins," Daman exclaimed. "Ancient magic, forgotten glyphs, records of feats nowadays only dreamed of! This blizzard is surely conjured up by their runes, to protect the temple. The ancient people -"

They never learnt what Daman was about to say about the ancient people, as he was silenced in the middle of his tirade by snow swirling into his mouth. Coughing and cursing, he turned to face forward again, stomping as if to beat the ice into submission.

"It's wrong," the dwarf said, shaking his head. "The ancients' magic cost me my right hand, and he wants *more* of that?"

"Seeking knowledge is not wrong in itself," Osten said firmly. "But the price he is willing to pay to get it... *that* is wrong."

He held out his hand to help Naami stand after she stumbled face first in the snow. The small healer endured bravely, but for someone who had spent most of her life in a desert, the climate proved a bigger threat than to the rest of them.

"It's fine," she said. "When we get back, I'll make us hot tea and we can warm ourselves by the fire."

"When we get back," Osten said, "I'll make us tea while you warm yourself."

"If we get back," Magnus grumbled. "The blizzard is only growing worse. It's madness to be out in this. Nature is fighting our every step."

Daman yelped and ran back a few steps, stammering about something in the snow. Osten signalled to Magnus and he nodded, stepping closer to Naami. The knight advanced to where Daman had stood, and went still. He slowly raised his shield.

"We have a problem," he said in a voice that barely reached to the rest of the party. "Stench of rotting flesh in a blizzard. We've entered the territory of -"

A red flash burst from the snow, whipping at Osten. He blocked with an oath, his boots digging into the snow under the force of the impact. Just in front of him, an ominous silhouette emerged. It was darker than the ice, tinged with blue like a deep frozen lake. Taller than a pillar, it grew a mass of blood-red tendrils near the top. The one that had hit Osten retreated, and the creature resolved into a gigantic slug, its head and back covered in crystals.

"What in the world is *that*?" Naami squeaked.

"Rime worm," Osten growled. "We've stumbled into their territory. We're prey now."

As if to give reason to the knight's words, the slug collapsed on top of him, dark maw gaping. Osten activated the magic in his shield; blue light pulsed in a shockwave, barely repelling the monster. He thrust with his sword, burying it into the creature's mouth. The rime worm recoiled with a howl that was more vibration than audible noise, rattling Naami's teeth.

"Monsters from cold climes, right?" Magnus asked, but did not wait for an answer. "That thing must be weak to fire!"

He held his staff aloft, a length of ash carved so it still seemed to be living and growing. From the tip, fire sparked into existence and streaked towards the slug. It sizzled as it hit, black smoke billowing from the impact. The rime worm reared into the air, tendrils lashing at the snow, then its body began to loom over the party.

"It's going to crush us, fall back!" Osten cried.

The two spellcasters obeyed, but Naami stepped forward instead. She had taken her gloves off, and her fingers traced sigils in the freezing air, precise patterns to guide her magic. The ominous shadow of the rime worm over Osten blurred and twisted, then leapt up and wound around its owner's body. Hands clenched into fists, the Halfling planted her feet into the snow.

"Can't hold the spell very long," she said through gritted teeth.

"I will protect you!" Osten said. "We can buy them time."

Behind them, Magnus and Daman stood close, threads of magic twining around them. Daman held his book close to his chest, speaking incantations in a clear voice. The words wrapped around a ball of flame hovering atop Magnus' staff.

"Now!" The dwarf said.

With a flick of his wrist, Magnus passed the fireball to Daman. The human's spell took in the blaze, and propelled it towards the slug at a speed Magnus alone would have been unable of. The burning ball hit the monster square in the face, sending it into a rage.

"It survived that?" The Halfling cried in disbelief.

"Naami, watch out!"

The knight threw himself in front of his friend, just in time to block several tendrils streaking towards her. They made a fleshy thud on his shield, but the sheer force of the attack forced Osten to his knees. He groaned, his voice raising into a scream as his shield arm fell limp to his side.

"Osten!" Naami's weaves snapped, her spell's hold on the rime worm fading.

Suddenly free, the monster crawled towards her, opening its maw wide. Osten scrambled to his feet, face white with pain. Naami reached out to him without thinking, her magic washing over her friend's body. Her powerful healing mended the broken bones, and Osten stood tall once more. With a nod of gratitude, he raised his shield. The mages at the back were channelling a new spell, combining the wildfire of Magnus' magic with Daman's years of obsessive study and his extensive knowledge of physics. One more spell would kill the monster. It had to.

Osten stood ready to block another attempt to devour him or Naami, but the slug did not fall forward this time. Inside the open maw, a sickly light flickered and grew, then took the shape of dark icicles, sharpened to a needle point.

"This thing has magic?" Naami cried, her stomach filled with dread.

"Get behind me!" Osten said.

He spared a second to smile at her over his shoulder before turning to face the monster, his shoulders squared, ready to endure anything. Behind Naami, magic swelled and shaped into another offensive spell. She wanted to close her eyes but she began to weave another healing spell instead, preparing to mend the inevitable wounds. A hail of frozen spikes rushed towards Osten; the magic of his shield expanded in a blue dome to protect them all. Black ice pelted the barrier in a blinding flash of magic. Naami's eyes exploded in pain as if they had been pierced by the spikes. She was only aware of magic for a dizzying moment; the shield's magic above her head, the rime worm's attack, the combined spell bursting into existence behind her. The spell rushed past her just as she recovered her vision, a ray of white-hot flame exploding on the slug's body. It gave one last reverberating howl and crashed onto the rocky ground, shuddering into stillness. Deafening silence swallowed the din of battle. They had won.

"It's... dead?" Daman said, spellbook trembling in his hands.

Magnus sank to his knees, beard full of ice, his hands reaching down to the earth beneath the snow. Naami released her spell, letting a web of positive energy settle on her friends. She was dimly aware of strength returning to Magnus' legs, of Daman's hands growing steadier. From Osten, she sensed nothing. Her heart went cold. He had fallen on his side with his shield arm at an unnatural angle, but her healing did not touch him. She made herself take a step towards him, then another, and each new step was infinitely heavier than the last. Deep down, she knew. Her spells never failed. She knew, but she could not accept it.

Her friend was dead. Dirt-blonde hair seemed dark against his face; his sapphire eyes stared at the sky. His pale eyelashes had frozen, and his armour was so covered in frost as to seem made of ice. A jolt of pain in her knees told Naami her legs had failed her. The pain of her body was distant, an annoyance that had no right to exist beside the agony in her heart. Osten had protected her in a world gone from wonderful to terrifying. Osten had shared tea with her on nights where the cold could have split the very mountains. Osten had always had a kind word, a smile, an encouraging gesture. Naami sensed Magnus and Daman on either side of her, kneeling in silence. She could not bear their sorrow. She heard it in their silence, in the lack of words from friends who were never quiet. Their silence was another drop in a sea of pain, and yet it was too much. She had to break it, before it broke her too.

"I can bring him back."

Naami realised she had spoken aloud. Stunned, she listened to the echo of her words in the frozen air. Her heart pounded in her chest, trying to break her ribs. Her legs would not move. She could barely feel her fingers from the cold, but she knew she had not only spoken from the depths of her heart; she had told the truth.

"Naami..." Magnus reached out to her with the stump of his right hand. "You're a powerful healer, you gave it your all, but you must not push yourself so. No one blames you."

"The amount of magic that would take... it is impossible," Daman said in the voice of a lecturer; as if he would ever have the patience for teaching. "We'll give him the proper rites, and take care of the living."

She clenched her teeth. They thought she was losing her mind, but she knew. As she had known Osten was dead, she knew she could bring him back.

"I'm serious," she said. "I need time, but I can do it."

She had to crane her neck to look at Daman, but she put all her resolve into that look. He knew the rules of magic better than she ever would, yes. But he was not a witch, and none of his theory could explain why she needed her spellwards to function, the same as she could not use his spellbook for as much as lighting a candle. He did not understand how her magic worked. She hardly understood her own magic, for the matter; she only felt that it would work. The gods be thanked, Daman saw she meant it. With a sigh, he rose to his feet and opened his book.

"I maintain we don't have enough magic. No sacrifice to make. But if you wish to try, then I will shield you from the elements."

He spoke as a king granting a favour to a commoner. In spite of herself, Naami grinned. Daman had a flamboyant manner, dominating a room with his presence despite his light build. This grand manner of speaking was just like him. Somehow this piece of "normal" opened a crack in the pain of her heart. Magnus merely gestured with his left hand, effortlessly conjuring a flame in mid-air.

"You'll need some warmth to move these fingers," he said gruffly. "I'll be looking at how you do it, if you don't mind me."

Naami surprised herself by giggling. "I expect as much. Thank you."

The dwarf nodded, a shadow of a smile hiding in his beard. He began melting the snow with his magical flame while Daman walked in a perfect circle around them, muttering incantations. Slowly the magic shifted in his wake, the air becoming warm and dry. A bubble enveloped the party, the snow sliding off the invisible barrier. Magnus' flames melted the flakes before they could bury the party's shelter. A piece of rough stone ground appeared as the snow was cleared. It would make an uncomfortable seat, but Naami sat by Osten nonetheless, crossing her legs under her heavy skirts. Her mind returned to her desert home; when she closed her eyes, she could imagine she was back in Ildilas. Of course Osten had never set foot on Bottleneck Coast. Maybe one day, he would. If she could only reach out to his soul... Naami shut out the world. She flexed her numb fingers and paused for a moment, feeling the smooth bands of the bangles which allowed her to control magic without being consumed by it. She made her breathing steady, made her mind calm, and she took off her spellwards.

Resting her fingers on Osten's chest, she cast out her mind far from the confines of her body. She searched the aether for a trace of Osten's soul, for the warmth she was now familiar with. Her mind wandered, little more than a vague sense of self in the darkness. She sensed sparks of life, but none felt like her friend. It was much too soon to give up, however. As an Ildic witch, one the omens had smiled on, she was acquainted with the veil between light and darkness, life and death. She strayed closer, calling out to Osten.

"Come back," she said in her trance. "Your story isn't over yet, so come back."

Silence answered her. This was not right; if Osten's soul had sensed her presence, it would have echoed her words. She could not explain how, but she knew. She called out again, to no avail. Letting silence embrace her, she allowed her mind to sink into motionlessness. A breath of cold touched her cheek; it was infinitely distant. Her body seemed to wait on the other shore of a dark sea, but the cold helped. Silence, stillness, and stasis had always strengthened her magic, until the moment she spoke the spell. Part of her sensed the danger of staying here, mind and body separate. Stay too long, and she would not find her way back. She ignored the risks. Instead of calling out to Osten, she merely thought of him, of his soul. Her own soul began to shift, like colour gradually changing, a wavelength slowly altering. It hurt; even as she was now, without a body, the shift made her ache more with each passing second. Intuition spurring her on, she persevered through the pain.

Responding to the paralysing ache, an echo touched her consciousness. Naami was so startled she nearly lost concentration, but she recovered in time to cling to the fading echo. It was Osten, but it also was not him. While she recognised his soul, it was so terribly far, so different from hers that it might as well come from another world. It was hollow and confused, missing part of what made him who he was.

"Don't go," she pleaded.

Pain washed over her in response, a hollow ache so strong she could have screamed. Like having her heart ripped out. She held onto it, sensing the answer lay this way. She made herself go closer to the pain, made the wavelength of her soul change further. She adjusted herself to the ache, embraced it, wishing she could cry. Within the pain was a sense of hunger, of yearning, stronger than she had ever known. It was on the edge of consuming her; she kept the most tenuous grip on her consciousness.

"Naami?"

Osten's voice. She would have burst into tears had she been able. She tried to respond through the pain, but she had no voice. The veil was a wall now, and the voice on the other side was entirely alien. She was a cloud trying to speak to a person. Holding on by a fingernail, she communicated the only way she could think of; by altering the emotion suffusing the ache threatening to tear her apart. She fed it all the pain she had ever felt, the grief, the loss. She gave it her own wishes, her yearning for the next sunrise. With a sharp click, the emotions within her aligned with those in Osten's soul. It shook her mind but she held on tight, the memories of her friend lending her strength. Now that there was a connection through the wall, which was the veil between this life and the next, she could speak to him. The words mattered very little in this space; emotion and magic carried the message. A whole world away, she heard a whisper come from her body.

"We miss you already. Come back."

Voices answered, so distant she only barely made them out.

"It... is impossible... magic wants a sacrifice... how is she doing this..."

"She is paying the cost. The sacrifice... is her."

The voices faded, Osten's presence growing clearer.

"Come with me instead. Pharasma calls to me. I'm drawn to a wide river. I don't want to go alone."

"You don't have to go," she said. "Come back with me."

"I'm afraid, Naami."

"Then follow me! We can go home."

"But the sound of battle is finally gone. I think... if I sink into the river, I will be at peace for the first time."

"If you go to the river, I will never see you again," Naami cried.

If Osten went to the River of Souls, he would finally know peace. Osten had lived a life of battles, until he made his last stand to protect his friends. He had earned his peace and rest. Tearing him from a realm where his soul would know quiet at last... that would be nothing short of cruelty. *Sometimes a healer must inflict pain*, Naami's mother had said when she was teaching her, a lifetime ago. Setting a bone would always hurt. Bitter herbs made you think you truly would do better without them. It was nothing, compared to robbing a soul of the peace it so deeply deserved... but the principle was the same. Naami was Osten's friend, but she was a healer, too. And... she missed him.

"Come back. Death will meet you later, but we are here now. We miss you. Let's spend just another day together, and if the gods allow it, another after that. Death will embrace you when our story is over."

No matter how long or painful the journey, it would have an end. It was a comforting thought. There would be quiet at the end, so why not make a little more noise in the meantime? Naami's thin grasp on consciousness was overwhelmed with warmth, with the feeling of Osten's smile. Had she had a body in this strange place, she would have opened her arms to hug him, to welcome him back. She would do it soon. His soul phased through the veil which was a wall for her, away from the River of Souls, far from the call of the Spiral of Fate. Side by side in a dream of twilight, they returned from a battle that had taken place in their hearts.

Naami woke to pain, her body burning. Her hands on Osten's chest felt as though severed from her body, lumps of flesh she could not command. A sliver of sensation remained, enough to know her fingers were ablaze with pain. Her head was light and heavy, her thoughts drowning within themselves. Breathing was agony, but there was just one last thing to do. One task left, and then she could rest. She smiled through the pain, gathered her magic, and settled it on Osten's body. Her magic whispered to his heart, reminded it of the beat of life. Her magic caught a wisp of air, leading it into her friend's still lungs. She guided the blood back into his veins, and when his body was restored to life, she gave his soul one last invitation.

"Come back to us, Osten."

As the knight's eyes opened, magic escaped Naami's control. It leapt from her, humming and dancing. A warm breeze laughed around the party, and flowers burst into existence beneath them and around them, a carpet of wild colours. She recognised none of the blossoms, and the ones who grew outside of Daman's barrier froze in a heartbeat, turning dark and stiff with ice. Inside the barrier, the rock was covered in vibrant colours, the air saturated with sweet scents.

"The magic..." Naami murmured.

When no one said anything, she looked at her friends. Osten was sitting up, still pale as death, a confused look in his eyes. Magnus was looking down at his left hand, and more intensely at the stump of his right hand. Daman had sunk to his knees, eyes wide, his usual charisma shattered.

"I saw... I was..." Osten began, voice hoarse. "Scales on my arms, bestial strength in them... I had claws... and the breath of winter in my chest... I was... What was I...?"

"I had a right hand again," Magnus said, "but it was different... wrong. And yet it felt like it was made for me, better than the one I had before. Dark magic around it... strange... my flames always burned so bright... it felt like home... but how..."

Daman was pale as the snow outside the barrier. His mouth moved soundlessly at first, unable to form words.

"The void," he said finally, his voice thin and weak. "Gods save us, the void is coming."

His eyes rolled back into his head and he crumpled in a faint. Naami tried to go to him to revive him, but exhaustion crashed down on her. Her head spun, and before she knew it, she was in Magnus' arms. His right arm was stiff as wood, but he held her gently. She realised she could not move, her strength entirely spent.

"Easy there," he said, the cold in his voice fading as he spoke. "You were sitting here for a full hour. You've done the impossible. Take a break."

The impossible. He was right. She had cast a spell that demands a sacrifice, without paying that cost. But then, she thought as she glimpsed her spellwards on the ground, maybe she had merely found another way to pay the cost for that magic; a way only a witch could find. She feebly reached out towards her bracelets. Osten handed them out to her. Colour was returning to his face; he breathed deeply as if relishing the very sensation.

"It's a strange dream I woke from," he said with a smile. "I think we all saw things, too. I'm not sure I want to know what Daman saw."

"Whatever it was, it's of no concern to us right now," Magnus grumbled. "There are more pressing matters. Slapping some life back into Daman, so we can be on our way. He'll talk when he feels like it, or he won't. Hopefully someone will pay us for killing this thing; nature is relieved by its death, at least. All I want now is mulled wine, my bones are frozen."

"I feel warmer, somehow," Osten said. "Like a deep cold inside me has been denied... turned away."

"Let's make it so it stays away," Magnus said, shuffling through the wild flowers towards Daman.

Naami grinned. She had a feeling that she would see stranger things the next day. And, if the gods allowed it, she would see even stranger things the day after that.

pages.name: 74.1 A Healer's Edge
pages.content:
Emilio's white hair seemed to glow in the dimness, a patch of clean snow on a backdrop of reddish hell. He raised his bandaged hand as if to curse the twisted creature that had Aviana in a chokehold; three bursts of energy leapt from his fingers and exploded on the mass of bulging flesh and organs. Clouds of purple smoke erupted, and the creature shuddered and collapsed, remaining still. It did not look like it had ever been alive, or even moving. It looked like a tangle of surgical mistakes, or insane experiments. It looked like madness clad in flesh, a chunk that had been torn off from this place. Aviana, finally free, began to argue with Plex. Naami started towards her, unable to look away from the wounds covering the harpy from talons to wingtips.

"I'll give us a semblance of safety so we can recuperate," Fearghas grumbled.

Spellbook in hand, he began to mutter and trace sigils into the air, raising a familiar barrier around the party. Just then, the voice spoke into their heads again: Yes, pause and breathe in the tranquillity, dear ones. The transition from the River to the boundless peace of Nirvana can be… intense. Rest is a balm, and I am here to offer comfort and guidance.

"That demon's weird," the dwarf said once the protective bubble was complete.

"Let me cast a spell of trap detection," Aviana said, frowning in concentration. "Ah, I see! The walls are traps. The floors are traps, and the ceiling is a trap, too. Now the danger of these traps is… are… confusion and disorientation, madness, acid, suffocation… errrm… poison, infestation with maggots, also exhausting, blindness… and losing the ability to escape. Well. Plex, can you bite me?"

Naami stared, her argument forgotten. Aviana the unbreakable harpy was bleeding and bruised, covered in acid burns, and she wanted to be bitten on top of it? Plex, who had been shrunk to the size of a rat by a wild magic surge, started to argue that he was too small to have a chance to even break the skin. Likely he still would be, even at his normal size. Plex, who had teleported away the moment we arrived here, willingly, and nearly got himself eaten, digested, and killed, in any order. Twice. Plex, whom Naami had healed at the cost of her own blood. She had been so relieved to see him alive, her control on magic had slipped, and she had transferred her life force to him, closing all his wounds. Plex was nonchalantly agreeing to more violence, only discussing the logistics of it, as Aviana was urging him to hit her.

In the madness of the situation, Naami's fear flashed to anger. She wished she could brush off her actions as consequences of emotion, as losing control of herself; a form of madness maybe. That would be a lie. She deliberately drew her sharp dagger. She decided to stalk to Aviana and point that dagger at her. Oh, she was much too small to threaten the harpy, grown to a huge size by alchemy. But a threat needed not be made on a person's life, and some wounds were worse than death. Naami angled her blade at Aviana's heels, where a small cut would be as severing her feet from her legs. She could heal a snapped tendon, though it would cost her.

"Aviana, you sit still now and let me heal those wounds, or I promise I will make you."

Just then, Plex worked out how to hit Aviana, and followed through with it, whacking her with his staff. She did not flinch, and Naami was past paying attention to it, but that did not stop Aviana from requesting Naami stab her with the dagger she had just threatened her with.

Before she could reply, the gentle voice spoke in Naami's mind; Please, try to be calm. Such reactions are echoes from the world you left behind. Here, in Nirvana, all spirits are to be cherished and guided with kindness.

"Shut up!" the Halfling snarled.

At the party's confusion, she shared the message telepathically, shaking in anger. That demon! How dare it! She fought to stoke her anger and keep it burning. She had to be furious, because fear was encroaching on the edges of her anger. She could not let her suspicions take form. Oh goddess, these were an angel's words. A demon would not know or care about the River of Souls, or Nirvana. It was an angel's voice. Not again, please, not again. Naami realised she was shaking too much to treat her friend's wounds. Shalkoc stepped in next to her, and with a gentle nod to Naami, cast a healing spell on Aviana. The wordless help brought her close to tears.

The voice spoke in reply to Shalkoc's spell: How wonderful! Your spirit already resonates with the compassion that flows through Nirvana. Such kindness is a true sign of your innate goodness.

"Oh, thank you," Shalkoc says. "We could be friends!"

Aviana agreed, but Fearghas snapped at Aviana, Shalkoc, and Plex.

"Have you three not been paying attention? You've been running amok since we arrived here, teleporting all over the place. We are fighting for our lives here! That thing is a demon! It is not a friend! It warps the very bodies and minds of its prey. Naami told you what it does, and look how traumatised she is! No one is going to hit you any more, Aviana. We need you in fighting shape."

"But my spirit is all down, I need someone to slap some sense into me. Someone weak, not you Shalkoc, your punches hit like a boulder."

Fearghas rubbed his temples with deliberate slowness. Emilio stared in utter confusion as Aviana continued to argue that it was truly a power she possessed, although she did not understand how it worked. With a carefully blank expression, Fearghas handed out healing potions, which seemed to finally stop this madness. The insanity only continued in the shape of the voice congratulating Aviana and Plex on a friendly trade of copper coins for a bottle of what could only be bright green snot.

"Naami, out of curiosity," Fearghas said in a weary voice, "was the one you met before like this?"

"It wasn't… I've suspected for a while, this isn't the demon talking. It's too long a game for a demon to play… they don't act like that."

"So that demon took control of a celestial?" Emilio said.

"Or worse," Naami said, shaking.

She tried to drown her fear in familiar motions, applying healing salve to Aviana's wounds and to her own. It was not as good as magic but… her magic, her life force, was limited. She had to hold onto it for when there would be no time for slower forms of healing. As she worked, the emotions faded to the background, her attention fully on the motions of her fingers, but there was only so much salve she could apply to any wound. The thoughts came back the moment she was done, and this time she was powerless to silence them.

"It's really an angel," Naami said, her voice distant in her ears. "It's trapped here, and deceived."

Summoned by the words, memories came rushing back into her mind. Her hands rose unbidden to her head, tangling into her hair. She tried to close her eyes, but it was worse. Opening them to the same nightmare that haunted her made her want to scream. She only managed a whimper. "Not again, not again, not again…" Seeming to materialise out of the shadows, Emilio appeared beside her. His voice sank into a soft whisper, unlike even the reserved personality he had shown until now. Despite a splinter of cold in his voice, it was reassuring.

"Don't let them get you," he said. "You are who you are, no matter what."

His eyes were drawn to movement in front of him, as Fearghas pulled a heavy tome from his pack. Complex patterns on the covers were shifting, and the entire book seemed to hum. Naami looked up to see Fearghas calmly skimming through the book, its pages covered in a tight script alternating with maps that seemed to move as she tilted her head. Star charts? She had used them before, to gather herbs during the right phases of the moon, but the charts she had seen did not twist and change under her eyes…

Next to her, Emilio went stiff as a statue, glaring at the spellbook in the dwarf's hands. His bandaged hands twitched, he seemed to shudder, and… he changed. Darkness like ink spilled into the white of his eyes, leaving the purple irises glowing in a sea of blackness. The bandages burst, revealing wicked claws set with a glowing purple gem like an eye, wrapped in crackling energy. With a squeak, the tiny Plex summoned his telekinesis and shoved Emilio out of the protection of Fearghas' spell.

"What in the nine hells?" Fearghas exclaimed. "Emilio, what happened to you?"

"Nothing. This is my true form." Emilio's voice had a rough, cold edge.

"Was this the secret you were keeping from us?" Naami said, face pale.

"Maybe it was."

"What are you?" She cried.

"I think we have more urgent matters to deal with," the warlock growled.

An awkward silence stretched before Fearghas admitted, reluctantly, that he was right. Unfazed, Shalkoc offered to cook some food for Aviana, who immediately asked for a spicy snack. At the utter lack of concern from his friends, Fearghas beckoned Emilio back into the protective bubble.

"We need to make sure Emilio doesn't attack us, right?" Aviana said in the middle of discussing chilies with Shalkoc.

"If I wanted you dead, you would be," he said, his black and purple eyes showing no emotion. "Besides… we need to get rid of whatever is in control here, fast. The tunnels are already changing."

He pointed at the warped tunnel behind him, twisted into nothing like the place the party had entered from.

"T-that's what they do," Naami stammered. "They change the corridors… just like last time…"

"That's not all," Plex said. "My curse… is silent here."

Fearghas went very still. Naami felt the magic around him shift, just subtly, without forming a spell. The two wizards exchanged a look, then Fearghas spoke:

"Teleportation magic will not work here. Or planar travel."

"We're trapped here?" Naami squeaked.

"Well, we can't run away," Fearghas said.

With a sigh, the party settled down to rest. There was little else they could do, after all. Naami sat very gingerly on the repulsive floor, trying to avoid the pulsating parts. She found a patch that seemed less squishy and, doing her utmost to ignore the resemblance with scar tissue, sat cross-legged for just a moment. Her arms still stung from the rush of uncontrolled magic she had directed at Plex; borne on her fear for her friend, the magic had taken her blood as fuel to heal the goblin. Not a lot of thinking had been involved; she had been too far for a spell that was safe for her, and he had been too injured for a weaker spell. Healing… sometimes, healing also meant hurting. Absentmindedly, she drew her dagger, the sharper of the two she carried. The other dagger was forged with magic, but this one was simply of extraordinary quality. It had a long handle formed to fit her hand, and a single-edged blade ending in a sharp tip, an unusual form for a dagger. Oh, she could probably pick a lock or disable a trap with it, not that she knew much of such things, but she would be loath to use this fine a blade in such a crude fashion. The needle point, the razor edge, they were for cutting through skin and muscle. It would slice through tendons with ease, requiring little force as long as her fingers were deft enough to guide the blade to the weaker spots of her target's body. Naami's weapon was a dagger only by name; it was the only weapon a healer needed, a surgeon's blade. She had had it forged at great cost, worth every copper, and she would have paid more if that meant she had it sooner. Her eyes lingered over the perfect edge without seeing it. If only she had had it sooner.

She had been carried out of a snowstorm and into the relative warmth of an inn, the weak fire on the hearth seeming a blaze of the ninth hell to her frozen limbs. Thoughts slow with cold, she sat close to the flames, dimly remembering to move her toes and fingers. Feeling returned in the form of needles; she gritted her teeth and continued. The alternative did not bear thinking of. As if in answer to her thoughts, the door banged open, letting in howling wind and snow.

"Close that door, man!" Daman snapped at the newcomer.

"Healer!" the man cried, ignoring the door and Daman. "You have a healer?"

Before she knew it, Naami had pushed herself to her feet. Osten was at her side with a steadying hand.

"Easy, you still need rest," he murmured.

It warmed her heart, if not her flesh, but she could not stop herself.

"I am a healer," she said as she tottered to the man.

He gave her a dubious look, but desperation was stronger than doubt. Not awaiting the innkeeper's permission, he deposited his burden on a nearby table. Wrapped in rags and furs was a boy barely out of childhood, his eyes closed, frost clinging to his eyelashes.

"My son," the man sobbed. "We were caught in the blizzard. Frostbite. Please help him, and all I own is yours."

Naami shook her head; she had no need for such promises. She was who she was. Running her hands over the boy, she summoned weak magic to examine him. Having closed the door, Magnus joined her, brushing icicles from his beard. They soon reached the same conclusion.

"His life force is tainted," Magnus muttered.

"Disrupted," Naami agreed.

She said no more out loud, to not frighten the father any more than he was, but Magnus and her knew the boy's condition was severe. Naami gave instructions; Osten helped drag the table closer to the fire while Daman fetched a tub of water. He waved his fingers over it, heating it to boiling in a flash of magic. Gently, Naami and Magnus removed the boy's boots and several layers of wool socks. The right boot was torn at the front, the socks cold and damp. Naami took out some of her herbs, her heart sinking. Even before seeing the boy's blackened toes, she knew herbs would do no good.

She tried. With Magnus' help and his control over fire, his fine perception of life itself, she tried. She rubbed the boy's feet with a salve and bathed them in warm water. When it failed, she summoned her magic, carefully at first. She was all too aware of her trembling legs, of the cold still trapped under her own skin. Magnus' magic supported hers, a current of warmth and strength under her unsteady weaves. Osten had firmly dragged the boy's father to the side and was distracting him to the best of his ability. Naami was not listening, but her friend's strong voice helped settle her nerves. Daman sat on a stool like it was a throne, observing, keeping watch on the magic itself, a notepad resting on the table before him. Naami wove magic into a simple healing spell, one to invigorate the patient and restore blood flow. The spell sank into the boy's body, but the cold was stronger. She gathered her strength for a spell of higher power, ready to melt the cold within his flesh. Magnus' only hand brushed against her arm.

"That's too risky," he said in a whisper, glancing at the father. "There is still a flicker of life there, but the two last toes are dead."

With a start, Naami let go of her spell without completing it. Her friend was right. She should have known. She would have known, if she had not been so cold and so tired. The Halfling bit her lip hard, willing for the pain to restore her concentration. She could not afford to mess this up. The father's anxious, short replies to Osten's chatter intruded into her concentration. The boy's shallow breathing was suddenly louder to her ears. His eyelids trembled, then opened to reveal hazel eyes clouded with confusion.

"Where am I?" he said. "Where is Dad?"

"Your Da's right here, lad," Magnus said warmly. "You'll be able to talk to him in a bit. Just be a little patient."

"I can't feel my toes," the boy whined.

"I know it's very scary," Magnus said, "but we're gonna do our best to help."

The dwarf glanced at Naami. She made herself meet his eyes.

"You're right," she said, her words strangled. "It's too late."

Using magic would only poison his blood and kill him in minutes. The only hope for the boy's life was to cut off the dead flesh, and heal what still had a chance to be healed. Naami ignored the painful churning in her stomach; she had to think of the practical side. With Magnus' help, she thoroughly examined the boy. Only two of the toes on his right foot were beyond saving. Two toes, on a boy whose voice had not dropped yet… No. Only two toes. He could recover from this, if he survived the procedure.

"Osten, we're gonna need space," she said, voice void of emotion.

The knight understood the message, and began leading the father away to the rooms on the first floor. There were protests, the innkeeper got involved, and Naami ignored all of it. She prepared more herbs, salves to stop bleeding, salves to protect from infection, and one mix that would send anyone into a deathlike sleep. Her hands shook only a little as she prepared the mixture, and coaxed the boy to drink it. When he was lying senseless on the table, and she had clean cloth and bandages ready, Naami took a deep breath. Her dagger was plain, the blade nicked, but it would have to do. She hesitated, then also removed her spellwards. Magnus shot her a glare.

"If you use this magic, you'll die," he said.

"And if I don't, he will die."

The dwarf exhaled explosively, frustration turning to anger.

"I can't tell you what to do," he growled, "but have a care for your own life."

"I am! I can do this!"

Daman looked up from the notes he was taking, face blank.

"Magnus is right, Naami. Don't be reckless. You can't save everyone."

"I can't if I don't try," she said between clenched teeth. "And I'm not alone anyway. Magnus can use healing magic too."

"I can't heal death," he muttered.

"No one can," Daman snapped. "Sometimes there is nothing to do."

"But not now," Naami said softly, as if to herself. "Now there is still a chance for this family, so let me take it."

Daman shrugged and returned to his scribing. Magnus gave Naami a level look.

"You better be sure of yourself, lass. The only thing I'm really asking you is, don't make your friends sad. Don't break your family to save strangers."

"I won't."

"Then let's be about it," he sighed.

Naami completed the preparations; cleaning up as much as possible, and asking Magnus to prepare certain spells. She hardly needed to say what she wanted him to do; they had worked together for some time. She stalled as much as she dared, but the inevitable moment came when she held the point of her dagger on the boy's skin. She aimed at the joint between the bones, the weakest point. She let magic fill her mind to calm her nerves, then leaned on the dagger with all her weight.

The blade sank into flesh and remained stuck. Gritting her teeth, ignoring the boy's whining through the sleeping draught, she whacked the dagger's pommel. It took two more tries before it bit into the wood with a thud. Despite Magnus' magic, the bleeding was already severe. There was simply no time. She applied the blade to the second toe, trying to wish more strength into her arms. It took only two tries then, but the cuts were uneven, the edges mangled by the chipped blade. Dropping the dagger, she set to weaving a healing spell. There was so much blood. The boy's face grew bone-white, his whimpers fading into silence. Naami summoned more power into her spell, power to knit wounds and restore life force. In the urgency of the moment, she paid no mind to the flood of magic rushing through her. She only rarely took off her spellwards, and in a crisis she acted on instinct fuelled by training and habit. Her spell blossomed into a torrent of positive energy, closing the wounds in a heartbeat. The boy's breathing steadied, colour returned to his cheeks. Dimly, Naami heard Magnus curse in tones of awe. She knew what he must be seeing; she felt it, a tiny circle of life with power over death, between her and the child. Life flowed from her into him, and the cold in his flesh lost ground until it was gone. She knew that in a sense, she had taken the shadow of death from him, and settled it on her instead. She knew that, and all the light around her was swallowed in a tide of silent darkness.

Naami awoke to a lumpy mattress and scratchy blankets. When she tried to raise her head, the small room spun around her. Voices came from the corridor, one angry and the other soothing.

"… told her! The idiot! She hardly controls her magic without those bracelets, but she had to!"

"She had to, and you know it."

"She can die for all I care! Burn herself out with that magic!"

"You don't mean that, Magnus."

"Mean it! That's easy for you to say! You can't see the weaves. The sheer amount of power she pulled into herself… do you have any idea…?"

An uncomfortable silence. Then Osten replied, in a much quieter voice, "No, I don't. But she is alive, and so is the boy."

Boots thudded on the floor, then the door opened, letting the tall knight in.

"Naami." He rushed to her side and knelt by her bed. "How do you feel?"

"Like an idiot?" she said, the words refusing to come out quite right.

"I suppose you would," Osten chuckled. "Don't mind Magnus. He is only frightened for you. When you fainted, he panicked."

"He… is right," she said reluctantly. "It was foolish. Reckless. I was a fool."

"If you know it, that's a step in the right direction. Just make sure the next step follows suit."

She nodded, her thoughts sluggish. Osten told her that the boy was alive and well, that he would walk again, if with a cane or a prosthetic. The father had burst into tears and sworn before the gods to pay with all he owned, cradling his boy. Daman had wanted to accept before Osten stepped in. Naami stared at the ceiling, listening with one ear. Her hands hurt with the memory of cutting the boy's toes; she feared she would be sick. The frayed edges of the wounds haunted her mind. It had all worked out in the end, but only because she had put her own life in danger. She hoped there would never be another situation like this one. She knew it was foolish hope, a dangerous wish. What she needed was time to recover her strength, and right after that, a new dagger. A sharper one.

Sharp pain brought Naami's mind back to the present, to the nightmare she was trapped in. She looked down to a nicked finger, and a drop of red on her sharp dagger. She fought down the urge to giggle as she cleaned the small cut; she feared her laugh might escape her control and spin into a mad cackle. She hoped they would make it out alive. No. She hoped they would destroy that demon, and she hoped her hand would be the one to end it. Her staff spoke of forgiveness; she recalled the dawn of the day she had found it, and the soothing cooing of doves. Her crime was forgiven, but the stain on her soul refused to fade, enduring in nightmares and breathless moments of panic. Redemption, she thought, was not a one-time thing; it was a choice, and she wanted to make that choice as many times as she could.

She sheathed her blade, remembering with a shudder that she had threatened a friend with it. She could not lose her nerve again. Naami patiently put herself through the breathing exercises that were part of Ildic witches' training. Her mind strayed, but she brought it back to the task every time. It was not foolish to have hope. It was not! As long as she also expected the worst.

As in answer to her grim thought, the gentle voice spoke in everyone's minds: Rest now, little spirits, you've just navigated the currents of the River of Souls. It's not uncommon to feel a little bewildered upon arrival. All is well here. And as if on cue, the shining darkness crept closer.

pages.name: 77.1 - A blue dress
pages.content:
The nightmare was different this time. As Naami slipped into a fitful sleep in one of the tower's cosy guest rooms, she expected to find herself in the cavern again, defenceless before her fear. She stood in darkness but it was the natural gloom of a deep cave instead of the painful magic-wrought darkness. It was similar to one of the caverns she had traversed with Matron Vandree's party; a high roof made a dome above her head, pierced with stalactites like giant teeth ready to bite down. A dark moss carpeted the rock and a wild array of mushrooms grew close to the walls, fed by dripping water. A purple fungus grew halfway to the roof, its stalks tough as wood. To one of these trunks, the dark shape of a male Drow was nailed by his wrists. His body hung limp as he struggled to breathe, growing weaker by the second.

"Madr!" Naami cried and reached out to her friend.

His eyes glittered with hate. Blood trickled from his mouth.

"Traitor," he spat. "Did we not take care of you? Protect you? You had to run to your kin of cowering surface-dwellers!"

"I was all but a slave," she cried. "I said I would free you. I can save you, too!"

She tried to get close to him but chains wrapped around her neck, and around her bare wrists. The sooty links were driven into the ground, anchored as solidly as if they had grown out of the rock. She struggled, but the cold metal only bit into her skin. Above her Madr's body convulsed, blood flowing out of his mouth now. His eyes closed as his face contorted with pain. Against her better judgement, Naami tried to raise her hands, tried to form the pattern in the Weave that would heal him. She could see the magic, although dimly. The chains dragged her down, draining her strength. If she could manage just one spell, she could save him. Screaming in frustration, fighting her shackles, she called the magic with all her might. It had always been here, an unseen force that would crash into her mind if she so much as thought of it. It would not deny her now! The cold radiated up from her wrists to her shoulders; her fingers went numb. The chain strangled her, now she too was fighting for air but Naami was no stranger to battles anymore. She tasted blood but her spell was taking shape, just another thread of magic and she could release it, seek out Madr's wounds and close them. She could save him. She could save everyone.

The Drow cried out as white wings burst from his back, wide and brilliant in the gloom. His face was no longer his, the sharpness of his features smoothed into a celestial's perfect beauty. Eyes of pure light gazed down on her, filled with worry and pain.

"I can help you, little candle," the winged man said in a caressing tone. "I can teach you to become a better healer."

"No!" Naami shrieked.

Her tenuous control over magic slipped and she released her spell. Knowing what would happen did not make it any easier. The celestial had worn Madr's face just a minute ago, but his body flashed into a tortured ruin, a mockery of what an angel had been. The spell closed mortal wounds, only for the skin to burst a moment later, spilling blood, torn entrails, and maggots. Held by her chains, Naami could only scream and writhe as her hands were splashed with blood, as squirming shapes climbed up her legs. Slicing through her screams a voice reached her, cold as a poison-coated blade.

"Traitor," Matron Vandree said, her silhouette looming in the shadows. "You have chosen your fate, and the spider goddess has blessed me with the duty to deliver you onto it."

"I healed your people!" Naami cried. "I offered my blood and my life force to close your wounds!"

"Only to plot to kill us all," she laughed, a joyless sound more akin to that of a blade being drawn. "How pointless. Is it the same with your surface-dweller friends? Do you also heal them, only for them to run back into the fight and get injured again? Why do you try? Why do you pay the cost in blood, time and again, for nothing to change?"

"Because that's who I am." Naami could not blame the chain around her neck for the pain in her throat, the stabbing heat of a lump announcing tears.

"Useless," the Matron sneered. "All you do is undone. Give up. After betraying me, there is nothing left for you anyway."

"You're wrong!"

She smiled; it was a threat. "Why don't you scream how wrong I am? But will anyone hear you?"

Naami's resolve flared; on the edge of delivering a biting response she saw the Matron lift her arm, fingers hooking around threads of magic. She uttered words of such power, Naami's bones hummed with it. Then all went black, vision and hearing swallowed by humid warmth and the overpowering stench of decay. Before she even touched the inner shell of a slimy egg, before her flesh began to spasm and change, she knew where she was; back in the Sibriex' lair, being warped into a monster, and she would not have Kyrin's luck. She screamed then, screamed until her throat was raw and her head spun, screamed until the darkness seized her and she slumped inside the black egg, her skin bulging in agony. She howled, and there was nobody to hear her.

Naami screamed herself awake and twisted out of the sweat-soaked sheets, brutally landing on the rug next to her bed. She lay on her back, eyes darting as she tried to catch her breath. The reek of blood and decay lingered in her nose; her fingertips still felt slimy. She grabbed at her throat, and could not stifle a relieved sob when she found no chain there. Her spellwards were snug on her wrists, a familiar coolness on her clammy skin. She drank in the quiet of the tower. She was safe here, was she not?

A bang at her door made her jump near out of her skin. She lay in the dimness, panting as quietly as she could, unable to move for her life. She listened with all her being but after a short moment, a familiar voice spoke.

"Naami? You're awake?"

It was Aviana's voice. Naami tried to stand twice but her legs would not let her. She had to settle for slumping on the rug, draped in her blanket.

"Yes. Um… Sorry if I woke you?"

"It's alright. Are you okay? I heard a noise."

Naami gathered her courage for a confident reply. She would give a little giggle and dismiss it as a dream and the harpy would laugh, maybe tease her, and be on her way. It would be as if none of this had happened. All she had to do was wave a hand and smile. She would climb back into bed, and go back to sleep.

"I had a nightmare," Naami said in a tiny voice, barely swallowing a sob.

A pause, then: "Can I come in?"

Naami gave a squeak in assent. The door swung open, admitting the harpy. Aviana sat on the rug next to her, her dark wings making the small room feel crowded. Naami reached out to brush the feathers, her hands shaking. In the darkness she could not see where the dark grey feathers turned to deep blue, but it was enough to know they were not white. Her stomach turned at the memory of brilliant white wings. How much longer would she suffer those nightmares? She had overcome her fear! She had defeated the monster in the Sibriex' lair!

With a lot of care, Aviana put one hand on Naami's head, her sharp talons curling away. The Halfling gave a surprised start, but at the first clumsy head pat the tension began to drain from her shoulders. Aviana's careful touch made her skin tingle; the friendly gesture, if awkward, was immensely calming. She realised her jaw ached from grinding her teeth, and made herself stop.

"The bravest of us have nightmares," Aviana said wisely. "Sometimes even when we are awake. Often, they're called Plex."

The Halfling giggled in spite of herself. Oh, she was still shaky, still haunted by the horrifying visions. But Aviana's words… they were real. Her friend was real, and they would protect each other.

"And sometimes, even Plex disappears," the harpy went on. "So nothing is so scary it lasts forever! Until Plex comes back, I suppose… Better to focus on the good things. I've only ever seen you in the green dress, do you have a blue one? Deep blue, like my feathers, that would really compliment your eyes, and it would go well with the bracelets you always wear."

"I do have another travelling dress," Naami said, her voice becoming steadier. "It's more of a light blue, though."

"Well that will hardly do," Aviana sniffed, dead serious. "We do need to go shopping some time. I also need another mug."

"Didn't Fearghas just buy you a mug?"

"Yes," she admitted, patiently drawing out the word, "but he bought it from the Duergar. Who knows how it was made. Probably by slaves. How unethical! It will make my drinks taste of low morality. And then my skin will get all dull. You need to pay attention to these things."

Tears rose to Naami's eyes faster than she could stifle them. She was blubbering before she had a chance to calm herself. Hearing Aviana's usual talk, as if nightmares had no power on her, on the world… the sense of relief was just too powerful for her shredded nerves. She wiped her eyes, only bringing out more tears. She grieved for the celestials, she feared for Madr and for her friends, but above all she relished Aviana's lively presence, she delighted in being alive and well herself. Angels or demons would not break her. She had powerful allies she could rely on, and they were becoming dear friends too. Neither the Drow nor the Duergar would stop her. She would find out what was happening in Ildilas, and she would go home and see her parents. She could introduce them to her friends!

"There, Naamilia. It's okay," Aviana said, her usually flamboyant voice dropped to a soothing whisper.

She draped one wing over Naami's shoulders. Silky feathers brushed the Halfling's skin, a cool caress and an occasional tickle. How had Aviana come up with this nickname? It didn't matter. Naami reached out for a hug, her hands growing steadier. Aviana hugged her back with great care, as if she was made of brittle glass. To the harpy's strength, she probably was even more fragile than glass. Beneath skin unmarred by scars, thanks to potions and magic, Aviana's muscles were steel. Even as she sat with her legs casually crossed, comforting a friend, she had the aura of a force of nature. She was a rock, steadfast and immovable, unlike the boulders she liked to move. There was no place safer than Aviana's arms in this moment.

"Thank you," the healer said.

"For what?"

"Everything. Not abandoning me to the Drow. For keeping me away from Dimzad and his chains. Even though I've only put you all in greater danger now."

"Ah, nonsense. There is always danger for people like us. Where is the fun, without a good arm wrestling session?"

"Speak for yourself," Naami giggled. "You have so much muscle."

"It makes my charm," Aviana said. "And you have… negative muscle, really. You are eating meat? And plenty of soup?"

"Yes mum," Naami teased. "I'm just naturally small."

"Hmmm. Doesn't hurt to make sure. I'll ask Shalkoc to cook a healthy breakfast for you. Dawn shouldn't be too far, now."

In the windowless room, it was impossible to be sure. Naami stood gingerly but her legs were steady enough for a dance now. She could not resist a little hop and a skip out of the room, to prove she could. She was not afraid anymore. In the tower's main hall, a pale light touched the high windows, making the floor tiles gleam. Motes of dust glittered in the air, reminding Naami to tease Fearghas about cleaning up the place. Soon her friends would wake up, and they would all gather for breakfast. The nightmare would really be gone then, dispelled by daylight and the party's noise, by hot tea and sweet treats. It would come back; Naami was certain of it. Confronting her fear was not the same as healing from it. When the nightmare returned she would be ready to face it again, as many times as it took. Aviana took her leave to be about her morning stretches; left to herself, Naami gave her face a thorough wash, and changed into her blue dress.

pages.name: The Gray
pages.content:
Just as Plex prepared to step through the portal alongside his companions, an unseen force yanked him back into the Feywild. Though the transition was not unfamiliar, something about it this time felt unsettling, as if the very essence of the realm had shifted.

When he opened his eyes, the usual kaleidoscope of vibrant, overwhelming colors did not greet him. Instead, a strange dullness had taken hold of the landscape, as though the world around him was slowly fading, its once brilliant hues bleeding away into shades of gray.

For a day, perhaps two, Plex wandered through this muted wilderness. He gathered curious and rare materials, though the joy of discovery felt unusually distant. Eventually, as he crossed a shimmering river, he encountered a Nereid.

It was Aranei, a familiar figure from Mennon's court, her uncanny beauty seeming diminished in this colorless light. She spoke of a strange veil that had descended upon Mennon’s palace and the surrounding lands—a veil that sapped not only color but also joy from everything it touched. The court had fallen into disarray, and the Dark Hunt, had been postponed indefinitely. "Far more pressing matters claim our attention now," Mennon had said in an unusually cryptic tone, laced with urgency.

Those of lesser strength within the court had been urged to flee, and Aranei had done so, retreating into the wild rivers she called home. As she fled, she noticed with dread that the veil was expanding, creeping outward like a living thing, muting colors, light, and joy as it spread.

Before Aranei could finish her tale, Plex felt the familiar tug of planar magic once again. The Feywild shimmered and blurred, and before he could offer any farewell to the Nereid, the world around him shifted.

In the blink of an eye, he found himself standing back on the material plane, just outside the party’s cabin.

pages.name: The Lantern
pages.content:
Meeting Familiar Faces

One moment Plex was in the middle of adjusting his gear, grumbling to himself about the ever-present dust in the lich's former lair, and the next—a hefty sneeze exploded from him. In that instant, the curse took hold, twisting reality around him in a familiar, disorienting flash.

The ground beneath his feet vanished, and with a jolt, he found himself standing amidst the chaotic beauty of the Feywild. It wasn’t his first time, nor would it likely be the last, but the sudden teleportation left him cursing the fates as he stumbled through the colourful, shifting landscape. The fact that the world around him was full of colour and life, and not covered in a grey veil like it had been the last time, was a relieving realisation.

After several days of wandering, his aimless journey brought him to a vast lake, its waters a shimmering cascade of colours that reflected the ever-changing skies above. At its center, a town floated on the lake's surface—an intricate network of platforms and bridges, held aloft by some ancient magic. The town was mostly inhabited by elves, their buildings graceful and elegant, seeming to glide with the gentle waves. Curious and with little else to do, Plex swam his way over to the town.

It was there that he encountered Antx and Prantx. The goblin twins had arrived just a few days before him and were lingering at the edge of town, trying to stay out of sight of the more suspicious elves. The town’s residents hadn’t been too keen on allowing the goblins to remain, seeing them as troublemakers who didn’t belong among their refined society. But after some tense negotiations, Prantx had managed to convince the elves to let them stay, offering his skills as a blacksmith in exchange for shelter. His craftsmanship was impressive enough to win them a begrudging place within the floating community.

When Plex approached them, the two goblins were quick to strike up a deal, exchanging a few small trinkets they had acquired during their travels in return for some basic supplies Plex had been carrying. It was after the trade that the twins shared their story of a recent incident with him.

The Brothers' Story

Antx and Prantx described the strange series of events with a certain level of disbelief, as if recounting a fevered dream that hadn't yet faded from their minds.

It had started when they got teleported into a region of the Feywild that wasn’t like anything they had ever seen before. The air was thick with a mist that seemed alive. It wasn’t like ordinary fog—this mist clung to everything, swallowing the vibrant colours that normally defined the Feywild. The greens of the trees, the brilliant blues of the sky, even the shimmering hues of their own skin seemed to fade. The world around them became dull, bleached of its usual lustre.

In the middle of this eerie, washed-out landscape, they found it—a lantern, standing alone amidst the fog. It was old and weathered, but something about it drew them in. There was a sensation, a pull, like the lantern was whispering to them, calling them closer. Neither of them could explain why, but they felt compelled to touch it.

The moment their hands made contact, the world twisted around them, folding in on itself. The colours that had been drained from the surroundings seemed to rush inward, converging on the lantern, before exploding into a blinding flash of light. When the light faded, they were no longer in the Feywild.

Instead, they found themselves in a clearing unlike anything they had ever known. The trees were twisted and dead, their branches brittle and sharp like claws against the perpetually dim sky. Above them hung a full moon, heavy and cold, but there were no stars, no sun—just an endless night. And no matter how much time passed, the moon remained still, locked in its position high above.

The clearing itself was small and unnervingly quiet. At its centre stood another lantern, eerily similar to the one they had touched. Unlike the lantern in the Feywild, this one didn’t drain colours. It was still, almost tranquil, but as they watched, a small, flickering mote of light formed within it. The mote wasn’t like the dim glow of the moon—it was vivid, almost painfully so, as if it had taken all the stolen colours of the Feywild and concentrated them into this single point of light.

Without hesitation, the mote drifted out of the lantern and began to float toward the forest, moving slowly but purposefully. It was the only thing that seemed alive in this dead, barren place. Antx and Prantx had considered following it, but the dark, oppressive forest felt too vast, too filled with unknown dangers.

Before they could make a decision, their curse took hold. Instinctively, both brothers reached out to the lantern on the clearing and held onto it, even though they knew full well it wouldn't stop the teleportation. Then they were ripped away from that strange clearing, transported back to the Feywild in what seemed like an instant. The moment they appeared again, the vibrant colours of the Feywild flooded their senses, and the oppressive feeling of the dead forest faded, though the memory of it lingered.

To their surprise, two were still holding onto the lantern they had just grabbed. After making sure it wasn't draining any colours from them, they decided to hold onto it to give it to someone who might know better what to do with it. And so they were relieved to meet Plex - after all, who else could have been better suited for such a task than the wise shaman of their tribe?

pages.name: Of Titania, Snot, and a Goat
pages.content:
By an accident Plex bumps in to Mennon and his entourage, They are searching for Titania due to the imminent collapse of the Fey-wild, and asks Plex to help him search. Mennon is annoyed since few of the creatures living around Titania's court welcome him, and they are making his search unnecessary difficult. Therefore he wants Plex, who is less known to sneak in and search for her. as a thanks he will let Plex borrow two of his new servants, Antx and Parnatx.

So Plex and his two tribe members travel towards the court of Titania. On there way Plex, Antx and Parnatx, discuss the the ritual that bound Antx and Parnatx together and the curse Elsa placed on them. Apparently the curse have started to become stronger, and are now teleporting Antx and Parnatx to other planes as well. For strategic reasons they therefor decided to try to also bind Plex to the two of them to increase their chanse of survival. However, it doesn't go as planed and the ritual fails multiple times during several Sleep cycles before they have to give up on the idea. It wasn't all for naught tho, since during there experimentation Plex manages to cook up a new spell instead.

A while later they arrive in a happy field in Titania court, filled with Pink and red flowers. Through the field cuts a luminous river that blocks the trios path. However the other side of the river is suspiciously quiet which worries Plex. They decides to follow the river, searching for a safer place to cross the river, when they come to a small settlement of frog-like creatures. Plex is greeted by a tribe of Bagiennik (a race of toad people with innate healing abilities concentrated in their snot) that are camping by the riverside.

They explain that they are searching for a white flower with innate healing abilities, but they are equally worried about the foreboding silence up ahead. They ask the trio to fetch the flowers for them and in return they are willing to share some of their magic knowledge.The trio agree and heads out into the silent field, picking white flowers, when Plex notices that the field is littered with patches of withered and frozen flowers.

He doesn't have much time to speculate on it tho, as they are suddenly ambushed by a group of Calpinas (insect like creatures who eat charisma form their pray) . The trio manages to fend of the insects and even capture one of them. After some interrogation Plex learns that the insects uses the magical flowers as a lure to catch unsuspecting pray. And that their numbers used to be much higher before they made the critical mistake to attack a Hag with her entourage that passed through, which Plex assumes was Elsa.

Plex also learned that soon thereafter almost no creatures entered the fields agin leaving them starving. But before Plex could squeeze out any more information, Antx and Parnatx disappeared, which gave the Calpina an opportunity to escape. Returning to the frog people with the magical flowers Plex was rewarded with a new feat and some bottles of snot.Here he also learned that there was no reason to search for Titania, as she and her entire court had diapered a while back.

Armed with the new information Plex heads back towards Mennon, but he is distracted by a "Lantern goat" (a goat that uses its lantern to lure and capture nearby souls on there way to the afterlife for consumption), that crosses his path. Plex hasn't given up on the idea to have a goat as his personal spy. So in an attempt to capture the goat, Plex sets up a trap and prepares a big net, readying himself to ambush the lantern goat. As the goat walks in to his trap Plex leaps towards the goat and tries to grab its horns. [and then he leaves the Fey-wilds]

pages.name: Of Bad Business, Guards, and a Seagull
pages.content:
Refurnishing the wardrobe of the room in the first floor of the Rimeskull tavern, where Drufi's father let the party stay, and removing the door to the room worked just as Plex had planned.

However trying to find customers amongst the frost giants proved to be impossible. While some might be willing to climb through a window, fewer would be willing to pay for it. The real issue however came from Plex offering to make them smaller - a suggestion the vast majority of frost giants finds highly disturbing.

To give you an image of the kinds of reactions Plex got, think of how you'd react irl if someone opened the window of a house you were just walking past, asked you if you want to pay 10€ to climb inside and get your balls cut off.

Needless to say, it didn't take long until guards were called and Plex had to make a run for it. After evading the guards for a while, naturally causing more chaos on the way, he noticed a black raven circling above and seemingly following him. Distracted by having to dodge an oar swung at him by a fisher who was not happy to see Plex standing in the middle of his catch, Plex lost sight of the raven for a moment.

Minutes later, after momentarily shaking off his pursuers, he found himself inside a narrow alleyway when the black raven appeared again. This time the animal landed next to Plex and dropped a piece of parchment it had been carrying in his beak in front of Plex's feet before flying away again.

When Plex read the parchment he watched as the ink lifted itself off the page, flew towards his spellbook, and inscribed a new spell into it, all in the blink of an eye. Only very little ink remained on the parchment of the scroll, spelling out the words: "A little token of appreciation from a fellow admirer of chaos. Good lu-"
Plex's head snapped to the side as he suddenly heard a loud thump at the entrance of the alleyway, only to see it blocked by the large figure of another guard.

Half an hour later, Plex enjoyed the view of the city of Utgard beneath him, with the cold and stormy ocean to one side and a seemingly endless stretch of glacier-covered mountains to the other. His enjoyment of the view was only slightly hampered by the fact he was holding on for dear life, clinging onto the feathers of a seagull that was very unhappy about being used as a mount...

pages.name: A Story about Goats
pages.content:
Just as Aviana's hand closed around Plex's neck, the goblin's curse took hold once more and transported him into the Feywild - only for Aviana's curse to take hold as well and bring her along.

The two appeared in the middle of a clearing in a vibrant forest, and surrounded by a few dozen Satyrs who're dancing, drinking, playing music, and partying. Their music suddenly stopped however once they got interrupted by Plex's choking gasps for air and Aviana's "Listen here you little shit...".

The satyrs clearly weren't amused and what followed was an honest effort of diplomacy from Aviana. Which was interrupted only briefly when she noticed that she was still holding Plex aloft by his throat, and that this particular image probably wasn't helping her diplomatic efforts. So she let the goblin go, who immediately teleported away from Aviana. Or rather tried to, as his first attempt resulted in him just teleporting from Aviana's left to her right. The 2nd attempt that followed was successful however and Aviana lost sight of the goblin.

She continued her efforts to make peace with the satyrs but was having a tough time as she made one social faux pas (in the satyr's eyes that is) after another. When Aviana saw the rainbow-colored glow and heard the bleats coming from the forest's edge, she immediately knew what was to come and instantly regretted ever letting go of Plex's neck. The Lantern Goat stormed onto the clearing with Plex on it's back holding onto its horns for dear life. Now that was the kind of diplomacy the satyrs could get behind, and soon the music, dancing, and drinking started again, with Aviana, Plex, and the Lantern Goat as guests of honour.

All were having a good time until Aviana couldn't restrain herself any longer. The large boulder at the edge of the clearing was the first thing she noticed when she arrived here and she instantly knew that not lifting it would be something she'd regret for the rest of her life. The boulder's bizarre shape just made it even more intriguing, as it reminded her a lot of a giant goat's head. So she went over, grabbed it, and - didn't lift it. "Strange", she thought to herself and tried again, putting all of her strength into the lift. Much to her satisfaction, the boulder moved.

Much to her, and everyone else's, dissatisfaction however, it wasn't just the boulder that moved. The earth beneath the clearing shook and rose, higher and higher, until all could see the tops of the trees beneath them. Off in the distance, Aviana even saw a large patch of forest was completely grey. She didn't have much opportunity to ponder that however, as the head-like boulder she tried to lift turned out to be an actual head after all. Namely the head of a mythical Mountain Goat, who had been slumbering for eons. Who was very displeased with Aviana's attempts to tear its head off.

A fight for survival ensued as the Mountain Goat bucked and shook. The satyrs tried to hold on but one by one they fell off the Mountain Goat's back, disappearing into the treetops below with a scream. Plex wasn't having any issues himself as he had correctly figured that a goat wouldn't have any issues standing on another goat, and so he had once again climbed onto the Lantern Goat's back. Due to his growing experience with using unwilling Lantern Goats as mounts, he was finding it easier and easier to hold on. This even allowed him to save several of the satyrs from certain death, as he teleported them safely to the ground.

Aviana, unwilling - and unable - to let go of ~~her boulder~~ the Mountain Goat's head, looked for a way to resolve this situation and the first solution that came to her mind was, unsurprisingly, the broken Iron Flask. She grabbed it from her pockets and threw it at the Mountain Goat - and missed. Plex, witnessing Aviana's valiant attempt from the relative safety of the Lantern Goat's back, couldn't help but be impressed by Aviana's ability to miss a creature the size of a small mountain as he saw the small bottle plummet into the forest below - only to be followed by Aviana, who had no intentions of losing her precious Iron Flask.

Figuring it was a good time for him to leave as well, he teleported himself and the Lantern Goat down to the ground where Aviana was frantically searching for her Iron Flask. After a few minutes of searching - while fighting off the Mountain Goat's attempts to trample her - she eventually found her Iron Flask and noticed that the brass stopper was firmly closed. Before she had time to wonder what was now inside the flask, the Mountain Goat's hoof stomped down and Aviana barely managed to turn around and catch it. The weight of the colossal creature made her sink into the ground but she didn't budge. Getting stomped to death by a giant goat was not how she planned to die!

The Lantern Goat Plex was riding - or rather was trying to ride as he had no way of controlling it - was about to run past Aviana and the Goblin figured this was a good an opportunity to leave as they were gonna get. He just needed a moment to cast a spell - and for that his mount would have to be still for even a second. He shouted at Aviana and the conversation that followed went something like this:

Plex: "Hold the goat!"

Aviana: "I AM! CAN'T YOU SEE THAT?"

Lantern Goat: "Bleeee!"

Mountain Goat ( *very annoyed*): "**BLEEEEEEE**"

Plex: "Nooo, the other goat!"

Aviana ( *also very annoyed*): "LISTEN HERE YOU LITTLE SHIT..."

Lantern Goat: "Bleeee???"

And so Aviana grabbed the Lantern Goat's horn as it ran past, now holding up the Mountain Goat's weight with just one hand. Plex used this moment to open a teleportation gate in the ground beneath them and he, Aviana, and the Lanter Goat all fell through. A few hundred feet away, at the other end of the gate, Aviana got launched several hundred feet into the air as the force of the Mountain Goat's hoof pushed her through. Her fall back down was slowed by several tree branches so she was barely falling anymore when she landed on the ground. Plex, pleased with his efforts to save himself, Aviana and, most importantly, the Lantern Goat, realised that the Mountain Goat was still coming for them. And that he would very much like Fearghas to see it...

When Plex felt Aviana's hand tighten around his neck like a vice once more, he felt the weave around him snap as her action caused a wild magic surge. The world around Plex twisted and he felt like his stomach was pulled through his nose - the oh so familiar feeling of unwilling planar teleportation.

pages.name: Zariel Contract
pages.content:
Task

Slay the angel named Shaik, last known to reside on Threshold, the first layer of Heaven. Immediately after Shaik's death, transmit Shaik's dying words to Zariel, Archduchess of Avernus, via a Sending spell. The signee is expected to make maintain consistent efforts towards the fulfillment of his task and failure to do so would be considered a breach of this contract.

Consequences of Failure

Zariel, Archduchess of Avernus becomes the legal and rightful owner of the signee's soul if the signee fails to complete the contract.

Upon Signing

Should the signee sign this constract, the transgressions of his ally, the goblin named Plex, are voided and his life spared.

Upon Fulfillment

Should the signee successfully achieve the task outlined above, he shall be rewarded with the requested items: 100000 gold pieces, 10000 lb of unspecified food, 3 magical tomes to be selected from the library of the Bronze Citadel, and a large, portable bathtub filled with magical milk that has the properties of a Philter of Love upon consumption.

The signee is expected to personally claim his rewards from the Bronze Citadel within one week of the contract's fulfillment.

Fearghas mumbles and opens an Tiny Hut while Plex starts eating a shoe.
This aggroes the forest and a fight breaks out.
Emilio twitch reaction teamsmokes and Kyrin gets lost in the Abyssal Haginfested Spriggan Woods.

Kyrin is VERY angry after the Spriggans surprise attack, but Shalkoc explains that the steaming angery makes her very hot, and for some reason Kyrin starts stabbing Shalkoc instead.

Obviously we instead use Plex as an escape vehicle and he brings us to Heaven instead of Hell.
Can't blame him.
We buy forks for Plex and head back to Hell with his Planetrotting.

Fireball rain greets us, as we march for hours towards the Black Vents.
The crevices spewing black soot of smoke, hosting an eerie intention towards us as we traverse it.

After 60 successful Wildmagic Checks in a row, Aviana uses her chains to make a bridge for the party to cross the crevice.
Sadly every single one fails and spends resources.
