The Halfling was starting to understand Aviana's fascination for the potions that grew her to that huge size.

"I've got a distraction for them," the harpy said, reaching into her pack.

Naami's heart froze in horror when she pulled out the dented iron flask, tiny in her talons. What was in there now?

"Aviana, no!" she screamed, but it was too late. The cork popped off, making no sound in the chaos.

A dark cloud rushed out, resolving in a tall horned silhouette. Although it was humanoid, it could never be mistaken for a person; not only because it was as tall as Aviana was after drinking the potion, but because it was made of dry wood and mossy bark instead of flesh and blood. Its arms ended in claws, a single one of those longer than Naami's staff. The curving, bone-white wood was sharp as razors. Where a face should have been, the creature had an animal skull from which sprouted imposing antlers. In the empty eye sockets, a spark of dark magic glowed.

Ignoring Aviana's attempts at friendly words, the creature raised a wooden arm. Threads of magic snapped into place around it, a spell taking shape. Fearghas held out a spellgem to try to prevent it, but the magic in the stone proved too weak. Emilio stepped forward, his fingers crooked, his eyes burning with magic as he spoke the counterspell. The creature's spell unravelled, but it showed no sign of caring. It flicked a finger, this time too fast for anyone to react. The ground cracked open, vines bursting out and lashing at Emilio. With a yelp he was caught and dragged back towards the chasm, far enough to be within range of the Seers. One of them took that chance and shot three orbs towards the party's new companion. Struggling with the vine, he had no chance to defend himself. Emilio did not raise his arms, did not cry out. His body went limp, slumping out of the vine's grasp.

Naami screamed, which only drew the creature's attention. Reflexes born of a lifetime of danger made her throw herself to the side. Wooden claws sank into the ground where she had stood, gouging the stone. Stunned, she could not evade a second attack. The claws cut through her shoulder with the ease of a blade ripping cloth. Her vision went dark, the world fading into nothing but pain. As light was about to disappear, Naami sensed Plex' magic around her. His ward against death was still on her! The weave fell apart now, leaving her barely conscious but alive. The shock dropped her to her knees, causing the creature's third attack to cut no more than a strand of hair.

Clinging to consciousness, a waterfall crashing in her ears, Naami scarcely made out Fearghas' voice.

"I'm sorry Shalkoc, I can't catch you in the spell's range. You and Aviana will have to run. Meet us back in the mines of Lessia."

A few steps away, the Dragonborn nodded gravely. The harpy leapt down the corridor they had come from, a blur of speed and feathers. Then Fearghas' teleportation magic formed around the rest of them, and the cavern spun into nothingness. There was one second of weightlessness, a heartbeat of dizzying disorientation, then there was ground beneath them again. Naami recognised the tunnel they had rested in, overlooking the smoke and noise of Ukgluz. The rock was cold and hard against her knees, but she found myself unable to stand. Her legs would not respond; her entire body shook. Emilio was next to Naami, lying on the ground with blood trickling from his closed eyes. The pained sound of his laboured breathing bounced between the tunnel walls. The grave urgency that had hung around him like a cloak was gone, and he looked much smaller, little more than a sickly boy. Naami could sense his life force flickering, a candle in the wind. If she could not stand, then she would crawl. She would not let him die. She would not let anyone die as long as she drew breath.

She reached out towards him, calling her magic. Her spellwards were cool on her wrists; if she took them off, could she save him? Naami's hands trembled as her thoughts tangled; at the back of her mind, she suspected that an attempt to channel would kill her, and no goblin magic would save her this time. But magic was not the only force that could save a life! She had herbs in her pack, and an ointment that could close wounds as fast as a spell. She could sew his worst wounds closed to stop the bleeding. She could...

"Drink this, lass." Fearghas' voice pulled her mind from its fevered track. "You're in a sorry state too. I'll get some life back in him."

He handed her a potion that glittered like liquid ruby dust. It took three attempts with her left hand to uncork the bottle; Naami's right arm was burning with pain, the muscles unresponsive. She sipped the potion, and the pain lost ground, sensation returning to her fingers. Fearghas crouched next to Emilio, dripping another healing potion into his mouth. In seconds, the young man opened his eyes, purple irises resting on Fearghas, then on Naami.

"We're alive," he murmured.

"Barely," Fearghas grumbled, standing up.

Naami got her first good look at Emilio's eyes then. They were narrowed as he winced from the pain, and blood coloured the whites, but that was not what made them so unsettling. As a healer, she had seen pain and agony; she had seen fear and broken courage. That was not what showed in Emilio's eyes. The haunting purple irises seemed hollow, as if to draw in light. His eyes did not belong in such a youthful face. These eyes... had seen entirely too much. As vague as this was, it was the only way she could describe the emptiness she sensed. Whatever he knew, it had taken a lot out of him. Maybe it had stolen something from him, forever.

Plex limped over to them, waving his hands.

"Magic got your tongue?" Fearghas said, a spark of amusement in his eyes even as his shoulders sagged under the weight of weariness.

The goblin nodded so empathically, Naami feared the sudden motion would aggravate his wounds.

"No can do, for now," the dwarf said.

"Where are Shalkoc and Aviana?" Emilio asked, struggling to form the words.

"Running. They'll meet us here, I hope." Fearghas grumbled.

"They better meet us here," Naami said, her heart aching with worry.

Plex nodded as Emilio murmured assent. It was frustrating to the point of madness, but there was nothing Naami could do but sit and wait, hurting and shaking. There was nothing to do but wait and hope.

pages.name: 73 - A strong neck can rule a nation
pages.content:
Aviana and Shalkoc escape arrest by the Duergar by… Shalkoc flying up, with Aviana inside the iron flask. They leave the Duergar to deal with the Leshen, and Shalkoc flies up to the tunnel where we had been huddling for about three hours. We've had a short rest, and Plex is no longer mute. Shalkoc releases Aviana from the flask; she is grimacing with a terrible headache, and is in a vile mood. After a few words from Plex, she again grabs his neck, and both of them disappear. Fearghas attempts to explain the process to Emilio, he does not seem very enlightened.

Shalkoc is very out of breath from flying all this way, so Fearghas casts Leomund's Tiny Hut as a ritual, conjures up Unseen Servants, and we set up camp in the tunnel. The bag of scolding grills Fearghas, we take a long rest. Shalkoc cooks up an impressive amount of bacon, egg, and sausage, helping everyone feel alive again.

We discuss our plans, the voidborn, and whether Shalkoc could conceivably feed all the void invaders to appease them (not likely). Motivated by Fearghas' enthusiam (and reluctance to burn a 6th level spell slot first thing in the… evening? We slept the day away), we walk down to Ukgluz. Many of the statues in Ukgluz are severely damaged, scratch marks like those left by giant claws. The hospital seems to be overflowing with wounded soldiers, most of them with broken bones like they've taken a big fall. Some look like they've been bitten by a swarm of mosquitoes. I ask the party if they know what kind of creature could do that. Fearghas says a spell could do that; Insect Plague.

We assume all these wounds occurred in the Duergars' attempt to capture the Leshen. :')

Fearghas asks for an audience with King Dimzad regarding the void portal. We are ushered in by excited guards who did not expect we would survive. We are all impressed by the strength of the neck on King Dimzad, supporting the massive hat on his head. He greets Fearghas, surprised and pleased to see him, congratulates him on the… use of his slaves (that's us). The Leshen apparently destroyed several of the Duergars' demon engines; they eventually caught it, but it's proving troublesome, "like a demon but not quite". Shudder…

Fearghas explains that the Leshen comes from the Feywild, but that he doesn't really know any more about it. Dimzad wants to get his hands on Aviana (alive or dead) to try to bind the Leshen. He does not seem to understand that Fearghas can't just sell him Aviana. Dimzad claims that the more emotional a demon gets, the easier it becomes to bind it. I'll keep that in mind… The king is pretty convinced that the Leshen is a demon and not a fey creature.

Fearghas reminds Dimzad that there was an agreement for assistance in fighting the Matron Vandree, but the king tries to backtrack and say that closing the portal only proved that Fearghas is "worth serving him". Fearghas guesses that Dimzad is just saving face in front of his court and not actually trying to short us. Phew… Dimzad and Fearghas proceed to have a very uncomfortable conversation over my head about training your slaves, and keeping me from escaping. The king suggests a chain of null-steel, and promises to gift one to Fearghas.

On the way out, Fearghas mutters that he hates Duergar. Shalkoc replies that we should deal with them once we are done with the Drow. I am shaking at the thought of anti-magic shackles. Emilio is brooding. One of the king's servants comes to us carrying a very heavy chain that looks like it's covered in soot, despite being clean. Fearghas receives advice to "bind the Halfling with that". He examines the chain with great interest. I am definitely uneasy. Fearghas? We are friends yes? We're at least allies?

Fearghas casts Detect Magic on the chain; it is non-magical. He knows that it inhibits magic, but does not understand exactly how, yet. Fearghas leads us into an alley out of sight, and casts Mordenkainen's Magnificient Mansion. It is an impressive dwarven mansion, with a cohort of servants that look like clockwork constructs resembling dwarves. Fearghas formally welcomes us in, and Shalkoc makes a beeline for the larder that is bursting with ingredients. Emilio and I are confused as to how anyone can casually cast a spell of such proportions. He's not wearing spellwards! Let alone taking them off!

One of the rooms is a "hall of grudges". A dwarven thing, Fearghas says. Don't worry about it. There are three categories in the hall, alphabetically ordered: A, G, and P. I wonder what is written in there… We start discussing magic and its various origins. Emilio says his magic was forced upon him, he is not comfortable with explaining. Fearghas says that wild magic surges did not always happen, that they appeared a long time ago, from the Feywild "bleeding" into the material plane. He also says that infusing spells into gems can bypass the wildness of magic.

Fearghas is still curious about the null-steel chains, and asks Emilio to bind his wrists with the chain. On the point of touching the chain, Emilio recoils and takes a few steps back. I offer assistance, but Emilio declines. Fearghas asks Shalkoc to bind him instead. It's a cold burn on his skin, and he grows tired and unfocused. He is not comfortable. Shalkoc winds the chain around his wrists, and does not seem to mind the cold touch.

I agree to have the chain put on me… for science. It's a little bit like my spellwards, just a million times more intense. Familiar, if uncomfortable. As I examine the chain I realise… the one dark spot on one of my bracelets is the exact same colour as the chain. I freeze, mind racing. Shalkoc and Fearghas kindly ask if I'm okay, but I start stammering that I need to know HOW these chains are made. I can't stop myself from shaking and praying that my suspicions aren't true. Concerned, Fearghas suggests that we look into it right now. I agree, trying very hard to keep my emotions together and mostly failing. We go back to Ukgluz in a hurry to figure this out.

We go to the market looking for a smithy. Looks like the Duergar eat a lot of fish from the many many lakes in the Underdark. A Duergar comes up to Fearghas wanting to buy Emilio. Fearghas politely declines. Emilio looks even more grumpy than usual, especially as the Duergar insists… Fearghas asks how the null-steel chains are made. The Duergar says they are regular steel chains, that are brought up to the priests in the temple, and the chains come out soot black and much stronger. I do not like where this is going…

Fearghas casts Discord call Rary's Telepathic Bond so we can communicate discreetely. I am questioned about my suspicions regarding the null-steel chains, and I reluctantly admit that I suspect the Duergar are using the blood of angels. I show my stained spellward to support my claim. Fearghas is intrigued, and Shalkoc assumes I have killed an angel. I can't find any words in response to that… Emilio wants to ask around about more voidborn, or another void portal. A frightening perspective. I wish our big and strong harpy was with us.

Shalkoc suddenly… claims that "we are working on it". Zariel just contacted him and asked how they are doing. He winks at me. I am so confused. He shares Zariel's messages with us, demanding to know Shalkoc's progress on their contract, and details. Shalkoc claims he met someone who kills angels. He means me. Now Zariel wants to meet this "angel-slayer" within a week. It's not a question, it's an order.

At the party's prompting, I confess that I killed an angel. I was trying to help, I did not mean to. Emilio tries to cheer me up, with little success. Fearghas says that we can't blame ourselves for circumstances outside of our control. If only their words could make the nightmares end… I clutch my staff to remind myself that even a stained soul can be forgiven. It will not make the nightmares end. Shalkoc just takes it in stride that I am an angel-slayer, and we can keep Zariel waiting before sending me to Hell to meet her.

We go browse herbs for Shalkoc who is looking for seasoning. Fearghas grimaces as we walk into a shop (something about "a bunch of snake oil"). The shopkeeper is doubtful about letting slaves in, but Fearghas insists. The lady shows us a very dubious brown mould… which I'm sure is some kind of body part… very much not fresh… She offers to let Fearghas sniff it. Shalkoc is enthusiastic and speaks up about wanting to smell it. Out loud. The shopkeeper is SHOOKETH at the lack of control Fearghas has over his slave… She then opens the glass right under Fearghas' nose. He downplays the absolute reek of the stuff with all the dwarven sturdiness he can muster.

I recognise glowworm root, that wriggles and glows in contact with air. It's edible and nutritious, if not pleasant. There is also a fungus called barrelstalk… drinkable, as they store a lot of water, but they taste like very stale, very mushroomy flavour. On Emilio's behalf, Fearghas asks the shopkeeper if she has seen any unusual creatures when she was out gathering plants. She claims some larva-like creatures near a nearby lake have been unusually large. Fearghas enquires about the deeprot (the brown mould) and its uses. He buys a portion for 15 gold, and she saws off a piece of the growth, scrapes up the mould, and hands it to our alchemist. She claims it's great for freeing up clogged sinuses. I am doubtful.

Fearghas mentions he is an alchemist and the shopkeeper begins to stammer. She was scamming us was she not… She says she has to close down the shop now. The apothecary very nervously closes down her shop. She did mention that the miners use the deeprot, and also the priests. We walk to the lake some miles away. It's relatively peaceful, for the Underdark. The water is very still, and on the shores grow bioluminescent lichen. As we walk up to the nearby shore, we smell something disgusting. The plants on the shore look mutated, leaves growing out of other leaves like cancerous growth.

We find the larvae mentioned by the apothecary. They are massive, and also mutated, growing into one another in a chaotic and twisted manner. Fearghas says there is something "fucked up" here for sure. Emilio doesn't sense anything void-y. Shalkoc argues that the larvae must be full of protein. Fearghas absolutely vetoes the idea and investigates, finding a faint trace of transmutation magic in the mutated things. It seems to be coming from under the lake. Fearghas hands out potions of water breathing. I can't swim, so Fearghas says "take my hand". We all drink our potions and jump into pitch-black water.

We lose all sense of up or down in the absolute darkness. Emilio seems to be able to see… just fine? For the rest of us, the colours are gone, so he updates us on the fish's weird colours. The fish are looking at us weirdly, some with all three of their eyes. We swim deeper down, pressure building on my ears the only indication that we are farther from the surface. In the distance, a bright light flickers. Fearghas is guiding us towards the source of the transmutation magic he sensed. We can't really gauge direction or distance from the light source. Is it moving? We can't tell…

We approach carefully, all too aware of the tactics of anglerfish. Emilio spots first the tips of multiple spikes, unevenly spaced, rising from below us. He says they look like quills, like they are part of something bigger. As we come closer, it's a full forest of them, about half a metre in diameter, growing to a very sharp point. D-do they look like needle-sharp teeth…? The light source we saw from afar is actually a tiny fish swimming in a circle, with a luminous growth on its head.

We give the glowing fish a wide berth, and swim on downwards. Emilio glimpses something moving in between the big spikes. I finally remember to use magic to enhance my vision. Out of the corner of my eye, I spot the end of a tentacle between the spikes, retreating out of sight. I stammer "k-k-krakeeen!!" in the telepathic bond, which seems to amuse Fearghas and Shalkoc. We spot a flat white surface below us; as we grow deeper, we see it's a brine pool. We swim closer to it but stop short of it, oh goddess I hope we survive this.

We spot more spikes, these looking more metallic and a bit rusty. These spikes are not attached to, but sticking through a surface… around the spikes is scar tissue… very old scar tissue, wounds that have healed and re-opened over and over again for years. I imagine this wall of scars in front of us is an ancient creature, and a very large creature that has been suffering for longer than I can imagine. We pick a direction at random and follow the wall, hoping to find a head or a tail. Fearghas swims down into the brine pool, promising to go back up immediately.

He swims back up a good 30 feet away from where he dove. There is a current in there. We follow the direction of the current with the idea that one person dives into the brine pool now and again, tied to a rope so we don't lose them. We figure out the rough shape of an immense flattened blobfish. At the edge of the brine pool, the skin of the creature becomes flat and glassy, a giant eye mostly immerged in the brine pool. The eye is so huge we cannot see it all. Multiple spikes are piercing the eye… we can see into it, the needles pierce all the way through. The outside wounds have closed, but on the inside, the wounds are a lot worse. We could squeeze along that spike into the body of that thing… there seems to be light inside.

I tell the party about what I think is torturing the creature. Sibriex. I show them my memories of an angel endlessly tortured. Clinging to sanity, I tell them that this is my problem, that I cannot let this demon live. We decide to go into the creature and attempt to end its suffering. As we are about to go in, the giant fish begins to shake as if in pain… This creature is alive, and it's being tortured. As it moves, the spikes tears bigger wounds in the tissue surrounding them. Shalkoc is leading, and squeezes through the opening with a squelching sound, and he disappears from sight.

A chilling thought occurs to me then. What if it was not a creature being tortured? Not a fish pierced by spikes but something that was never an animal in the first place. What if this was a space shaped by a demon? A Sibriex' lair.

pages.name: 73 - Summary - A strong neck can rule a nation
pages.content:
Shalkoc flies away from the Duergar with Aviana in the iron flask. She is not happy about this, and when they meet up with us in the tunnel, she tries to strangle Plex, and both disappear to the Feywild. Again. We set up camp in the tunnel with the use of magic and grilled sausages.

We return to Ukgluz where many soldiers have been wounded in capturing the Leshen. Fearghas obtains an audience with King Dimzad, who is surprised to see him return alive, but more friendly than last time, and very forthcoming with (unwanted) advice on how to handle his slaves (that's us). There are some casual mentions of how to bind demons (shudder), and the "demon engines" the Duergar are using. This definitely is just an edgy name of no actual significance. Has to be. Right?

Fearghas requests a day of preparation before going to war with Matron Vandree. Dimzad agrees, and gifts to Fearghas a null-steel chain to better control his slaves. Fearghas invites us to his beautiful 7th-level mansion, and we have tea and investigate the null-steel chain. Emilio is particularly bothered by it. For Fearghas and I, it uncomfortably inhibits magic... and the chain's colour sends me into a panic as I suspect it's been made using the blood of angels.

Don't ask me how I know.

They ask me how I know.

Shalkoc assumes I have killed an angel.

Words fail me, surely this will have no consequences.

The party agrees to investigate the process of making the chains. We return to Ukgluz, ask around, learn that the chains are regular steel which are then treated in secret by priests, and no one is allowed in to see the process. Oh. No. Somewhere on the way, Shalkoc gets a ~~Discord ping~~ Message from Zariel checking in on his progress. Shalkoc replies that he has found an angel-slayer (HE MEANS ME) and Zariel orders him to present this person to her before the end of the week. Well this escalated quickly.

We can't figure out a way to spy on the priests yet, so we go to an apothecary for Shalkoc's needs of tasty herbs. We ask the apothecary if she has seen any unusual creatures, as Emilio insists the voidborn will return.

The Duergar just love to tell people how to handle their slaves. The apothecary scams us with foul-smelling "mould" (I'm convinced she chopped that off a rotting corpse somewhere) and mentions larvae larger than usual by a nearby lake. Fearghas freaks her out by saying he is an alchemist, and we walk to the lake.

Nature is twisted here, plants and larvae mutated, but Emilio doesn't sense the touch of the void. It reminds me too much of a certain demon and I grow increasingly anxious. Fearghas detects transmutation magic coming from inside the lake. We chug potions of water breathing, and jump in.

After a good half-hour of nerve-wracking swimming in darkness, and glimpsing tentacles among sharp pillars, we reach a brine pool and a fleshy wall pierced with long metal spikes. It looks like a huge, ancient creature being tortured. Reluctantly, I tell the party about the Sibriex lair I was in. I give them as much information as I can, including telepathic images of half-organic corridors and twisted creatures, but my courage fails me at the end.

We follow a current to a giant eye, also pierced with spikes. We can squeeze in... we don't talk very long before deciding to go in. The party is intrigued, but my conscience will not let me walk away. This thing is so close to a city full of people... slavers, yes, but people nonetheless.

Wait... the Duergar use "demon engines"? What if this big creature was *not* a giant tortured fish? What if the close proximity with Ukgluz is deliberate? I am filled with dread at the strong suspicion that we are... intruding into the lair of a Sibriex... that is *working with* the Duergar.

pages.name: 74 - AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA
pages.content:
As Shalkoc disappears inside the Sibriex lair (?), Emilio turns around and sees Aviana appear, with one hand around Plex' neck and the other hand holding… a screaming goat, making a lot of bubbles. Shalkoc sticks his head through the opening at the base of the spike, and signals that the inside is dry. We follow him in. Aviana asks about the goat, arguing that it was going to be a sacrifice. Fearghas rolls his eyes, and promptly roasts the goat with a Fire Bolt; "we don't have time for another goat." He pushes me through the opening; I collide into Shalkoc who smelled the roasted goat and wonders what is cooking.

We eventually all slip through the opening, in the residual smell of soggy goat curry. The tunnel we are in is damp, uncomfortably warm, walls glistening and pulsating. It smells like a constitution save… we hold our noses in disgust, but Plex and Emilio don't look so good. We hear an androgynous, gentle and caring voice in our minds telling us: I felt your arrival, like soft whispers in the æther. Fear not the crossing; you are safe now within this hallowed realm. Emilio is very angry at this. Something about enough voices in his head…? I tell the party to not trust it, that the demon is trying to get us to let our guard down. Fearghas agrees, and hands me a vial of silvery powder… He does not say what it is, only urges me to consume it as he hands a similar one to Emilio.

Aviana explains that Plex acquired a goat hat, and the curry goat that Fearghas murdered. She also says that she and Plex could not save the kittens in the Feywild from the red caps, and that we have to return there to save the kittens. Fearghas hands the null-steel chain to Aviana, who goes on a tirade about king and why we should all settle for bondage instead. Plex pulls out his thinking cap, a Headband of Intellect in the shape of a goat. Aviana grabs the headband with the plan to reforge it into thinking glasses.

Fearghas asks me whether the Sibriex has mental powers. I say yes, though I can't be entirely certain. He uses a spellgem of Mind Blank on Aviana. Plex no longer detects her with Detect Thoughts. She is no longer a thinking creature as far as his spell is concerned… He then recasts Rary's Telepathic Bond to include Aviana and Plex into the connection. Plex casts Fey Step, ignoring Fearghas' warning against teleporting in here… He takes a step up… and thinks to us that there are enemies next to him. We can't see or hear him. I summon my Umbral Spirit, Fade, and tell her to find the goblin. I also heal Emilio to cure the poisoning incurred when he stepped into the lair.

Aviana steps up to me and says proudly "Look! I can do magic too!" She says some gibberish words, then casts Death Ward on me! Fearghas is incredibly proud. Plex is being attacked by humanoid creatures that… look like they used to be people. Some bits swapped, a messed up jaw, and psionic shullbit. Fearghas considers breaking through a wall to get to Plex, then evaluates the thickness of the wall, and reconsiders. He sees something up ahead, and is in turn seen by it too. It's a swarm of maggots, and something invisible. I miss my mum and dad…

Shalkoc runs past Fearghas into the left branch of the tunnel. He sneezes on the swarm of maggots, like only a Dragonborn can, burning them all like popcorn. Delicious… Something lashes back at him, and he is stunned. Fade runs down the tunnel, attracting unwanted attention. She does not find Plex, and blends into the shadows, turning invisible. Plex casts Ashardalon's Stride to unleash fire on the maggots, but a wild magic surge turns him tiny. He picks up popped, not burnt, maggots.

Aviana congratulates Emilio on being the most sensible, least aggressive member of this party. Plex glimpses an honest-to-gods ABOMINATION, bloated with a second head that is nothing but a gaping maw. I very frighteningly sidle close but not too close to a big lump of wall-flesh… Bits of it seems to be chewing… I don't want to know on what… I inhale the silvery powder Fearghas gave me, trying all the while to look everywhere at once. Aviana chugs a potion of growth and becomes big again.

Fade is hit by a psychic ray from a Walleye, but the charm has no effect. Plex is getting attacked by something bitey but he's so small he dodges… once. On the second bite, he is swallowed by the Bloater. Plex uses his gift of the Gem Dragon to push it back, inflicting minor damage. He is still inside the thing, swimming in stomach acid. Fade runs back to where I was to report, as I don't share her senses… but I do feel what Plex is feeling and it's not fun.

Plex blasts the Bloater from the inside with his magic, hard enough to be spit out. Emilio buffs himself somewhat uselessly, but who knows what the future may bring? He joins Shalkoc by a pile of dead maggots. The Bloater dashes towards Aviana, this waddling thing as big as Aviana. It's aptly named… it's so full of fluid, the skin is tight and it makes sloshing sounds. Disgusted, I focus my magic at it and fire a Guiding Bolt! It hits real hard, and I leave Aviana to deal with it as I join Shalkoc, Emilio, and Fearghas. The latter is grumbling at something and flailing with his axe. A wild magic surge makes him explode-y.

Aviana is highly disgusted by the Bloater and dreads getting vomit on her new dress. She enters rage and slashes at the Bloater with her talons, tearing it open. Fluids spill all over her. She is deeply disgusted. I don't blame her. Plex is considering the benefits of being eaten again, even though he is already in a rough shape after the first time he was snacked on. He is bitten by the second Bloater, swallowed again, and uses a MYTHIC FEATURE to convince himSELF that he is not blinded in there. I'm screaming in the telepathic bond because I feel his wounds, and he will die if he is exposed to the stomach acid again. He beholds the wonders of the inside of the Bloater's stomach with eyes open. If we did not need the telepathic bond for a petty thing like SURVIVAL, I would nope out.

Fearghas enquires on the state of the Bloater. Aviana says it's probably almost dead; I squeak that it is still very much moving despite leaking fluids everywhere. Fearghas sends a barrage of Magic Missiles towards it. This is how he figures out that there are two of them; because Plex is broadcasting the inside of a Bloater through the telepathic link, and no impacts happen. Shalkoc is punching another monster (the one with a very altered jaw; Obscuroth). As he kills it, Shalkoc hears a voice in his mind again. Almost motherly, it says: I sense your confusion, and it is alright. Many souls arrive still carrying the shadows of conflict. But that creature… it was just another soul, like you, perhaps a little lost in its own way. Let us try a gentler path to understanding. When he shares the message into the telepathic bond, I feel sick… and increasingly angry.

Fade runs towards the slashed Bloater and leaps out of the shadows to bite it, before fading into the darkness once more. Plex barely survives being digested by using his Abjurer's Bangle. He throws an immovable spear into the Bloater's stomach, then gets out by using Fey Step. Emilio blasts maggots and another invisible Obscuroth. He then also hears something in his mind and shares it to us: Please, children, there is no need for such harshness in this place of healing. Let understanding be your weapon, not violence. Healing?! I'm going to MURDER this thing! Emilio blasts the Obscuroth all the harder; it responds with a Psionic Rebuke, but Emilio saves.

I slap a Chill Touch on the Bloater, but it's not enough to kill it. I back off just before Aviana slashes it again; it collapses and explodes in a burst of acid. Aviana goes down the right-hand tunnel and finds… a cloud of magical darkness. She decides to CHARGE INTO IT. She hits a flesh wall, and attacks the darkness. A Walleye spots her, and fires a Psychic Ray at her. She resists the charming, and continues into the darkness. Plex is calling out in the telepathic bond… none of us knows where he is. I'm sticking with my friends and letting Fade scout.

One of the Obscuroths attacks Emilio, breaking invisibility. He reacts with a Hellish Rebuke, frying it where it stands. Shalkoc… catches… a Psychic Ray… and tries to slap a Bloater, to no avail. He dashes, slaps again, but his hand only meets a wall with a disappointing wet sound. Fade takes some acid damage, shakes herself to get rid of the acid, and runs up almost to Aviana. There is a Walleye there, it casts Darkness, nobody can see Aviana anymore. There is also an Obscuroth there, but Aviana scares the wits out of it. That's how we figure out it still had wits of a sort. Knowing that does not help in the slightest, because it indicates that there is maybe a person enduring in the monsters…

Plex casts Maelstrom, trapping Shalkoc in it while the Bloater escapes the spell almost unscathed… The Dragonborn exclaims "What the hell? I'm coming to save you!" I call out to Plex and try to find him, but in my haste I run right into the line of sight of a Walleye… The Psychic Ray hurts, but I resist the charm. I asked Emilio to stay close to me, he confirms he will follow. Aviana shouts out to me, but she is not in the telepathic bond and I'm too far to hear. She swaps her Spirit Beast's Blessing to Tiger. She pokes a Walleye, then grabs it. She jabs her thumbnail into the eye, making it lose concentration. The darkness disappears but Aviana still can't see a thing.

Another Psychic Ray shoots out of the wall; I ignore the pain, barely keeping concentration, and resist the charm with all my might. Fearghas tries to find Aviana; why did we split up agaaaaaain?! He blasts an Obscuroth with a Ray of Frost, then laughs at it magically. "You've got a face like a burst kebab!" He says, dealing psychic damage. Shalkoc takes damage from Plex' Maelstrom. We take care of one another in this party… Shalkoc delivers a bonk on the Bloater with enough force to stun it, then punches it a lot more for good measure.

Fearghas points out an enemy for Fade. She crits her bite, but doesn't manage to kill it, and fades (haha) into the shadows again. The invisible monster hits her hard in response; she is very close to dissolving into darkness. Plex drinks one repulsive potion to heal himself (it's snot), then casts Sapping Sting on the Bloater. I step right up to the edge of the Maelstrom and throw my +2 dagger at the Bloater. It hits! The monster still stands, barely. Aviana squeezes the Walleye she is grappling, piercing it with her talons. It's still not dead, so she jumps in place, causing one massive blast from her Thunderfeet Footwraps. It hits her too, and she yanks the eyeball out of the wall.

Fearghas once more laughs at the invisible Obscuroth, which barely fails to kill it. "Naami, your cat's got this," he says and walks away. He finds Aviana, who chucks him the eye she ripped from the wall. Shalkoc is still unable to escape Plex' spell. This is getting embarrassing… Shalkoc goes into the centre of the Maelstrom to punch the Bloater to death. It explodes, but Shalkoc dodges the acid blast. Turns out, Fade hasn't got this. Her bite misses, and the Obscuroth kills her. My poor Fade dissolves into dark mist.

Emilio launches three blasts against the Walleye that'd been hitting me every turn, but it reflects one of them onto me. It hurts… but I can finally see Plex! Heedless of the cost, I extend a hand towards him… the magic takes my blood to fuel a healing spell. I don't care. Plex' wounds are healed, and a voice speaks in my head: Such selfless acts are the very essence of Nirvana. You bring joy to this tranquil place with your innate kindness. You understand already. I am livid… but suspicion begins to sneak in. Is this the demon speaking, or is it something worse?

Aviana runs past me, and attracts the attention of the Walleye. Emilio asks me for permission, but he won't say what for. I yell at him that this is not a time to keep secrets. Fearghas backs me up, but Emilio refuses to speak. I'm very upset with everyone except Fearghas. Emilio is hit by the Walleye, and reacts with a Hellish Rebuke. Aviana hears something come towards us… something huge, stomping with meaty sounds. Emilio stammers that it's bigger than Aviana. The monster (Major Malleable) grabs her; she calls Shalkoc to come help. Plex casts a spell of Detect Thoughts to try to locate the enemy, but the range is too short. Plex is eating the maggots again… he convulses, and collapses, unconscious. Uncontrolled terror blinds me for a second, my mind flooded in memories and overwhelming dread. Do I even dare healing him? What if…

Emilio blasts the Major. I run to Plex and examine him… he is afflicted by a form of madness that will last 8 minutes. A spell of Calm Emotions or Lesser Restorations can cure this! Just as I figure this out, a spellgem begins to glow in Plex' pocket, reanimating him. I yell at him as Aviana dares him to eat another maggot. I heal some of my own wounds, but my magic feels weak, my hands are shaking. I don't think using healing magic on Plex would have harmed him… but the dread that overwhelmed my mind for a moment is not entirely gone. It will get worse. I need to get a grip.

Aviana flexes and makes her cloak billow. Only Emilio sees this because of the magical darkness. She grabs the Major and drags it out of the darkness. She jumps with it, landing in a blast of thunder. That monster is not only huge… it's amorphous, with organs that don't belong in their places… I've seen the like before… I have seen… I see Aviana's wounds, and all my fear returns in a rush as the Major attacks her and grapples her. Half of her wounds would kill me.

Fearghas chugs a Potion of Maximum Power, and casts Scorching Ray. Three powerful rays of flame hit the Major. Shalkoc repeatedly punches the Major, and realises it is completely immune to acid damage. Plex casts a level 7 Tether Essence on Shalkoc and Aviana. They willingly fail the save, letting the spell take effect. Emilio pummels the Major with three blasts, exploding in purple clouds. The misshapen creature collapses and dies.

Finally, the chaos ends… for now. Fearghas begins to cast Leomund's Tiny Hut as a ritual… and the voice speaks up in our heads again: Yes, pause and breathe in the tranquility, dear ones. The transition from the River to the boundless peace of Nirvana can be… intense. Rest is a balm, and I am here to offer comfort and guidance. Fearghas grumbles that this demon is weird. Aviana casts Find Traps and says that the walls are traps, the floor is a trap, the ceiling is a trap… everything around us is a trap of confusion, disorientation, madness, acid, suffocation, poison, infestation with maggots, exhaustion, blindness, and losing the ability to escape.

Aviana requests Plex to bite her. I draw my dagger and threaten her with it, telling her to sit still and let me heal her. The voice tells us: Please, try to be calm. Such reactions are echoes from the world you left behind. Here, in Nirvana, all spirits are to be cherished and guided with kindness. I snarl at it to shut up. Shalkoc casts Cure Wounds on Aviana, which pleases the voice. Plex bites Aviana. Fearghas starts violently scolding Aviana and Plex, with good reason.

We attempt a short rest, and heal up. Fearghas pulls out his void explorer spellbook. Emilio glares at it for a second; his hands twitch and he struggles for a moment, then transforms into his Void Form. The white of his eyes go black and the bandages on his hands burst open, revealing wicked claws. Eldritch energies spark around his claws. Plex freaks out and pushes Emilio away and out of the bubble with his telekinesis, knocking him prone in the bargain. We question him, but he growls that this is his real form, and there are more important matters to take care of.

As Emilio is thrown out of the hut, he sees that the hallway behind us… looks nothing like it used to. Shalkoc begins to cook an eyeball cake for Aviana, with very little concern. Our wizards figure out that teleportation and planar travel do not work here. We're trapped.

As we settle down to rest, the voice speaks again: Rest now, little spirits, you've just navigated the currents of the River of Souls. It's not uncommon to feel a little bewildered upon arrival. All is well here. I am convinced now that this is not the demon speaking, but a celestial from Nirvana. While we sit and rest, the magical darkness moves towards us. The celestial (?) speaks about the light of dawn as the darkness is coming closer.

pages.name: 74.1 A Healer's Edge
pages.content:
Emilio's white hair seemed to glow in the dimness, a patch of clean snow on a backdrop of reddish hell. He raised his bandaged hand as if to curse the twisted creature that had Aviana in a chokehold; three bursts of energy leapt from his fingers and exploded on the mass of bulging flesh and organs. Clouds of purple smoke erupted, and the creature shuddered and collapsed, remaining still. It did not look like it had ever been alive, or even moving. It looked like a tangle of surgical mistakes, or insane experiments. It looked like madness clad in flesh, a chunk that had been torn off from this place. Aviana, finally free, began to argue with Plex. Naami started towards her, unable to look away from the wounds covering the harpy from talons to wingtips.

"I'll give us a semblance of safety so we can recuperate," Fearghas grumbled.

Spellbook in hand, he began to mutter and trace sigils into the air, raising a familiar barrier around the party. Just then, the voice spoke into their heads again: Yes, pause and breathe in the tranquillity, dear ones. The transition from the River to the boundless peace of Nirvana can be… intense. Rest is a balm, and I am here to offer comfort and guidance.

"That demon's weird," the dwarf said once the protective bubble was complete.

"Let me cast a spell of trap detection," Aviana said, frowning in concentration. "Ah, I see! The walls are traps. The floors are traps, and the ceiling is a trap, too. Now the danger of these traps is… are… confusion and disorientation, madness, acid, suffocation… errrm… poison, infestation with maggots, also exhausting, blindness… and losing the ability to escape. Well. Plex, can you bite me?"

Naami stared, her argument forgotten. Aviana the unbreakable harpy was bleeding and bruised, covered in acid burns, and she wanted to be bitten on top of it? Plex, who had been shrunk to the size of a rat by a wild magic surge, started to argue that he was too small to have a chance to even break the skin. Likely he still would be, even at his normal size. Plex, who had teleported away the moment we arrived here, willingly, and nearly got himself eaten, digested, and killed, in any order. Twice. Plex, whom Naami had healed at the cost of her own blood. She had been so relieved to see him alive, her control on magic had slipped, and she had transferred her life force to him, closing all his wounds. Plex was nonchalantly agreeing to more violence, only discussing the logistics of it, as Aviana was urging him to hit her.

In the madness of the situation, Naami's fear flashed to anger. She wished she could brush off her actions as consequences of emotion, as losing control of herself; a form of madness maybe. That would be a lie. She deliberately drew her sharp dagger. She decided to stalk to Aviana and point that dagger at her. Oh, she was much too small to threaten the harpy, grown to a huge size by alchemy. But a threat needed not be made on a person's life, and some wounds were worse than death. Naami angled her blade at Aviana's heels, where a small cut would be as severing her feet from her legs. She could heal a snapped tendon, though it would cost her.

"Aviana, you sit still now and let me heal those wounds, or I promise I will make you."

Just then, Plex worked out how to hit Aviana, and followed through with it, whacking her with his staff. She did not flinch, and Naami was past paying attention to it, but that did not stop Aviana from requesting Naami stab her with the dagger she had just threatened her with.

Before she could reply, the gentle voice spoke in Naami's mind; Please, try to be calm. Such reactions are echoes from the world you left behind. Here, in Nirvana, all spirits are to be cherished and guided with kindness.

"Shut up!" the Halfling snarled.

At the party's confusion, she shared the message telepathically, shaking in anger. That demon! How dare it! She fought to stoke her anger and keep it burning. She had to be furious, because fear was encroaching on the edges of her anger. She could not let her suspicions take form. Oh goddess, these were an angel's words. A demon would not know or care about the River of Souls, or Nirvana. It was an angel's voice. Not again, please, not again. Naami realised she was shaking too much to treat her friend's wounds. Shalkoc stepped in next to her, and with a gentle nod to Naami, cast a healing spell on Aviana. The wordless help brought her close to tears.

The voice spoke in reply to Shalkoc's spell: How wonderful! Your spirit already resonates with the compassion that flows through Nirvana. Such kindness is a true sign of your innate goodness.

"Oh, thank you," Shalkoc says. "We could be friends!"

Aviana agreed, but Fearghas snapped at Aviana, Shalkoc, and Plex.

"Have you three not been paying attention? You've been running amok since we arrived here, teleporting all over the place. We are fighting for our lives here! That thing is a demon! It is not a friend! It warps the very bodies and minds of its prey. Naami told you what it does, and look how traumatised she is! No one is going to hit you any more, Aviana. We need you in fighting shape."

"But my spirit is all down, I need someone to slap some sense into me. Someone weak, not you Shalkoc, your punches hit like a boulder."

Fearghas rubbed his temples with deliberate slowness. Emilio stared in utter confusion as Aviana continued to argue that it was truly a power she possessed, although she did not understand how it worked. With a carefully blank expression, Fearghas handed out healing potions, which seemed to finally stop this madness. The insanity only continued in the shape of the voice congratulating Aviana and Plex on a friendly trade of copper coins for a bottle of what could only be bright green snot.

"Naami, out of curiosity," Fearghas said in a weary voice, "was the one you met before like this?"

"It wasn't… I've suspected for a while, this isn't the demon talking. It's too long a game for a demon to play… they don't act like that."

"So that demon took control of a celestial?" Emilio said.

"Or worse," Naami said, shaking.

She tried to drown her fear in familiar motions, applying healing salve to Aviana's wounds and to her own. It was not as good as magic but… her magic, her life force, was limited. She had to hold onto it for when there would be no time for slower forms of healing. As she worked, the emotions faded to the background, her attention fully on the motions of her fingers, but there was only so much salve she could apply to any wound. The thoughts came back the moment she was done, and this time she was powerless to silence them.

"It's really an angel," Naami said, her voice distant in her ears. "It's trapped here, and deceived."

Summoned by the words, memories came rushing back into her mind. Her hands rose unbidden to her head, tangling into her hair. She tried to close her eyes, but it was worse. Opening them to the same nightmare that haunted her made her want to scream. She only managed a whimper. "Not again, not again, not again…" Seeming to materialise out of the shadows, Emilio appeared beside her. His voice sank into a soft whisper, unlike even the reserved personality he had shown until now. Despite a splinter of cold in his voice, it was reassuring.

"Don't let them get you," he said. "You are who you are, no matter what."

His eyes were drawn to movement in front of him, as Fearghas pulled a heavy tome from his pack. Complex patterns on the covers were shifting, and the entire book seemed to hum. Naami looked up to see Fearghas calmly skimming through the book, its pages covered in a tight script alternating with maps that seemed to move as she tilted her head. Star charts? She had used them before, to gather herbs during the right phases of the moon, but the charts she had seen did not twist and change under her eyes…

Next to her, Emilio went stiff as a statue, glaring at the spellbook in the dwarf's hands. His bandaged hands twitched, he seemed to shudder, and… he changed. Darkness like ink spilled into the white of his eyes, leaving the purple irises glowing in a sea of blackness. The bandages burst, revealing wicked claws set with a glowing purple gem like an eye, wrapped in crackling energy. With a squeak, the tiny Plex summoned his telekinesis and shoved Emilio out of the protection of Fearghas' spell.

"What in the nine hells?" Fearghas exclaimed. "Emilio, what happened to you?"

"Nothing. This is my true form." Emilio's voice had a rough, cold edge.

"Was this the secret you were keeping from us?" Naami said, face pale.

"Maybe it was."

"What are you?" She cried.

"I think we have more urgent matters to deal with," the warlock growled.

An awkward silence stretched before Fearghas admitted, reluctantly, that he was right. Unfazed, Shalkoc offered to cook some food for Aviana, who immediately asked for a spicy snack. At the utter lack of concern from his friends, Fearghas beckoned Emilio back into the protective bubble.

"We need to make sure Emilio doesn't attack us, right?" Aviana said in the middle of discussing chilies with Shalkoc.

"If I wanted you dead, you would be," he said, his black and purple eyes showing no emotion. "Besides… we need to get rid of whatever is in control here, fast. The tunnels are already changing."

He pointed at the warped tunnel behind him, twisted into nothing like the place the party had entered from.

"T-that's what they do," Naami stammered. "They change the corridors… just like last time…"

"That's not all," Plex said. "My curse… is silent here."

Fearghas went very still. Naami felt the magic around him shift, just subtly, without forming a spell. The two wizards exchanged a look, then Fearghas spoke:

"Teleportation magic will not work here. Or planar travel."

"We're trapped here?" Naami squeaked.

"Well, we can't run away," Fearghas said.

With a sigh, the party settled down to rest. There was little else they could do, after all. Naami sat very gingerly on the repulsive floor, trying to avoid the pulsating parts. She found a patch that seemed less squishy and, doing her utmost to ignore the resemblance with scar tissue, sat cross-legged for just a moment. Her arms still stung from the rush of uncontrolled magic she had directed at Plex; borne on her fear for her friend, the magic had taken her blood as fuel to heal the goblin. Not a lot of thinking had been involved; she had been too far for a spell that was safe for her, and he had been too injured for a weaker spell. Healing… sometimes, healing also meant hurting. Absentmindedly, she drew her dagger, the sharper of the two she carried. The other dagger was forged with magic, but this one was simply of extraordinary quality. It had a long handle formed to fit her hand, and a single-edged blade ending in a sharp tip, an unusual form for a dagger. Oh, she could probably pick a lock or disable a trap with it, not that she knew much of such things, but she would be loath to use this fine a blade in such a crude fashion. The needle point, the razor edge, they were for cutting through skin and muscle. It would slice through tendons with ease, requiring little force as long as her fingers were deft enough to guide the blade to the weaker spots of her target's body. Naami's weapon was a dagger only by name; it was the only weapon a healer needed, a surgeon's blade. She had had it forged at great cost, worth every copper, and she would have paid more if that meant she had it sooner. Her eyes lingered over the perfect edge without seeing it. If only she had had it sooner.

She had been carried out of a snowstorm and into the relative warmth of an inn, the weak fire on the hearth seeming a blaze of the ninth hell to her frozen limbs. Thoughts slow with cold, she sat close to the flames, dimly remembering to move her toes and fingers. Feeling returned in the form of needles; she gritted her teeth and continued. The alternative did not bear thinking of. As if in answer to her thoughts, the door banged open, letting in howling wind and snow.

"Close that door, man!" Daman snapped at the newcomer.

"Healer!" the man cried, ignoring the door and Daman. "You have a healer?"

Before she knew it, Naami had pushed herself to her feet. Osten was at her side with a steadying hand.

"Easy, you still need rest," he murmured.

It warmed her heart, if not her flesh, but she could not stop herself.

"I am a healer," she said as she tottered to the man.

He gave her a dubious look, but desperation was stronger than doubt. Not awaiting the innkeeper's permission, he deposited his burden on a nearby table. Wrapped in rags and furs was a boy barely out of childhood, his eyes closed, frost clinging to his eyelashes.

"My son," the man sobbed. "We were caught in the blizzard. Frostbite. Please help him, and all I own is yours."

Naami shook her head; she had no need for such promises. She was who she was. Running her hands over the boy, she summoned weak magic to examine him. Having closed the door, Magnus joined her, brushing icicles from his beard. They soon reached the same conclusion.

"His life force is tainted," Magnus muttered.

"Disrupted," Naami agreed.

She said no more out loud, to not frighten the father any more than he was, but Magnus and her knew the boy's condition was severe. Naami gave instructions; Osten helped drag the table closer to the fire while Daman fetched a tub of water. He waved his fingers over it, heating it to boiling in a flash of magic. Gently, Naami and Magnus removed the boy's boots and several layers of wool socks. The right boot was torn at the front, the socks cold and damp. Naami took out some of her herbs, her heart sinking. Even before seeing the boy's blackened toes, she knew herbs would do no good.

She tried. With Magnus' help and his control over fire, his fine perception of life itself, she tried. She rubbed the boy's feet with a salve and bathed them in warm water. When it failed, she summoned her magic, carefully at first. She was all too aware of her trembling legs, of the cold still trapped under her own skin. Magnus' magic supported hers, a current of warmth and strength under her unsteady weaves. Osten had firmly dragged the boy's father to the side and was distracting him to the best of his ability. Naami was not listening, but her friend's strong voice helped settle her nerves. Daman sat on a stool like it was a throne, observing, keeping watch on the magic itself, a notepad resting on the table before him. Naami wove magic into a simple healing spell, one to invigorate the patient and restore blood flow. The spell sank into the boy's body, but the cold was stronger. She gathered her strength for a spell of higher power, ready to melt the cold within his flesh. Magnus' only hand brushed against her arm.

"That's too risky," he said in a whisper, glancing at the father. "There is still a flicker of life there, but the two last toes are dead."

With a start, Naami let go of her spell without completing it. Her friend was right. She should have known. She would have known, if she had not been so cold and so tired. The Halfling bit her lip hard, willing for the pain to restore her concentration. She could not afford to mess this up. The father's anxious, short replies to Osten's chatter intruded into her concentration. The boy's shallow breathing was suddenly louder to her ears. His eyelids trembled, then opened to reveal hazel eyes clouded with confusion.

"Where am I?" he said. "Where is Dad?"

"Your Da's right here, lad," Magnus said warmly. "You'll be able to talk to him in a bit. Just be a little patient."

"I can't feel my toes," the boy whined.

"I know it's very scary," Magnus said, "but we're gonna do our best to help."

The dwarf glanced at Naami. She made herself meet his eyes.

"You're right," she said, her words strangled. "It's too late."

Using magic would only poison his blood and kill him in minutes. The only hope for the boy's life was to cut off the dead flesh, and heal what still had a chance to be healed. Naami ignored the painful churning in her stomach; she had to think of the practical side. With Magnus' help, she thoroughly examined the boy. Only two of the toes on his right foot were beyond saving. Two toes, on a boy whose voice had not dropped yet… No. Only two toes. He could recover from this, if he survived the procedure.

"Osten, we're gonna need space," she said, voice void of emotion.

The knight understood the message, and began leading the father away to the rooms on the first floor. There were protests, the innkeeper got involved, and Naami ignored all of it. She prepared more herbs, salves to stop bleeding, salves to protect from infection, and one mix that would send anyone into a deathlike sleep. Her hands shook only a little as she prepared the mixture, and coaxed the boy to drink it. When he was lying senseless on the table, and she had clean cloth and bandages ready, Naami took a deep breath. Her dagger was plain, the blade nicked, but it would have to do. She hesitated, then also removed her spellwards. Magnus shot her a glare.

"If you use this magic, you'll die," he said.

"And if I don't, he will die."

The dwarf exhaled explosively, frustration turning to anger.

"I can't tell you what to do," he growled, "but have a care for your own life."

"I am! I can do this!"

Daman looked up from the notes he was taking, face blank.

"Magnus is right, Naami. Don't be reckless. You can't save everyone."

"I can't if I don't try," she said between clenched teeth. "And I'm not alone anyway. Magnus can use healing magic too."

"I can't heal death," he muttered.

"No one can," Daman snapped. "Sometimes there is nothing to do."

"But not now," Naami said softly, as if to herself. "Now there is still a chance for this family, so let me take it."

Daman shrugged and returned to his scribing. Magnus gave Naami a level look.

"You better be sure of yourself, lass. The only thing I'm really asking you is, don't make your friends sad. Don't break your family to save strangers."

"I won't."

"Then let's be about it," he sighed.

Naami completed the preparations; cleaning up as much as possible, and asking Magnus to prepare certain spells. She hardly needed to say what she wanted him to do; they had worked together for some time. She stalled as much as she dared, but the inevitable moment came when she held the point of her dagger on the boy's skin. She aimed at the joint between the bones, the weakest point. She let magic fill her mind to calm her nerves, then leaned on the dagger with all her weight.

The blade sank into flesh and remained stuck. Gritting her teeth, ignoring the boy's whining through the sleeping draught, she whacked the dagger's pommel. It took two more tries before it bit into the wood with a thud. Despite Magnus' magic, the bleeding was already severe. There was simply no time. She applied the blade to the second toe, trying to wish more strength into her arms. It took only two tries then, but the cuts were uneven, the edges mangled by the chipped blade. Dropping the dagger, she set to weaving a healing spell. There was so much blood. The boy's face grew bone-white, his whimpers fading into silence. Naami summoned more power into her spell, power to knit wounds and restore life force. In the urgency of the moment, she paid no mind to the flood of magic rushing through her. She only rarely took off her spellwards, and in a crisis she acted on instinct fuelled by training and habit. Her spell blossomed into a torrent of positive energy, closing the wounds in a heartbeat. The boy's breathing steadied, colour returned to his cheeks. Dimly, Naami heard Magnus curse in tones of awe. She knew what he must be seeing; she felt it, a tiny circle of life with power over death, between her and the child. Life flowed from her into him, and the cold in his flesh lost ground until it was gone. She knew that in a sense, she had taken the shadow of death from him, and settled it on her instead. She knew that, and all the light around her was swallowed in a tide of silent darkness.

Naami awoke to a lumpy mattress and scratchy blankets. When she tried to raise her head, the small room spun around her. Voices came from the corridor, one angry and the other soothing.

"… told her! The idiot! She hardly controls her magic without those bracelets, but she had to!"

"She had to, and you know it."

"She can die for all I care! Burn herself out with that magic!"

"You don't mean that, Magnus."

"Mean it! That's easy for you to say! You can't see the weaves. The sheer amount of power she pulled into herself… do you have any idea…?"

An uncomfortable silence. Then Osten replied, in a much quieter voice, "No, I don't. But she is alive, and so is the boy."

Boots thudded on the floor, then the door opened, letting the tall knight in.

"Naami." He rushed to her side and knelt by her bed. "How do you feel?"

"Like an idiot?" she said, the words refusing to come out quite right.

"I suppose you would," Osten chuckled. "Don't mind Magnus. He is only frightened for you. When you fainted, he panicked."

"He… is right," she said reluctantly. "It was foolish. Reckless. I was a fool."

"If you know it, that's a step in the right direction. Just make sure the next step follows suit."

She nodded, her thoughts sluggish. Osten told her that the boy was alive and well, that he would walk again, if with a cane or a prosthetic. The father had burst into tears and sworn before the gods to pay with all he owned, cradling his boy. Daman had wanted to accept before Osten stepped in. Naami stared at the ceiling, listening with one ear. Her hands hurt with the memory of cutting the boy's toes; she feared she would be sick. The frayed edges of the wounds haunted her mind. It had all worked out in the end, but only because she had put her own life in danger. She hoped there would never be another situation like this one. She knew it was foolish hope, a dangerous wish. What she needed was time to recover her strength, and right after that, a new dagger. A sharper one.

Sharp pain brought Naami's mind back to the present, to the nightmare she was trapped in. She looked down to a nicked finger, and a drop of red on her sharp dagger. She fought down the urge to giggle as she cleaned the small cut; she feared her laugh might escape her control and spin into a mad cackle. She hoped they would make it out alive. No. She hoped they would destroy that demon, and she hoped her hand would be the one to end it. Her staff spoke of forgiveness; she recalled the dawn of the day she had found it, and the soothing cooing of doves. Her crime was forgiven, but the stain on her soul refused to fade, enduring in nightmares and breathless moments of panic. Redemption, she thought, was not a one-time thing; it was a choice, and she wanted to make that choice as many times as she could.

She sheathed her blade, remembering with a shudder that she had threatened a friend with it. She could not lose her nerve again. Naami patiently put herself through the breathing exercises that were part of Ildic witches' training. Her mind strayed, but she brought it back to the task every time. It was not foolish to have hope. It was not! As long as she also expected the worst.

As in answer to her grim thought, the gentle voice spoke in everyone's minds: Rest now, little spirits, you've just navigated the currents of the River of Souls. It's not uncommon to feel a little bewildered upon arrival. All is well here. And as if on cue, the shining darkness crept closer.

pages.name: 75 - There are TOO MANY fluids!!
pages.content:
Fearghas crushes a gem of Mind Blank and smears the dust on my forehead. I am excluded from the telepathic bond, but immune to psychic damage, charmed, mind reading, and scrying spells. Shalkoc makes me a batch of… meat… cookies? Lacking in crunch, they are surprisingly tasty. I try to not wonder too much where the meat comes from. Plex pulls out a stash of Silver Tears and requests something in exchange for them, which makes Fearghas grumble. After trading with our goblin for cocaine, Fearghas casts Foresight on Shalkoc to give him the power of the Echo and advantage on pretty much everything. I give Aviana a root to eat and recover 21 HP. She claims I am the only one who cares about healing her, which is not only false but mildly pisses off Shalkoc (understandably).

Clouds of magical darkness drift past us. We're already completely lost in the maze of shifting corridors… We eventually gather our courage and leave the bubble. As we walked along a narrow hallway, then walked back, we found a wall. Then another wall as we turned around. The ground started to open up, a puddle of blood forming, sizzling like acid. Emilio and Fearghas start to feel unwell. The hallway in front of us opens up and the walls around us twist and shake with growing intensity. A cloud of darkness comes towards us! Just in time, Emilio warns us of a creature in the darkness, then says the wall blinked, removing one of the Walleyes.

Emilio goes ahead and describes a lake of blood to us in the darkness, and a big creature ahead. There is a snake-like creature in the pool, along with body parts and, below the surface, items like in a waste pool. We wonder if there is a stomach up ahead, I interject that this is not a real creature we are in. Emilio fires his three blasts into the darkness, and hits another Major Malleable. A snake made of guts slithers from the blood pool and up the wall. The Slithering Bowel (eat dirt, Aerelia) sprays digestive fluids at Emilio, he dodges most of it.

Aviana walks up to Emilio; the tunnels are barely wide enough for her. She casts Resistance on herself, then takes out the dented iron flask and holds it at the ready. One of the eyes on the wall glares at Emilio with such intensity that he is charmed. I heal him of his poison, then apply Piercing the Veil. Emilio turns to me and says that now he is not the only one cursed with knowledge. Shalkoc tries to blindly punch the Slithering Bowel, but misses, punches a hole into the wall that immediately closes itself. Another of those abominations spits a tooth at Shalkoc, who deflects it onto the other bowel. It spits another spray of digestive fluid at us. I am so disgusted I dodge it close to perfectly, but Plex on my shoulder is not so lucky and gets a whole drop on him.

Plex and Emilio are blinded by the acid. Emilio is hit by more acid, and dazed. Fearghas mumbles at the back, and then casts a Lightning Bolt, under my direction. His spell only grazes us harmlessly, but it hits two bowels and the Obscuroth from last time that we didn't chase. It was just chilling invisible at 1 HP. F in the chat. It appears as its corpse drops on the shore of the blood lake. Shalkoc is grabbed by something exceedingly fleshy and dragged into the acid pool. He managed "elp" before he got attacked by a Major Malleable.

The walls are spasming violently, tripping Emilio who was already blinded, charmed, and dazed. From the ground, he shoots three blasts at… Fearghas? They all miss, and Emilio shakes himself from his daze. He breaks free from the Walleye's charm too, but he is still lying prone. One of the slithering bowels spits acid at us, blinding Emilio and Plex all over again. Aviana works herself into a rage and steps into the darkness and grabs a bowel, at Emilio's urging to tear it apart (he is very sick of being blinded). She can't see through the darkness, and steps into the blood pool. She struggles out and climbs up on the wall, still squeezing the bowel, shouting to Shalkoc all the while.

Shalkoc gets hit by the Walleyes' psychic ray, but deflects it. He still gets charmed. I start towards Emilio to heal him, but as I do so, a wild magic surge surrounds me in magical darkness. I'm distracted and my spell comes out weak; the spasming walls trip me and I stumble next to the warlock. Plex falls off my shoulder squeaking. I grit my teeth and channel a Healing Word on Emilio, doing some actual healing this time, but ANOTHER wild magic surge makes me allergic to cloth. I am wearing cloth. My eyes are just streaming at my own dress, and the channelling fatigue hits hard.

Not my day.

Plex dodges the meat folds in the ground, and climbs back up on my shoulder. He casts, blindly, Ice Storm. Aviana dodges it, but the terrain is all slippery now. Shalkoc is charmed by the Walleye, but uses Stillness of Mind to remove it. And that's another surge, the next dog he sees in in fact, god. Anagrams, y'all. He is still being grappled by the Major Malleable in the acidic blood pool; as Fearghas puts it, "gently caressed by the meatball".

Fearghas is tripped by the spasming walls, jumps to his feet, and uses a spellgem of Dispel Magic to clear up the magical darkness around me. It's a big relief… although my dress still itches and makes my eyes water. Grappled by the malleable, Shalkoc is being drained of his spirit so hard that even his max HP would be reduced, but he uses a mythic power to resist it. Another cloud of magical darkness erupts from the Major Malleable, from the same wild magic surge I got a minute ago. Emilio is still prone but gets up at last. He is pissed off and goes into Void Form of his own accord. He stumbles into the icy area left by Plex, and fires Eldritch Blast on the Slithering Bowel. The latter wriggles free from Aviana's grapple and slithers away. Aviana smacks her talon down on it and crushes it before it can escape.

She calls out to Shalkoc, leaving one cloud of magical darkness and stepping into another one. Shalkoc calls for help, he is being grappled. She grabs the Major Malleable that is holding Shalkoc, and drags it, then jumps while holding it. "Shalkoc, do not resist," she says, as Shalkoc is dragged along, through the air, and takes heavy damage from the Cursed Thunderfeet when Aviana lands. The Walleye sees Aviana get too close, and becomes very uncomfortable. It casts Darkness.

I channel my summoning spell and call a powerful form of Fade to help in the battle. Emilio describes to Plex where the enemies are as he loads up a Gravity Fissure. Plex is no longer blinded, but he can't see through magical darkness like we do. I point Plex at the monsters like a gun. Aviana, Shalkoc, and the Walleye dodge, but both Major Malleables fail. Fade runs towards one of the Major Malleables, hunting by sound, and bites it hard, then becomes invisible. Shalkoc punches the Malleable to death and chugs a potion of speed. He vibrates out of the grapple and punches the other Malleable very hard, you might say critically so, then shifts to Turtle Stance and moves back, screaming he needs help.

Now that the Dragonborn is close, I see his injuries are critical! Just then, a Slithering Bowel spits acid from behind us, blinding me and Shalkoc. Plex dodges it somehow. Fearghas dodges the spasming walls with impressive agility. He puts on his Glasses of True Seeing, and chugs a potion of Maximum Power. The Malleable shuffles towards Shalkoc, stepping over my invisible Fade. It hits Shalkoc, who shields himself with his Protective Wings.

Emilio gets to the Malleable and starts tearing it apart with his claws. I only hear concerning slashing sounds… Aviana grabs the Walleye and squeezes it, then pushes her talons into it. She is pulling it out of the wall and almost has it out, but a bit at the back is still sticking. I wobble towards Shalkoc, blind but guided by Fearghas. Plex is shouting into my ear a lot of lines to the general effect of "let me at 'em!" He is distracting me and I step into the pool of acidic blood… Metal crunches under my feet. I cast Heal on Shalkoc, unseasoned because I am spending way too many resources already.

Plex chugs a Potion of Heroism. None of us like where this is going. Plex grimaces like he is ready to bite. Level 13 Wizard by the way. I hope he does not bite me… Fade shreds the Bowel with her teeth and knocks it prone, but doesn't manage to kill it. Shalkoc brutally slaps the Bowel, which attempts to slither away into a hole under the acid blood. Emilio slashes it on its way, killing it.

Fearghas' magic reaches to Aviana, ripping blood from her and crystallising it into three spikes that stab the Malleable to death, and pin the corpse against a nearby wall. Aviana says "hey the walls are helping us!". A mouth in the wall opens up and replies "No we're not.". I stare at Fearghas in shock. I climb onto the fleshy island in the middle of the blood pool to get out of the acid. Something revolting bursts under my hand, and Emilio lends me a steadying… errr… claw. The celestial speaks to us; I try to answer, but Emilio snaps at it.

Now that we can see again, we can distinguish what is at the bottom of the blood pool. Low-quality clothes and chains like that of the slaves in Ukgluz, some useless items… and a lot of coins. Some of the coins are too deep to pick up without diving, but Fearghas uses Mage Hand.We estimate that there are around 9700 gold coins in there! Aviana casts Find Traps, with the same result as before; everything is a trap.

The problem is time. How much time are we willing to sacrifice to fish out gold coins? There are other items in the blood pool, stuck in the crevices so someone will have to dive down to retrieve it. There is a silk robe embroidered in gold, untouched by the acid. There is also jewelry, potentially magical. Fearghas casts Guidance on Aviana, she casts Resistance on herself, and prepares to dive to retrieve anything of value (that isn't money). She spots a gold chain with an opal set inside, and a gold locket. The harpy dives in, pushes the flaps of meat aside and retrieves all three items, taking minimal damage in the process, as she is resistant to acid.

Emilio picks up the gold chain set with the fire opal, and Aviana takes the gold locket with a painted portrait inside, as well as the silk robe with gold embroidery. Emilio is mesmerised by the fire opal. We start walking, trying and failing to find our way. The tunnel shrinks, space is getting too tight for comfort… we can either let it squeeze us into a direction, or try to resist and stand our ground. Fearghas breaks a gem of Leomund's Tiny Hut, shielding us all within a dome of force. The walls begin to crush the dome; if we had tried to resist this, we would probably have suffocated. The bubble doesn't move, and after about three minutes, the walls expand again. We move on.

We reach another area of magical darkness. Emilio and Fearghas walk in, I hesitate next to Shalkoc. Behind us, Aviana hears a trickling, then a rushing. A wall of greenish bile floods the tunnel towards us. We brace for it and withstand it, but Fearghas and Emilio are swept away, pushed into a wall, and dragged along. Fearghas manages to hold on, but Emilio is pushed farther from us, unable to find his footing. (he's failed 6 saves at this point and we are screaming)

Something tries to snatches Emilio before he can be swept into a hole but he wriggles out and falls into the hole. HE FINALLY SAVES, holding onto teeth at the edge of the maw. He pulls himself up and out of the gaping maw at the cost of extensive acid burns. Left behind, Shalkoc starts to stumble through the magical darkness. He uses Step of the Wind to catch up to Emilio, but I lose sight of him completely.

I cast Piercing the Veil and advance through the magical darkness. Fade caught up to us, she is invisible but her presence reassures me. Less so Plex' on my shoulder, but he hands me two bottles of very dark wine as thanks for carrying him. To maintain the balance of trade, I hand him a torch. I don't think it will help him see through the magic-wrought darkness, but it's symbolic, right? I'm worried about Emilio, I'm sure he is injured. I need to get to him. Fearghas went ahead of me, and caught up to him and Shalkoc. I can't be too far behind.

Plex drinks some of the same dark wine. The magic around him shifts, shapes into a spell just short of casting. An invisible Obscuroth slides just in front of us, and Plex releases his Thunderwave… triggering a MAJOR WILD MAGIC SURGE. THAT BLINDS ANYONE WITHIN 60 FEET OF PLEX. I'll need a 9th-level spell to remove that!

An unfinished flesh golem is speaking to Emilio and Fearghas, begging to be left alone because it's been tortured so much, all its scales ripped of. It has the head of a juvenile dragon, on a humanoid body. The Dragonflesh golem unleashes an Elemental breath on Emilio, knocking the life out of him. The golem cries that he is sorry, then returns to being an emotionless golem.

Aviana tears through the wall of flesh, emerging next to the others whom I was trying to catch up to! Fearghas shouted that Emilio was down, from the shouts I hear, he could be dying. Fearghas shouts to Aviana to put Emilio in the flask. Shalkoc runs up to Emilio and feeds him snot, which revives him with a lot of coughing. He weakly thanks Shalkoc, who is silenced and just gives a thumbs up. The celestial's voice congratulates Shalkoc for pouring snot down Emilio's throat while he was unconscious and dying from his wounds.

What a time to have ears.

I dash towards the noise made by my friends, Plex guiding me. How the tables turn. I call out to them and say I'm blind. Unable to cast a spell, I draw my sharp dagger and clutch it for dear life. I hear a Walleye fire a Psychic Ray, and Fearghas grumbles about Wizard bullshit. He summons a Spectral Hand and uses a spellgem of Dimension Door to drop Emilio and Shalkoc next to me, by grabbing them with the very spooky hand. Fearghas joins us, swinging his obsidian battleaxe. Level 13 Wizard by the way.

Plex offers to Fearghas to buy his Haste Potion. Fearghas retorts "Plex, do you understand the concept of DYING?" Aviana is getting attacked by something. Shalkoc gains inspiration as the Dragonflesh golem is proof of the existence of dragons. Plex uses Fey Step and disappears on the other side of a wall. Again. This time he is not far from us, and he casts Gravity Sinkhole. We discuss what to do with the Dragonflesh golem, and decide to put it out of its misery. I argue that I prefer to spend my most powerful spell on my friends rather than attempt to save a creature twisted beyond recognition, that has tried to kill us.

Plex shunts the Dragonflesh golem into the gaping maw. It screams in terror that it doesn't want to fall into that hole again, then sinks beneath the waves.
