I feel so sick… The darkness is suffocating… I can't fight it, it comes from my own eyes. Can we survive this? Will we even live to find the Sibriex? I can't break now, I am still needed. An Obscuroth wanders close to Fade, she tears it to shreds. The golem struggles in vain, shouting it doesn't want to go there again, not again. I can't shut out the screams, they sound too much like mine. The last we hear from the golem is that it doesn't want to "receive any more mercy from that thing". What a sickening thing to hear…

Emilio is completely unconcerned with his own survival, and enters Void Form again. I will dose this man with catfern and mavinsleaf if we ever get out of here. Abundantly. He applies Accrued Vitality and gives himself 26 temp HP, so maybe I will maybe it a slightly weaker brew. He slashes at a Bloater that is right in front of us. I get hit by a Tooth Spit from a Slithering Bowel, and dazed, but I keep my concentration on Fade. She dashes to us, but can't attack this turn.

Aviana shoves a repulsive enemy like Captain Falcon, straight into the maw in the middle of the room. Shalkoc hesitates to kill the Bloater because they explode when they die, he (rightfully so) fears he'll kill us (Emilio and me). I use a Mass Cure Wounds but it turns out to be weak sauce on everyone but me. Since I'm dazed, I can do nothing else…

Aviana gets critted and recovers a lot of resources! She brings up wanting to be bitten again. Fearghas casts Shocking Grasp on the Bloater, then slices at it with his axe, with precision entirely out of place for a Wizard! He moves away from us, past Fade, and drinks another Potion of Maximum Power. Fearghas spots a kind of flesh… workbench? in the distance. On it rests a heavy tome, and he gets this glint in his eyes…

Plex pushes the Bloater away from me, but closer to Fearghas. The monster tries to eat Emilio; he takes damage from the bite, then gets swallowed. Plex, still tiny, convincingly shouts at Emilio that he can, in fact, SEE in there! The Bowel next to Aviana tries to slither away, but she kicks it, sending it close enough to attack me, which it does. I take acid damage, and I am dazed again. This time I lose concentration and Fade dissipates in a burst of dark mist. Emilio somehow survives the Bloater's stomach acid but he is still severely injured. In clawing his way out, Emilio kills the Bloater, which explodes in a burst of acid. Our warlock emerges covered in acid, enraged.

The Bowel spits acid at me again. I can't think for the pain… We finally kill that last Bowel, and combat ends. I'm still blind, so I cling to anyone I can find. Fearghas picks up the tome; a Manual of Fiendish Flesh Golems. It is bound in many kinds of skin. He also finds a cloak woven in dragon scales, which he hands to Emilio. Shalkoc's last remaining braincell whispers to him to not run away on his own. Thank you so much, braincell.

I'm standing in place, paralysed with fear, when Fearghas walks up to me with a spell scroll and a spellgem, and removes my cloth allergy, and my blindness. I can finally see! And I see the blood in the pool in the middle of the room draining… The celestial's voice speaks to us not in our minds, but from below the pool, welcoming us.

Fearghas says out loud what we all think; we are in no condition for another fight and we absolutely need to rest. Emilio trades with Plex; one haste potion for Aviana, in exchange for Plex' last surviving chicken, which Emilio held onto. Fearghas prepares to put up the tiny hut, and we settle for a short rest next to the corpses, the acid puddles, and the empty pool of blood.

pages.name: 76 - Healing fear
pages.content:
Aviana and Plex begin to argue, which ends as usual with Aviana grabbing Plex by the throat and squeezing, and them both disappearing. Teleportation out of here is impossible, so we assume they are still in the lair. Fearghas pulls out alchemical supplies, grumbles at our friends' disappearance, and we hear a sound coming from the north-east corridor. Fearghas says the telepathic bond ended when I bring it up, so we go look for them using our little feet, Emilio and I leaving a trail of blood from our injuries. Emilio's blood is black?!

We follow the twisting corridor to a room where we find a small Malleable that has… wings? Behind it is a large black egg. Emilio and Fearghas immediately blast the Malleable; its body melts into the ground, leaving feathers behind. The egg is warm and has a thin, slimy shell like a snake egg. Fearghas and Shalkoc say it looks nothing like a dragon egg… How do they know that? Not the time to ask. Something is moving sluggishly inside the egg. A humanoid hand seems to try to break through the shell, but is too weak to do so.

Before Fearghas can advise against this course of action, Emilio punches a hole through the egg, spilling fluid onto Emilio. Inside the egg is a gooey, disheveled… human woman. She is not happy, understandably so. She is small, blonde with green eyes, wearing black armour. Groggily, she asks where she is.

"We're in the lair of a demon."

"At the bottom of a lake."

"In the Underdark."

5 iridescent feathers on the ground, untouched by the filth.

The blonde woman introduces herself as Kyrin. She is spooked by Shalkoc, towering over the party. She offers me a healing potion, then upon seeing Emilio, hands it to him instead. No hard feelings. He is hurt even worse than I am. She hands me a second healing potion. Emilio and me drink gratefully; a little of the tension goes out of him.

We return to the drained blood pool and Fearghas carries out the ritual for Leomund's Tiny Hut. Kyrin examines herself, checking for any unnatural growths that may have occurred while she was in the egg. Her shadow seems… strange. Doesn't move quite right, like it's lagging behind. I speak up, but Fearghas and Kyrin say I'm maybe seeing things. For a moment her shadow looked like mine… I must be imagining. Shalkoc cooks a thankfully vegetarian soup for Emilio and me.

I patch up Emilio with the bandages and herbs I have, then treat my own wounds. Shalkoc cooks a big medium rare steak for Kyrin, generously spiced with ginger. What meat is that? After handing her food to Kyrin, Shalkoc gives me a very soothing high-five with his Hand of Healing. Fearghas insistently asks Shalkoc where he got the steak from, which makes Kyrin hesitate until Shalkoc assures he bought the steak in the city. Shalkoc cooks more meat, this time some kind of chicken, as a snack for Fearghas.

The voice calls from the hole: "Yes, pause and breathe in the tranquility, dear ones. The transition from the River to the boundless peace of Nirvana can be… intense. Rest is a balm, and I am here to offer comfort and guidance." Emilio shouts at it to shut up. Fearghas offers him a drink, he refuses. The dwarf insists, and pours him some dwarven ale. Kyrin enquires as to why Emilio is so angry at the voice. His voice seeps barely controlled fury as he speaks about the abysmal luck he's been having.

I offer to treat the party's remaining scrapes and hurts. They decline, but the celestial speaks in my mind, saying they are impressed with my dedication to heal, and they are eager to teach me to heal even better. I go positively green at that. Fearghas hands out potions of heroism, which we all drink as we steel ourselves.

The hole in the middle of the room is deep, with slippery walls. Fearghas suggests to cast Feather Fall, and just jump. AAAAAAAAAA. We float down into a large fleshy chamber, very humid and reeking. A big hole in the north wall leads to another chamber, presumably. We hear skittering, squelching steps. There is no sign of the Dragonflesh golem… The voice calls "There you are, let me tend to you." Kyrin crouches behind a fleshy growth, all but disappearing from sight. Fearghas takes a steeling drink. I panic and use Shadowslip to disappear (and a major wild magic surge giving me a permanent 1d8 to my charisma checks!). Shalkoc uses Guardian of Nature: Primal Beast. Emilio glares.

The skittering comes closer… Hands, followed by elbows, more hands, more elbows… It straightens, a monster of arms and more arms that moves gingerly but dextrously. The monster cradles what remains of a celestial, or rather, many celestials stitched together. Bones sticking out of its fingers make dreadful claws. It asks us to come into its embrace. Emilio is enraged and threatens it. The monster responds with kindness…

We roll initiative.

The Perfected Deva takes two steps towards us, then teleports very close! It swings claws at Fearghas saying soothing things, to which Fearghas grumbles heartily. It encourages us to come closer, and sweeps across the entire area with its claws. It hits and grapples Fearghas, restraining him as it pulls him into its loving embrace. Urgh. Emilio gets hit and delivers a spicy Hellish Rebuke in reaction, but the boss saves and takes half damage. Emilio gets grappled as well. I get hit even in shadow form, breaking the spell, and grappled. Shalkoc blocks the attack with his wings. Kyrin is not noticed by the monster at all.

I resist the curse, try to escape the grapple, but fail. Shalkoc goes into Mantis Style and punches, then attempts to deliver a Stunning Strike, twice. He does damage, but both strikes fail to stun the Deva. He unleashes a Flurry of Blows, triggers Chromatic Hardening, and tries one last Stunning Strike, to no avail. He steps away, unharmed by the monster.

Emilio resists the curse like it's nothing. He casts Void Torrent, and teleports away; the acid does not seem to harm the Deva at all. He goes into Void Form and uses Accrued Vitality but it's weak sauce and he only gains 8 temp HP. Tragic. Kyrin gets cursed. The Deva tells us to not be afraid, which promptly frightens Shalkoc and me (I rolled with advantage, and thankfully, because that was a 4 and a 1…). Kyrin pulls out a SUN BLADE and swings at the monster in a sneak attack, dealing a ton of radiant damage. She follows it up with a Psychic Blade, but the attack misses. She runs to safety.

The Deva uses Helping Hand (a claw attack with free necrotic damage and spicy crit range) and crits Fearghas for a massive chunk of HP. He casts Misty Step to get the hell out, leaving me alone in the grapple. He casts Hold Monster from a spellgem.

"Aerelia if this thing is immune to paralyse, I'm going to shank you." Karnack, 2025.

We don't find out because the Deva saves, and Fearghas is very upset. The Deva uses Gentle Light, spawning a cloud of magical darkness on Kyrin. The Deva uses To the Rescue, teleporting to Shalkoc and dragging me along. Pressed into its ribcage, I feel squirming underneath the skin. There is a lot of maggots in there… The Deva hits me, it's another crit. I take heavy damage, leaving me at low health with a half-baked plan.

The Deva has a legendary resistance, and I only get one shot at a healing burst. I levitate myself out of the grapple, run away 20 feet in the air, and apply a healing word on myself, healing barely anything. Shalkoc punches for all he's worth, with a lot of feeling, but does not stun the Deva, so he shifts to Turtle Stance. The Deva uses Don't be Afraid again, but we all endure the wave of fear without flinching. Emilio growls that he has seen much worse in the void, and pummels it with an Eldritch Blast. Two beams hit, and Emilio uses Grasp of Hadar to drag the Deva closer to him.

The monster unleashes another wave of fear, terrifying Shalkoc and Kyrin. It uses Empathy/Loneliness as a reaction to her failing the save, forcing us to make two other saves which she barely passes, at the cost of light psychic damage. She sidesteps out of the magical darkness and throws a Psychic Blade because she is frightened and unable to move closer.

The Deva feels lonely and teleports to Kyrin, who flips it off as a free action. "What a gentle gesture," it sighs. "Oh I've got a gesture for you all right!" She says. Fearghas steps in cat puke IRL then casts Scorching Ray. It would deal massive damage, but the Deva uses a Legendary Resistance! Then Fearghas chucks a Spiritual Weapon at it. The Deva uses a legendary action to attack Kyrin on Fearghas' turn, she uses her Uncanny Dodge to halve the damage.

The Deva hits Kyrin again, taking half her life in one blow. She then hits me; I drop to 1 HP and the Death Ward dissipates! I stop concentrating on Levitate and float to the ground. Through the Staff of Power, I cast Wall of Force and put myself in an unbreakable box to buy time. A Healing Word on Shalkoc gives him courage to approach the enemy and punch the living daylight out of it. Emilio gets close and readies up a spell. The Deva uses a Helping Hand on Kyrin, who dodges it perfectly. Close call!

Kyrin gets an otherworldly inspiration called Karnack; she hides, applies Shadow Strike to increase her reach, then attacks with a melee Psychic Blade, and marks the enemy's soul. She books it to a safe distance. A new wave of fear rolls out from the Deva, but none of us are afraid! Fearghas commands his Spiritual Weapon to attack, then prepares a Scorching Ray.

Another wave of fear hits us, and this time it's too much for everyone but Fearghas. Shalkoc indirectly saves my life by using a Dreamfeather and allowing me to reroll, avoiding psychic damage from Empathy/Loneliness. Kyrin gets hit by it but saves, barely surviving. On its turn, the Deva goes to her. Shalkoc tries an attack of opportunity, but is hit by a wild magic surge that inflicts disadvantage on all his attack rolls, cancelling the advantage from his future sight. Kyrin gets hit by Helping Hand, and goes down. The Deva jumps back to Shalkoc's rescue and bumps into my Wall of Force. Eyes lock onto me and hands feel at the Wall of Force, looking in vain for an opening. It looks disappointed, but it waits for my barrier to fall off.

Emilio and Fearghas unleash their readied spells, Tasha's Mind Whip and Scorching Ray. The Deva rolls a critical save on the mind whip and does not use resistance… Five of Fearghas' rays hit, and the Deva uses Legendary Resistance!

Steeling myself, I drop concentration on the Wall of Force. The hands reach out to me as I am defenseless, critically injured, but I am faster. Ripping my spellwards from my wrists, clutching the Staff of Power, I channel my strongest healing spell. A torrent of positive energy rushes towards the Deva, closing all wounds but also feeding the maggots inside and making them multiply until the creature's skin tears and the disgusting things burst out. The Deva's twisted body crumples, and the ruined face looks up at me. In a last whisper, it says "Thank you". For a moment I am filled with serenity and thoughts of the dawn's light, just like the day I received my staff.

Maggots are swarming all over. I step around them, casting a Healing Word on myself, and start toward the unconscious Kyrin. Shalkoc makes short work of the maggots with a fire breath, popping them like corn. Combat ends at last, and I rush over to Kyrin and get her back on her feet. Fearghas harvests the maggots, while telling Shalkoc to NOT eat them or even pick them up. He tries to get materials from the Deva's corpse, but it's too corrupted to make anything out of.

Kyrin finds 15 gleaming Springseeds. I scoop them up carefully and put them in my bag of herbs, hoping to plant them on Promise soon. We consider taking another rest, but the lair begins to quake and spasm. Again a rushing sound comes towards us from above. We cannot take another wave of bile now! I can confirm that we are in a stomach, urgh. The hole up north should be a throat of sorts; we dash into it, chased by the rushing sound becoming louder behind us. I block the tunnel with a Wall of Force as soon as we are through, but if the wall is unbreakable, the sticky walls of flesh will not hold much longer. We burst out of the sticky throat into a mouth with several rows of enormous teeth, closed.

Fearghas casts Shocking Grasp to get the creature to open its mouth, and his Lich Hand to tickle the uvula. It doesn't work out, so Emilio tries with a Mage Hand, but fails miserably. Kyrin stabs the tongue with her Psychic Blade. The blade goes in to the hilt, but we see no wound. The tongue rises to crush us against the roof of the mouth, but the teeth are cracking open. A wall of water rushes in…

Fearghas and Emilio very quickly put their heads together, talking quickly about magic. They come to the conclusion that teleportation should now be possible. Fearghas says "Get in my mouth!" and nobody understands until he polymorphs himself into a whale and takes a deep breath, filling his mouth with air. We all hop in.

"I am the coo of the sea!" Fearghas, 1497.

The water is a lot murkier, polluted with blood and bile. Whaleghas spots small Aboleths in the water. He swims up, and beaches himself on a… beach, and kindly opens his mouth to let us out. He reverts to his true form spitting, saying one of us tastes awful. Emilio apologises.

We are in a cave we've never seen before. Kyrin suggests a Detect Magic spell, so I take out my wand and give it a happy little wave. Kyrin seems to see just fine, she is intently looking around the cavern as if searching for something. We discuss our options; do we return to Fearghas' mansion in Ukgluz, or teleport to Promise? We quickly brief Kyrin on our… history with the Duergar. And the Drow of House Vandree… We decide to head back to Fearghas' mansion, on foot. Fearghas pops a spellgem of Find the Path.

We are on the other side of the lake, so it isn't far, but we have to go through the water again. Not a problem, as Fearghas turns back to Whaleghas to ferry us across. On the way, Kyrin says she was employed by the Drow to investigate Ukgluz, then tried to infiltrate Lessia with the Duergar, but she messed up, and can't be seen by them now. The last thing she remembers is Matron Vandree telling her she will never disappoint her again, and the next thing she knew she woke up in a gooey egg in the lair. The whale noises stop at that, then resume, and Whaleghas sneakily slaps Shalkoc with his tongue. Whalegas spits us all out on the other side of the lake, on the side of Ukgluz. The mutated larvae here have grown even larger…

Fearghas, back to dwarf form, grumbles about "mahr-might taste" again, and blames Shalkoc, who is offended. We make for Ukgluz, but Kyrin stops. She fears being recognised. Anxiously, she asks us not to tell on her as she shapeshifts into a child with the look of an urchin. Although she is smaller, her shadow grows larger. Irritatedly, she stomps on it and mutters at it under her breath. Her shadow behaves, and with child-Kyrin in tow, we walk to Ukgluz. Fearghas sticks the hat on his head and reminds us that we are all pretending to be his slaves.

As we reach the alleyway where the manor is, Fearghas stops abruptly. We all collide into him, which amuses a Duergar nearby, who asks how he will punish his slaves for this, and thankfully leaves. Right in front of the manor's invisible door is one of the Duergar's statues. Apparently these are the "demon engines" or are powered by them. It hasn't noticed us yet.

We investigate a little, then sneak past the statue. It doesn't move and we slip into the mansion unnoticed. Fearghas officially welcomes us to the Chateau de MacAllistar. We chill and get Kyrin up to speed about why we were in the Sibriex lair. Fearghas mentions, with no ill intentions I'm sure, that we went into the lair because I insisted on it. We nearly died in there… Suddenly choked with guilt, I excuse myself to the kitchen to make tea, but Kyrin thanks me for saving her, that if we hadn't gone into the lair, she would have been warped into a monster. I try to reply, but only squeak, and hurry to the kitchen, asking Shalkoc if we can make some cookies for everyone, too.

Fearghas, Emilio, and Kyrin discuss origins, reputation, and casual racism in the dining hall. We return with tea and snacks. Fearghas contacts Aviana with a Sending, asking where she and Plex are, and whether they are both safe. Aviana replies very tensely with "where the fuck are you", "what is this bullshit", and something about her dress being all dirty, and she was done with sewers, and she was done with filthy places! And this is more than 25 words for sure.

pages.name: 76 - Healing Fear (Summary)
pages.content:
Aviana grabs Plex' throat after 2.5 seconds of arguing and they both teleport. Good start. They can't have gone far, what with the teleport restrictions here. I ask if Fearghas can contact them telepathically, but that Discord call ended while I was forcefully offline thanks to Mind Blank.

We leave to look for our missing companions, but find instead a... Minor Malleable? With wings? Emilio and Fearghas blast it dead, we pick up 5 dreamfeathers and share them among us. There is a large black snake-like egg, with movement inside. Emilio punches it open and a petite woman comes out, a human who woke up from the worst nap ever.

We introduce ourselves and explain to her where she is. Her name is Kyrin and she has very little idea how she got here, poor soul. She gives healing potions to Emilio and me after seeing how beaten up we are, how nice! The potions that is, not the beating up part.

We return to the blood pool room and take a short rest in the bubble. There is a lot of healing to be done, Shalkoc cooks a big steak for Kyrin which prompts relentless questioning from Fearghas to ascertain the origin of the meat. Bless this dwarf. Kyrin's shadow seems odd, but I brush it off as imagination.

The celestial's voice encourages us to rest, and Emilio snaps at it. Fearghas offers him ale, for his nerves. Emilio refuses. Fearghas insists. Kyrin asks why he is so angry (Emilio, not Fearghas, understandable mistake dear reader). Emilio grumbles about his terrible luck. The celestial wants to teach me to heal better. Hard pass. I'm fine. Nuh-uh.

After some much needed R&R, we jump down the maw in the middle of the room, and live thanks to Fearghas' Feather Fall spell. We end up in a large, disgusting, vaguely round cavern. No sign of the monsters we chucked into that hole last time, I'm sure that's nothing to worry about. Something is coming! Kyrin hides so well I can't see her at all. I panic and slip into my shadow. Fearghas quaffs some ale. Shalkoc casts a spell to make his muscles bigger. Emilio glares.

We're attacked? By a monster with FAR too many hands, claiming it just wants a hug. It has the celestial's voice, but the body is corrupted beyond recognition and twisted into a fiend. In spite of this, it kept its good intentions and keeps trying to help us, which turns into trying to kill us.

"Aerelia if this thing is immune to paralyse, I'm going to shank you." Karnack, 2025.

It's a hard battle, the Perfected Deva always targets the lowest health character to "help" them, and it grapples like a son of a kobold too. It teleports, inflicts fear, and generally hits like a truck. Kyrin flips it off as a free action. I'm grappled within an inch of my life and I realise that under the creature's skin, maggots are teeming. If they could teem a bit more, we could get interesting results. Speaking from experience.

We hatch a plan. Emilio and Fearghas ready their spells to hit the Deva on my turn and force it to use its legendary resistance. I put myself in a box, that is Wall of Force, because I am at 1 HP and my Death Ward triggered. Kyrin goes down despite some sick dodges, but all is in readiness. I drop concentration on Wall of Force, take off my spellwards, and channel for all I'm worth.

I CAST HEAL AT 9TH LEVEL!

According to plan, the maggots multiply and the boss explodes! It thanks me in a last whisper just before Shalkoc grills all the maggots with a dragon breath. Do not eat the maggots. I rush to help Kyrin but it's too soon to celebrate, as another wave of bile is coming for us. We run into the only exit, a sticky tunnel that I block with a Wall of Force. This only buys us a little time, as the flood of bile is so bad, the throat-like tunnel will give out before my spell does. We exit the tunnel into a huge mouth with several rows of teeth, firmly shut.

We think on how to escape, but soon Fearghas says "Get in my mouth!"

Nobody knows what he is talking about. (except Emilio for meta reasons)

He polymorphs into a sperm whale.

Everybody knows what he is talking about.

Shalkoc gets slapped by a tongue, one of us tastes like Marmite, we are carried to freedom by the glorious form of Whaleghas.

"I am the coo of the sea!" Fearghas 1497.

After learning Kyrin is a changeling, we decide to return to the Chateau de MacAllistar in Ukgluz. We dodge a statue that was staring at the door, thankfully without consequences (right?), get in, chat over tea and cookies, and send a Message spell to Aviana, with a response that is mostly grumbling about her dress being all dirty.

pages.name: 76.1 - The darkness below
pages.content:
The magical darkness drifted away as though possessed by a mind of its own. Naami breathed a sigh of relief, but the emotion was short-lived. Looking outside Fearghas' protective bubble, she recognised nothing in the shuddering flesh walls; not a landmark nor a previously explored tunnel. Her hands trembled in spite of her efforts to stay calm. There could be no escape from here, not without killing the demon. She ran her fingertips on her spellwards, longing to remove them to invite the torrent of power that would crash into her mind. How she would love to end it. Not likely; she was a healer after all and not much of a combatant. But... her thoughts chased one another in dizzying circles. Celestials. Her spellwards. The Staff of Power. Blood and darkness. The light of dawn, and death in her hands.

"Naami, come here," Fearghas said, interrupting her uncomfortable daze.

He was sitting quite close in fact, and simply pulled a gem from his bag. It was a beautiful diamond, which the wizard mercilessly crushed in his fist to activate the spell within. He smeared the dust on Naami's forehead with a hand covered in writing calluses.

"There. This will protect you from mind reading and other unpleasant mental spells."

Naami murmured her thanks, just as she realised her head was suddenly quiet. Confused, she looked around questioningly.

"Ah, yes," Fearghas added. "Forgot to mention, that also excludes you from the telepathic bond."

"It's fine," she said. "We're sticking together anyway. Nobody wanders off on their own."

The last came with a pointed look at Plex, who was skimming a spellbook filled with tiny illustrations. The goblin ignored it; most likely he had not noticed the reproach was targeted at him. The healer's disapproval shifted to Shalkoc, who was muttering and tinkering with utensils and ingredients. How was he cooking? Here of all places? With a grin, the Dragonborn straightened and craned his neck to look at Aviana. He handed her a large bowl that seemed a thimble in the giant harpy's talons.

"Energy soup," he said proudly. "Fix you right up! I made something for Naami too."

A plate of small round cookies was thrust into Naami's hands as Shalkoc gave her a winning smile and an invitation to eat up. The plate was warm; a thin curl of steam rose from the cookies. How had he just baked treats? Naami took one, and nearly dropped it in shock.

"They're meat cookies," Shalkoc chuckled. "Full of tasty energy!"

Naami's stomach lurched. She tried to look away from the fleshy walls, but it was impossible. The ground and ceiling shivered too, occasionally oozing blood or dripping sizzling acid. Groans and gurgles drifted from the floors and ceilings, all too reminiscent of a tortured stomach. The whole place reeked of rotting flesh and the heavy, sickening metallic smell of blood. She thought if the party made it out alive, she might never want to eat meat again. Or to eat at all.

"Don't be shy," Shalkoc said. "It's protein!"

Shalkoc's cooking had always been excellent. Naami held a cookie in a trembling grip and closed her eyes to shut out the revolting surroundings, only to open them again. It was worse without seeing. It was so much worse. Silencing her thoughts, placing all her trust into her friend, she took a bite. What looked like cookies were more akin to ground meat patties, seared just right and lightly spiced. Savoury warmth and a chewy texture gave her newfound strength, as even the ache of bruises and scrapes faded away. She surprised herself by taking a second cookie, and a third, reconsidering and discarding vegetarianism. Shalkoc beamed when she handed him a cleaned plate.

"You got meat? No fair," Aviana pouted as she sipped the last of her soup.

Despite her pouting, the harpy looked better as well. She flexed her talons gingerly, then with more force. When she stretched her legs she gave a wince; it was gone in a flash, but Naami had noticed. Reaching into her dwindling supplies, she pulled out a sizeable piece of nirca root and handed it to Aviana.

"Here, if you eat this for dessert, it should help your legs."

The dark root near disappeared into Aviana's hand. She popped it into her mouth, chewing experimentally.

"Hey, no more pain! Thank you Naami, you are truly the only one in this party who cares to heal me."

"T-that's not true!" The halfling protested, just as Shalkoc exclaimed "I'm always cooking for you!"

"Now now children," Fearghas interrupted in an amused grumble. "If we're all fixed up, we should get ready to leave. The bubble won't last much longer."

Emilio, back to his usual form, gave a short nod. Plex waved at Naami from the ground.

"Pick me up!" The goblin squeaked. "I'll ride on your shoulder!"

Naami obliged, though it was somewhat unsettling. Plex began to argue in her ear that it made sense, with her being able to see through the darkness. Tactical advantage, the need for reasonably-sized people to stick together in a world of knees, the whole tirade. She listened distractedly, wondering why her and not Emilio, who could see through the horrible shining darkness without having to cast a spell. One glance at the warlock answered her question. His white hair seemed to ripple in the absence of a breeze, and his pink eyes shifted so the irises seemed to blur. His slender body was tense with focus. His bandaged fingers curled around nothing as if eager to transform into claws again, or to cast one of his destructive spells. Ally. He was in control of his powers. He would remain in control, and she was not trying to convince herself of it.

It was time to leave. Fearghas passed through the bubble first, dispelling the magic. The party picked a corridor at random, and walked down the narrow tunnel in uneasy silence. Soon, they were face to face with a wall writhing with cramps. Emilio shook his head and turned around, his jaw tight. It was a shorter walk back the way they had come, and they only found another wall. Shalkoc leapt aside with a yelp; on the ground, a small hollow had opened up and was continuing to expand, filling with dark blood. The foul liquid sizzled and Shalkoc examined the hole that had been burnt through his boot.

"Are you hurt?" Naami said.

"No," the Dragonborn said after a short hesitation. "I was too quick for it."

His enthusiasm sounded forced. The pool's edges crept up and apart, threatening every foot in the vicinity. When it seemed like the only option was to buy time by climbing up, one of the walls groaned and ripped open in a sickening squelch. Fearghas gagged and cleared his throat. Emilio paled, swallowing convulsively. Before Naami could treat their nausea, black tendrils rushed towards the party, darting out of another cloud of magical darkness which engulfed them all.

"There's something up ahead," Emilio said. "Something big. And the wall... the wall... blinked? Ugh... a lake of blood ahead, and something snake-like inside. Arms and legs in the lake, waste below the surface. Are we in a stomach?"

"It's not a real creature," Naami said, unable to keep her voice steady. "We're not inside a giant animal. It's all a product of filthy magic."

Emilio responded by raising a bandaged hand and firing crackling energy through the dark cloud, producing wet impact sounds and a twisted howl. With a white-knuckled grip on her staff, Naami wove threads of magic and settled them on her eyes. The blinding shine of the dark cloud dimmed, the foul mist lifting. She wished she could use the same spell on Plex, who was blindly gripping a strand of her hair, but she had never managed to make it work on someone else. Emilio sensed the magic and directed a joyless smile to Naami.

"Now I'm not the only one cursed with knowledge," he said coldly.

"Ah, make way, Lord of Ultimate Darkness," Aviana said, ducking her head to fit in the narrow tunnel. "I want that snake thing."

Her talons wrapped almost tenderly around an item Naami had learnt to fear; the dented iron flask the harpy treasured.

"This thing is empty, right?" Naami said.

"Of course! Shalkoc put me in it just recently. An unglamorous experience." Her mouth twisted at the memory.

"I was there," Naami said impatiently. "But you were whisked off to the Feywild after that while strangling Plex. Last time that happened, you came back with an ancient fey in the flask that nearly killed Emilio."

Aviana waved the comment away. "It's empty, for now."

The greedy look in her eyes made it clear she did not intend for the flask to remain empty. Not much reassured, Naami looked down just in time to see a misshapen monster rear towards her. Twisting bowels, too many for one creature and most jutting out of others, made up a serpentine mass that tilted back before spewing acid at her. Naami threw herself to the side, her stomach cramping. A yell in her ear told her she had failed to protect Plex.

"It's in my eyes! I can't see a thing!"

The tiny goblin wiped his eyes frantically; soon enough, Emilio suffered the same fate.

"Oh for the love of... Naami, where are they? Guide me!" Fearghas muttered from behind the others.

She tried her best to describe the situation to him, pointing and tugging strands of magic for him to sense. As he spoke a spell, she realised in panic he meant to hit her. Before she could dodge, a bolt of crackling lightning sped past her, lifting her hair, and blasted three of the monsters in the cavern, killing one. The corpse of a mangled humanoid crumpled and slipped into the bloody lake, the scarred skin sizzling as the acidic liquid attacked it.

"That lake is acid too," Naami cried.

As if on cue, a fleshy limb thrust out of the darkness and squeezed around Shalkoc, dragging him into the lake.

"Help!" He yelled as the acid touched his scales.

His screams were silenced by a heavy thud as he grappled and fought with a mass of flesh and organs, much like the abomination that Emilio had blasted earlier.

"The walls," the warlock groaned, clutching his head. "The walls... moving... Danger... Have to... get close!"

He had taken several blows, Naami realised, some of them acid burns spreading on his skin. Aside from the physical injuries, a fevered glint glowed in his eyes. True to his words, the walls shifted and heaved, tripping him and Naami alike. Plex tumbled from her shoulder screaming.

"Get close!" Emilio growled.

He twisted around and pointed at Fearghas, shooting three purplish beams at him. The dwarf dropped to his knees cursing, dodging the spell.

"Emilio, what in the world?" Fearghas called, struggling to his feet.

With a cry of pain ending in a triumphant shout, the warlock whipped his head around.

"It took over my mind for a minute; that eye in the wall did. I broke the spell. Sorry for aiming at you. I only wanted... I wasn't in my right mind."

"No harm done, lad," the dwarf said, unconvinced. "Oh watch out!"

Emilio spun around only to be hit in the face with another splash of acid. His hands went to his eyes as he made an inhuman sound deep in his throat, pain and fury tangled as one. Naami reached out to him; he was too far to touch, but close enough to hear. She used her voice to carry the spell, infusing a single word with positive energy. She felt some of his wounds closing, some of the pain receding, but the magic escaped her control. It leapt, resonating, strands chasing one another and weaving chaotic patterns, only to unravel and snap into place. Plex, who had finally wiped the acid from his eyes, tugged at the hem of Naami's dress.

"Why'd you throw me off? I can't see a thing again! Pick me up!"

Too distracted to pick up the wizard, Naami watched in horror what the magic had wrought. Another cloud of seething darkness surrounded her, emanating from her. It was not her own magic, but it had sprung into existence because of it. One of the wild magic surges plaguing the world, it *had* to be magical darkness of all things... She fought the urge to laugh at the irony, knowing it would sink into a mad cackle. The magic did not even stop at that. Instead of dying down, it surged even stronger, this time wrapping around her body. Powerless to stop it, she felt shuddering magic touch her skin and melt into it. Immediately her eyes watered, and she was wracked with one sneeze after the next.

Plex, who was climbing back on his perch, had to hold for dear life as the poor healer sneezed uncontrollably. When the goblin finally made it up, gripping a fistful of Naami's hair, he confirmed her suspicions.

"You're allergic to something," he muttered, out of breath from his climbing ordeal. "Something really common, like wood or metal."

"Cloth," she cried. "I can't just take off my dress!"

"I would not recommend it," the goblin said pragmatically, and pressed a hand to Naami's cheek. "Now, tell me where the monsters are!"

She guided him verbally between sneezes, and he replied with the pressure of his fingers to confirm her instructions. When he was pointing straight at the monsters, and also Aviana who was pummelling the mass of flesh to make it release Shalkoc, she murmured "fire". Plex seemed to take offense to this, and unleashed a blizzard onto enemies and friends alike. Aviana dodged with a squawk, but Shalkoc had no such luck as he was still held by the monster. He yelped in the cold, then screamed as he was being squeezed. Too soon, his screams dwindled into gasps as the strength was leaving him.

"Plex can't keep shooting blindly!" Naami cried, feeling so much worse for her part in it.

"Calm down, lass," Fearghas said, cracking a spellgem in his fist.

The darkness around Naami dissipated, eliciting a shout of delight from Plex. Relieved, she thanked the dwarf, who only grumbled and settled a pair of ornate glasses on his nose.

"Shalkoc!" Aviana shouted.

His friend's voice gave him new strength; the Dragonborn's eyes blazed and he let out a roar that belonged on a much larger creature than him. Aviana paid it no mind, and sank her talons into the monster.

"You are being rescued," she said. "Do not resist."

With a powerful flex of her legs and wings, she leapt into the air. Shalkoc was dragged along yelping with increasing dread as they fell back down and crashed in an explosion of lighting from Aviana's cursed footwraps. Shalkoc slumped in the grasp of the fleshy horror, stunned for a moment, but came to his senses when an eye bulging out of the nearby wall grabbed hold of magic and spread a stain of darkness around itself, swallowing the two friends in gloom.

"Enough of this!" Emilio growled as he changed, eyes growing dark, his claws bursting out of the bandages.

Free from the restraints of his "disguise", he threw himself forward and into the area frozen over by Plex' blizzard. Slipping and stumbling, he managed three blasts of force on his way, then rushed towards another monstrous lump of flesh. There were two, Naami realised, one who was squeezing the life out of Shalkoc and the other falling prey to Emilio's slashing claws. Plex tugged Naami's hair, getting a yelp for his trouble.

"I can't see over there," he snapped. "This way?"

"Yes," she stammered. "Two big ones. More to the left! You'll hit Aviana and Shalkoc. Now, here!"

The goblin grinned as he uttered words of power, words that made Naami's hair stand on end. The magic shifted, flows twining and braiding into cords that lashed at reality, tied knots into it and *pulled*. A rift opened, not in the ground but in the air, slamming invisible weight on the monsters. It lasted only a moment, leaving Shalkoc and Aviana unharmed, but the fleshy abominations were squashed by overwhelming force, muscle ripping, organs tumbling down into the sizzling lake. Shalkoc twisted out of the grapple at last, crying for help even as he inflicted draconic punishment on the enemy.

"Fade, help us!" Naami cried.

Shadows gathered in front of her, coalescing into the feline form of her umbral spirit. Silently, Fade lifted her head then sprinted to the closest enemy, her fangs finding warped flesh and blood underneath. Naami started towards Shalkoc, her heart cold with worry at the Dragonborn's weakening cries. Struggling to keep her footing on the spasming floor, she got her first good look at her friend since the fight had begun. A breath of stale, reeking air caught in her throat; Shalkoc's scales were torn around deep gashes, he was covered in acid burns and wings had sprouted from his back, his last shield against the blows raining upon him. He could only defend himself, breathing in short gasps that spoke of broken ribs. His shoulders sagged, his legs trembled, and he looked ready to collapse.

Naami raised her arms, her spellwards catching a feeble red glow. She would not look away from her friend, would not blink, as if her gaze alone could keep him on his feet, grant him strength to stand long enough to be healed. She wove her spell, urging more strength into it, feeding it her life force. The magic resisted her efforts, refused her offering of blood. She did not stop to wonder why; Shalkoc's injuries were too severe. Naami released her spell with a flash of regret, knowing she could make it stronger if only it would obey her! As the restorative energy sank into her friend's body and mended the cracked bones, she knew. Her spellwards were protecting her. The cool metal on her skin, her father's hands on her wrists, keeping her from drawing such power that would consume her.

"Dad," she sobbed. "Thank you for watching over me. But I'm a big girl now."

"What are you talking about?" Plex said into her ear. "No time for sentimentality! We fight! Get closer, let me at them!"

The goblin bared his teeth in a snarl. Naami feared he might forget about magic altogether and simply bite holes into anything that came his way. She hoped her neck would not enter his calculations. Sickening tearing sounds told her that Emilio had found something to slash at. He was helped by Fade who jumped in and out of invisibility, appearing long enough to deliver an iron bite.

"Out with you," Aviana muttered, pulling the cursing eye out of the wall.

The eyestalk stretched, producing a shriek despite the absence of mouth, then snapped with a wet crack. She held up her trophy, one talon piercing the eyeball that dripped bloody jelly down her arm. She looked a hero with her giant size and triumphant pose, and at last the battle was ending as Emilio reduced a slithering mass of guts into a pile of gore, and Shalkoc delivered a final blow to one of the large abominations. The last one remained, bloodied appendages slamming down in a frenzy.

"Oh let's end this," Fearghas snapped. "Aviana, trust me?"

"Wha... of course!"

The harpy flashed a winning smile and a thumbs up, displaying the eye impaled on her talon. Fearghas heaved a sigh, then muttered a spell. Naami watched magic twist in his grasp; there was a darkness to it. She wanted to look away but made herself watch as the dark magic flied to Aviana, ripping gashes into her raised arm. She cried out as her blood gathered in mid-air, cradled by Fearghas' magic. It twisted, then crystallised into crimson spikes; in the blink of an eye, they plunged into the monster and tore it from where it stood. The sheer force of the magic drove the abomination to the far wall of the cavern, nailing it to the vertical surface.

"Hey! The walls are helping us!" The harpy said happily, ignoring her new wounds.

The far wall twisted next to the staked monster, ripping open into a mouth devoid of lips, possessing two rows of chipped teeth.

"No, we're not." The wall said, then the mouth spat frothing pink blood and closed, leaving a frayed line.

"Fearghas?" Naami squeaked. "What was that?"

"A spell," he said absentmindedly. "Nothing to write home about. Shalkoc, look here, in that pool."

Naami shivered. Nothing to write home about? Half of Bottleneck would have a fit if they heard about that spell. There was dark magic, and there was this. There was necromancy to stray close to the veil between this life and the next, only to be used to delay and deny death, or in self-defence to call death under threat to a witch's life. Those spells were not evil in nature, but as any magic or weapons, they became evil when used for evil ends.

This was blood magic, and all it could do was harm allies and enemies alike.

She looked at her friend differently then, and saw a darkness in his eyes, close below his usual grumpy but caring demeanour. There was greed, a bottomless pit of hunger as if the dwarf yearned with all his soul for something he would not speak of. In the hellscape of a powerful demon's lair that had been havoc on her nerves since she realised what it was, she knew chilling fear. The nightmarish cavern lurched around her and she stumbled, losing her footing. Searing pain attacked her legs when she splashed into the pool of acidic blood. Fighting the urge to vomit, she clambered up on the fleshy mass that jutted out of the pool, forming an island of sorts. Feeling her way up, she grabbed a bulbous growth that burst under her fingers. With a scream of disgust, she tumbled back and would have landed into the acid if not for Emilio's assistance. He offered a claw for her to grab on, his black eyes emotionless. She grabbed at his wrist to not slice her fingers on the razor-sharp claws, allowing him to pull her to safety. Shaking, Naami tried to catch her breath when a gentle voice spoke in her mind.

"How beautiful! Lending a helping hand really shows the good in you, the very essence of Nirvana."

The celestial's voice. Naami's mind snapped back to another cavern, ripping a sob from her throat. If she could only find them. This time, she knew better. She could heal them. She could save them. Atone. It would never wash the blood from her hands, from her soul, but maybe there would be fewer nightmares. Maybe she could sleep a night and not wake up screaming, seeing her hands covered in bloody entrails and maggots. Maybe there was hope this time.

"I'm scared," she said truthfully. "Where are you?"

She was hoping for an answer from the celestial, for any help in finding them, but her hopes were soon dashed.

"Shut up!" Emilio snarled next to her.

The voice answered neither. Could its owner even hear them?

"Hate to interrupt the voices in your heads," Plex said, "but there is stuff in there."

Naami turned her attention to the blood pool the goblin was pointing at. Scrubbing tears from her cheeks, she saw that both wizards had summoned spectral hands to search the acid.

Fearghas whistled. "There's a small fortune in there. How's that hoard of yours looking, Shalkoc?"

The Dragonborn beamed. "Can always use a top-up."

"Other things," Plex said, scooping up bits and pieces with his disembodied hand. "Scraps of fabric, from clothes? Yes, clothes... poor quality, pretty much rags. Chains. Broken items. Something over there that isn't dissolved yet."

"Same chains the Duergar put on their slaves in Ukgluz," Fearghas said darkly.

It all but confirmed Naami's theory; the Sibriex was not here by chance. Despite the damply warm air, she shivered. Slaves' chains in the lair. Null-Steel chains. Demon engines. King Dimzad's mentions of binding demons. Were the Duergar sending slaves to the Sibriex as payment? As material? All the twisted monsters they had slaughtered... The misplaced organs she recognised, from learning how to heal their injuries and illnesses... She found herself pressing her spellwards onto her skin, leaving marks on her wrists.

The stain on her bracelet.

The sooty Null-Steel chains.

Two large wings nailed to the ceiling by thick metal rods, only one still attached to their back. A once beautiful face forced to one side, roughly sewn to the shoulder from temple to jawline, the stitches infected and swollen. The right eye gone, replaced by a growth akin to a hornet's hive.

Naami ground her teeth against the scream building up in her throat. She could not... not now... not again... Focus! She made herself look at her companions and name them one by one. They needed her. She needed them. She could not lose herself to terror again. Fear would paralyse her, and lead her to the wrong choices.

Magic surged through her, for a second chasing away everything but the cleanest awe. Such power as she had only known in the most desperate situations, and without doubt this was one of them. She guided a flood of positive energy towards the ruined body in front of her. Power to close mortal wounds. Power to cure unknown plagues. Power to turn souls away from Pharasma's call. Eyes of pure light looked down on her, pity turning to fear. Then to sadness.

She wished she could scream now. She barely breathed. Her friends. Need. It had to end. She clutched her spellwards. Ildilas, surrounded by chaos. Mum, Dad. Even if they survived this, could she ever return home? Would the nightmares ever end?

End the fear.

Her friends' voices began to reach her, first in short bits, a word or two. Then she caught sentences. Shaking, Naami focused on the words, applying all of her willpower to listening and understanding. Fearghas repeated several times to Aviana that she was resistant to acid. Aviana protested, asking why she should be diving in. Emilio talked about time, and Shalkoc was rambling about numbers. A splash as the harpy dove in, excruciating wait, and she resurfaced holding valuables.

"A gold chain, a locket - also gold! And a robe. Shame it's not a dress, the embroidery would really compliment my wings."

"There is no way you're putting on a robe this size," Fearghas said in tones of long suffering.

"Why I never! Are you calling me fat!?" The harpy choked.

The dwarf rubbed his temples. "You're tall even without a potion of giant size. How exactly would you get your wings through this robe anyways?"

"Well, you know... I can have it modified for me!"

"Quicker to have a new one tailored for you. And it's hardly the time or the place for this kind of conversation!"

"He's right," Emilio said. "The longer we stay here, the more danger we are in."

"But there is so much money in there!" Shalkoc complained with a longing look to the pool of sizzling acid blood.

"We do not have time," Fearghas said, emphasizing each word.

"But my hoard?"

"No. Treasure is useless to the dead."

Realising that pleading would get him nowhere, Shalkoc gave a small sob. Aviana had handed the gold chain to Emilio at his request; the young man was gazing at the flawless fire opal set in it, oblivious to his surroundings. It was a beautiful stone, shades of orange giving the illusion of a flame frozen in time. His lips moved silently, his fingers just short of touching the smooth ornament.

"Come on everyone, let's continue," Fearghas said briskly.

With a start, the warlock tucked the piece of jewellery away. Aviana stuffed the robe and the locket into her pack. Shalkoc was the last to leave, reluctantly. The party picked a tunnel at random; there was no way to orient in the maze of foul corridors and even had there been landmarks, they would not stay in place. Naami followed, legs trembling and thoughts skittering. She kept her eyes down, focusing on her footing on the treacherous ground but that did not help her shut out the sounds. Groaning and rumbling told of spasming walls, which the ground also reflected. The noise increased until it was constant, forcing her to look up and ahead. Suddenly, her companions' half-heard concerns made too much sense. The walls ahead were closing in, near closing the narrow tunnel shut.

"I don't think we are running from that," Plex said pragmatically.

"We could stand and endure it," Aviana said with a flex of her muscles.

"And hope the tunnel opens up again?" Emilio said, voice full of doubt.

"That, or let ourselves be squeezed and pushed along," Fearghas said.

"I say we stand our ground," the harpy said.

As the party argued and the spasms came closer, Naami's mind grasped for an elusive piece of half-remembered information. The sounds filled her perception; what was it they reminded her of? Time was growing short. She had to remember. She could all but feel the pain in those cramps. Did this place... creature... thing... feel pain? Then it hit her.

"If we stand our ground we'll die!" She exclaimed.

The party looked at her questioningly.

"The way those walls move, it's like intestinal cramps," she said disgustedly. "These are severe, they can last several minutes. We'll be crushed."

"Not if I have a say on it," the dwarf said.

The closing walls were almost upon them. Fearghas took out a gem and smashed it; the now-familiar dome of force sprung into existence, just big enough to shield them all. And just in time. The fleshy walls squeezed on top of the group, pressing down on the transparent bubble. On all sides, diseased flesh and muscle twitched and clenched, burying the bubble in oozing tissue. Nobody spoke, watching, trusting the dome would hold. Tortured sounds filled the air, making Naami want to clutch her stomach. She had helped people suffering this kind of cramps, people who writhed on their beds. The toughest patients had howled with pain as disease ravaged their insides. She had despaired then, when her herbs had brought only minimal relief. She despaired now, when all light was swallowed by the moving walls. The world shrank to a pinprick of poisonous air smothered by flesh held at bay by a thin sheet of magic. Her head spun. If they survived this...

Would she ever see home again?

Her fingers twitched with a memory of magic that turned into the urge to channel. Healing. If only she could heal the source of this madness. What happened if she healed a demon? How would an embodiment of chaos and destruction react to a force of pure good? Although... healing magic was not good, was it? It could hurt. Heavens have mercy on her soul, it could kill. Would it be evil to kill the Sibriex? She knew the answer without dwelling on it. Naami had only ever killed when there was no choice, when it was her life or the enemy's. Except for that one time. The demon needed to die, and if she could, she would kill it.

With a shock, the halfling realised she was cowering next to Aviana and murmuring breathlessly "Kill it, kill it, kill it.". It required an effort to stop. The harpy looked down and beamed at her, giving her the thumbs up. Her talons were still bloody from piercing the eyeball. Naami's head spun; for a moment she did not know who she was. Did Aviana take this seriously? Did Shalkoc? Fearghas' earlier outburst made more sense with each passing moment. They had to stick together no matter what. The healer's hands shook; she blinked away the vision of blood and maggots. Killing the cause of such corruption and torture could not be an evil act.

Seconds trickled past, pooling into minutes. Naami shivered when she realised she had been right. It took all her willpower to stop herself from shaking. She had been right, and Fearghas had had a spell to deal with it. All would be well. They would live. She fought the urge to crouch; the ceiling was so close. She could not imagine how Aviana must feel; she had to bend her considerable knees. The harpy did not look anxious, and Naami could not decide whether it calmed her, or terrified her more. After what seemed like hours, the walls relaxed and expanded again, with slow reluctance as if there was a will at work, a creature that had tried to smother them. There probably was, at that. Or maybe this had just been the work of twisted magic and tortured flesh. Naami decided she did not want to know.

"Do you guys hear this?" Aviana said.

The tunnel was open, if not exactly wide, and Fearghas had dispelled the bubble. Another cloud of twisting darkness loomed just ahead, hurting Naami's eyes.

"Hear what?" Shalkoc said.

"Trickling," the harpy said. "Like water? It's getting louder."

There was no water in this warped place. Before she even heard the rushing of liquid coming closer, Naami knew.

Her wounds still ached under the fresh bandages, burns and scrapes, a few nasty bruises. Nothing too serious, unlike some of the Drow. She had patched them up as best she could, but some of those injuries needed a closer look and time to heal. Real rest. Naami was setting priorities in her mind when one of Lady Vandree's consorts shouted a warning. The walls quivered, then shook, then convulsed. The Drow drove their swords deep into the walls and Naami imitated them, pushing her dagger to its hilt in the repulsive wall. Just in time; a surge of reeking bile flooded the tunnel. Naami clutched her dagger in a death grip, but it was not her fingers that failed. The blade was made to her small hands, its bite not deep enough so it was torn from the wall before she could scream. The acid burnt her skin; she shut her eyes in terror, unable to breathe as she was dragged away by the corrosive torrent. She slammed into walls and tried to get her feet under her, only to get turned upside down. She could not breathe. She could not...

"No!" She screamed.

Her fear roared into sight, a wall of yellow-green liquid speckled with black and red; seething, diseased bile. Her hand went to her dagger, and fell to her side. It had not worked last time; why would it now? What could she —

The flood hit her full force, and she only managed to squeeze her eyes shut. In a second it had passed, leaving her trembling and stinging but otherwise unharmed. A yelp behind her made her spin around and she saw Fearghas and Emilio swept away. The dwarf was pushed onto a bend in the wall, where he grabbed hold of a jutting flap and held tight until he could stand again. The warlock had no such luck and was dragged screaming into the darkness. The world tilted around Naami, her vision going dark.

Pain returned first, heavy limbs and scathed skin. Then Naami realised the burning in her lungs was gone, and so was the sickening liquid that had submerged her. She could breathe again! Relieved, she took a deep breath, only to gag on a stench of rotting flesh and unspeakable things. Coughing and retching, she fought the nausea with all her might. Then she heard it, another sound filling the reeking space. She froze, stomach turning and eyes scanning the darkness, to no avail. It was unnatural, nothing like the gentle twilight or the mystery of deepest night. This darkness shone brighter than the midday sun, hurting her eyes and turning her blood to ice. It was... corrupted. Suffocating. Perverted. Twisted. EVIL.

Naami screamed herself out of her waking nightmare, calling out to Emilio. He did not answer but she had no way of knowing if he was already too far, or if he could not shout. What if he was unconscious? What if he had been swept far away, to a cavern filled with corruption and torture?

"Emilio!" She shrieked in terror.

Her chest hurt as if stabbed, yearning for the telepathic bond that would let her feel what her companions felt. It would hurt, but she would know. Being left to wonder and speculate... She thought having an arm torn off would not be a lot worse.

"He's hurting," Plex said on her shoulder. "He's been swept away and into a hole in the floor. A hole with teeth. Barely caught himself on one."

Of course, the others still had the bond! Cursing herself for not realising sooner, Naami asked details from the tiny wizard. She grimaced when he said Emilio's burns were severe, and more so when Plex mentioned an enemy close to Emilio. She had to get to him! Sharing her sentiment, Shalkoc dashed ahead, stumbling through the darkness. Naami reached out for her magic, for a simple spell to pierce the darkness. She had to make two attempts before she could weave the magic to suit her; the strands seemed to slip and escape her. She could not calm her mind. She had to find Emilio and heal him. If she could ride Fade... but she could only keep her in the world a short while, and her time was up unless she resummoned the spirit. No. She needed her magic to heal Emilio.

"Naami, I must offer my thanks for carrying me," Plex said with no prompting whatsoever.

"This is really not the time," she stammered.

"There is time while we walk. By we, I mean you. But here, a small token."

The goblin rummaged into his bag and handed her two minuscule bottles. As she took them and the magic affecting Plex lost its hold, the bottles grew to their normal size. It appeared to be wine, thick and dark so it was nearly black. Naami slipped them into her bag, ignoring the thoughts of bottled blood that had sprung up in her mind. Remembering Plex' insistence to uphold the balance of trade, she offered a torch in exchange; it would not help him see through the magical darkness, but she hoped the symbolism would count for something.

"Good year," Plex said as he sipped some of the syrupy wine.

How many bottles had he been carrying? Naami started in the direction Emilio had disappeared, through the cloud of magical darkness. It didn't hurt her eyes as badly now, and she could see through it, but her skin pebbled with discomfort at the thought of the corrupted magic touching her. Frightened fancies, she reprimanded herself. She prepared to weave magic into a pattern of healing, anticipating finding Emilio. If she could just get close...

Plex' magic intruded in her concentration. He was preparing an offensive spell, his demeanour more collected than Naami thought possible in this place. A sound just ahead gave the goblin the excuse he was waiting for and he released his spell, booming thunder and crackling lightning erupting in the darkness. It hit a monster, breaking its invisibility and knocking it to the ground but instead of dissipating, the magic lingered in a wide circle around Plex. Throat closing with dread, Naami cast out her magic sense. Another surge? The magic swelled like waves, an ocean just out of sight. It rumbled, an earthquake that did not touch the earth but shook the air and hummed in complex, ever-changing patterns. It howled like a silent wind, imperceptible to those lacking the gift but undeniable in its presence. It seized reality itself, making Naami's head spin. Plex went very still, in awe or excitement she could not tell. Tides of energy leapt about, a force driving the world, a fleeting sensation of wild colours and roiling chaos.

And light was no more.

Naami blinked, feeling for her darkness-piercing spell. It was still here; she sensed her magic on her eyes, but she could not see shapes nor light. A wall of complete blackness surrounded her on all sides no matter how she spun around. It did not hurt her eyes like magic-wrought darkness. It had nothing of the night, or the absence of light in a deep cavern. She was not being shielded from the light. There was no light.

She was blind.

She heard herself scream, a cry of uncontrolled despair, uncontrollable terror. Mentally she clawed at the magic that surrounded her, suffocated her. She could not see the strands of magic to cast a spell! She sensed the force of the wild magic on her and it was implacable, merciless in its strength. She had felt magic this powerful a couple times; she had cast the like herself, but only ever for healing. This was a curse with the strength to level a mountain range, or alter the flow of time. Her knees went weak, all sensation draining from her legs. She only remained standing thanks to Plex yelling in her ear.

"What's going on?" The goblin asked. "Get close! We need to help them!"

"I can't," she said, her voice distant in her ears. "I'm blind."

"You're not serious?"

She sobbed, unable to repeat the words. Plex shouted a direction and she stumbled forward, feet numb, her eyes uselessly open as wide as they would go. The voices of her companions started to drift to her from up ahead. A bend in the tunnel? Her hands shook, she was too terrified to even reach for the walls. Anything could come out of that and bite her, or grab her. She would have no warning.

"Please leave me alone," an unfamiliar voice cried. "Please I've been tortured so much. All my scales have been ripped out to make a cloak. Don't make me go back there. I don't want to go back in there!"

Then a groan, a cry, and a sound ominously reminiscent of Shalkoc's dragon breath, except Naami was sure it was not him. This sounded deeply wrong, a breath that tore out of a scorched throat.

"I'm sorry! I'm so sorry!" The voice cried again, rougher than before and ending abruptly.

"Emilio's down!" Fearghas shouted.

"Oh this is stupid," Aviana growled.

She had been guarding the rear, and now stomped towards the voices. There was a horrible tearing sound, wet like rotten cloth ripping. The smell of blood and decay, always present here, became so much sharper. A stomach-turning squelch, more ripping, and Aviana stomped away.

"W-where are you going?" Naami sobbed. "Don't leave me alone."

"You're not alone," Plex said. "Aviana broke through that wall. Over there! I'll guide you now."

How the fates had shifted, Naami thought, a tiny spark of irony in the terror threatening to consume her.

"Put Emilio in the flask!" Fearghas' voice. "He's not from this world right?"

"I'm pretty sure that will not work," Aviana said.

"I'll save him!" Shalkoc said.

Naami strained her ears, until the darkness in her eyes faded to the background. She heard weak coughing and choking, then Fearghas' incredulous voice.

"Did you feed him snot?"

"Ah!" Plex chimed in. "The Bagiennik's snot! Excellent for healing injuries."

"That's... real?" Naami asked.

Plex launched into a passionate description of the frog-like Bagiennik, growing very graphic on the topic of the abundant produce from their noses. A fascinating subject certainly, but Naami cared more for Emilio's condition. She heard gasping and gagging, then a voice unmistakably Emilio's, hoarse and feeble.

"Thank you..."

Relief flooded her mind and body. She steeled herself and followed Plex' directions, drawing her sharp dagger. She needed to see to make magic work, so the dagger would have to do if she was attacked.

"Naami! Shalkoc and Emilio are badly hurt!"

Fearghas' voice again. "I'm blind!" She shouted back. "It's a surge. Can't cast anything!"

"I will personally obliterate the Feywild. I'm sending them to you!"

Before Naami could ask what the wizard meant by "sending", she felt a tug in the weave of magic and heard her friends yelp in surprise, then Plex giggled.

"He opened a dimension door, and chucked them through it with his spooky magic hand," the goblin said.

Naami felt around her, praying to find her friends and not some disgusting piece of unidentifiable organic material. Her fingers brushed against Shalkoc's rough scales, and then Emilio's smooth cloak. Acting on instinct alone, she spun a web of restorative energy and pushed it towards them both, letting the positive force sink into their battered bodies. This close, she sensed their pain as her own, the agony of countless burns knotting their muscles into iron-hard tangles. Emilio was breathing heavily, swaying on his feet. Naami feared he would fall, but instead he transformed. With a deep growl, he assumed his void form and snapped his teeth shut as if he had bitten through something.

"There's one of the explode-y fellows," Shalkoc said in a strained voice. "The acid will splash all of us."

"Protect Naami. I'll kill it." A barely-human snarl from Emilio before he leapt to the attack.

Naami's heart froze. Her healing spell had barely done a thing, unfocused as she was fighting the panic born of her blindness. Did Emilio not feel pain? Did he not realise how serious his injuries were? He had been very near death a minute ago and he was jumping right back into the fray! Naami carefully avoided the obvious question, that of his sanity, which of course only made doubt loom larger in her mind. She promised to herself if they survived this nightmare, she would dose him with a brew so bitter he would think twice before rushing into danger. Oh, she knew what herbs to boil for this!

"Don't make me go there again! I don't want to go, not again please! I don't want any more mercy from that thing!"

The unfamiliar voice again, the last of his screams drowning into liquid sounds.

"Dragonflesh golem," Shalkoc said through gritted teeth. "So corrupted... part of that was a dragon, once. This is mercy."

Naami nodded, her stomach lurching. The creature's screams still rang in her ears, too near the screaming in her mind. Not again. Aviana roared in fury, a sound followed by a heavy thud and distorted shrieks. Another splash suggested this monster had suffered the same fate as the golem.

"Fearghas is using his... axe?" Plex said, horrified. For a wizard to be fighting with a weapon! "Hey Fearghas! Would you want to buy my potion of haste?"

Dwarven curses, then Fearghas retorted in a biting tone: "Plex, do you understand the concept of dying? This is no time to be trading! If you have a potion, fork it over!"

This apparently insulted Plex. With a sniff, the goblin used another of his infamous short-range teleportation spells. His weight gone from her shoulder sent Naami into panic. She called out, her voice shattering. Not again!

"I'm right here!" Plex squeaked, thankfully close by. "Take this!"

The ground quaked with one of Plex' gravity-altering spells. Monstrous shouts told Naami it had found its mark, but celebration was short-lived. There was a cry for Emilio to watch out, and the warlock's own shout was cut off.

"What happened to him?" Naami cried.

"Eaten," Shalkoc said, defending against more attacks.

"The acid will kill him!"

"Don't worry Emilio!" Plex interjected convincingly. "Stomach walls are not really walls. They are in fact creature parts, tissue if you will, so it makes sense that they don't block your vision! If you think on it, you can see even in there!"

Clearly it was enough to convince Emilio. In a sickening cacophony of slashing, slopping, and ripping sounds, the warlock clawed his way out of the creature that had swallowed him. A burst of acid hit Naami and Shalkoc; he merely grunted, but Naami was too slow to dodge. Acid gnawed at her arms and legs, making her howl in pain. She half-collapsed against Shalkoc and pushed herself off him to not hinder his movements. Her thoughts... would not work anymore. Magic? There was only burning.

"I am so done with this place," Emilio growled, panting with pain.

"You and me both," Fearghas grumbled.

An explosion, a hiss, and silence descended on the party. Naami stood paralysed, sobbing and shaking. She did not hear Fearghas until he was right in front of her.

"Don't move now," he said.

In a rustle of paper and an incantation, he ended the relentless itching from Naami's cloth allergy. Realising how bad it had been, she let out a shuddering breath. The crack of a spellgem, and her sight returned. She squinted in the sudden light, met with a horrifying landscape of blood draining through a maw in the ground and on the far shore of the emptying pool, an altar covered in strewn tools. The horror of the torturer's workbench was nothing next to her sight returning. She could have hugged Fearghas had she not been covered in acid.

"I could not see any of you," she cried. "I was so scared... so scared you would die..."

"We're all alive," the dwarf said gruffly. "Bad wounds, but we can take a moment to fix them up. We're going to have to. Something bad is waiting for us below."

Naami peered down the maw at the centre of the room but she was too far to see anything else than a hole descending into darkness. From the hole drifted a voice, the same she had heard in her mind so many times. Except this time it was not in her thoughts.

"Welcome."

A warm, earnest invitation. She swallowed hard. The celestial was down in the place that had made the golem scream; the place Emilio nearly fell into.

"We need a moment," she said faintly.

Nobody argued. She set to patching up Emilio's injuries; most were severe burns and he winced when she treated them. He did not cry out or protest, which somehow made her sad. Fearghas handed out healing potions while Aviana carefully scouted the room, bringing back items she found by the altar. When she brought back a heavy skin-bound tome, Fearghas' eyes lit up with the same hungry glint Naami had seen before. It lasted only a moment as he examined the tome, muttering arcane terms under his breath.

"Emilio should have the cloak," Shalkoc said. "I can defend in Turtle Stance, but his style is all-out attack."

The Dragonborn handed over a black cloak made of overlapping scales. In Naami's mind, a twisted cried echoed; _All my scales have been ripped out to make a cloak._ She tried and failed to push it out of her mind. It didn't matter, she told herself. If Emilio was better protected, then he should have it. It was mercy on that poor soul; it had been far too corrupted for saving.

She worked in silence, avoiding the middle of the room as she treated her friends' injuries and her own. Fearghas put up his protective bubble once more.

"About that haste potion?" Plex began, then swallowed the rest of his sentence under Fearghas' withering glare.

"I'll trade you for it," Emilio said.

He reached into his pack, grimacing as the motion pulled on his wounds. Gingerly, he pulled out a small wooden figurine.

"My chicken!" The goblin screamed, half disbelieving and half delighted.

Emilio held the carved bird out of Plex' reach, which was easy considering his diminutive size, though somewhat pointless if he decided to teleport.

"The chicken for the potion," he said.

Plex accepted immediately, handing out the potion to accept the last survivor of his chickens. Emilio handed the potion to Aviana.

"We'll need you in the front line," he said. "Don't want anything in exchange."

The harpy accepted and slipped the potion into a belt pouch, in easy reach. Amid the carnage of corpses and acid, on the shore of the drained blood pool, the party settled to gather their strength for the upcoming battle. This one would decide their fate.

pages.name: 77 - Cookies and threats
pages.content:
While the rest of us are safe in the Chateau de MacAllistar sipping tea and eating cookies, Aviana and Plex are still in the Sibriex lair, fighting for their lives. They do a very respectable amount of ripping and tearing until it's done, and find loot equal to 1700 gold (850gp each). Their resources all but spent, they are attacked by a giant ooze that… promptly dies by melting away as it moves, flooding the entire hall in blood and bile and other disgusting things. (This is when Aviana gets Fearghas' message spell, as she was waist-high in that ichor with Plex on her shoulder.)

They get to one closed butthole and ponder how to get out. Aviana ponders tearing it a new one, literally, but decides against it and tries to pry open the existing one. It does not work out, as she is too grossed out, and attempts to use Plex as a towel to avoid touching it. Plex is at 8 HP. He has some ideas, none of them good. He settles on Prestidigitation, which triggers an irrelevant minor surge, to clean up Aviana so she doesn't use him as a towel. Plex hands Aviana a slice of cloth cut from a tent, from the time we first met Emilio.

Plex casts Pulse Wave to force the butthole open. They exit the lair into pitch-black water. Below them is a mountain of waste from the lair; some things within are shimmering. There are 3 pyropes and 3 jades, which Plex grabs with his mage hand. Because of the earlier surge that teleported Fearghas to the Plane of Water, both Aviana and Plex know where Fearghas is, and they know where his manor is. Plex casts a Dimension Door to the surface, but Aviana doesn't fit through it, not just because she is too big but also because Plex is too small (he is still tiny).

Aviana grabs Plex, who chugs snot to survive her Vice Grip. This circumvents the issue with Dimension Door, and they teleport to the surface. Plex would 100% have died without the snot. They swim ashore; they know where to go, but must be sneaky about it to not be taken for runaway slaves by the Duergar again. They are immediately spotted by two Duergar who call out to them.

Plex stands on Aviana's shoulder and says hello, which confuses the Duergar because they can't see the tiny Plex. He says he wants to get into Ukgluz to meet a friend. The Duergar demand to know what they were doing, and who owns them. Plex guesses he is owned by Mannon, who is not there at the moment. The Duergar call for reinforcments. Plex requests to be grabbed by Aviana again, and casts Vortex Warp at 4th level on himself to teleport into Ukgluz.

This of course attracts a lot of attention and soon 15 guards are running after them. Plex panics, casts Fey Step and teleports 20ft to the East. Fearghas' Plex-sense is tingling; he gets a splitting headache out of nowhere, sends a Message to Aviana, who screams in answer. Fearghas gets The Look (tm) on his face as he says Plex and Aviana are running amok in the city, and he needs to go and get them. We all go out to look for our… friends.

We soon hear a commotion three streets over, of a now-normal-size harpy running like Jack Sparrow shouting "What did I do? Stop chasing me!". She runs into a market stall, prompting more screaming that guides Fearghas and the rest of us towards them. Plex pockets a piece of cloth, Aviana runs into soot and her face is now black. She spots Fearghas dashing towards her with The Look (tm) on his face. Aviana is chased by 20 guards shouting to stop these runaway slaves. Plex teleports him and Aviana a short distance.

Fearghas says "play along" and cracks both of them on the head with his staff, shouting at them. I try to stop the violence, to no avail. Emilio nods like this is the most reasonable thing. Fearghas apologises to the Duergar and makes a good show of a repentant master. The Duergar are visibly losing brain cells, and say that they will have to report this and Fearghas is to show up at the court house by tomorrow for the report.

The Duergar insists that Fearghas puts his slaves in chains, so Aviana says she brought her own chain and pulls out a regular chain, a pair of manacles, and finally the Null-Steel chain. Fearghas chains Aviana up with the regular chain, and Plex with the Null-Steel chain, and we head back into the manor the moment the guards have their backs turned. Fearghas hesitates to unchain Plex, who is very confused about the Duergar (he has never met them directly). Fearghas explains. Plex is confused as to who Fearghas can't be the slave.

Aviana is stuck in the steel chain and calls Fearghas for help. Kyrin meets Aviana for the first time as her face is black with soot. Fearghas cleans her up with Prestidigitation, and makes the introductions with Kyrin. I hand Aviana a cookie and gain inspiration, yay!.
