The Fire Giants are the first who ever treated Imix with respect, and they are the closest he has to family. He says Shalkoc doesn't even know his true form. Shalkoc says he was alone a lot, doesn't know his parents, his master died… Imix seems sad, then asks if Shalkoc has ever met someone else who can fly despite not being born with wings, or breathe fire despite not having fire glands. We say friendly words to Shalkoc, as his "chosen family". Shalkoc mentions Ivernia, which bamboozles Imix. Taking care of the spawn of another colour?!

"Stop mocking me," Imix growls when Shalkoc says Imix is special for not having wings. Dragons who didn't fit their progenitor's image were culled. "You ask me to reveal my form to you, when you hide in the shadows," Imix says when Kyrin asks. Send nudes. It sounds very wrong, but Kyrin reveals her true form as Imix consents to reveal his. She compliments him as a handsome dragon and asks permission to give him a gentle pat. "Don't burn yourself," he growls. "Sometimes, family sucks," she says. She does burn her hand.

I start towards Kyrin to offer help, but the massive dragon scares me… Imix taunts me for being afraid, so I plant my feet and cross my arms and defiantly claim I'm not afraid. Imix asks for Shalkoc's name, and he launches into a tirade that makes Fearghas facepalm with a loud clank. Somehow Emilio's patron is laughing. We also admit we swore an oath to Loki to break this siege, but for all that… we don't want to kill Imix. Then there is the matter of Rovagug's prison. We speak about the gods and their squabbles, but they are not likely to let Rovagug escape.

We ask Imix if he would let us return here, unharmed. He says of course, he never denied passage to pilgrims. We… saw evidence of this. I feel even worse about our intruding now… Shalkoc even offers to give the items we looted back, but Imix doesn't want them back, he only ever wanted peace. There is a teleportation circle at the end of the bridge, we can use it to come back here. Fearghas says we will talk with Loki about the conquest of Muspelheim, but warns Imix that Loki will want something in return. Imix does not care who rules over the Fire Giants; Narsund or Loki. Our oath is only to break the siege, and this can happen in a variety of ways.

We could try to resolve this war, by giving both sides a higher priority. If the gates were to be sealed again, this war would be over. Fearghas knows where the gates are, and how they work. They will be guarded, and closing them would break our alliance with the Frost Giants. Fearghas is starting to fear he might have to go give his god a stern talking-to and end his squabbling with Surtr. If Rovagug's chain was to be reforged, Surtr would have an immense incentive to end the war between giants, to protect his people.

Grumbling, Fearghas resolves to go to Torag and make him listen, which pleases Imix. Completely unrelated to all this, we speak about the Eye of Dahak driving the King of Lessia mad. Imix struggles to comprehend we, of all people, broke the Key to the World. Fearghas explains it was Aviana. "What, the chicken and the snack?" Imix laughs. "Just the chicken, really," Fearghas says. Imix coils up for story time. Fearghas tells about Dahak tearing up Deadlight looking for Vrazzak. Later on, we found out Dahak had died, and much evidence pointing to Vrazzak being his murderer. Fearghas comes to the eye poisoning the mind of his king, and our inability to help.

Now the Matron of House Vandree made off into the Astral Sea with the Eye of Dahak and uh we don't know what to do. Imix says it must be Dahak's left eye, housing the spirit of Tiamat, and the only way to balance this is to expose the king to Bahamut's influence from Dahak's right eye… likely in Vrazzak's keeping. The plot clumpens. (I've been writing this lore as we go and it's kind of incredible when I think of it. So much story! Wow! I even feel inspired somehow…)

Imix asks where in the Material Plane we are from. We say Erastrea, sort of, close enough for me really, still the Old World eh. Deadlight was in the New World, most of it still is, Shalkoc just happens to have a chunk of it which we now call Promise. When Imix mentions the Ashur Plateau, Kyrin asks about the Redwind Sands and what may be buried here. I recall lore we read in the tower in Jotunheim, and Imix says the Redwind Sands used to be a lush valley home to Yuan-Ti.

Kyrin's Dragon Compass can grant us safe passage with the Fire Giants. Imix asks for proof that Fearghas' claims are true. Aviana being in the Feywild, we decide to prove our claims with the means of a spell, Candle's Insight. I explain its effects and cast it, and Fearghas and Shalkoc speak again to Imix, with the flame remaining steady all the while. Imix tasks us with speaking to Torag, and then returning to him. I offer to return Imix' followers to life, but he laughs and say they would not want to return from a death earned in battle. I say we will then carry their honour with us.

Fearghas talks MAD shit about Kyrin to Imix, then tries to herd us out of here. She gives Imix the locket which captured her saving Shalkoc from his linguistically inclined surge. Fearghas contacts Frengald with a Sending, telling him to pull back his forces, the siege isn't breaking. Imix appreciates the present, and says a good conversation is also a treasure. He is becoming friends with Kyrin and I'm standing here with tears in my eyes this is so wholesome aaaaaaaa. Anyways.

Emilio asks about dragons in the Void. Imix says the Void corrupts any who look into it, and not everyone gets out of it with a mutually beneficial situation. Well eeeeeh Emilio's case is a bit more complicated than that, considering the absolute state of his village. Imix advises Shalkoc he can't run from what he is, from who his ancestor is. "Try living like a green dragon more; you're on your way to discovering your true draconic nature, your true form. Look inwards, find out how green dragons work." This shows the path to Shalkoc's Mythic Dragon 3!

We say goodbye to Imix, and Kyrin's shadow gives him a little wave before we leave. Fearghas impatiently makes us all hold hands and casts Plane Shift, taking us all to Promise.

pages.name: 93 - summary
pages.content:
Suspicious winking, Fearghas give me strength

Plex and Aviana argue about the best way to bathe in blood, disagree of course, and as Aviana chokes Plex they both teleport away. A normal Monday.

Kyrin scouts the way to a room bursting with treasure. As we join her, Shalkoc's eyes nearly fall out of their sockets, but the moment we touch something we are yanked away and teleported to another room, where we promptly begin to fall towards lava. I do a little screaming, we fly and teleport to safety. Emilio breaks an altar with the power of a nat 1, Shalkoc licks one of the sarcophagi, tastes dusty. I say we should let the dead rest, so naturally Fearghas opens the sarcophagi and out come two skeleton boys.

We have a chat in Draconic, the skeleton boys are confused and want Shalkoc to bleed one of his slaves (that's us) on the altar to open the doors. Shalkoc says slavery is bad, we sharply remind the skeletons they are dead. Shalkoc wanted to bleed himself on the altar while I heal him, and was trying to convey this in a wink. No. That's a no.

Since we spilled no blood on the altar, the metal gates are closed. I offer to use my shadow magic to scout, as it allows me to slip under the gates. And… dragon. Just a skeleton? I'm convinced it's actually an undead. I find a way out and we decide to go for it, but the problem of how to open the door remains. Naturally we blast the door with extreme violence, waking the Dragonbone Golem.

After a short fight and a linguistically inclined surge (ask Kyrin what languages she can speak now), Fearghas siphons alchemical components off the golem and we proceed to — gasp! — a puzzle room. With some trial and error and a lot of jumping, we find the answer thanks to the magic of symmetry and imagining Fire Giants splashing in the lava. The puzzle room has 3 exits leading to the obvious boss room, the dragon hoard, and a library.

Fearghas herds us to the library where we find many spell scrolls and delicious lore in a book called The Birth of the Soul. We hop to the dragon hoard and loot the living daylight out of it, taking absolutely everything. A lot of money, rocks for spellscribing, and some magic items. One of them can only be used by a sorcerer, yoink. Emilio acquires the power of sniffing.

Before entering the boss room, a divine voice advises us to rest. Fearghas and me exchange glances, we're not getting our spell slots back anyway? We realise everyone else is VERY out of resources and if we run into a big fight now without Plex and Aviana, we will certainly die. Fearghas puts up the bubble and I use the Wand of Catnap to put Kyrin, Emilio, and Shalkoc to sleep. We try to talk over the snoring, it does not go well. As our companions sleep, the boss checks in on us all casual-like, a column of flame capable of seeing into Leomund's Tiny Hut. T-that must be the fire god Imix.

We saunter into the boss room. Rovagug's chain is right here! Then Imix appears and we start talking, very tensely because we just stole all of his stuff and murdered his people. Unsurprisingly, Imix is a dragon who cloaks himself in flame. Kyrin reveals her true form, and encourages Imix to do the same; we see he was born without wings and he tells us he was nearly killed because of it, as the dragon aspect cull their unwanted spawn.

I talk everyone's brains off with lore in the telepathic link, making the DM happy. We speak about the dragon aspects, Imix speaks to Shalkoc as one dragon to another. Shalkoc hopefully asks if he can be turned back to black, with confuses Imix; he thought Shalkoc had gone from white to green, on account of him being so hungry.

We talk with Imix for several hours, and he warms up (haha) to us, to the point he accidentally burns Kyrin's hand when she gives him a pat. She becomes best buds with the dragon, and we promise Imix to go speak with the gods (Surtr and Torag) so they stop squabbling among themselves and reforge the chains into Rovagug's prison. We hope this would encourage the Fire Giants' god Surtr to end the war with the Frost Giants, granting Imix the peace he so desires.

A few closing words:

  • Imix referred to Aviana and Plex as "the chicken and the snack". His words not mine, don't shoot the messenger.
  • We need to find the other eye of Dahak to try to cure the king of Lessia of his madness
  • The Ashur Plateau south of the Drakengard Mountains is a plateau because Dahak threw a tantrum and sliced off a mountain
  • Imix advises Shalkoc to be more like a green dragon, unlocking his mythic rank 3!
  • Kyrin receives a secret message just as we teleport away, I'm sure this doesn't contain any plot points

pages.name: 94 - Goblin chaos and dwarven prophecy
pages.content:
Monday, 16th of Undecimus, 1497

17:30

Meanwhile, in the Feywild.

Plex and Aviana land by Mennon's mansion, which is completely consumed by the Grey. They wander into the library, to which Plex was granted access to before… except for one room. They get into the forbidden room, where Plex picks up a spell scroll of Ambling Abode. They also find a heavy tome with a large eye on the front cover. The eye opens tiredly and goes "Oi! Get your dirty fingers off me!" The book refuses to open until its wish is granted. The book has seen the world fade to grey before, and contains records from that time.

The book's wish is to see a play of "The Fall of the Gith" but played by an all-Flumph cast.

Plex agrees to fulfil the book's wish, and picks it up. He teleports to Elsewhere, a region in the Feywild, but he lands elsewhere from Elsewhere and finds a party of hungry partying satyrs who want to grill a goat. They task Plex to acquire a goat. Plex finds a goat the size of an elephant, Aviana wrangles it, a goblin's voice comes from the mane of the goat. The goat-riding goblin Nailix is of Plex' tribe, and he used to bully Plex some time ago but he's mellowed out and is now a proficient goat-wrangler who performs in rodeos.

Plex promises to show Nailix a mountain goat. Nailix is not impressed, mountain goats are softies, don't you want a mount that is always trying to throw you off? He's got a point, Aviana says. Plex teleports Nailix on top of one of the satyrs, the goblin grabs his horns with expertise, the satyr tries to throw him off. Nailix is hanging on one-handed, holding his cow-boy hat in the other hand (goat-goblin hat?). Aviana captures the Elephant-Goat into the Iron Flask. She grabs the satyr Nailix is riding in one hand, Plex' neck in the other hand, and LEGS IT.

The hungry satyrs are too drunk to chase them. Nailix is having the time of his life; the satyr is not. Icky green booger-like things stick to Aviana's legs, which Plex recognises as the territorial markings of Snotlings; goblinoids who keep the frog-like Bagiennik as pets. Aviana is pissed off at the snot sticking to her feathers. She chokes Plex, who defends himself by saying "Look where you're running!". Wise advice under any circumstances, maybe not super helpful here. Aviana strangles Plex to within an inch of his life as he tries to scrape snot off of her for a late-night snack. As Plex is about to pass out, Aviana stops, causing Nailix to complain and request more running.

Aviana pours water over herself to try to wash off the snot, and tells Plex to teleport to Promise or something?! "Oh yeah," Plex answers and licks Aviana's feathers to heal himself. She yanks open the transdimensional door somehow and they end up on Promise, Nailix looking extremely entertained as Plex is shaking him so he drops the satyr.

We teleport in to this exact scene: Aviana covered in green slime, trying to shake off a licky Plex, holding the horn of a satyr in the other arm. A goblin is holding the other horn of the satyr, both of these are very confused. Aviana questions the satyr in Sylvan, he is still very drunk and does not make sense. Fearghas casts Prestidigitation to get the slime off Aviana, to Plex' despair. Kyrin asks if Aviana tastes like chicken.

Emilio tries to intimidate Nailix, but he can't stop laughing by the power of a natural 1. "Don't worry," the goblin says, "it happens to a lot of my fans when they meet me!" Emilio Eldritch Blasts the goblin, Plex launches Nailix 20 feet into the air, Aviana jumps in front of the goblin to protect him. Plex jumps with his rockets in front of the goblin to protect him from Aviana and her cursed Thunderfeet. Fearghas grumbles a Counterspell to stop Emilio's Eldritch Blast. Aviana lands, exploding from her boots (which hurts the satyr's head) but Plex falls down, somehow maintaining concentration on Telekinesis and holding Nailix in the air.

"As much as I'd like to, you can't just kill people like that," Fearghas grumbles to Emilio. He reluctantly welcomes Nailix to Promise and invites him to join the goblins' quarters. Nailix wants to continue riding goats, Fearghas threatens to let Emilio kill him if he causes trouble, Aviana says "but we have a goat right here" and releases the Elephant-Goat from the flask. Fearghas asks why there is now a giant goat in the room. The goat locks eyes with Fearghas, who gets roasted by the Bag of Scolding as he pulls out the Wardstone. Yep, the goat is hostile. It charges at Fearghas, slams into his armour with a deafening clang, and the goat sags to the ground confused. It has never had a headbutting contest with a dwarf before…

Fearghas realises he has earned the respect of this goat, as it submits to his superior stability. "Stay," he says to the goat. The goat stays. Fearghas prestidigitates a cold shower over the drunk satyr to sober him, and asks if he can get back to the Feywild. "Do you get along with dryads?" Kyrin asks. "Yo dryads are the hottest shiiiieeet," the satyr says. Please please please we are not introducing him to Joline, she will MURDER him. Kyrin takes him to Joline, dragging him by the horns. Fearghas retreats to the cabin for a stiff drink, shouting "Heel!" to the Elephant-Goat.

Emilio and me follow Fearghas to the cabin, him because he got a spicy headache from this entire debacle, me to make sure Fearghas doesn't drink himself halfway to death. Kyrin is talking the satyr out of drinking, he is trying to hit on her and falling asleep. Then he begins to bellow "songs" in the forest, making all the birds flee. Joline is not happy to see the satyr (that's an understatement). She tells Kyrin about fast-fermenting fruit in the Feywild, which made the satyrs and the goblins best friends (on account of keeping them drunk). Her point: if the satyr is drunk enough, he'll get along with the goblins. Just do not let him, or any satyr, get sober.

"What's a sober satyr like, then?" Kyrin asks. "Well alcohol has a reverse effect on satyrs, the drunker they are, the clearer their minds are," Joline explains. That… makes no sense, yet explains a lot. Kyrin takes the satyr to the goblin quarters; they've been busy brewing and are very happy to get a satyr friend. Kyrin gives them stern words of warning to leave the goats alone for the gods' sakes. The goblins are weirded out, then ask if this is about Nailix. Yes this is about Nailix. "Baa means no," they say, and add they will need to talk to Plex.

The goblins request snot from Kyrin, as it is "valuable and nourishing". She goes very green so the goblin ask what she does with her boogers. Kyrin shows them how to shoot a snot rocket, and they are disappointed she lets them go to waste. The goblins dig for gold in demonstration that the further up you go, the better they taste! They have a conversation about beer, giants, and dragons. "Dragons are cringe as fuck," the goblins claim and Kyrin leaps to her new friend's defence. "Imix is hot!" Goblins claim dragons all eat sweets, not people.

Kyrin casually says "I have a castle we could drop the sponges on." The goblins are interested. She explains about the feodal lord's bully of a son Antoine from the Green Sea. We all meet in the cabin with the Elephant-Goat just outside, looking in through the window. Fearghas is avoiding the goat's gaze while draining his 5th tankard under my worried supervision. Kyrin is taunting him about the goat. Fearghas tells Plex and Aviana about Imix (while Plex is lighting a previously-eaten jade on fire). He explains our plan to talk to Torag and potentially Surtr so they will reforge Rovagug's chains, without breaking the party's oath to Loki to break the siege.

We discuss Mennon, Plex' boss. Aviana recounts their latest adventure in the Feywild just before they appeared back here. They mention Buttercup the Fey dragon, whom Plex assumes will help us talk to the Void dragon. Fearghas and Emilio lose their minds trying to explain to Plex that 1) the Void dragon is not his friend and 2) the Void dragon wants to kill him and likely all of us too. Kyrin asks if I can revive someone who has been eaten. I've never tried… and I would rather not find out, honestly.

Plex mentions talking to a door in Mennon's palace, then takes out his brand new sentient book. The eye looks around, then orders Plex to turn him around so he can see the rest of the place — not so fast I'm getting dizzy! The book is confused because we're not Flumphs. I explain about Flumphs, which I've seen before in the Underdark, hanging around Aboleth lairs. At Plex' asking, the book says it contains pictures made of crushed pixies. Oh dear… can't wait to find out this book is filled with stories like Aviana enjoys reading.

I ask Fearghas for some ale, it might help. He slides me a tankard. Cheers, friend. Kyrin says we can ask Claude in Heaven about the play. Plex suggests naming a lot of goblins "Flumph" so they can perform the play, as goblins breed rather quickly. "Nonono don't tell your friends to start breeding immediately!!" Fearghas yells at Plex (who spelled this particular adverb "emidiatly" and this needs to be documented). The book says it was written by a Gith. "What's a Gith?" Kyrin asks. The book explains, and Fearghas adds a Silent Image showing a Gith he's met before. "They were assholes," he adds.

"Have you seen how thick I am??" The book asks, then tells Plex to put him down, all this moving is making it dizzy. Kyrin is asking the book some questions, offensive ones apparently. Or the book just has a foul temper. Plex is burning a 4th-level spell to make a bookshelf. Fearghas is phoning "our boy in Heaven" Ezeriel with Contact Other Plane to check on the weather so to speak, is it a good time, any hellish sieges going on? And does Heaven have Flumphs, Plex asks as he tries to drag in a tree. "Leave the tree outside!" Fearghas says. "But I want to build a bookshelf," Plex says. "Do that outside!"

Plex concludes there are better bookshelves in Heaven and casts Planetrotting, teleporting us all and the sentient book to Threshold. Thankfully, the Elephant-Goat is not transported to Heaven. Miraculously, Plex is on target and we end up in the correct plane. While Plex is casting his spell, I ask Fearghas about the planar quake, the Key to the World, and Vrazzak. In this deathly serious conversation, Plex and Aviana begin yapping in Sylvan. Fearghas grumbles the spell Comprehend Languages and immediately regrets it.

We speak about Vrazzak and what he may do in his madness. Undeath is wrong and makes anyone mad… "Hmm," Fearghas says. Aviana complains about having to hold hands with Plex while casting the spell, and wants to holds hands with Emilio.

I ask about the Giants' war and why the Frost Giants are invading. Fearghas explains he opened the gate as a part of a deal with Loki to free Aviana's tribe from servitude. Ah so this entire conflict… was caused by the party. Okay. Well the Giants wanted to throw hands long before the party got involved. We talk about Imix and the Dragon Aspects, Shalkoc falls down the stairs, Plex' spell finally goes off and we appear in Heaven!

We're taken to registration and Shalkoc is mulling over his conversation with Imix, wondering how to behave more like a green dragon. He has no idea how green dragons behave. Sometimes I forget Shalkoc can read and Plex cannot… Plex reminds us he got a wild magic surge that causes any door he walks through to slam shut and become locked. Oh no… We kindly ask Aviana to punt him through Heaven's Gate so he is not technically walking through.

Shalkoc does surprisingly well in the angel's questioning; his 5 bodyguards were already waiting outside and are disappointed but proud when he gets a level 3 guidance. "They grow up so fast," they cry. Kyrin fist-bumps with Huey, Dewey, and Louie on the way. Fearghas asks about getting an audience with Torag about the chains of Rovagug, and we are directed to Shaik. We drop by the library on the way to ask Claude if he can research "The Fall of Gith" for us. He can, but it will take 18 days and should be done on Friday 4th of Duodecimus. Kyrin asks him for any lore on the Mistborne Isles, as she suspects Imix meant to mention that area of the world. Just before we teleported, he telepathically told her "That reminds me of Rasa. I haven't seen him since he went into the mist—".

We discuss what drugs each plane of existence is running on. Hell is definitely running on coffee and the Abyss on meth. Mechanus is on Adderall. Hades on antipsychotics. Nirvana on weed. Heaven is just sniffing incense. How in the world did we even get to this? Ah we glimpsed a book in the library… this is cannon now.

Leaving the library proves to be an issue, as the door is locked because of Plex. We eventually unlock the door and climb to Shaik's office. She asks how we've been, says she is proud of us for dealing with the Hell issue. I'm getting tears in my eyes… Fearghas talks about the chains of Rovagug, and our need of an audience with Torag. She says she will speak to the Chalkost, Torag's honour guard. I ask Shaik if I could speak to Master Clementiel. She says all the healers are very busy, and she will let him know. I thank her, it means a lot to me.

We bid farewell to Shaik, and go fetch a pumpkin spice latte for Aviana because she is basic, then head to the Pilgrim's Path. We walk up the mountain and it gets colder, the path soon covered in a thin layer of snow. The path becomes a cobbled road and as we enter Torag's realm in Venya, the third layer, we receive the Forgefather's Blessing, the realm effect of this place.

Forgeheart is a beautiful place with holds carved into the mountains and snowy valleys. Fearghas sighs, "It's beautiful." We feel inspired to do smithing work, except Aviana, her wisdom modifier is too low. The celestials here are living like dwarves, and the architecture is exactly the dwarven style Fearghas knows. He is very satisfied to have his certainty confirmed, Dwarvenkind number one. We meet one of the Chalkost, Bergi Ironfinger, who says she has received the message from Shaik. She asks whether we've forgotten the rules by which Forgeheart abides. Ummmm… Apparently we need an invitation from Torag himself, a forgehammer of pure oathgold called Torag's Toil. Striking the gate of the first forge with this hammer will open the gate.

A shrine to Torag consists of at least an anvil and a hammer. Upon receiving an invitation from Torag, the hammer on a dwarf's shrine will turn into gold. If we are seeking an audience though, we can be brought to the Forge of Visions where we may receive a vision of what our task is. This will be for Fearghas exclusively, as he is the only one of us who worships Torag. On his way there, Fearghas notices an absence of breweries and… alcohol in general really. He asks Bergi, who replies "There is no indulgence here, the dwarves who would miss the taste of ale even in their afterlife would go to Elysium instead, where the god of brewing has his domain." Yeah, makes sense.

At the Forge of Visions, Fearghas is instructed to take a hammer, close his eyes, and start smithing. Despite not being a proficient smith, he falls into a trance. He wakes up to a scythe of blackened steel, nonmagical but covered in runes to contain evil, and words heard in his vision:

When madness grips the noble heart,

The flame of hope shall soon depart.

Into the east, where mountains mourn,

Where past in mist and shadow lorn.

Beneath the earth, in death it rests,

In ruined halls, on shattered crests.

Dear child of stone, to claim the hold,

Thou must wield wisdom, cursed and old.

Take heed and ward thy golden soul,

Lest thy dark might consume thee whole.

A very ominous weapon, unlike anything other worshippers have crafted here… I wonder how far east we should go? Bergi seems a little shaken as she returns with Fearghas. Plex is screaming the verbal component of Chain Lightning. I prepare to tackle him but he doesn't seem to be performing any somatic components. Emilio's eyes glow with power, I know that look, that's a Counterspell readied. Aviana innocently (?) asks if she would get kicked out of Heaven if she kicked someone into a mountain. Asking for a friend. Eye twitching, Fearghas glares at Plex. "You don't know this spell, why are you screaming the words?" Plex replies "I know, can you teach me?" Fearghas says, "Absolutely not."

Fearghas shares his vision with us and assumes we should go to the Mountains of Mourning. Well that is certainly in the East… far in the East… Kyrin suggests asking Imix about it, so Fearghas again ritually casts Contact Other Plane, this time to contact Imix. He asks if he knows about any lairs of Vrazzak's in the Mountains of Mourning. Hm the signal with Muspelheim is not great… "Aviana, hoist me up! Oh! I've got it!" Imix doesn't know. Kyrin asks about the rest of the phrase Imix said to her when we got teleported away, but the spell doesn't allow for more than a few words.

I ask Fearghas to relay a question to Imix; "Does "the flame of hope" mean anything to you?" I'm half-expecting it to just be a metaphor, but Imix responds with "platinum". Well that's definitely unexpected… We can't take a long rest until Thursday so we have 3 days to kill. And there is the small matter of the full moon on Friday night, oh dear. We decide to return to Threshold to kick back, and hopefully I'll be able to speak to Master Clementiel.

We thank Bergi and walk back down the Pilgrim's Path while Plex is desperately trying to teleport his way out of taking a long walk. Plex messes up, find himself on the wrong side of Heaven's Gate and has to go through registration again. Verita asks him why he has to slam the doors so violently behind himself, this is no place for violence… Plex says he got a wild magic surge, and Verita arranges for someone to follow him around 24/7 and unlock doors that slam shut behind him with the means of a Silence and Knock spells. Along the Pilgrim's Path, we see beautiful crystalline flowers and some made of metal by the Chalkost. Kyrin politely asks if she may take one of each kind. She meets some confusion but receives permission and very happily picks two flowers.

We arrive in Threshold tired after our long walk, and find Plex in the baths with a pumpkin spice latte. He calls out a happy "Hello!" and I can feel Aviana's murderous urges. We discuss the prophecy Fearghas received and Kyrin suggests using the Sheeshah of Revelations to get more clues.

Master Clementiel messages me with a Sending spell, and I ask to meet up with him to talk about Lioriel. I ask whether his soul should not have returned to Heaven. Clementiel doesn't know why his brother's soul hasn't returned to Heaven; he trusts things are well, and it's not his place to question how these things work, souls don't necessarily return immediately or with their memories intact. I understand but… if Lioriel can be found, I'd like to try. Much as my guilt over causing his death is still very much alive, I want to help him if I can.

Fearghas offers to scry for Lioriel in Heaven and on the Material Plane; when we return to Promise I could also ask Kali to cast the spell for me. Fearghas takes out a crystal ball as a divination focus, and casts Scrying in Heaven, holding the feather I found after escaping the Sibriex lair. The spell fails.

We return to Promise via anchorchain the following day. Fearghas wants to scry on Dahak with the help of a Minor Illusion. The spell bounces off as if the target was protected from divination magic, but we can still deduce two things; Dahak is in the Material Plane in a state that is not death, and spells of 5th level or lower don't work on him.

Aviana wants to go hunt big game to feed Ivernia and Kaar. "Shalkoc, park the island and we can drop down." Kyrin says we killed Griffons recently and still have their meat. Aviana and Shalkoc just want to go hunt for fun, and Plex is trying to contact Buttercup. Fearghas asks them to please kill the Flesh-eating Butterflies Plex brought from the Feywild. With a flex, Aviana requests a Potion of Giant Size from Fearghas. With the power of a nat 20 he crafts 3 potions and hands them all to Aviana.

Buttercup responds to Plex, "There is nothing to talk about, leave me alone. I wouldn't want you to know where I am." I ask if Buttercup was always so… edgy? "Nooooo, she was a little ball of happiness," Fearghas says. "Very emotional," Aviana adds. Well that is concerning. Shalkoc suggests going fishing, turns out Emilio is pretty good at fishing but his methods are odds to anyone else; he jumps into the water, grows his claws, and skewers fish left right and centre. Works best on large fish.

Fearghas is spellscribing and gets teleported outside by a surge. Plex is jumping out the window and tries to bring the tree inside the house again. Fearghas forbids it. Non-negociable. He gets another surge causing him to lose proficiency in two skills and gain proficiency in two others. Much like the surge Kyrin took from Shalkoc, it can't be undone. Plex uses a Martyr's Locket to take the curse from him. "Do I need Arcana proficiency?" the goblin wizard asks himself. He loses Insight and Survival, gains Animal Handling and Stealth.

Kyrin looks lonely after we left Imix, so I give her a hug. Then we go bake heart-shaped chocolate cookies with Shalkoc, but his tend to look like butts instead. We have a little cookie party and hand them out to others.

I use a Sending scroll to contact my mum and ask what is happening on Ildilas, and whether her and dad are safe. I get no response… Panic? Panic. Some time and a cup of tea later, I go down to the forest and cast Speak with Animals as a ritual, taking my time to get it right. I kindly ask the spiders if I could speak to Kali if she has time. The spiders say since I'm not flying, and I'm not Kali's mate, she probably won't eat me. Thank you, spiders. I find Kali and ask her to cast Scrying on Lioriel for me, handing her the feather. The spell fails.

I have a very awkward conversation with Kali about spider and Drow mating habits. I… I saw… and heard… THINGS back in the Underdark, when I was travelling with the Matron's party. Some of the healing I had to do, all right… Whatever Kali does with her mate is none of my business and I'm happy for it to remain this way thank you very much.

Shalkoc, Aviana, and Emilio jump off the island for a spot of hunting. Emilio teleports to the ground with Void Torrent just before hitting, Aviana uses the Spirit of the Eagle, and Shalkoc unfolds his wings. Emilio eats a surge inflicting a permanent penalty to Strength checks. He was already a leaf in the wind, now he is an even thinner leaf in the wind. No big deal, whenever he gets a worse surge I'll cast Remove Curse on him and this surge will be washed off at the same time. Shalkoc hunted a sheep, Emilio murdered a herd of 5 horses on account of not being able to decide which one he wanted, and Aviana got one horse.

Neither Shalkoc nor Emilio are strong enough to carry any of these animal carcasses through the transdimensional rift. Plex follows them on a sponge, but before he jumps off the island he casts Death Ward on himself. "Remember, you have exactly 0.2 seconds to grab the sponge and climb on! I'm landing at 07:45:03." — Plex

Plex is falling and screaming, but as he falls much faster than he screams, he slams down like lightning on the sponge, immediately shoots back up, and only then do the others hear his scream. Plex halves the weight of the sponge to fall faster, slams into the ground and shoots back up. Halfway to the island he realises he has no passengers. He shoots 2 miles past the island into the sky, rolls Animal Handling to see how well he can steer his sponge, natural 1. "Naami, do you have the resources for Raise Dead? Revivify?" Fearghas asks out of nowhere. Um… yes?

Plex falls down and shoots back up sideways, near parallel to the ground "at mach fuck you". He is a hypersonic missile streaking towards a lord's castle in the Green Sea. "The goblin knows where he is by knowing where he isn't," says Karnack and we lose our minds. Emilio worries Plex might reach escape velocity. Plex is shooting towards a circular tower, he tries to aim for a window. Back on Promise we casually wonder how Plex, as a tailor, does not have a parachute yet. A goblin glider, if you will.

Plex threads the needle at mach fuck you, flies through the bedroom window of the castle where the lord is currently standing in front of a mirror and acknowledging his… excellent physique. "Do I have time to cast a spell?" Plex asks the DM. "You have one action," Aerelia says. "He's coming with me," Plex says and casts Vortex Warp, grabbing a naked French lord. Plex feels the added surface area of the nobleman, especially the flapping bits, are really creating more air drag and he is nearing the ground again.

Plex turns the sponge around so it faces the ground and as it slams down, it doubles its speed. Again. He fashions a ramp with his trusty Mold Earth but as he is bouncing and not gliding, he slams into it and bounces at an angle. He pops above the cloud, the French lord screaming behind him. He falls towards Promise now with the kidnapped noble. Fearghas randomly looks out the window then, sees a meteor falling towards the island, realises the meteor is 2 parts pinkish skin colour, 1 part green, and 1 part yellow from the sponge. Plex casts Feather Fall and gently touches down in the town.

Fearghas is dashing towards the town, I follow. The people of Promise cheer for Plex as he lands with the naked French lord. Kyrin is extremely tired and reads Fucker Fell instead of Feather Fall. After his crazy flight, Plex unlocks Mythic Trickster 3! Fearghas shouts at Plex and tells him to put the nobleman back where he came from, GENTLY. The lord is crying in French, no Fearghas I cannot translate it. Suddenly, Aviana's portal opens! Emilio and Shalkoc stumble through, followed by one dead sheep and six horse corpses, five of which showing clear signs of having been killed by Emilio.

Emilio glares at the naked lord, who to his credit does not die of sheer terror. Fearghas is telling Plex to let the Frenchman go, but Plex wants to take him to the goblins and grill him. Aviana steps through her portal, gets slingshot over the town, glides back and as she lands, flowers bloom at her feet. The explosion of her touching down fries the flowers and now everything smells like roses. Aviana is a Disney princess, confirmed. Plex is trying to sneak the crying man into the forest but Aviana hears the crying, grabs the man and flies him back down in the ruins of his town, destroyed by a shockwave left by Plex. Then she anchorchains back to Promise.

Fearghas is shaking and I greatly worry for his health once more, I better check on his blood pressure sneakily.

pages.name: Fyeywild Adventure 1
pages.content:
I found myself in a dense and sad mushroom forest,the first couple of weeks I tried to find myself a way out but whit little effect.

What i did find however. Was a small, slightly less sad mushroom hut I could use as shelter.

The hut must have belonged to a sad wizard who stumbled into the Feywild at some point judging by the pile of bones and clothing found on the floor next to the table.

after some days with no complains from the Wizard i assumed he didn't need his dusty spell book anymore and I took the liberty to translate some of his spells into more sensible pictures.

Unfortunately I didn't have much time to study his spells before I was interrupted by a group of 3 grumpy Redcaps who apparently gotten lost in the sad forest.

With my quick thinking I put on my trusty Redcap-hat and pretended to be one of them. And they agreed to believe me if they also lived in the mushroom hut.

It sounded like a fine deal to me, which it was until dinner time arrived.

When after a democratic vote on what we should have for dinner (With 3 votes against one), I was selected as the main course.

Luckily I had already set up my traditional Distraction trap made of a bed sheet a rope and lots of ash from the fireplace.

It gave me just enough time to wall my housemates inside the hut with my newfound spell and quickly flee into the sad forest again.

pages.name: Plex adventures 2
pages.content: Plex stumbling upon a moonlit clearing where a covey of ethereal nymphs danced around an ancient, gnarled tree, their laughter echoing like the tinkling of bells. A capricious nymph named Luna took a liking to the goblin's sapphire cloak, which gleamed under the silvery moonbeams. She attempted to coax it from him, offering a dance and a whispered secret in return. However, plex had a secret of his own - a lightning quick goat he used it to escape her grasp, leaving her bewitched and the nymphs baffled, as they searched the clearing for their vanished guest.

pages.name: Spider Recipe
pages.content:
Ingredients

4 servings

2 cups canola or vegetable oil

1 Giant death spider

1 cup tempura batter

1 teaspoon smoked paprika

Preparation

  1. Step 1

    In a deep saucepan or deep-fat fryer, heat the oil to 350°F.

    Step 2

    With a sharp knife, sever and discard the abdomens from the giant Spider. Singe off any of the spider's body hairs with a crème brûlée torch or butane cigarette lighter.

    Step 3

    Dip each spider into the tempura batter to thoroughly coat. Use a slotted spoon or your hands to make sure each spider is spread-eagled (so to speak) and not clumped together before dropping it into the hot oil.

    Step 4

    Deep-fry the spiders, one at a time, until the batter is lightly browned, about 1 minute. Remove each spider from the oil and place it on paper towels to drain.

    Step 5

    Use a sharp knife to cut each spider in two lengthwise. Sprinkle with the paprika and serve. Encourage your guests to try the legs first and, if still hungry, to nibble on the meat-filled mesothorax, avoiding the spider's paired fangs, which are tucked away in the head region.

pages.name: Draconic Poem - Translated to Common
pages.content:
In timeless age, gods forged the plane,
their craft divine, their essence chained.

From plane's own core, the gods are born,
their being shaped, their fate is sworn.

Tiamat and Bahamut, twin gods of old,
their bond a strife eternal, joint in hate untold.

Their clash laid waste, no corner spared,
the plane engulfed, a realm ensnared.

Their last embrace, their breaths entwined,
life sparked anew, from death combined.

Hate's demise, a sacred birth,
ten Aspects rose, from ashes' worth.

In temples grand, their praises sung,
their children rose, with banners flung.

With scales aglow, in royal hue,
in mortal realms, their kin ruled true.

Fortune bloomed, in realms untold,
mighty kingdoms, shone in gold.

In towers tall, their sages spun,
with strands arcane, from seams undone.

In childrens' hearts, that craved yet more,
ambition's flame began to soar.

For power sought beyond the skies,
a thirst unquenched, in restless eyes.

He sought to weave a tapestry bold,
reality's threads, in his grasp to hold.

Boundaries blurred, the veil grew thin,
lone mortal realm, now touched by kin.

Amidst the fray, the world did fall,
as planes converged, in chaos' thrall.

A seal forged strong, the world's salvation,
the dragons bound, in joint oblation.

Their children sworn, the vigil true,
to guard the seal, their purpose due.

Eternal watch, their wisdom sacred plight,
in secret kept, through ages' dying light.

pages.name: Assassination Contract
pages.content:
To the Esteemed Kali Savaris,

I trust this letter finds you in the shadows, where your formidable reputation precedes you. The undercurrents of the underworld speak highly of your... expertise, and it is this very skill that I require.

My cousin, Thelgem Grumblechest, met an untimely demise while on a critical diplomatic mission. His life was taken not by the scoundrels he sought to negotiate with, but by an outsider – an adventurer named Aviana. This harpy possesses abilities that border on the fantastical, growing to a colossal size and causing destruction with the ease of a child stomping on a sandcastle. Though the tales may be inflated, one cannot afford to be dismissive of even the slightest possibility. Thelgem was a mighty warrior and this accursed creature has to be to an awesome foe to have slain him.

Your mission, should you choose to accept it, is to track down and eliminate Aviana. She currently resides on the island of Deadlight, in a cabin near the island's sole city, also named Deadlight. Discretion is paramount; while this is a matter of clan honour, it is imperative that the clan's involvement remains concealed as to not taint our diplomatic efforts in the region.

For your successful execution of this task, you will be compensated handsomely with 10,000 gold coins. Consider it not just a payment, but the settling of a grudge. The Grumblechests do not forget, and we do not forgive such transgressions lightly.

The terms are simple: Aviana's life in exchange for the reward.

I await word of your success.

A Vengeful Benefactor

P.S. – To give you an edge, enclosed are the last known sketches of Aviana and a map of Deadlight. May they serve you well.

pages.name: Orders for Immediate Execution
pages.content:
Commander Sicus Ponticus
Deadlight, Quattrus 14th, in the Year of our Emperor 1497

To Gaius Varro, Praetor of the Assassin's Cohort,

Under my command and with the utmost urgency, you are hereby ordered to proceed with the elimination of Fearghas MacAllistair, a dwarf wizard of significant capability, currently residing in a cabin outside the city of Deadlight. The success of this mission is critical, as MacAllistair's creations pose a threat to our strategic interests.

These orders come directly from our superiors, and while I personally find this decision regrettable, given my own favorable opinion of MacAllistair, the necessity of our empire's security must take precedence. His creations, though admirable, are too dangerous to be left unchecked.

You are to execute this task with the highest level of discretion and caution. The implications of our involvement becoming known could severely damage the diplomatic relations between the Taldorian Empire and the nation of Deadlight. Failure to maintain secrecy is not an option.

I trust you resolve this matter swiftly and silently. Upon completion, report back to me directly.

This letter serves as your official orders. Destroy it upon memorization.

By my command,

Commander Sicus Ponticus
High Admiral of the 5th and 6th Imperial Fleets, General of the 4th, 11th, 17th, and 21st Expeditionary Regiments, Imperial Envoy and Chief Overseer of the Empires Diplomatic and Military Affairs in Talia

pages.name: The King's Coaster
pages.content:
As told by Farrow Windwhisper:

Let me spin you a tale few outside the frozen halls of the frost giants know. This is a story passed down by my wife's people, whispered in the winds of glaciers and shared over roaring hearthfires. It is a tale of Utgard-Loki, the cunning king of the frost giants, and how he outwitted one of the most fearsome beings to ever walk this world: the lich Ul'katir.

Now, Ul'katir was no ordinary lich. His power was vast, and his knowledge of arcane secrets… well, it was said he knew more spells than there are stars in the sky. His greatest treasure was a grimoire, a book so filled with ancient and forbidden magic which he guarded jealously, letting no soul touch it. Except... except for the day he crossed paths with Utgard-Loki.

Utgard-Loki, as we all know, is no mere giant. He is a wizard of great renown, a trickster whose wit could cut sharper than any sword. He longed for that grimoire, not because he needed its spells—oh no!—but because he wished to prove that no one, not even a lich, could outmatch his cunning.

And so, Utgard-Loki approached Ul'katir with an offer. "Mighty lich," he said, with a honeyed voice, "I have heard tell of your grimoire, a tome filled with such power that even the gods might tremble. I would ask only to read it—once—so that I, too, might witness its greatness."

Now Ul'katir, ever wary, narrowed his glowing eyes. "And what, pray, would you offer me in return for such a privilege?"

Utgard-Loki smiled that sly smile of his, the one that made you think he already knew how the game would end. "I will give you my most valuable tome. Surely, it will be a worthy trade."

The lich pondered this. A most valuable tome, you say? He thought to himself, "What could the king of giants possess that rivals my power?" But greed is a trap, and so Ul'katir agreed, though not without a safety net. He enchanted his grimoire, binding it with a spell that would return it to him the very moment Utgard-Loki read even a single word.

But Utgard-Loki… well, he is not one to play fair. He handed the lich his "most valuable tome"—and what was it? Not some ancient spellbook, not some arcane artifact. No, it was the teenage diary of Thor himself, which the trickster had stolen years before!

(At this, you might laugh, my friends, and you'd be right to! For this was the same Thor who, in his younger years, wrote poems of unrequited love, tales of his embarrassing misadventures, and dreams of one day growing a beard worthy of his hammer!)

Ul'katir, expecting some great magical work, opened it, only to be greeted by page upon page of Thor’s… rather juvenile musings. The lich, of course, was furious! But before he could act, Utgard-Loki was already gone, his prize grimoire in hand.

Now, what does our trickster do with this mighty tome? Does he read it? Does he unlock its secrets and claim its power for himself?

Nay! He takes it back to his hall, places it on his table, and uses it as a coaster for his drinking horn. Yes, my friends, the great grimoire of Ul'katir, the lich’s greatest treasure, became nothing more than a rest for a giant's mead!

Why, you ask? Because Utgard-Loki knew well the spell laid upon it. He knew the moment he read even a single word, it would vanish, returning to the lich. So instead, he let it sit beneath his horn, never once turning a page, and Ul'katir’s magic was powerless.

But that's not all! Oh no, the tale is not yet done. For you see, Utgard-Loki went a step further in his cleverness. He sought out Thor, yes, the very god whose diary he had given away. And with a whisper of false sympathy, he said to him:

"Thor, my friend, I have terrible news. A foul lich by the name of Ul'katir has your private diary, and he reads it aloud to all who bring him treasures, gems, and scrolls. Tales of your beardless days, your youthful dreams of being a 'great poet'—he spreads it far and wide!"

Thor, as you can imagine, flew into a rage like none had seen before. His thunder echoed across the realms, and with a flash of lightning, he set out to find Ul'katir and reclaim his diary. And Ul'katir, who had been so annoyed with his newfound 'tome,' found himself on the receiving end of the Thunder God's fury.

By the end of it, the lich had no grimoire, no diary, and a very sore skull from the wrath of Mjolnir.

And so, my friends, Utgard-Loki tricked not one, but two mighty beings. The lich, who thought himself clever, and Thor, who thought himself wronged by an innocent lich. All without ever casting a spell or lifting a weapon. Such was the cunning of the frost giant king.

And that, is the story of how the mighty Utgard-Loki made a coaster of a lich's greatest treasure, the grimoire which he proudly uses to this day.

pages.name: Note to future self
pages.content:
Hey, Linzi. So, if you're reading this, you're probably furious and stomping around the tower because you can’t leave until you finish your “basic routine” tasks. You’re probably muttering something about how this is all stupid and unnecessary, and honestly? I get it.

But before you start tearing apart the enchantments (because let’s be honest, I know you’ve thought about it), I need you to remember why you’ve put them up in the first place.

You’re a disaster sometimes. Not with magic—you’re good at that, obviously. But everything else? Everything else? You can barely keep it together. You forget to eat. You forget to sleep. You forget to take care of yourself like a normal person. And, yes, it’s embarrassing to admit, but it’s true.

I mean, look at the plants. How many have you killed so far? And don’t even get me started on the portal you left open a few months ago… What was it? An aboleth, a deva, a horned devil and a very confused goat? You can't keep letting things slide. This is supposed to make sure you stop acting like an incompetent idiot when it comes to the basics.

Here’s the deal. I enchanted the tower to force you to get your act together. Why? Because we both know you won’t do it unless you have no choice. You’re too good at avoiding it, making excuses, or getting caught up in something else. So, no more excuses. No more letting things pile up until it’s overwhelming. This time, you’re going to handle it.

What you need to do before you can leave (and no, you can’t skip any of these):

  • Take a bath. With soap! Not just splashing water on your face. (And please remember to put on clothes afterwards. No more accidents. We don’t need another embarrassing incident.)

  • Eat a meal. A proper one. Not just some random snack. A meal. With veggies. And proteins. And no, potions don’t count as food.

  • Water the plants. Yes, all of them. Especially the one in the study is practically begging for help. You’re the reason it looks like that.

  • Close any portals you’ve opened. Seriously. You don’t want even more stray creature messing up the tower again. On that note, I still haven't found the dust devil that snuck through last week…

  • Keep the tower tidy. All of it! I know, you hate it. But do it anyway. It’s about having a clear mind and a space where you can actually find things! Dust and clutter distract you, and you know it.

  • Finish your experiments. No more half-finished nonsense blowing up in your face because you walked away for “just a minute.” Complete what you start or don’t start at all.

  • Feed your prisoners. If you went through the effort of imprisoning someone, you should at least keep them alive along enough to get whatever information you wanted out of them. So don’t forget about them like last time. I sure hope I learned from that and you better not prove me wrong.

  • Keep the artifact vault locked. If I have to thaw out the entire tower because you forgot to secure that artifact again, I swear I will scream.

I know you’re going to hate this, but it’s necessary. If you want to stop feeling like a complete mess every time you finally come up for air, you need to fix these things. And yeah, I know part of you is reading this and thinking “but I’m too busy” or “I don’t have time for this,” but you do have time. You’re just choosing to ignore it. And that’s what got us here.

So suck it up, do the tasks, and maybe—just maybe—you’ll start feeling less like a walking disaster and more like… well, I don’t know. Someone who has their life together, at least a little.

Hopefully enchanting the tower and locking you inside will finally force yourself into actually being a functional adult. You're too powerful to be this messy and disorganized.

With love (and frustration), Yourself

P.S. I swear if you undo the spell, I’ll re-cast it twice as strong.

pages.name: The Oathsworn of Azgaraz
pages.content:
Azgaraz was a dwarven hold infamous for their 'acceptance' of magic and famous for being skilled monster hunters. Once upon a time their crown prince journeyed to Jotunheim with a large expedition to slay one of the legendary Jormungandr (Ice Wurms/Snakes) there.

While making camp, two of the dwarves went for a walk where they encountered a frost giant child.

The three talked and when the dwarves told the child that they were looking for a Jormungandr, the child told the dwarves of a place it had once seen one. It also told the dwarves story of a frost giant who once killed a Jormungandr, only to be slain by his own kin shortly afterwards and explained that Jormungandr were sacred to frost giants.

When the two dwarves headed back to their expedition, they were in two minds about the information they had just learned. One was exciting for having been told where they could find such a beast, while the other was concerned about the tale they'd been told and worried that a similar fate could await them.

When they returned, they spoke with the crown prince who didn't take the dwarf who voiced his concerns seriously, mocking him in front of the entire expedition and calling him a superstitious coward. The dwarves continued their journey and in the weeks it took them to find the place the child had told them about, the entire expedition treated the dwarf who had voiced his doubts with distain.

When the expedition reached the place, not far from Utgard, they found the Jormungandr and prepared for the fight. To add insult to injury, the crown prince forbade the doubting dwarf to take part in the upcoming battle, stating that a battlefield was no place for someone so soft.

When the battle began, the lone dwarf left behind at camp decided he had enough and went to Utgard to tell the frost giants about their expedition. The frost giants didn't believe him at first, after all why would anyone ever want to kill a Jormungandr, especially someone that short, and sent him away.

The dwarf returned to the camp and was surprised to see that his expedition had already won the battle and slain the mighty creature. When asked why he had abandoned his duty to guard the camp during the battle and where he had gone, the dwarf lied but it raised suspension anyways.

The expedition was celebrating their victory, feasting and drinking in a way only dwarves can, and so they didn't notice the small army of frost giants who had come from Utgard to investigate the dwarf's claims until it was far too late. When they arrived and saw the corpse of their sacred creature and the camp of celebrating dwarves, they went mad with rage and attacked.

Even though the dwarves were taken by surprise, they were all experienced veterans and put up a fierce fight. The crown prince, who had put two and two together, called the doubting dwarf a traitor and slew him before he, as the last dwarf standing, was slain by the frost giant's general soon after. With his dying breath he, in the name of all loyal dwarves under his command, swore revenge upon traitors and frost giants alike.

Thus only one dwarven soul came to be judged by Pharasma that day, as all but the traitor's still linger on that battlefield, bound by their crown prince's oath of revenge.

pages.name: Letter from the Devil
pages.content:
To Fearghas MacAllistar,
Executor of the Binding Agreement,

Pursuant to the terms of our duly executed pact, this correspondence serves as formal notification that the time has come for you to fulfill your obligation. The target of your contractual undertaking, Zacharias, has been notably absent from his primary domicile within the Infernal City of Dis.

It is incumbent upon you to locate and eliminate the aforementioned devil in accordance with the terms agreed upon. As a preliminary resource, you are advised that Zacharias' mansion remains situated along the road connecting the Iron Tower to the Pleasure Gardens. While his residence has been unoccupied for some time, it is a reasonable expectation that pertinent information regarding his current location may be found therein.

Let me remind you that while the specific methodologies of your pursuit are left to your discretion, promptness and efficacy are both implied expectations under our arrangement. Failure to proceed with due diligence would constitute a breach, the consequences of which are presumed to be comprehended and need not be reiterated here.

Should you require clarification of the terms or have need of an intermediary to relay further updates, you may direct your inquiries to the bearer of this letter.

By the Authority Infernal Law,
Zurvan
Adjudicator of Eternal Obligations

pages.name: Duergar Creation Myth
pages.content:
As told by the Dwarves

In the days of yore after Torag had chiseled the Dwarves from solid rock in his image, our ancestors flourished under his tutelage. They built grand halls and forged weapons, armors, and trinkets, as mighty as they were beautiful, and Torag was proud of them. They mined deep, uncovering ever richer veins of ore, but eventually Torag came to them and warned them to not dig any deeper. Something profane lay below, he told them, and our ancestors were wise enough to heed our creator's augury without question.

For some foolish few however, this councel wasn't enough and in their quest to sate their own greed and curiosity, they continued ever deeper, and Torag's heart grew heavy, for he knew they'd soon find what he tried to protect them from. Our ancestors worried for their kin but when the fools returned, our ancestors wept for they realised that they were kin no more. Their skin was burnt and blackened, and their eyes shone like smoldering embers, and when Torag saw this, he came and called them Duergar, and exiled them, for they were his children no longer. The Duergar pleaded for forgiveness but Torag knew their wrong was too great and when he denied them, the Duergar denouced him and crawled down into the deepest reaches of the Underdark, their hearts forever filled with hatred and spite.

As told by the Duergar

In the days of yore after our Father had chiseled the Dwarves from solid rock in his image, we all flourished under his tutelage. We built grand halls and forged weapons, armors, and trinkets, as mighty as they were beautiful, and our Father was proud of us. We mined deep, uncovering ever richer veins of ore, but eventually he came to us and warned us to not dig any deeper. He told us to be afraid. "Something profane lay below", was all he spoke, expecting us to do his bidding with a the blind and unquestioning obedience of a child, and many lucky fools did.

Yet some of us yearned for understanding, striving like any child to one day to become as wise as our beloved Father. And so they forged on and soon found the flame our Father tried to protect us from. It burnt us, charred our skin, and we called it Azgal, the Ebon Fire. We fled in terror back to our Father and brothers, yet upon our return, we were met not with warmth and succor, but with cold contempt and scorn. Confused we pleaded for our Father's forgiveness, but he betrayed us, renounced us, denied us as his children, and called us Duergar. For this is when we finally realised that our beloved Father views us not as children to be raised but as cattle to be kept under a yoke. And our former brothers stood by and watched, their eyes first showing the very look of superiority with which they still look down on us today, for they don't mind being nothing but obedient dogs as long as they get to sit next to our creator's feet.

pages.name: 01 - A Brewer and a Butcher
pages.content:
The damp cold of Krasnograd was fertile soil for nightmares to grow in. Stanislav crawled into bed in his clothes while the fire glowed infuriatingly, its dying embers far from enough to provide warmth. He didn't need the feeble light. Even the cold wasn't the worst of it. But this damp, even when rain froze into snow ere it fell, the constant shroud of humidity that manifested in mist… that was maddening. It made the cold bite deeper, obscured sight, and generally made life miserable. Stanislav yearned to keep the fire burning through the night, but all the timber he could afford was pine. It would blaze bright and high, the resin crackling, and in minutes the fire would die down. There was plenty of pine to go around. Slow-burning oak, though, was a luxury reserved for the burghers and the aristocrats. Low folk like him slept in damp cold.

Stanislav realised he was grinding his teeth. He stopped, knowing full well he would subconsciously begin again in a moment. He distracted himself by opening his mind to the darkness, within and without, and touched the fabric of magic. He brushed against the invisible strands, caressing them, savouring their presence. Responding to his will, a dark flame burst into existence just in front of his face. It produced no light, but he made it as warm as he could. The radiating heat dispelled some of the damp; Stanislav felt himself relax. The flame would endure after he drifted off, not very long, but enough for him to be fast asleep. Or so he hoped. He had used this trick in the past, and he'd woken up in the damp the minute the magic dissipated. He tried not to make it a habit, anyway. There was always danger to using magic, even a weak spell like this one. Lately, the damp had been unbearable. He lived in a shack, with more holes than solid wall. A good kick would tear the door right off its hinges. Tomorrow, this would begin to change. He would get paid; at least he hoped he would. Stanislav's thoughts began to unravel as the black flame lulled him to sleep. His final thought, heavy with spite, was that even a dreary shack was better than the house he had grown up in. He would choose being alone in the cold in a heartbeat, over spending another minute in Nikodim's house.

Iosif's face was lost in the shadows. He was a tall man but he walked with his shoulders slumped. He slouched when he sat, too. As if a blanket of wet wool was draped over his shoulders, that no one could see. Stanislav looked away from his father's face, and down to the uneven paving stones. His shoes were worn; a bit of woollen sock poked though at the toe. The cold was bitter today, the sky uncommonly clear. Iosif's hand rested heavy on the boy's head, making his skin erupt in gooseflesh. His heart raced, the blood beat in his legs. He crouched ever so slightly, ready to take off at a dead run.

"We aren't friends, Iosif. Why would I agree to this?"

A rough voice, in front of Stanislav. He peeked at the shoes of the man facing his father. Stout stained shoes, but free of holes.

"I've heard your wife gave you a daughter," Iosif slurred. "Congratulations, and all. You'll need a man to work, though."

"And so you bring me your boy?" Disapproval in Nikodim's voice, he was unconvinced.

"He's no boy of mine," Iosif spat. "It's because of him… because of him, Nastasya is gone. I'm alone. Take him, and give me something to drink."

The other man sighed. "You'll regret that once you're sober."

"Never!" Iosif barked.

His hand formed a claw, his nails digging into Stanislav's scalp. The boy stood very still, his heart pounding in his throat. He could run. He could bolt and never see either of those men again. And where would he go? He was only seven. Who would feed him? Where would he sleep? He did have his tricks, but…

"Fine, I'll take him," Nikodim said. "I could use an extra pair of hands, especially now Yegor caught the chills. I'll give you a crate for him."

"Two."

"One and a half and you'll get no more from me."

"Two, or you can teach your infant daughter to stir."

"You'll be the death of me, man. Two crates for the boy."

They shook hands on it, and so Stanislav was sold to the brewer for two crates of beer. He never saw his father again.

Stanislav thrashed on his mouldy pallet, knowing in the dark depths of his heart the nightmare had only begun. He would have preferred to dream of monsters, of fangs and claws, of growls in the night. He would have given much to dream of hulking beasts stalking him for his lifeblood. Even dreams of the undead haunting this land and preying on people's minds would have been better. But he knew, as did anyone who didn't drown their wits in drink, that no wild beast of wayward spirit of Strazhland could ever be as monstrous as the land's own people.

He was eight and a half, he thought. It didn't matter a lot; Yegor and Mikhail were still older than him. They were the brewer's apprentices who were learning the craft, helping Nikodim produce more drink and earn more coin to feed his wife and daughter. Stanislav was not an apprentice. The other boys were cold with him, following their master's example. They'd put sawdust in his bed, itchvine in his shirts, mud on his toothbrush. Maruska took pity on him sometimes, when she wasn't caring for baby Klara. The extra rolls of dark bread, given when nobody was looking; the thick new socks appearing in the chest at the foot of his bed; the errands he was sent on with a few coppers in hand and the hushed instruction to buy a piece of candy… they made it bearable.

Stanislav had just returned from one of those, the taste of sugar still on his tongue. He carried a sack of dried hops, separated into smaller labelled bags. He hurriedly took off his shoes, his socks damp from the snow. He slipped into his hard clogs, ignoring the wet socks with all his might.

"What took you so long?" Nikodim bellowed from the workshop.

Stanislav ran over and offered the sack of hops to his master, who snatched it. He opened it and counted the bags, then glared at the boy.

"You didn't steal any, did you?"

"No, master." What would he even do with those? They were dry and bitter… or so he guessed.

Nikodim cuffed him over the ear. "Don't speak so insolently and make yourself useful. Kettle three needs cleaning, mind that you give it a good scrub this time."

Stanislav bowed his head and scurried away, clogs clacking on the tiles. He snatched a boar-bristle brush and a rough linen rag from the shelf, scooped up a handful of soap shavings from the box in a drawer, and grabbed a tin bucket. He dumped the soap flakes in, and went to the workshop pump to fill the bucket. He all but let himself hang from the heavy handle, jumping up and down to get the water flowing. Rag hanging from his belt, he threw the brush into the cold soapy water and lugged the bucket to the kettle. It had been lain on his side for cleaning, and was big enough for an adult to crawl into. Not that Nikodim ever would. Cleaning was Stanislav's work. The other boys cleaned too; there was plenty of scrubbing to do in a brewery. But the other boys also brewed, helped with recipes, and handled a variety of instruments which purpose Stanislav could only guess at. He only ever cleaned. Wooden barrels and vats, the bronze kettles, funnels and sieves, scales and pans, the long-handled spoons to stir the wort. And bottles, of course. Stanislav cleaned enough bottles to dream of them most nights.

He crawled into the kettle, all the way to the bottom of it, and started scrubbing. The smell of bronze quickly mixed with the heavy, bittersweet smell of wort. His arms ached as he worked. Sweat stung his eyes. The air was immobile and stale and so, so damp. Crawling back out to rinse the brush was a treat. The taste of candy was all but forgotten now. Taking one last breath of drier, cooler air, Stanislav crawled back in. His shirt clung to his back. He wanted to be done with this so bad. His stomach growled. The work was not even half-done. If only he could speed this up. He was never fast enough for Nikodim anyway, never thorough enough. Every task had to be performed twice at least, with a cuff over the ear and a reprimand. What would it matter if he bungled it the first time? His ear burnt, blood beating in time with his frustration. He scrubbed with a vengeance, his thoughts racing. What if the opposite happened? What if he did it so well this time that even his tyrannical master could find no reason to punish him? What if…

What if he used his tricks?

Stanislav knew it was a bad idea, but he was just so tired. The heat in his ear made it difficult to think. His legs trembled. His arms were numb, the skin of his hands wrinkled. The smells of boiled grain, bitter hops, and metal twisted his stomach. Closing his eyes, Stanislav gave in to temptation. He reached out with his mind, touching something that was always here, his companion at night. His eyes went cold as if made of snow. He opened them to the dark bottom of the kettle. He saw clearly each bit of grain and froth clinging to the metal. A thrill raced through him as he used his trick. At his bidding, a patch of dirt vanished, leaving the metal shining and good as new. He would never have done so clean a job with the brush and rag! Exulting, Stanislav prepared to repeat the trick on another patch of the kettle. The job would be done in no time.

A big hand grabbed him at the back of the neck and yanked him out. The fingers wrapped around his throat, making it painful to breathe. Stanislav found himself facing Nikodim, way too close. The brewer's face was red, his thick lips curled in disgust below a moustache like a giant slug. Stanislav's stomach lurched. The cold faded from his eyes, but he knew it was too late. He'd been caught.

"What did you just do?" Nikodim asked, his voice terrifyingly quiet.

"Cleaning, master."

"Don't be clever with me. That was magic."

Stanislav drew a painful breath and looked down. The brewer only tightened his grip.

"You used magic in my brewery, on my equipment."

There was no use denying it. Stanislav nodded. If Nikodim just looked inside the kettle, he would see how clean it was! Surely that wasn't so bad? The brewer took a deep breath.

"Come along, boy."

It was not a question; he dragged Stanislav by the neck. Through the workshop, through the shop in the front, outside the house. In silence, they crossed the street to the butcher's shop. They entered, Nikodim greeting the butcher with a gesture. No words were exchanged, and Stanislav didn't dare look up. He was dragged through the shop and into the room beyond. The smell of blood assaulted his senses. Nikodim twisted his grip, making him look up. The butcher's workshop was a small room with another door left ajar, offering a glimpse of buckets full of snow and carcasses hanging from the ceiling. Opposite the door, a long table was built into the wall, covered in scraps of meat. Above it hung a wide array of knives. The far side of the room, facing the door to the shop, was dominated by a heavy machine all gleaming dark metal. A ladder led up the back of it, to a large funnel. A gangly boy with a patch of scruff on his chin was standing at the bottom of the ladder, carrying a crate heaped with chunks of meat, streaked with white tendons and tough nerve. A small girl, maybe Stanislav's age, turned the handle on the machine. She pushed her entire body weight on it to make it swing down, then used the momentum to bring it back up. Her simple dress was dark, but the stains were nonetheless obvious. She was focused on her task and didn't look up. Maybe she was a little too focused. The older boy stepped away from the ladder, looking down.

Nikodim stalked up to him and snatched a chunk of bloody meat from the crate. He dragged Stanislav up the ladder and pushed his head close to the funnel.

"Look," he grated. "Look well."

Pushing the boy's face closer, so close his nose nearly touched the iron teeth of the meat grinder, he dropped the chunk of meat into the funnel. The machine devoured it, metal gnashing against metal, crushing the meat between them. The tough flesh was squished and torn. A drop of blood splashed on Stanislav's cheek. The brewer dragged him down the ladder, past the little girl, to a metal tub the machine fed into. Coarsely ground meat dropped through the grate into the tub. Nikodim made Stanislav look across the room at the carcasses hanging among the buckets of snow.

"Does the meat in the bucket look anything like the animals?" The brewer asked, his voice trembling with fury.

"No, master."

"Does it look like it was ever alive?"

"No, master."

Nikodim knelt in front of him, still holding his neck, face uncomfortably close.

"If you ever use that foul magic of yours in my workshop again, or in my house, or anywhere near me, I will put you in that grinder. The gods as my witness, it will be your meat through that grate, and your bones for glue. Do you understand me?"

"Yes, master."

"Speak up!"

"I understand, master."

Nikodim released his grip then, shoving Stanislav. The boy stumbled and fell, his nose filled with the stink of blood and raw meat. He scrambled to his feet, his stomach clenched like a fist.

"You go back to the workshop now. And scrub that kettle. Properly. Any magic, and you know what happens."

Stanislav ran.

Nikodim made him scrub the kettle three times, late into the night. There was no dinner for him when he was done, not that he had wanted any. He was sick that night.

Stanislav woke with a start, his heart pounding out of his chest. The damp chill held him like vines wrapped around his limbs. He felt at his throat, gasping. His eyes were icy as he looked around the room. In the shard of mirror on his nightstand he saw they had turned black again, eyeballs as flooded with ink. He made them bend to his will, made them return to their usual grey. In the weak light of dawn he lay on his back, breathing, cursing the nightmare. He was not a child anymore. He had escaped. His past no longer existed, so why did it still torment him? Why would it not go away?

He got up stiffly and tried smoothing the wrinkles from his clothes, to no avail. Grinding his teeth, he stripped off his shirt and cracked the thin layer of ice in his washbowl. The chill did him good, and he washed away the sweat from the nightmare. He pulled on a clean shirt and scrubbed his teeth. With luck, he could afford a good breakfast before going to his new job. Not one of those gritty, dense rolls made of boiled malts. He longed for white bread made of clean wheat, a treat that smelled nothing like beer wort. Stretching, Stanislav wrestled with himself for a short while, then gave in. He embraced the dark power within and conjured up a flame in mid-air, burning the humidity from the room. He filled the cramped space with the smell of baking bread and turnip stew. He warmed his hands around his black flame. He made blue sparks dance in the room, covered the walls in fanciful symbols, made a knife appear in his hand and then vanish. He conjured up illusory candy, revelling in the power flowing through his mind. As usual, letting the magic go was an ordeal. It was not foul. It was not shameful. It was part of him.

He would not be a terrified little boy. If his past would not be buried, he would burn it with his magic, until not even ashes were left. He pulled on his coat and stalked out, locking the door with a wave of his hand. The smell of pastries wafted from up the street. He counted the coins in his purse and made up his mind. He would be paid tonight. Things would change. He bought as many treats as he could eat.

pages.name: 02 - Grandma's Laundry
pages.content:
Yanka kept to the shadows. She tiptoed through the dark streets of Krasnograd, the faint red of sunset leaving a faint reflection in windows. She longed to see a real sunset one day, untainted by the mists. Pushing her wishes from her mind, she focused on keeping her steps soft. The creaking of her wicker basket was loud in her ears; it could give her away. She tried to meld with the budding darkness, giving herself to its embrace. She reached the fountain unnoticed and set down her burden. She picked the spot farthest from the street light and, gritting her teeth against the icy water, began washing the dresses in her basket. There was not enough soap to go around, but was there ever? She worked methodically, her eyes picking out the stains in greyscale. No sensible person would be doing laundry at this hour, but Yanka did not have the luxury of being sensible.

Whose dresses were those, now? Kostyusha's. She was frail and bent, and she had been telling Yanka about her daughter's family who went west, seeking their fortune near Gond's Hammer. The grandmother had shaken her head, eyes clouded. "She said they would leave Strazhland. It's not so easy, leaving this place. The roads are dark. Much safer to stay and endure another winter. I hope she sees her folly and comes back." Maybe it was the folly of youth which possessed Yanka to have the same goal of leaving the region. In truth, she feared for her life if she was found. Her foggy memories indicated that much, at least. She was hiding in plain sight for now, just a face among thousands in the capital city. She just needed a little more time. Sighing, she turned her head towards the city wall, most of it obscured by a jumble of houses and shops. She could almost sense the forest beyond.
