Again, she had to fight the urge to abandon her task to climb the wall and look out over the Krasnyles. Guards would definitely spot her before she made it to the top of the fortifications. One glance at the Grove of Crimson Beauty, as much as she desired it, was not worth being noticed.

One of granny's dresses was torn, Yanka saw. She would offer to mend it, for a price of course, though she doubted Kostyusha would accept. Her eyesight was still good, even if her legs didn't carry her so well. Her memory didn't seem to be failing, either. Not the best employer Yanka had found. Last month, she had cooked for a widowed man who had never got her name right. He had been a good catch, one of her easiest. Once she had found the coins in his mattress, she had simply slipped wolfsbane into his soup. Had the body been found yet? It certainly had been cold enough for the smell to delay in its appearance. She'd been fairly sure no one would miss him and even if they did, well his failing memory would explain it all. His tiny garden had been choked with wolfsbane, growing next to the aromatic plants. His valuables alone would buy her many supplies, but not here. She would not risk being seen here. No, she would first leave the city and travel to a smaller town or better yet, a village. She didn't need a lot, certainly. How difficult could it be to catch a few rabbits out in the woods? She trusted in her blood to guide her swiftly.

Footsteps. Yanka fell into a crouch behind the fountain wall. Those were heavy steps, accompanied by the clanking of armour. Guards no doubt, though it didn't sound like many of them. A chill raced down her spine as she realised she had left her basket on top of the wide wall for anyone to see.

"Hello? Is anyone here?" A male voice called.

Yanka kept very quiet, her breathing slow and shallow. Her hand rested on the hilt of the dagger in her soft boot. The clanking came nearer.

"Show yourself!" The guard called, drawing his sword.

Yanka did nothing of the sort. There was no way he had spotted her. Was there? If only she hadn't left that blasted basket up there! The wind swirled, fluttering the hem of her ragged dress. It really was cold tonight. She hoped she would not catch her death, getting her hands wet in this weather. Her eyes watered as her nose started itching. She had time for an exasperated thought — Oh, come on! — before she started sneezing; once, twice, three times. They always came in threes. As quiet as her sneezes were, it was impossible three had gone unheard. She stood up, her hands raised. She could probably kill a guard if she got the drop on him; this was very much not the case. With a start, she saw how close the man was. A little more, and he would have stumbled on her.

He was a grizzled human carrying a tiny lantern at his hip, ruining his night vision. Not that humans had much of that, she remembered. They were blind as birds after sunset. This particular bird carried a short sword and a buckler; as Yanka had guessed, he wore the uniform of the guard. Surprisingly, he was alone. Maybe he had just ended a shift and was on his way home? Just her luck.

"Why were you skulking around with your laundry?" He asked.

"I wasn't skulking around. I was washing, and I slipped."

"Even so," he said, clearly unconvinced. "Laundry at this hour? Surely you can't tell the stains from the clothes?"

She hesitated. She had her hood up as usual, the fur lining obscuring her face. Another one of her customers had bought her that cloak… not deliberately, but it had been his money all the same.

"I see well enough," she said. "My mistress needs this done tonight, so if you would let me return to my task?"

He narrowed his eyes. "Who is your mistress?"

"Lady…" She barely caught herself. "Seleznyova."

"Doesn't sound much like a lady's name."

"Ah, every mother is a lady to one as young as me. I was raised properly in the respect of my elders."

He stepped right in front of her. "I have rarely heard a more obvious lie," he said softly.

Caught unawares, Yanka looked up at him. He had a scar on his cheek, old and faded. Silver-streaked brown hair, cropped short, poked out from underneath his helmet. His scale mail was scuffed in several places, but clean. The leather straps at his shoulders shone, worn smooth with use. His dark eyes took in her features.

"Uncommon colouring, for an elf," he said. "I imagine you are not from the city proper. Now why would one such as you lie about doing laundry at nightfall?"

"I was really doing laundry," she stammered.

"For Lady Seleznyova?" He prompted.

"For one old lady," she muttered.

"Give me one reason to think you just happened to be doing honest work and I should let you go free."

"I was doing honest work!" For once. "I was washing grandma Kostyusha's dresses, because she can't walk all that well herself."

"But why at night? Even if the darkness doesn't bother your eyes, the cold should deter you."

"Because…" With a shock, Yanka realised she had revealed the name of her employer. Well, she didn't seem all that rich anyway. And she had the one daughter who might return. "I need the money, sir. I spend the days working, but the pay is not enough."

It was true, after a fashion. She had no reason to reveal why she needed the money.

"It's noble of you to help the elderly," he said. "But not if it comes at the cost of your own family's well-being. At the barracks, we can always use extra hands. Clerks, healers… scouts. The pay is steady."

His eyes never wavered. Yanka was sure he was being honest, but his gaze also seemed to pierce her to the soul. He had taken in her dark dress, her soft boots, the hood of her cloak obscuring her elven features, and he had added "scouts". He did not take her for a simple housewife, despite his assuming she was feeding a family. She guessed he wanted to keep an eye on her; after all, she was not making a very good display of innocence.

"It won't cost you to come and have a look around, at least," he insisted with a half-smile. "The western barracks. Ask for Makar, that's my name. I'll show you around, explain the tasks you'd get. Now, I need to run, I'll be on duty soon."

"Maybe," she said noncommittally.

He shrugged. "The pay is decent. I'll see you soon, laundry lady."

Makar smoothly sheathed his sword, turned sharply and loped into the night, armour clanking. What was that all about, Yanka thought as she fished out the sodden dress and resumed scrubbing. The cold seemed so much worse now, and her bones ached with a vengeance. Just one more, she told herself. She doubted Kostyusha could afford to pay her, but she'd feed her and give her a place to sleep. In the morning, Yanka would look for a new target. Working for the guard? Why would she ever do such a thing?

The next morning, Krasnograd was buried under a deep blanket of snow. Looking out the near-opaque window in Kostyusha's house, Yanka grimaced. The old lady had let her sleep in her daughter's room, small and sparsely furnished but warm and reasonably dry. Yanka crawled out of the heaped blankets and pulled on her clothes. A dark grey linen shirt went down to half her thighs. She stuffed it into her long stockings and laced them at the waist. Those were almost like breeches but made of fine-spun wool, soft and fleecy. They were bulky enough to hide the shape of her legs, but more importantly they kept her warm. She pulled her black dress over her head and pulled her shirt into place, then struggled with the buttons at the back. The dress was snug, unadorned except for a touch of embroidery at the neck, red thread in a garland of yew berries. It was coarse wool, and the cuffs itched. The skirts were narrow and divided. She had done the needlework herself and it was ugly, but who would inspect a seam there? She would be able to crouch, sprint, and ride without fearing to bare her good wool stockings to the freezing mists. That was, if she happened to come by a horse or some other mount. Not likely, but Yanka preferred to be prepared.

Once decently dressed, she began the task of combing her hair. Her wavy locks reached to her shoulders, which was plenty long and already getting in her way. Ribbon and string didn't come cheap. Hair clips? She'd have to fashion them herself; their price was prohibitive, for someone with her plans. She worked her bone comb, one of her most prised possessions, through the heavy tangles and snarls. It was an exercise in patience. She contemplated cropping her hair short, then discarded the idea as she always did. Combing it every morning and night was meditative, a ritual of sorts. She needed to practice patience in all things if she was to escape the city and find her people out in the wilds. Yanka had no doubt she would succeed, eventually. Ancient blood flowed through her veins, the blood of wood elves who lived free, within nature. She would start in Volyansk. Well, she would start by finding Volyansk. She'd heard the name whispered enough to know it was a place of free people, far from the aristocrats' eyes. Yanka had many answers to find, and there would be none under the gazes of the highborn. A shiver raced down her spine at the thought of aristocracy; the mists in her memory roiled, resisting her efforts to dispel them.

How her search for answers led her to the western barracks, she couldn't tell. Intuition? Fate? More questions? Any reason was good enough for her, really. She was not surprised to find Makar grinning at her as he put on his armour.

"Laundry lady!" He called as she approached. "Didn't expect you so soon, but you are quite welcome!"

"My name's Yanka," she said, a little colder than she meant. "I only came here to turn you down."

"Don't rush yourself so. Have you had breakfast?"

She'd eaten half a beer roll and left the cheese to the grandmother. Her stomach growled, which amused the guardsman.

"Off to the mess hall with you then, I'm pretty hungry myself."

She let herself be lured by the promise of food. It was difficult to ignore Makar's good mood; it spread to the other guardsmen and the few guardswomen. For every person they met, he had a smile and a wave. He stopped sometimes to exchange a couple words and a clap on the shoulder with a fellow soldier. Yanka easily pictured Makar brightening up the place all on his own. When his voice boomed through a courtyard, the grey buildings seemed less dreary, the mist didn't cling as wetly.

The mess hall was a long room with worn floors, worn tables, and worn benches. Guards shuffled to get their breakfast, most still half-asleep. At Makar's good morning call, they stood up straighter and squared their shoulders. It was systematic. Yanka fought an urge to giggle. She could not remember the last time she had wanted to giggle. Soon enough she was seated at the end of a crowded bench, balancing on half her bottom. Makar had obtained her a tray with a crusty roll of dark beer bread, a thin slice of cheese, a thinner slice of ham, and a bowl of thick soup. She was not sure of the ingredients, and didn't care. The soup filled her stomach with warmth that radiated into her limbs. Her toes were delightfully warm. She stacked the cheese on the ham, rolled them up, and dipped them into the soup. Soon, she was scraping the bottom of her bowl with the last of the bread. As usual, bits of sharp barley husk got lodged between her teeth. She fought to pry them free, then gave up. Such was life, when most bread was made with leftover malt. It was ground up to crush most of the husks, mixed with a little finer flour and eggs to make it all stick. The result was a dense loaf, often baked as fist-sized rolls, bitter with a well-hidden hint of sweetness, mushy and nutritious from the eggs. Cheap to produce thanks to the large quantity of by-product from the breweries, it was a staple throughout Strazhland. Low folk muttered the burghers' beer bread was ground to perfection without any sharp husks inside, and mixed with diced ham and cheese. It sounded delicious. Yanka sipped from the cup of strong tea she had received along with her meal. She could have used sugar, but that was a luxury. Well, bitter tea was worlds better than cold water. She'd have to get her hands on some leaves, before she left.

"You could be working with them, feeding us all," Makar said. "Bet the soldiers would be awake and lively, just to see a pretty face like yours."

Heat crept up Yanka's neck. It had nothing to do with the soup.

"Look, if you've only lured me here to hit on me…"

"Lured you! I invited you here."

She stared at her tray which was wiped clean, every crumb picked up and eaten.

"You'd be fed, here. I'm not trying to convince you, just please consider it. You look like you've been through hard times."

"Who hasn't?" She said, repressing a shudder. Hard times? If she could only remember them! On impulse, she asked, "I don't suppose you have a good healer? Not just a barber, mind. Someone who uses magic. For… my little sister."

Makar's eyes grew grave. In the daylight Yanka saw their true colour, a warm brown like the bark of a towering oak.

"What ails your sister? Is her life in danger?"

"Ah, no… but she can't seem to remember some things. Like fog in her mind, she says."

The soldier frowned. "I can ask Artyem if he has time to make a visit."

"I wouldn't want to impose," Yanka said hurriedly. "But if I could speak with him on the matter? It might give me ideas."

"Hmm? Do you practice magic as well?"

Stone-cold goat shit, she cursed in her mind. Her lies would get her killed one day, the way she dug herself into a pit with them.

"Not really." That was just the truth. "Lighting a candle is within my abilities, but no more."

"I see," he said. "Well, a conversation can be had for free."

She nodded, disliking the inquisitiveness in the man's eyes. He had it out for her, really! A scoundrel she may be, but to warrant such scrutiny from a stranger! Be honest, she admonished herself. I'm not some street thug, I'm a criminal. The fact these people won't be missed doesn't make it any less murder. Makar's eyes didn't seem so warm anymore. A lump formed in Yanka's throat. If he was onto her… She had to flee anyway, but she'd wanted to gather more supplies first, to prepare better. She didn't have a clue to finding Volyansk. Her blood would guide her to her people in the forests, wouldn't it? She would… she would know where to go! She would, right? That was how it went in stories.

The tolling of bells interrupted her racing thoughts. Chimes blended in a deafening cacophony, each bronze call adding its own pitch, filling the air with vibrations.

"What's going on?" She cried, her voice drowning in the noise.

"Attack on the gates. Stay here. Stay safe. I'll be back."

And Makar was gone, rushing out with the other soldiers. Yanka was left alone, prey to her questions.

Makar had hoped for monsters. Wolves, bears, even the monstrosities that ate the former. Giant insects would have been good. Instead the "threat" was people, Strazhland's own people, a mob carrying the proverbial pitchforks and torches but also any and every rusty weapon and farming tool they could gather. A sea of farmers and craftsmen, youths and housewives, voices overlapping and yet joining in anger. Makar knew what they were screaming about. It was not the first time he witnessed such an "attack". It was not the first time he had to fight men who were like him. His heart seemed a stone left too long in the cold. The people only wanted warmth, safety, and food.

"We're not fighting our own people," he snapped at anyone who passed near him. "Disarm them, restrain them if you must. Send them fleeing. If any of you does more than bruise them, he'll answer to me! They are our brothers and sisters!"

"Makar, with due respect," a man said as he snatched a pike, "those brothers and sisters are here for our blood."

"All the more reason," he grated. "Break the cycle of hate. We can't talk tomorrow if we kill today."

The young man sighed, and ran to join his unit. Makar strapped his buckler to his arm, and slid the long crook into the slot at the centre of the shield, where it clicked into place. The crook was good for turning blows and disarming opponents. He took a deep breath, memories of past battles flitting at the edge of his mind. Today… must not be a battle. Blood would be spilled, that was inevitable. But the more blood the people spilled onto their own land, the more bitter the defeat. Movement at the edge of his vision caught Makar's attention; it was one of the new recruits. He had heard the man's name in passing; Stanislav? Despite not being a soldier, he had been hired as a mage. He looked too young to fight, his sandy hair thin and messy. The youth clutched a crude staff with a piece of smoky quartz at the end, held by coppery wire. If nothing else, a good whack with the stone would hurt. The mage's cloak hung on his scrawny frame. For a heartbeat, Makar could have sworn the boy's eyes had turned black, but it was impossible. No man had eyes like that.

The gates opened and the guards spilled out. Makar ran at the front, seizing strands of magic as he ran. He breathed in the magic, let it blossom within his lungs. He let it out on the next breath, shouting an incantation as he scattered a handful of sand from the pouch at his belt. His free hand moved through the motions of a familiar spell, a weapon much stronger than the sword, a weapon for avoiding battle. He saw everyone around him turn their heads away and he shielded his eyes with his buckler as he released the spell. The pale sunlight exploded in countless shards of every colour, dazzling, blinding. Makar's brothers-in-arms knew his tactics well, and they expected this spell. Very few were affected. The attackers, however… they cried and stumbled, their hands flying to their eyes. Not all of them, but a good amount. Those dropped their weapons and stopped in their tracks, their blood safe in their veins for now.

Makar's chest filled with heat as words spilled out of him. "Your brothers' crimson rage, your cousins' spite, Let them be wind, make them the dust you tread! A father's anger swiftly fades from sight; No words can grow, where family has bled!"

His soldiers roared. They fought with the pommels of their swords and the butt of their spears; they swung lances like staves. They kicked and shoved, screaming wordlessly at the attackers. More than one peasant turned and ran. Many were bruised, some had the lights knocked out of them, but the majority of the defenders tried their best to not spill blood. Some of the tension left Makar; he blocked a blow with his shield and twisted his arm, catching a club — basically just a thick pine branch — with the crook. He stepped right into his opponent's space, their noses nearly touching.

"Go home!" Makar shouted. "You cannot help your family by dying here!"

The man screeched and turned tail, abandoning his improvised weapon. A branch. Makar tasted ashes. If farmers attacked the capital armed with branches, their trials must be dire indeed. Did the aristocracy spare no thought for the people growing their food? An explosion shook the earth to Makar's left. He spun, searching for its origin, and found it was none other than the scrawny mage. He had climbed on a flat-topped boulder and was waving his hands, sending dark energy streaking into the fray. One crackling bolt hit a woman with a pitchfork; she crumpled to the ground motionless. A death sentence — she would be trampled by the mob. Screaming his frustration, Makar knew he could not save her. Instead he dashed to the boulder, leapt up, and crashed into the young mage. They tumbled together in the sparse grass, the youth taking the brunt of the impact. He cried out and went limp. Shaking, Makar scrambled to his knees and checked for a pulse. The boy had just been knocked out. Not the solution he had hoped for, but it would do. There would be no more killing if Makar could help it.

The skirmish was over in minutes. Limbs aching, one leg pulsing with pain from his fall, Makar retreated to the barracks. He made sure to keep an eye on that mage, choosing the words he would have with him once he woke up.

pages.name: 03 - Wishes in the Mist
pages.content:
Erakho didn't mind bad smells anymore. You learnt not to, in this line of work. You learnt fast, or gave up faster. Erakho would not give up. These jobs, nobody wanted to do them, so he got paid well. The gold would grant his wishes; he would buy gifts for his mother. The work would grant his wishes; he would understand it all.

He'd been sent to the harbour today, under a grey sky that seemed to weigh on the warehouses' peaked roofs. Small fishing boats huddled at the docks as if for warmth, jostled by a slate-coloured sea. The waves would get high and splash the docks, soon by the look of that sky. Erakho doubted anyone would be mad enough to set sail. The weather was never really good for it, when the waters were navigable at all. When winter was at its harshest, even the sea froze and none of the small crafts stood a chance against the sharp sheets of ice flung about by the ocean. As he worked and warmth spread through his limbs, Erakho thought about the mountains to the north. He dimly remembered a small village nestled in a hollow between tall hills with jagged slopes. He'd been too young then to seek meaning, but somehow the land itself had sought him. Even here, among cut stones and metal, the land whispered.

"Oi scrawny!" A rough voice called behind him. "Hurry it up, this storm won't wait for us!"

"On it!" Erakho shouted, out of habit.

His daydream interrupted, he had to admit his co-worker was right; the weather was getting worse by the minute. Callused hands gripped the shovel and dug into the reeking pile of discarded fish skins and insides. He shovelled the guts, scales, and bones into his cart. The metal of his tool scraped against the uneven stones of the docks. He set the shovel in the hooks at the side of the cart and stepped between the shafts, grabbing the cart's handle. He threw his weight against it to get it rolling, then straightened his back. This would be a lot easier with ponies to pull, but then he wouldn't be paid as much. Racing the coming storm, Erakho rushed his reeking cargo into the warehouse alongside the other orcs.

He wasn't an orc, not really. His co-workers reminded him often enough. Half-blood, they called him. His mother had explained why. He didn't care, so long as he got paid for his work. At the market, he had seen a lady selling shawls made of the wool of big rabbits. They were dyed fanciful colours, and though he hadn't dared touch them with his dirty hands, he was sure they would make a good present. Valya… his mother. She was the source of his courage. A pretty shawl was the least she should have. Erakho could not afford it yet, but he was setting money aside bit by bit. Tonight, though… maybe he could negotiate with one of the fishermen, for cleaning up after their work. How Valya would love a piece of fatty fish for dinner! As the rain started pouring down, Erakho decided he would try.

He saw a large hand come just before it grabbed him. Zakhar the shift leader yanked him by the chain on his neck. The cold metal bit into Erakho's skin, numbing him to the shoulders. He hated when they did that. He endured for the money, for the sake of his wishes.

"What are you loitering about for?" The tall orc growled at him. "Get your cart emptied, and start filling bags. Good-for-nothing half-blood."

The half-orc swallowed a snarl as his blood boiled. He bowed his head even as the chain pressed on his windpipe. Zakhar was bigger than him, and a lot heavier. Erakho had seen the corpses of animals who had tried to fight bigger ones; it never ended well. He was the small one here. Lay low, stay hidden. Zakhar shoved him with a scoff. Erakho hid a victorious grin; he was alive and well. He continued his work, filling coarse sacks with a stinking mixture of fish guts and straw, chopped small. They would hand it over to wagon drivers, who would see it delivered to farmers outside the city walls. Did the burghers know what made the turnips they dined on grow so round? Would they turn up their noses if they knew? He didn't let the amusing thought distract him, but it made the work feel lighter.

The knight was lost. Mist gathered around him, dyed crimson in the sunset light piercing through the clouds after the storm. Willows clad in the fiery hues of autumn lined the muddy road, silent guardians watching him struggle. His armour weighed him down, each step cost him more of his waning strength. How had he come to this road? He had been travelling alone a while, after losing his horse to wolves. The beasts were so hungry they attacked people… what savage land was this? Who cared for it? There was a road, muddy and neglected as it was. There must be people. He looked up at the sky, trying to make out the sun through the fog. Half the sky was ablaze with sunset, as if bathed with blood. An omen? He hoped not; he knew nothing of divination. If only his friend was with him…

He shook his head and focused on walking. Wishes would not save him. Night would fall soon. Beasts were not the only danger; the cold and damp would further sap his strength. He had eaten the last of his food earlier, and his stomach growled. If he did not find a settlement soon, even just a farm, he would have to forage or hunt. With this suffocating mist, his chances were slim. He clenched his fists, clearing his head. He had fought all his life. He had been brought back from a place of no return. He would not die of exhaustion on a nameless road in the woods! Controlling his breathing and managing his strength, he walked on with iron determination. He would see the end of this road. His story would not end here.

Erakho walked home with a spring in his step. His hands and arms were cold from washing in icy water, but he had found some soap to scrub the stink off his skin. He brought a present for him and his mother, a thick slab of fresh, pink fish. It would make an excellent dinner, a reward for their hard work. As he reached the small yard at the back of their house, Erakho's ears picked up a familiar squeak. He crouched, taking a moment to call his magic, the land's magic, and drape it around his head. Just as he lay the spell on himself, threads of magic slipped from his grasp and snapped in chaotic patterns around him. He tried to regain control, but the primal force was entirely out of his grasp. His fingertips tingled, then stung. He looked down to see his nails growing at impossible speed to the length of claws, cracking and splintering. He sighed, then turned his attention back to the crack in the wall, from which his friend had called.

"Smula, are you here?" He murmured, his voice coming out distorted to his ears.

"Always here," a tiny voice replied from the crack in the stone. "Your hands?"

"Wild magic surge," he said with a grimace.

Emerging from the wall, the rat seemed to giggle at him. "No one controls magic. You have food?"

"Of course, my friend."

With some difficulty, Erakho pulled dry bread and a small hunk of cheese from his pocket, and placed them in front of the small rodent. She happily got to work on the cheese, her pleased squeaks sounding like words of thanks mumbled around a mouthful of food. The half-orc waited for her to finish eating, then asked:

"What news while I was away? Is mum well?"

The rat brushed crumbs from her whiskers, and ate those up as well. "As per our pact," she said solemnly, "so do I watch over Valya. In exchange for tasty snacks. She went to the town walls today, returned late, picked up a stray."

"A stray?"

"A human," Smula said. "He did not look well. Valya had someone carry him into the house."

"When?"

"Short time ago."

"Thank you, my friend. Anything you'd like?"

"I don't suppose that fish of yours still has the tail attached? You tall people throw out the best parts…"

"Sure it has the tail," Erakho grinned. "I asked for it just for you. I'll leave it out in a moment."

The rat tapped her tiny paws in a happy dance, then scampered off. Straightening, Erakho tapped on the door with his unwieldy nails, and entered. The kitchen at the back was small but tidy, full of shelves stacked with labelled jars and pots. Valya had insisted Erakho learnt his letters and he has never been a fast reader, but he could make them out if he had to. He hated to write, the pen refusing to make letters as pretty as his mother's. Well, he supposed she had a lot more practice than he did, being a clerk.

"Mum?" He called. "Are you here?"

Valya appeared at the door, a small woman with wild silver-streaked red hair. She stumbled and grabbed hold of the doorframe. Erakho rushed to her side to support her but she was already straightening. Her legs had never been strong.

"Good, you're here," she said. "Can you help? I've taken in a man, he collapsed close to the walls and the guards didn't have time for him."

"Your heart is too good," Erakho growled. "What if he's a bandit?"

"He's not. What happened to your hands?"

"Wild magic."

"So it is," she shrugged. "Come with me, now."

Grumbling, the half-orc put down his wrapped-up fish and offered his arm to his mother. She leaned on him gratefully as she urged him to the other room, which was in great part occupied by a long table, half of it cluttered with writing implements, candles, and clothes awaiting mending. On one of the wide pine benches, his face lit by a sputtering candle, lay a man clad in armour. He didn't look a bandit, not with the battered breastplate and the heavy saddlebags next to the bench. A lost traveller, or a mercenary.

"Tell me what happened," Erakho said as he knelt by the stranger.

"The guards were just bringing him in. But there was a skirmish earlier, and their healers were busy. They were going to leave him in a corner until they could spare time for him. He is not from here."

"He certainly looks like an outsider," he said, examining the pale blond hair and fair skin. "Does he bear symbols?"

"He carried a shield, but it's too damaged to make out the design for sure."

"Hmmm. He doesn't seem injured, but help me remove his armour. Though first… I need to trim these nails."

After a short battle with the clippers, they struggled with the armour straps, Erakho holding the unconscious man while Valya slipped off the heavy breastplate. No wounds below, yet he barely breathed. Erakho pressed his hand to the man's cheek. His skin was much too cold.

"He was out too long, I imagine. He can borrow my bed until he comes to, and I'll sleep on the floor if necessary. We have enough blankets."

"But he'll live?" She asked anxiously.

"If he warms up and we feed him, I don't see why he wouldn't. But he is very weak. Whatever possessed him to travel these roads alone…"

"We can ask him when he wakes," she said. "Did you bring something for dinner? We still have potatoes and a little bit of kale."

"I brought fish," Erakho beamed.

"Fish! What a good boy you are. I'll set it to baking, and make broth with the bones."

"Just don't throw away the tail," he warned as he lifted the man and carried him up the narrow stairs.

"Of course not!" Valya called from the kitchen.

They had a sumptuous dinner that evening, not just the mother and the son but also the little rat outside, along with her many siblings. Valya kept a rich broth simmering in the pot above the fire, with instructions for Erakho to feed some to the stranger if he woke. She shuffled to her bed shortly after dinner, leaving her sewing for another day. Erakho stayed longer, heating up some water so it wouldn't be stone cold, as he washed in the small copper tub. He didn't dare burn enough wood to heat up all the water, just one pot's worth of it to dilute the cold. He scrubbed the sweat and the stink from his light green skin, and washed his short black hair. The tub was too small for him to sit in, but it was fine to stand in. It was luxury to even have a tub, but Valya was paid well and so was he. It was not a rich life, but they were safe in Krasnograd, and life was good enough as long as they were together. That night, Erakho made himself a pallet in his room and slept on the floor, keeping his ears sharp in case the man woke, but he didn't stir until dawn.

pages.name: 04 - Cold Dreams
pages.content:
Osten carried a body in his arms. It was small and much too light, like that of a child. The person he was carrying stirred and struggled, though weakly. He was not entirely sure she'd been awake just a minute ago. There were two other men walking to either side of him, one a dwarf, the other a human. With this, Osten remembered. These people were his companions, his friends. He blinked, and the space around him became a familiar town, sturdy buildings surrounded on all sides by colourful stalls and tents. Crossroads of the plains, the heart of the Diamond, the merchant town of Yarinn blossomed around him.

"Osten, please let me down. I can walk, really."

The halfling's voice was tiny, a whisper he doubted the others had heard.

"Not a chance," he said.

"I assure you, I am quite fine! This is embarrassing now…"

"Pretend you are a princess who lost a shoe," he joked, but she didn't smile.

"She speaks!" The dwarf muttered with a glare. "Naami, you are an idiot. This magic will kill you."

"I know my limits, Magnus."

"Oh you do? That's why you saw fit to burn your very life away? Don't deny. I saw it. You know it too."

"It was necessary," she said with that stubborn set to her mouth.

The dwarf sighed. "Maybe. But to my eyes… you are a candle burning too bright, too fast."

"I'm… really better at controlling it. Osten, if you'd just let me down, please."

He looked down at her. Some colour had returned to her cheeks, and her voice was stronger. He hesitated, but crouched and gently lowered her to the ground, letting her stand on her own. True to her words, she could walk, if somewhat slower than usual. It cost her; her face was set in a frown, and her shoulders had a stiffness to them. She was fighting through her fatigue, but he had to admit she was right. Before, when she used that magic, she had lost consciousness. It hadn't happened this time, though it was a near thing. She recovered faster than she had.

"I wish you'd explain it to me," the other human said, pulling his flamboyant purple cloak tighter around his shoulders.

Naami smiled. "I've tried, Daman. It's not something I can teach."

"If I visited the place you come from, maybe," he continued, but his eyes were distant as if set on a place even farther away.

His eyes had been wrong, ever since the visions. Months had passed, but the wizard was no longer the same. He'd stare into space and mutter to himself, and he had done those things before but always with grand gestures, picking words from his sentences and shouting them for effect. He had done it for an audience, though he might not admit it. His musings had turned sombre, his face often overcast with an emotion akin to dread. He refused to speak of his vision any further, and Naami could not find anything wrong with his body. Whatever he had seen that day, it had altered his mind.

Without thinking of it, Osten slowed to fall into step with Naami. She put on such a brave face. He hoped the baker was still in town, the one who sold the poppyseed and lemon cakes. And he would get some mead for Magnus, to appease his grumbling. For Daman, well… short of ancient secrets and promises of long-lost power, he didn't know what could still please the man. As he thought along these lines, the wizard muttered some kind of excuse and drifted away to a stall stocked with books and arcane components. This really was getting —

He stood alone in a dark place. Shadows shifted around him and his bones ached with intense cold, yet he couldn't see his breath in front of his face. He had forgotten something important, and try as he might, he could not bring to mind so much as a clue to it. Within his chest was a pull, a yearning, the wish to answer a call. Desire to prove himself, to reveal who he really was. He tried to move but his body was sluggish, as if severed from the mind. The sound of rushing water came ever closer. He had no sensation of moving, no sensation whatsoever, but the noise… He was drawn near, by a power surpassing all he had ever known, to the river.

Naami called his name, and the dream shattered.

Osten woke with a start, gasping for breath. His body was so heavy. It wasn't so cold here, though it was damp. He welcomed the humidity, welcomed the ache in his limbs and the gnawing emptiness in his stomach. He was weary and famished, but he was alive. Where was he? He'd been walking through a burning forest. No… it had been autumn leaves, their colours so vivid against the mist. He couldn't remember finding people but he was definitely lying in a bed, inside a house. Through thick windows almost more bubbles than glass, he glimpsed the grey light of dawn. By the wall, a shape stirred and rose from a pile of blankets. Osten held his breath, numb fingers feeling for weapons and finding none.

"So, you are alive after all," a deep voice said, the words still heavy with sleep.

"Where… am I?" The words barely came out; his throat seemed to splinter and crack inside.

"Safe. Mum picked you up and brought you here. Stay in bed. I'll be right back."

The man stretched and lumbered to the door. He wore loose trousers and his chest was bare; black hair made a strange contrast on his green skin. He was tall even by Osten's standards, with a prominent jaw and a bulky build. An orc? Osten's thoughts were slow, his mind refusing to work. He nearly slipped into slumber again, but the delicious smell of fish and herbs reached him and he was wide awake. His host returned with a wooden bowl and spoon.

"You're probably hungry but take it slow, we don't want you getting sick. Think you can sit up?"

By sheer force of will, Osten forced his exhausted body into a sitting position, then leaned on the wall behind him. He was fully dressed, but even so the wall felt cold. As he reached out to accept the bowl, his hands were shaking so much he would certainly drop it. He tried to make them steady. His head spun. The feeble light seemed to glow and shimmer. A callused hand felt his forehead, radiating warmth.

"Aren't you in a sorry state. Mum will cry her eyes out if you die, so drink up. Slowly."

The smooth wood of the spoon touched his lips, and savoury fish broth trickled into his mouth. Osten drank greedily, though his host only let him have small sips. The hunger pangs grew worse but the room came back into focus, the light growing steadier. New warmth spread throughout his body. His hands still shook but they weren't as heavy.

"You're really lucky, you know. Your strength was almost spent. If mum had found you any later, it might have taken magic to bring you back."

Deep unease sent shivers running down Osten's spine. He did his best to ignore them, but the chill lingered.

"Thank you," he managed.

"No need. I'm Erakho. It was my mum, Valya, who had you carried here. Mind your manners around her."

"Of course. I'm Osten."

Erakho raised an eyebrow. "Not from here, are you?"

"Where…" He had to clear his throat. "Where is here?"

"Krasnograd."

"I'm… not familiar."

Erakho set the empty bowl down on the small nightstand. "This is the capital city, man."

"Which country is this?"

"Strazhland. How did you even get here?"

Osten sighed as memories came flooding back. "I'm not sure why I returned to the Old World. It's folly to be here. I was on my own, something beckoned me far away. I chose to go east, at random. I was riding for months, and some days ago my horse was killed by wolves. Poor Moonstone, she was a good steed. She saved my life by throwing me off. Bought me time. Is there no one maintaining your roads? I walked through mud without seeing a soul."

"You must have walked the old Krasnyles road. No one comes through here anymore."

"That's putting it mildly."

Erakho shrugged. "This land is old. Places wither and die, others emerge. It's only natural."

He opened a closet that decidedly leaned to one side, retrieved a shirt and pulled it over his head. Yawning, he fumbled with the laces, gave up, and shrugged into a sleeveless tunic of dark green wool. Just then, the door opened and a small woman limped into the room. Valya, Osten assumed. He tried a small seated bow, with debatable success. She gave a start and rushed over to him.

"You're awake!" She exclaimed. "Are you well? I see my boy fed you."

"Yes, thank you."

"You looked near death last night. We're not wealthy, but we'll help you get back on your feet. I have to go out after noon but I'll stay here a while, if you need anything."

Osten nodded, though his head was growing fuzzy.

"He might need more sleep," Erakho warned. "I doubt you're getting a story out of him today."

"One can hope," she said with a sheepish grin. "I'll be downstairs, you need some breakfast."

"Thanks mum!"

She called something in response, but Osten didn't catch it. His eyes would not stay open. Erakho was at his side, supporting him as he lay back down. The pillow was thin but so comfortable, a cloud beckoning him. Sleep was a mire lying in wait for his unwary steps.

"Get some rest," he said in a surprisingly gentle voice.

"Wait," Osten called, words spilling from him. "Can you… chase away the nightmares? Ward my dreams?"

A smile. "My magic doesn't really work this way. But I'll ask my friend to watch over you. Don't be afraid of the rats in this house. We have a deal."

Osten blinked. A deal with the rats? Was he already dreaming? But he felt so warm. Nightmares were always cold with the chill of death, now. He doubted his god would listen to one such as him, but he offered a prayer. A prayer for warmth in his dreams, and memories of happier days.

"You want to go to the guardhouse now?" Erakho said incredulously. "It's dark!"

"It's usually dark here, it seems," Osten mumbled around a mouthful of beans. "And they kept my weapons."

They were all seated at the table, the end which wasn't too cluttered. Osten was trying to hold back but he found himself devouring the simple fare; dark beans boiled with fish broth until mushy, roasted turnips with herbs, and a basket full of crusty rolls of coarse bread. Did people not shell their grain here? He spat a sharp piece of barley into his hand, trying to be stealthy about it, but neither of his hosts seemed to care. There was goat butter with the bread, and a little bit of sliced ham carefully divided among the three of them.

"Of course they kept your weapons. You're an outsider."

"I need them back so I can ply my trade."

"You're a mercenary then?" The half-orc asked.

"I… was a soldier. But now, I'll fight where I'm needed. I must pay you back, for taking care of me."

Valya, who had been eating in silence, drew herself up. She was still much smaller than the men at the table, but her stern expression made up for the lack of height.

"You would be insulting us," she said in a frosty tone.

"But… You saved my life."

"And I don't want money for it." Her tone softened. "I didn't take you into our home in hopes for payment. I did it because life… all life… is precious."

"Mum…" Erakho began, but she motioned for him to wait.

"My son has long since learnt this lesson," she said proudly. "This land is cold and merciless, but for every evil, there is good to be found. Often hidden, like the cabbages who sleep under the snow, but it is here if you know to look for it. I choose to do good. For years, I have chosen to break the cycle of evil. I don't ask that you do the same, but respect my choice. I do not want payment from you."

Across the table, the big half-orc sniffed and scrubbed at his eyes before taking keen interest in his turnips. Osten felt a tug deep inside his chest. Valya's eyes shone with resolve. Such strength of will… he bowed his head.

"Forgive me," he said.

"There is nothing to forgive. Your intentions were good."

"They remain so," the knight said. "Would you accept a present, at least? For no reason other than I wish you to have it."

She hesitated, but nodded. When the meal was consumed and nothing but crumbs remained, which Erakho carefully collected and took outside, Osten searched his pack and pulled out a square of blue silk folded around a small pendant. The silver chain had some dark stains despite his precautions, but the pendant itself was as beautiful as ever. He thought it was garnet, cut and polished in the shape of a heart and delicately set in silver. He gave it to Valya, along with the silk.

"If you want it, it is yours. I think it would suit you."

She held the pendant to the light of a standing lamp, watching reflections dance within the stone. "It's beautiful," she whispered.

"Mum, wait," Erakho said just as he returned. "Let me have a look."

He held the pendant reverently and closed his eyes, a look of concentration on his face. The air seemed to shift. Magic? The half-orc had mentioned magic, in the morning. So he could work spells. Not for the first time, Osten wished he had the gift of magic as well. He had suspected the pendant to be magical, but had no way of knowing for certain.

"It does have magic!" The man exclaimed. "Faint, but it seems safe from what I can tell. It's steady, don't think it will cause surges. Some kind of protection."

"That is too valuable for me to accept…"

"Please," Osten said. "I hadn't known it was magical. The colour will compliment your hair."

She chuckled and put on the necklace, holding the pendant to her heart. Her eyes widened as she let out a long sigh and leaned against a wall.

"They're not aching as much," she said. "My legs. Is it the magic?"

"Might be," Erakho said, "though I'm not entirely sure. It could be another type of magic altogether."

"Another magic?"

"Your magic, mum." He pulled her into a hug.

Osten busied himself with the dirty dishes, bringing them to the kitchen and placing them in the stone sink. He went outside and cracked the ice in the rain barrel, which conveniently doubled as a snow barrel, and drew a small bucket of water. He set the plug in the sink, poured the water, dropped in a shaving of soap, and set to work with the brush. He took his time, letting himself get absorbed in the simple task. When he had washed and dried the bowls and cutlery, he swept the small stone counter and placed the neatly stacked dishes on top. He found a broom leaning in a corner and gave the floor a sweep as well, pushing the dust out into the backyard. His work done, Osten stretched in the tiny yard, feeling strength return to his body after the hearty meal. The cleaning had helped too, loosening the stiffness in his muscles. He was still weak, but his knees no longer threatened to buckle under him. Could he handle himself in a fight? Not yet. Hopefully he would not have to.

A knock on the door announced Erakho's presence. He filled the doorway, his heavy build framed by the light from within. The half-orc cleared his throat.

"Thanks for giving us space here. And the help is really appreciated."

"No problem. You've still helped me more than I've helped you."

"You're… not trying to settle debts?" Erakho asked.

"No. I'm just doing what feels right."

The half-orc nodded with a small smile. Instead of beckoning Osten in, he stepped out and shrugged into a patched cloak. He handed Osten his own cloak of heavy wool, dark blue and threadbare in places.

"The guards won't be asleep yet," he said. "It's just a short walk away. Think you can manage it?"

"Sure," Osten said. "And… thank you."

Erakho waved his hand as if to dismiss the formal gratitude and they set out down the dark street, ice crunching under their boots. The earlier rain had drenched every street and every stone; by morning it would all be frozen in a smooth, deadly mirror. With luck, snow would fall and cover the ice but if not, these people had better have grips for their shoes. He had used some, a lifetime ago, when he was still growing into his boots. Straps of leather fitted with low-grade iron nubs could be tied on any shoe, and greatly lessen the risk of slipping. It was a good solution for poorer folk or children, who could not afford a pair of winter boots with sturdy iron grips built into the soles. Even a lifetime of living in the cold did not make you immune to a bad fall.

Osten put on a brave face, but by the time they reached the guardhouse his exhaustion had returned. He was drenched in sweat and breathing hard, and it took a lot of his willpower to not lean on the wall as Erakho knocked at the brass-banded pine door. A man in uniform opened but before he could say anything Osten caught a strong voice from inside, reprimanding another by the sound of it.

"… out of your mind? I gave clear orders!"

A mumble answered.

"I don't give a goat's arse that you're not a soldier. There are orders, you obey them. For everyone's safety."

The guard at the door looked like he very much wanted to trade places with the door, maybe even the stone it was set into.

"Are we… coming at a bad time?" Erakho asked.

"You could say that," the man said. "New recruit making trouble."

"We don't want to add to the trouble," Osten said. "I was found unconscious close to the gates yesterday. I just want my sword and shield back."

Inside, the stern voice quieted. It was subtle, but Osten saw Erakho relax.

"Errm, you'll have to speak with the lieutenant about that. Regulations. I think he's done now so why don't you come in? We're on duty, so no beer, but we can spare two cups of tea."

"That'd be lovely."

They were led into the small guardhouse, a circular room on the ground floor of one of the city wall's towers. A fire roared and popped, bright yellow flames devouring resinous pine logs. A squat man with greying brown hair motioned for them to sit at the table, and stepped to the other guard for a word. Osten was not trying to eavesdrop, but the lieutenant's voice carried. In a room this small, it was impossible not to overhear.

"Keep an eye on Stanislav. I don't want to be rid of a mage so soon, but his actions yesterday concern me."

The guard nodded, saluted, and left the room, leaving the older man alone with Osten and Erakho. He spread his hands in welcome, his voice booming in the confined space.

"Good evening, gentlemen. Let me get you a warm drink, then we can talk."

Within minutes, they were all cradling a steaming mug of tea. There was nothing to add to the tea, and when Osten tried the beverage he nearly spat it out. It was so bitter, his tongue wanted to curl in on itself. Erakho nodded appreciatively and took a long swallow.

"So, what brings you here at this time of night? I'm Makar Semyonovich, lieutenant of this happy little band."

Erakho nodded to Osten, nudging him to speak. He introduced himself as he had at the door, adding his first name only, and asked for permission to retrieve his weapons. Makar raised a bushy eyebrow.

"So it was you," he said. "I wanted to keep you here, but with the cough going through the barracks this week, our remaining healers are overwhelmed. Good thing Valya took you in, then. I'm glad to see you back on your feet. What brings you to Krasnograd?"

"I was lost, really. I was told I ended up on an old road which nobody travels anymore."

"Aye, truly unfortunate. What were you doing on that road anyway?"

"Looking for a settlement, a farm, anything. Wolves killed my horse."

"Wolves." His dark eyes did not move from Osten's face as he gulped his tea.

"I was shocked they'd attack travellers on a road, even one as ill-maintained."

"And where did you come from, on that horse?"

"From Lessia."

"On your own?"

"I've been travelling alone for some months," Osten said, beginning to feel uncomfortable under the scrutiny.

"Do you not know our roads are dangerous to unwary travellers?"

"I did not. I'd never been this far east."

"So what brought you this far?"

Osten shrugged. "Curiosity? An urge to see what's over the next hill."

"What are you running from?" Makar asked in the same tone he'd used for every previous question.

"The cold," Osten answered without thinking.

Makar's eyes narrowed, and Osten knew he had fallen into a trap. His throat went dry; he hurriedly took a long drink of tea and regretted it. Years of practice kept his face composed.

"This is not a good place to be running from the cold, son."

"I've realised as much."

"So I ask again. What are you running from?"

Osten shifted his feet, keeping a tight rein on the memories threatening to overwhelm his mind. "I'd rather not have this conversation with a man I've just met. With all due respect."

Makar leaned forward, his voice dropping to a whisper. "You are a guest in this land," he said. "A rude guest who does not share his last name, but a guest nonetheless. Now this rude guest only asks for his weapons back, offering nothing in exchange. I'm responsible for these people's safety. What am I to make of you? Tell me why I should let you walk through our city with so much as a bread knife, Osten."

Uncomfortable silence. Erakho was running his finger along the edge of the table, his head tilted to one side as if listening for something the others couldn't hear. Makar's eyes flickered to him, then back. The odd behaviour wasn't helping him look innocent, Osten realised. And, he admitted with a sigh, Makar was right.

"I've been an adventurer for years," he said reluctantly. "I'd rather not speak of my life before that. My father tried to have me killed. There is no place I call home anymore. Maybe that's why I'm travelling, maybe I'm running from my past. I was with three friends, but we fought a rime worm. One… one of us fell. We disbanded our party. I picked a direction of the compass at random, and set out thinking maybe I'd meet new companions."

"That's a story," Makar said.

"Just answering your questions." His throat was tight. He blamed the tea.

"I imagine I got more than I bargained for, but I see you understand why I have to ask."

Osten nodded. He wished there was water to drink. Even close to that blaze, he felt… cold. Deep inside. His breath caught as his heart raced. No, stay calm. He had a chance to prove himself less suspicious, and he must not ruin it with nerves. He needed his shield back. There could be other swords. A spear or a mace would do. But his shield…

Pure force crashed on him, slamming down on his shield. He dropped to his knees from the sheer weight of the blow. His arm splintered in a thousand shards of pain. A scream was torn from his chest, pulled from his throat. He'd felt the bones snap. For the sake of those behind him, he'd held the line. Not a step given, not an inch lost. Sickly blue light, and black spearpoints. Overwhelming… cold.

He hauled his mind back to the present, pushing his hands flat against the tabletop to hide their trembling. He made himself speak, to keep his throat from closing. He put strength into his voice, firmness, confidence. As a Defender I will stand solid as the walls… No. He was not worthy of that pledge.

"My shield is worth much to me. With it I protected dear friends. Please, if you must keep my sword, at least return my shield to me."

"What would you do with just a shield?"

Defend. "Protect."

Makar let out a long sigh. "I don't suppose you're looking for work… and can follow orders?"

"I could consider it, but I take it you are really spread thin if you're offering work to outsiders."

The older man grimaced. "Better an outsider who follows orders than a local who fires on peasants. But we need mages. This one particularly lacks training… and common sense."

"That's a liability…"

"I'll be damned if I don't know that," Makar growled, "but when the direwolves come back, or those giant insects attack, or the dead walk from their graves, we need to take risks."

"Strazhland is a rough place, it seems."

"Rougher than you think. What about your silent friend? Those arms can handle a weapon I'm sure."

"I'm… not a fighter," Erakho said, his eyes darting. "I'm a cleaner."

"Ah, I did not realise, without the red chain."

"Don't blame you," the half-orc said. "I don't have to wear it off-duty, so I don't."

"A chain?" Osten asked. It strayed far from the topic at hand, but he could not help his curiosity.

"Cleaners like me wear it around their necks, so people know to stay away. We handle filthy things. Don't want disease spreading, so it's necessary. But that chain… I don't like it much."

Osten suppressed a shiver. A chain around the neck, in this cold? Cruelty, plain and simple.

"You're doing crucial work," Makar said. "The chain should be cause for pride."

"Yes," Erakho said, "it should be."

A heavy silence, filled with loud thoughts. Then, Makar spoke:

"You'll have your weapons back. But if it's not too much trouble, come back some time. About the job, but about something else too."

Osten looked up questioningly. The lieutenant seemed to struggle with his words, tapping his fingers on the table and sighing.

"I'm not as concerned you'll be a danger to the city," he said at last. "More worried you'll be a danger to yourself. Something's eating at you, isn't it."

Shifting shadows and bone-grasping cold; the rushing sound of the river he would never return from. A feeble voice seeking him through the darkness, calling his name.

"I'm all right," he said, his voice hollow in his ears.

"You're young, still. Trust me son; silence will not help you."

"I… I will know where to find you."

He stood, and would have fallen if not for Erakho.

"You still need rest," the half-orc growled.

"You could sleep here," Makar offered. "I don't think this cold would do you good."

"He will sleep here," Erakho said. "I'm not carrying him back, and he's burning up."

Osten's head spun; he could not stop shivering. "The cold," he muttered through chattering teeth. "The cold…"

"You know what," Erakho said, "I'm sleeping here too. I'll apologise to mum in the morning. You're short on healers right? I'll watch over him so he doesn't eat his tongue in his sleep, or something."

"Um… appreciated. Have you introduced yourself?"

"Erakho. I'm not rude. I just don't have a father."

Makar led them to two empty beds in a corner of a small infirmary; two other occupants were fast asleep.

"I'll check on you in the morning," Makar said as he withdrew.

"Appreciate it," Erakho mumbled to himself after the door had closed. "Second night of keeping you alive, eh?"

With surprising care for someone of his build, he helped Osten remove his tunic and trousers, and settled him into bed. He searched the infirmary for herbs his mother had fed him when he was sick. He lay a damp cloth on Osten's forehead to break his fever, then lay in the unfamiliar bed and listened as sleep eluded him.

pages.name: 05 - A Visit
pages.content:
When she first saw the man, Yanka thought she was still dreaming. He stood by her narrow bed in the guardswomen's barracks, motionless as if watching her slumber. He seemed an apparition, a vision of an impossible creature. His skin was bone white in the gloom, his fine features unsettling in their perfection. His beard was elegantly trimmed to a point, giving him a villainous flair. His shoulder-length hair was glossy black with a hint of deep green, framing his face in waves. His clothes were clearly tailored, with dark trousers showing the shape of his legs, a gold-gleaming seam running up their side. He wore a short tunic, wine red in the darkness, the fabric folding like syrup at his waist. A thin leather belt worked in intricate patterns and set with gleaming studs held the garment in place. Slung over his shoulders as if in haste, a heavy coat covered his arms. The collar twinkled with sprinkled stars, its lapels set with tiny gems. The sleeves were embroidered with gold thread on royal purple velvet. A thin gold circlet on his forehead completed the regal appearance, the metal worked in flowing shapes like mist solidified. A dream of a king from a faraway land, she thought. Then the man touched her cheek.

"Here you are, my little snow bunny," he said in a fond tone. "I've been searching all over Strazhland for you. My wife is so very anxious to have you back home."

"Who… are you?" She managed, her voice strangled.

He frowned, his features taking on an impression of pity. "You poor thing. Your memory is damaged, isn't it?"

"Do you know me?" She would remember a man of such beauty and opulence, certainly?

"Ah, my poor Snowdrop. You are my lady wife's favourite. We will return these elusive memories in a moment. You need but come with me."

"Where?"

"Back home, of course," he murmured. "Where you know you belong."

She found herself leaning into his touch as she rose out of her bed. What was she doing here anyway? The other women slept in the long room, undisturbed by the man's presence. How they were missing out! Yanka knew she was chosen by him, lifted from the dirty masses of Krasnograd. He was here to deliver her from her miserable life. She would never need to run, now.

She had been running. From village to town, through forests and rocky hills. She'd stumbled along the path of rushing rivers, their waters white as they roared towards the sea. Running from what? The man smiled at her, but something wasn't right. He'd spoken with the fondness a child would have for a pet crow, a farmer for his favourite goat. Not as person to person, but as person to thing. Well, nobles had little regard for the common folk. Yanka was special even so. Something nagged at the back of her mind, a pesky memory like a bothersome smell. Dusty and sickening. She'd hated that smell on her. She'd loathed the feel of it, the soft yet dry weave on her skin. As she mechanically picked up her cloak and settled it on her shoulders, her mind strained towards the unpleasant memory. It evaded her thoughts, slipping away like tendrils of mist. Frowning in spite of herself, she drew the dry smell deep into her lungs. The skin on her arms itched with half-remembered sensation. Her mouth twisted in disgust, and finally she knew.

Silk. She hated the smell of silk.

She found herself following the man out of the building. One step from the door, she stopped. He was ahead of her, leading the way into the moonlit courtyard. Under the milky light his features looked sharper, his eyes burning with impatience as he turned to beckon her. Words piled up in her throat and her breath came in short gasps. She didn't know who he was. She didn't know where he meant to take her. She only knew she didn't want to go, not for her life. She took a step back, her body going cold and numb.

He clicked his tongue in annoyance, and immediately composed himself again. "Come now, Snowdrop," he coaxed.

His voice was irresistible, bursting with unspoken promises of luxury and idleness. She longed to take the white hand he stretched towards her… but… the smell of silk clung to him and turned her stomach. She shook her head. This time his smile had nothing of fondness or temptation; he bared his teeth at her and where the canines should have been, fangs glistened in the moonlight. A weapon… Yanka searched in vain for her dagger. She could run back in. He'd only follow. Words tugged at her memory, and without thinking she shouted:

"You're no longer welcome! You may not come in!"

The man recoiled as if hit, just short of the threshold. His face was inhuman and cruel now.

"I will return," he hissed. "There is always someone to let me in. I will have you."

In a burst of dark magic and a flutter of wings, he disappeared. Left alone, the door gaping open and the cold creeping in, Yanka fought for control over herself. For agonising seconds she willed her cold limbs to move, until she could step forward and slam the door shut. She rammed the iron bolt into place, and let the bar fall into its hooks. Then all strength drained out of her and she slumped to the foot of the wall, shaking uncontrollably.

Stanislav woke to a hand over his mouth and a blade at his throat. He remained very still, barely breathing as his aching mind raced.

"Not a sound, or I'll kill you," a female voice whispered in his ear. "Come with me and I'll let you live."

He waited excruciating seconds for the cold metal to leave his neck. He gave a tiny nod, raising open hands towards his… aggressor? She was a small woman, light of build with a natural feline grace. She wore the greys and greens of a scout, the tight uniform emphasising her figure. The darkness was nothing to his eyes, and he freely took in her tilted eyes, her pale skin, her small nose, and her thin lips. She was beautiful. He mentally kicked himself for noticing these things not a full minute after she had threatened to slit his throat.

"Where?" He said hoarsely.

"Out. Take all you have."

He obeyed, not so much out of fear for his life but rather out of curiosity. Now her knife wasn't on his skin, he could easily drop her with a spell and wake the guardsmen. He chose not to. His blood beat at his temples, roaring in his ears. He had to make an effort to control his breathing, and found himself licking his lips. As quietly as he could, he gathered his few belongings, shrugged into his cloak, and slung his pack over his shoulder. The man next to him muttered and rolled over, but did not wake. Stanislav exhaled in relief as he gripped his staff with bloodless knuckles. He would have clubbed the man over the head. He was glad he did not have to. He tiptoed out of the barracks at her urging, exiting to biting cold. The mists spread the moonlight over the city and the snow shimmered in the ghostly light. It was plenty to see by even for normal eyes, he supposed. Once she had shut the door behind them without so much as a click, she turned towards him again.

"We're leaving the city and going north."

"At this hour?" He said.

"Particularly at this hour," she hissed. "As fast as we can. I just need to drop by a place on the way."

"I can't. I have a job here."

"You have a job with me now."

He hesitated. "You can pay me more?"

"Yes."

He doubted it, but her blue eyes never wavered. "You're fleeing," he realised in a whisper.

"None of your business. Follow me now."

He lunged forward and grabbed her arm. As he expected, she was thin under the warm uniform. Her wrist was brittle as a branch under his fingers. "Tell me what you're running from."

Suddenly he wasn't holding her anymore. His fingers found air where her delicate wrist had been and her blade was at his throat once more, her other hand gripping his hair.

"I pay you, you do what I say," she snarled. "Or I silence you."

He considered taunting her; certainly such a pretty young thing had never killed before. The words died unspoken. With her face so close to his, he saw into the hood of her cloak. Her long ears ended in points.

"You're an elf," he breathed.

"How observant," she said in a snarky tone. "Are you going to be sensible now?"

"Lower your blade," he said. "I'll follow you."

"I very much doubt that. You're going first."

She walked right behind him, no doubt with her dagger at his back as she led him towards the gates.

"How are we leaving the barracks?" He whispered urgently.

"Can you use magic on the guards?"

"Not unless want me to kill them."

She swore under her breath. "Let's do this the old-fashioned way, then."

Dragging him to a shadowy corner close to the gate, she took her dagger between her teeth and picked up a handful of snow, packing it into a tight ball. She retrieved her weapon, drew her arm back, and launched the snowball across the courtyard. The commotion drew the lone guard's attention and he left his post to investigate, long enough for the two of them to sneak out. She led him along dark streets to a house that seemed abandoned.

"Wait here," she snapped.

Before he could make a witty reply, she sheathed her dagger and jumped up, scaling the wall. She moved like a shadow, or maybe a spider. She disappeared onto the roof and he waited uneasily, not hearing a sound. Stanislav decided to keep watch and he scanned the street in both directions, his eyes useless against the swirling mist. There were no street lamps here so he strained his ears. There was a small sound above, and the elf dropped down next to him with a bundle strapped to her back. He bit back a shout. He had not heard her climb down at all. She eyed him coldly.

"Now we leave the city."

"The gates are closed at night. You can't just snowball your way out of this one."

"We're not going through the gates. I know a place."

The place turned out to be an iron grate in the wall, to which a shallow canal led. The water was black in the darkness, and without touching it Stanislav knew it was ice cold.

"Reassure me," he said, "we're not wading through?"

"Of course not. I've been scraping at this stone for the past two months, it should come loose."

She crept to the foot of the wall and started pushing at one of the building blocks. Upon closer inspection, Stanislav saw the mortar was indeed very damaged, but would it be enough to move the enormous slab of stone? He watched the elf struggle, but the stone did not budge. At her urging, he gave it a try as well. The stone was loose, but not enough to be moved by someone his strength. He was all too aware of time passing, of the moon travelling across the shrouded sky. Dawn was still a couple hours away, but a patrol could come anytime. He supposed it was not too likely; the stream was full of refuse, most of which remained stuck in the grate, and the smell made his eyes water. Even with the reek, once dawn came they would be all too exposed.

"Stand back," he sighed. "And be ready to run."

She looked up at him, but said nothing as she retreated. Stanislav raised his hand and felt his eyes grow cold as he called upon his magic. The power filled his mind, more intoxicating than liquor, more enticing than a woman's touch. He allowed himself a few seconds to delight in it, to drink in the darkness of his magic. He bathed in its cold, revelled in the flow of power. He could do anything. He could reduce this entire wall to rubble. A smile tugged at his lips. Reluctantly, he formed the spell and released it. A dark blast streaked towards the wall and hit the stone; the explosion shook chunks from the wall, and chips of mortar rained into the canal. The dust fell, revealing a hole where the loose stone had been. The block had been blown cleanly a metre out of the city. To her credit, the elf didn't stand and stare. She crouched, and took off at a dead run through the wall. Stanislav followed at a jog, already hearing startled voices behind him.

They ran as far as they could, following the river until they came to a coppice of weeping willows, their branches aflame with the colours of autumn. They all but dove into the trees and abundant shrubbery, Stanislav breathing hard as he crouched behind a bush, silvery in the darkness. He had to lower one knee to the ground, leaning on his fist until the pain in his side began to subside. Weak grey light trickled through the leaves.

"Whatever is chasing you," he panted, "I sure hope it won't track us."

"It will," she said. Infuriatingly, she wasn't gasping for breath. "We're only stopping until you catch your breath. Then it's time for stealth."

Blowing up that wall wasn't exactly stealthy, he grumbled inwardly. What had he got himself dragged into? For a pretty face, of all things. He shook his head. Her beauty hadn't convinced him. Waking to find his life threatened had done it. His heart had been pounding out of his chest, his mind instantly awake. He had forgotten everything except survival and the blood rushing through his veins. On the verge of death, he had felt so painfully alive. Besides, secrets had a nasty habit of hiding other secrets. It was just a hunch but he hoped following her would lead him to more power. Even if it just meant being free to use his spells, he would take the chance. What kind of officer scolded his soldiers for fighting, anyway?

"Answer me one thing at least," he said. "Why me?"

"Because you're a mage."

"Do I… know you?"

"I suppose not," she said hesitantly. "But I heard Makar tell you off for using your magic. So you must be powerful."

He frowned. "You heard him?"

"I eavesdropped," she admitted.

"Of course," he sighed. "And may I know the name of my new employer?"

"Yanka. And you're… Stanislav, was it?"

"That would be my name."

"Well met, Stanislav."

He could not help but chuckle. "It's the first time I hear this from someone after she put a knife to my throat."

She shrugged. "Needs must."

He had expected some kind of embarrassment, but he was disappointed. "What are you running from, anyway?" He asked again.

"My past," she said. "Not that I can remember it."

He only had more questions, but she shot him a hard look. "If you can chatter, you can run. Let's go."

He snapped his mouth shut and followed her through the forest.

pages.name: 06 - Eyes, Ears, and Noses
pages.content:
Makar woke at dawn with a distinct premonition; today would be a bad day. He wasted no time in trying to convince himself it was just a figment of his imagination; instead he got up and dressed and set to expecting the worst. He tucked his linen shirt into his trousers and tied them at the waist. He slung on his tabard and fastened the thin leather belt over it. He shaved and washed his face, scrubbed his teeth, and combed his hair just once. The water in the pitcher was cold but it had not frozen. As he emptied the washbasin out the window, the night's dream brushed against his consciousness, leaving an ache deep in his chest. Someone had spoken to him as he slept… he strained his mind, trying to remember. Like trying to catch mist. With a sigh, he abandoned the impossible task. The memory would return, or it would not. He had more immediate worries to address. Stretching, he left his quarters. He was on his guard with every step, as if expecting an attack in the guardhouse itself. That was unlikely of course, but an attack was not necessarily a dozen of beastmen charging in with fangs bared and claws seeking men's pulses. He had a quiet breakfast of bread and soup made of yesterday's leftovers and just as he exited the mess hall, his intuition materialised in the shape of a round, balding man dressed in faded velvets and moth-eaten lace.

"Sergeant Semyonovich?" The man asked, mopping the sweat from his forehead.

"I am he," Makar said.

"A word in private. My master has a task for you."

The soldier nodded and led the fat man into his office. The room was cramped with chests of drawers, cabinets containing maps, and endless reports bound in scrap fabric. Makar's desk, which he seldom used, had been varnished once but now bore the scars of many administrative battles. He sat in his chair, motioning for the visitor to take the other seat across the desk. What could bring a burgher to a guardhouse? Why had the man come himself, instead of sending a messenger? Makar controlled his anxiety, not without effort.

"What's this urgent task, then?" He asked, his hands steady on the desk.

"Well first off… ahem. Ippolit Valeryevich, in humble service to our lord and master Alwin Rurik von Muratova-Finsterthal…"

Makar motioned impatiently for the man to get to the point. The burgher gulped audibly.

"In the name of… ah… um… you are currently sheltering a criminal, a pale elf female with blue eyes and red-brown hair. You are to deliver her to Castle Krasnograd by this evening and no later."

The soldier kept a blank face, though his heart was pounding. "What crimes has she committed?"

"That is none of your concern," Ippolit snapped. "You are to produce her by tonight."

"Will she be judged then?"

The round man drew himself up. "You are overstepping yourself. I give you an order, you follow it. Questioning me is questioning our lord's authority."

"Very well," Makar sighed. "This was too important to send a courier, I take it?"

"That is…" he began, and stopped himself, glaring. "This conversation is at an end. You have your orders."

Without waiting for a reply, the burgher dropped from his chair and waddled to the door. He put a pudgy hand on the doorknob but before he could make a move to leave, the door opened from the outside, nearly knocking the burgher down to the floor. Not that the fall would hurt him much. Makar had to bite his lip to conceal a smile. The arrival of his deputy Samuil put a abrupt end to his amusement.

"Sergeant," the scarred man said as he saluted. "There was an attack during the night."

"Where?"

"By one of the canals."

Samuil stepped right up to the desk, pulling out a roughly drawn map of the immediate surroundings. He pointed to a circled spot with a gloved finger.

"There was no intrusion the patrol could see," he continued, "but there is a gaping hole in the wall."

"A hole? In the city wall?"

"I did not believe it myself, sir."

"With all due respect, Samuil…"

"It's real, Makar," the man said in a lower tone. "The patrol healer said she sees traces of magic. Someone blew up part of the wall."

Next to the door, the all-but forgotten burgher made a strangled noise, and ran out of the office.

"Who was that?" Samuil asked absentmindedly.

"More trouble," the sergeant sighed. "I want to see that wall with my own eyes, but first I need to find our new scout."

"The elf?"

The voice from Makar's dreams flitted closer to his consciousness, lingering just under the surface of his mind.

"The elf," he confirmed. "I need to speak with her. And also check on two men in the south wing infirmary. Hopefully both are alive."

Samuil raised an eyebrow but said nothing, falling into step behind Makar as he left the office. Through wooden corridors creaking in the morning's cold, they made for the closest destination, the guardswomen's barracks. Entry was denied to men, so the sergeant rapped on the banded pine door. It opened almost immediately, and he looked down on a diminutive blonde woman, one of his best scouts. Her hair was in disarray and she stifled a yawn.

"Makar? It's ungodly early."

"Sorry to disturb, Nastka. I need to speak with Yanka, it is urgent."

"The elf?"

"The very same."

"You're out of luck," she grimaced. "She snuck off last night. Her bed is cold, all her stuff is gone."

Makar bit back an oath as his insides twisted, the premonition he had upon waking taunting him. "Any idea why?" He prompted.

Nastka shrugged. "Second thoughts? She seemed shady. Good riddance if you ask me."

"You're probably right." He forced a smile. "Pardon the intrusion, my lady. I'll leave you to your morning rituals."

She giggled at the mock formality. "Same ritual for us all, m'lord. Ten laps of the yard, then off to breakfast."

"All the same, I leave you to it. Good day."

She saluted and he left, Samuil shadowing him.

"That's hardly a coincidence," the scarred man muttered.

"No doubt about that," Makar said. "All the more reason to find her."

"She could be anywhere in Krasnograd by now!"

"Or out of it," the sergeant said, his heart sinking.

"To the wall, then?"

"The infirmary first. I want to check on last night's visitors."

The small room was one of several infirmaries in the complex, holding only six beds. Disease being common, it was built with the idea to quarantine people early on to nip the epidemy in the bud, but it had never really worked. There were just too many people milling around the barracks, and by the time they started sneezing, the healers said, they had already passed on the disease.
