The sickrooms served mostly for the very ill or the severely injured who needed calm more desperately than the others. Makar nodded to the other two men present, though one was sleeping off a bad flu, judging by the colour of his nose. The other one was stretching his shoulders and arms as his right leg was bound to wooden splints. At the far end of the room, Erakho was just putting on his coat and Osten was sitting up in bed, still in his shirt.

"Gentlemen," Makar said, spreading out his arms in greeting. "I see the night treated you well?"

"As well as it could, considering," the half-orc muttered. "But he's alive so I must have done something right."

"I'm right here," Osten said, though a grin betrayed his stern tone.

"Good for you," Erakho retorted, "you're staying here. And resting. You're still tired."

"I'm feeling fine now."

Erakho shook his head. "None of that from you. You near collapsed from overexerting yourself."

"You can stay here and rest a few days," Makar said. "I can give you tasks that won't tax you. Can you read and write?"

"In the common tongue, yes," the blond man said.

He was still pale, and his eyes were marked by fatigue. He could probably be made to do inventory of supplies, or help prepare food. It didn't take a lot of stamina to peel potatoes. His strength clearly lay elsewhere, but as much as Makar wanted to see Osten fight, he would not put so much as a quarterstaff in his hands now. A broom, maybe. Even as he considered Osten, the sergeant felt Erakho's eyes on him; a piercing, searching gaze that began to make him uncomfortable. Makar opened his mouth to ask the reason for this scrutiny when the memory hit him with the force of an avalanche. It was only a whisper drifting from the mists of his dreams, but it was her voice. As he slept he had seen Inessa's warm eyes, from a time before the world's lights went out. Her soft whisper was almost a brush on his skin as she murmured… follow her. Makar blinked away tears, his chest hollow. Most days he kept himself busy and took care of the living instead of mourning the dead, but the pain was never far. Years ago now, a part of him had been torn out; the pain would never fade completely. The sergeant struggled to bring his mind back to the present, to keep his face calm and friendly. Erakho's eyes seemed to see right through his façade as he asked:

"Are you all right? You look like you've seen a ghost."

Heard one, maybe, Makar thought with crushing sorrow. He felt Samuil's concern from behind him. He had to be in control. He had to play it off as he always did, laugh and joke and reassure everyone. Time had not healed his wounds in the slightest; he had merely learnt to distract people from them.

"No ghosts here that I can see," he forced out. "But there is a matter of some concern to me."

It was really just a hunch. Erakho's green-brown eyes never shifted; anyone else would have snapped at him for staring. He was a cleaner, but…

"Erakho." It sounded like a plea. Makar cleared his throat. "You said you have a job but by any chance, do you have skills in tracking? Say, finding a missing person."

The half-orc blinked, taken aback. "I… would not say so. Not in a… conventional sense, at least."

Makar's eyes narrowed. "Explain."

"Well…" He shifted his feet, finally breaking eye contact as he looked around the room. "Usually people don't like to hear about it. But let's say, when you don't know where someone has gone, in a city this size, there are plenty of eyes, ears, and noses which could have noticed your person. I just tend to ask where others can't."

"You can use magic," Makar guessed from the evasive response.

"A little bit," the big man admitted.

"In a way that can help me find someone."

"Possibly."

"Who are you working for?"

"An orc named Zakhar. Cleaning duties. We get ordered to a different place each day."

"Not a problem, I'll have someone find him. I'm borrowing your talents for the time being."

"You… might well be disappointed," Erakho warned.

"Chances are I'll survive that," Makar said and motioned to Samuil to find a messenger. "You two are my guests for the time being but don't worry, I'll put you to work soon enough. I need to see to something. It won't take long, so in the meantime I'd suggest you go have some breakfast, inform any relatives of your change of employment. And gather anything you may need for a search. Osten, you may have your weapons back but please have a care for your health."

Both men nodded. As Makar turned to leave to finally inspect that wall, a lanky guard came running in.

"Sergeant," he panted, "I've been looking for you everywhere."

"Catch your breath man. What is it?"

"Stanislav's gone. Weapons and all. Like he's never been here in the first place."

Makar sighed.

There was a hole in the wall. Even at this early hour the place was full of people; curious bystanders, guards trying to maintain a semblance of order, masons awaiting instructions. Makar even spotted another burgher in a crimson dress and fur-lined cloak who was very obviously pressing a handkerchief to her nose. The towering wall was not in danger of collapsing from one missing stone, even considering the size of its building blocks. The missing stone had been dragged just outside the hole, with barely enough space to squeeze through the gap. Despite the use of magic, the stone itself wasn't very damaged. The grey mortar was almost gone, and it looked like the stone had been pushed out with overwhelming force. He rested his hand on the smooth stone, blueish from the presence of fool's silver. Chips of mica scattered inside gave it a starry glitter. It was Mourning slate, brought all the way from the quarries at the foot of the Mountains of Mourning. Makar could not begin to imagine how much it had cost to build this wall, hundreds of years ago; how many backs had been broken in the process. He waved to a small man in a scout's uniform.

"Any clues here?"

"One set of footprints for sure," the scout said. "Probably a human judging by the depth and size. The snow was disturbed outside, but with the snowfall and wind last night, I can't really make out anything. We'll need hounds, if they can still smell anything in this cold."

"We'd need wolves," Makar muttered.

The scout shrugged. "I'll be honest, we might need a small miracle to track whoever went through. We'll try. Can't guarantee anything."

"Do your best," Makar said, giving the man a pat on the shoulder as he ran off.

He didn't exactly have a miracle at hand. Or did he?

Erakho jogged through half-frozen streets, paying little attention to his footing. He slipped several times, fell once and scrambled to his feet. When he reached the backyard he spotted whiskers poking out of the crack in the wall. Smula the rat rushed out to meet him, her squeaks incomprehensible to him.

"Sorry friend, I can't understand you now. The magic isn't here. I need to check on mum."

He hoped she understood. He could not spare a moment to cast the spell. His hands shook as he unlocked the door and struggled out of his boots, scattering snow inside. He stumbled through the kitchen and into the small room beyond, where Valya was sitting slumped on one of the benches, her head atop her arms. She'd fallen asleep on the table, but she woke up as he approached. Her eyes widened and she jumped up, rushed to Erakho and caught him in a hug.

"Where were you?" She cried, her voice rough with sleep. "I was so worried!"

"I'm sorry mum," he said, hugging her back. "I'm so sorry. I'll explain everything, let me make you some tea."

She stepped back reluctantly, her eyes shining. With a stab of guilt to his gut, Erakho squeezed her hand before he returned to the kitchen. He swept out the snow he'd brought in then filled the pot with clean snow from the barrel, packing it in. He carried the black iron pot to the living room and hung it from the hook. Examining the fireplace, he grimaced. There wasn't so much as an ember left. The fire was dead, the place freezing. He stomped back outside to the lumber pile, picking up dry pine logs and thinner branches to serve as fire starters. He set the branches in a little heap and closed his eyes for a second, calling the land's whispers to him. He sensed threads of magic around him and guided one to the fireplace. As he opened his eyes, smoke rose from the branches and sparks soon began to crackle. He fed more pine to the fire and was soon rewarded with high yellow flames. The snow in the pot melted in no time, and it took only minutes before he sat at the table with his mother, both of them cradling hot mugs in the warming air. Erakho explained the situation with Osten, and why he had stayed overnight to watch over him. Valya relaxed, her shoulders slumping under the patched blanket she had draped over herself.

"And now I'm being, ah, employed by the sergeant, to find a missing person."

"Won't that be dangerous?" She asked anxiously.

"Not more than working for that bully Zakhar," he grumbled. "It will be fine I'm sure. But I don't know how long it will take, or if I'm going to be away from home."

"You're still so young…"

"I won't be alone, mum."

"I have a bad feeling nonetheless," she said. "Why you?"

"I'm not sure. Because of my magic I guess."

"What use would the town guard have for talking to rats?"

"Well… it's on me really, I offered. People don't pay attention to small animals but they are everywhere. They notice things, it's a matter of survival for them. Not just rats; there's a lot of bats here, cats and dogs, a good amount of birds…"

"Magic is dangerous," she said as she sipped her tea.

"I know. I'll be careful."

"As long as you come back to me in good health," she sighed.

"Always," he promised.

"Then you better not keep the sergeant waiting. If you're looking for a lost person, every moment could count."

He nodded and gulped down his tea, the hot drink burning his throat as he stood and headed upstairs into his room. What would he need to take with him? He had a threadbare backpack he used to carry food in when he had time to go to market. It may not last long, but it would have to do. He packed spare clothes, his razor, a piece of soap, a blanket. He only had the one pair of boots but they were good boots, broken in and sturdy. Better remember to get his boot grips as well. He took his treasures, a leather pouch filled with things he had collected over the years. It held leaves and feathers, stones, and even bits of insects. He wasn't too sure why he had picked them up but each of the little treasures seemed to whisper to him and he was reluctant to part with them regardless of their supposed lack of value. He took his waterskin and his walking staff. He always had a knife at his belt, a heavy hunting knife he'd had to use at his work a couple times. It had been a coming-of-age present; the handle was worn smooth and seemed to fit perfectly into his hand.

As he ran down the stairs, Valya gave him a small leather scrip which he immediately recognised.

"You'll need these more than me, so no arguing," she said sternly. "I can get more herbs. You may not have time to stop and pick leaves."

"Are you sure?"

She nodded, smiling to banish the worry in her eyes. "Maybe you will find someone who needs them even more than either of us."

He took the pouch of herbs with reverence. "I'll use them well."

"Of course you will. I've taught you properly, have I not?"

"I'll miss you, mum."

"Only for a short while. I'll be here waiting for you."

"The rats will watch over you in my stead."

"I know. I'll keep your friends fed," she promised. "Off with you now. Take care of yourself. Always remember you are the light of my life."

"I love you, mum."

And with one last hug, Erakho was gone.

"You're going to ask animals?"

Erakho nodded. "People don't know where your elf lady went, do they?"

"I suppose not," Makar said. "So how does the spell work?"

"We're going to need a lot of food."

"As a spell component?"

Erakho smiled. "As a bribe."

With Osten's help they gathered scraps of meat and vegetables, dry heels of bread, cheese from which small bits of salt seeped out, and even some grain. They sat in the courtyard at first for a wide sweep, as Erakho thought of it. Pigeons and crows came first, cooing and cawing as they spotted the scattered grain. To the half-orc who performed the ritual, these sounds made sense and he could translate them to the common tongue with ease.

"You can really… understand them?" Osten asked.

"Yes. They're mostly squawking over the food now, but once they've had some we can have a conversation."

The prospect seemed to make him deeply uneasy, but Erakho ignored it and focused on the birds. When he spoke, his words sounded normal to him until the magic snatched them from the air and warped them into sounds the animals would understand. For birds it was mostly sound. For most beasts, some words would be magically translated to smells. The bigger part of their communication was missing, as even magic could not create the twitch of a tail or the flap of a wing, but it carried intention and that was enough.

"Have you seen an elf?" He asked the birds, "pale skin and red-brown hair, wearing the colours of the forest?"

There were many responses amidst fluttering feathers, none very informative. People made no sense to animals, who ignored them unless threatened… or bribed. Erakho had prepared with this in mind.

"Tell your friends," he said. "There is food for those who have seen her. There is warmth and care for those who want it. Tell your family and your allies."

The birds dispersed and only a few minutes later a new flock arrived. One crow had seen her, she claimed, climbing up to a roof and disappearing through a hole in the tiles. She had a friend with her, the bird said, another person. Erakho tried to pry, but the bird had flown away to sleep without investigating further. He got similar answers over the course of two hours (and as many wild magic surges).

"It definitely happened at night," he said to the other men. "We should be asking owls and foxes. Cats, if we can find one who was nearby."

"Lead the way," Makar said.

"I'll leave you to it. I'm staying here and getting some rest."

Osten was pale as he shuffled off to the infirmary. The other two left the courtyard and walked through the streets, following the vague directions Erakho had pieced together. He was focused on his task and initially didn't notice Makar was speaking to him.

"You are practiced in medicine?" The soldier asked again.

"Somewhat. My mum is good with herbs, she taught me. Magic can help."

"Good. If this man hunt, or woman hunt as it were, went wrong, I can count on your skills."

He made it sound like a question. "Sure. You're paying me now."

Makar chuckled. "That's one reason, I suppose."

"What other reason is there to work?" Erakho asked absentmindedly.

"Many. It depends. You're wearing your chain. I thought you didn't like it?"

"Force of habit."

"As good a reason as any."

"I think that's the roof the crows meant, maybe."

They stopped and examined their surroundings. It was a narrow street made darker by the overhangs from the houses' second stories. The ground would have been churned to mud if it wasn't frozen over. Erakho licked his lips and tilted his head up, closing his eyes and focusing with all his might. Crows had mentioned a warm updraft, a feature more meaningful to them than any visual elements. For a flightless creature, it was all but impossible to find. Sighing, Erakho looked back down and searched for cracks in the walls. Rats tended to be forthcoming with information, for the right price (usually, cheese). They had a fondness for gossip, little of which was reliable. Sometimes the rodents told stories to one another for the sole pleasure of inventing and exaggerating grand feats.

He performed the ritual again, without any side effects. Dropping crumbs at the foot of walls, he waited — but did not have to wait long. Quivering noses and whiskers appeared, and tiny paws reached for the food. Erakho began asking his questions again, mentally filtering out the less-than-useful answers.

"I saw her," said a young rat with a notched ear. "Up the wall, not a sound, like a spider."

"Where did she go after that?"

"Into the attic and back down. Another person, human smell, male smell, magic smell. They left together."

"Which direction did they take?"

"That of danger!" The rat squeaked. "There, we don't go. Claws and fangs, quick in the dark."

The little rodent had communicated direction by pointing down the street with his nose, whiskers trembling. Erakho pulled a piece of cheese from his pocket and placed it in front of the rat, who pounced on it.

"How very generous!" He squeaked around a mouthful of cheese. "Watch yourself if you follow. You are big, but claws are sharp."

"Thank you, little one. I will be careful."

"Bring more food some time."

Erakho straightened and stretched his back as he reported to Makar.

"What do you suppose they meant by claws?" The sergeant asked.

"A cat probably. That's good for us; cats' senses are good, and they're generally closer to people. They don't care about what we do, but they notice."

"What about dogs?" Makar asked as they walked.

"Dogs care too much, if you can call it that. They get so excited to talk to a person, it's difficult to get any less from them than half their life story."

The soldier snorted with laughter, no doubt imagining it. They spent the better part of the day searching and talking; Makar asked people if they had seen Yanka, and towards the evening he added Stanislav's description. Erakho asked small animals, with widely varying results but generally the beasts proved to be more informative than the people, on account of having different sleep schedules and sharper senses. Neither were surprised when the search led them back to the hole in the city wall, which was being guarded during the investigation. The two men shuffled back to the barracks just in time for dinner. Makar seemed lost in thought and was uncommonly quiet, which Erakho appreciated; the repeated use of magic, the surges, and the many questions had left him with a splitting headache. He ate his meal with haste to escape the noise of the mess hall and retired to the infirmary where Osten was already asleep, writhing beneath his blankets as if in the clutches of a nightmare. Too tired to check on him, the half-orc stripped to his smallclothes, crept into bed and finally found restorative sleep.

pages.name: 07 - The Round Turnip
pages.content:
Stanislav stumbled after the elf through the snowy forest. She seemed to float above the ground, leaving shallow footprints while he struggled. Maybe she somehow walked on hidden ice every time. The mage wished he knew a spell to walk on top of snow, or erase their tracks, or melt the snow. Anything, really. Yanka had insisted on moving fast over sneaking, claiming the next snowfall would cover their tracks soon enough anyway. They still trailed pine branches behind them to muddle the tracks somewhat, though he doubted the rudimentary strategy would fool anyone. It was morning, though he could no more gauge the hour than see the sun; he only knew because they had been running most of the night and it was lighter now. Yanka had set a murderous pace, running then catching their breath at a quick walk, then running again. Stanislav did not consider himself weak by any means but this speed was taking a serious toll on him. His new employer did not seem to struggle with the pace any more than with the snow. In fact he could hardly see her most of the time as her scout's uniform made her blend into their surroundings. He only picked out her form now and then, against a backdrop of blazing red leaves. He could have kept up with the pace, a little longer at least, had his head not seemed ready to fall off his shoulders. He called for a halt, to no avail.

In the moment he decided to cast a spell, Stanislav knew it was a bad idea. He wanted to blame the landscape for it. He had never been out of Krasnograd before; the twisting streets, the star-speckled Mourning slate, and the darkness had become part of him. All these bushes and trees splattered fiery colours on snow and stone; even in the weak light it was overwhelming. He had broken into another world by blasting a hole into the wall. He was chased, if only by association. Stanislav thought he was familiar with fear and he was forced to admit this was different. He knew Krasnograd well and had not thought about how vast the world outside would be, or how small he was. In the distance, the trees and shrubs blurred into a wall of crimson flame. The glittering snow left not a speck of shadow. He was too exhausted to scream so he grabbed his staff and sought magic, beckoning invisible threads to carry the words his voice could not. He whispered his plea for a halt, and let the spell carry it to Yanka. It was a basic spell, one-way telepathy, and just now it was far too much for him.

With a snap, pain cracked through his head. He cried out and stumbled, tried to catch himself on the nearest tree. His hand slipped, the forest lurched around him and he found himself lying on his side in the snow, his shoulder aching but it was nothing next to the pain in his head. A presence at his side — his elven companion, quietly asking questions he could not make out. His mind blurred and the words tied themselves into a tangle without beginning nor end. He remembered hitting his head just two days prior; he had done a lot of sleeping since, but the headaches endured.

"Stanislav! Look at me!"

With an effort, eyes half-closed against the light, he turned his head. Yanka's form was fuzzy as if obscured by fog. Her pale skin seemed to melt into the grey light, ghostly and indistinct.

"I heard you, in my mind," she said. "I'm sorry. I didn't realise you were so exhausted. It's light anyway, let's hide and rest. Can you walk?"

"I can try." His words bounced in his skull. Pulling himself to his knees, he felt nauseous.

"You're… really pale," Yanka said, which was rich coming from her. "Did you hit your head?"

"Suppose I did. Not now. Two days ago. I was pushed, nearly cracked my skull on a rock."

Her eyes widened. "You did what? And you're running around?"

"Well you didn't leave me much of a choice, did you?"

Standing, he leaned against the trunk of an ancient willow and waited for his head to stop spinning. There had been the injury at the skirmish… he thought another man would still be sleeping it off. It had been bad before he used magic, but the pain had become lightning in his head when he cast the spell. He wiped his nose with the back of his hand and groaned at a red smear on his glove. Yanka's bright blue eyes were filled with concern.

"I'll find us a good place to rest," she said. "Stay here. I won't be long."

"Hey… wait! Don't…"

Stanislav's protests faded into the mist. He leaned his head back against the tree, tasting blood. She would not abandon him, right? Not after going through the trouble of… practically abducting him. His magic… it still worked? It had to. Why had a simple spell hurt him so much? The pain was fading now, though the earlier migraine still pulsed inside his skull. She better not lose her way. How did one tell these trees apart? Every direction looked the same. He heard a stream flowing nearby, but could not see it. There was no wind. Despite the cold, a blanket of fog covered the ground, making it difficult to gauge the depth of the snow. The mist was thicker than in the city, making his exposed face damp and numb. It seemed to curl around him with a will of its own, and he could do nothing but breathe it in, breathe in tendrils of gaseous ice trickling into his lungs. He caught himself before he could shake his head, deciding the sudden motion would not help matters. Instead of trying to ignore his surroundings, he looked inward. His eyes still scanned the forest but his mind sought the darkness within, the force behind his magic. It was unscathed; he imagined a swirl of dark smoke in his chest, but really it was nothing he had ever seen. It was an ever-present companion, like a stone in his pocket or an old scar on his finger. His mind caressed the feeling of power, shielded it, cradled it.

"I've found a spot. Come on."

Stanislav flinched. His companion had appeared right in front of him, where he'd been looking, yet the forest had been empty one second and she had been here the next.

"How do you… do that?" He grunted.

"Do what? Follow me, it's not far."

Leaning on his staff, he trudged through the snow and mist, not seeing the forest around him. He watched his feet, trying to spot uneven ground or jutting rocks but to no avail; he kept tripping and stumbling. The sound of water grew louder, and they came to a rushing stream just downriver of a clear pool.

"It's just up the slope. A really good find."

He had to admit the elf was right. The river had hollowed out a bend in the rocky soil then deserted it seasons ago, leaving a shallow dry cave. Yanka had to point it out for him as it was obscured by crimson shrubs with long, narrow leaves. In places the shrubs' branches intertwined with the hanging roots of a cluster of Dragonclaw willows, their twisting branches heavy with rust-coloured leaves. At Yanka's urging, Stanislav crept into the cave. Shielded from the mist, the place felt almost warm. She snuck in beside him and arranged the branches to better hide them.

"Lucky," he mumbled.

"I almost stumbled into this cave. We're going to have to make a fire, but as small as possible."

As she spoke she opened her big pack and took out supplies. With river rocks she build a fire pit, and stacked some tinder inside it. She closed her eyes, waved her fingers, and a spark ignited the wood chips.

"I thought you couldn't use magic," Stanislav said.

"You've seen the height of my power, I'm afraid. Sometimes I can make a puff of wind."

"Can't we all."

She rolled her eyes. "Not that kind of wind. I don't suppose you have any food or water?"

He shook his head and winced. She frowned, and continued: "We'll share, for now. I can only carry so much, so we'll have to resupply on the way."

Stanislav asked the burning question on his mind. "Do you even know where we're going?"

"Not… exactly," she sighed. "I'm looking for a town, but I don't know where it is. People are rather closemouthed about it, don't really blame them though."

He raised an eyebrow. She busied herself with a small pot she hung on a blackened tripod over the fire. Filling the pot from a waterskin which she then handed to Stanislav, she unwrapped a bag of beans, dried mushrooms, and ribbons of dried carrot. From a smaller bundle she sprinkled in some herbs and stirred with a ladle which had seen better days.

"The stew will be a while so let's get comfortable in here."

She unstrapped a single bedroll from her pack and shrugged apologetically.

"You were planning to travel the wilds alone?" He asked.

"Or with better-equipped companions. I know," she said, holding up a hand to forestall additional grumbling, "I didn't leave you much choice. I had to leave in a hurry. We'll manage. Wrap yourself up in this, will you, you look frozen to the bone."

She handed him a big blanket, thin and lightweight but surprisingly warm. He settled on the bedroll with his back against the rounded wall of the cave, winding the blanket around him. He had not realised how cold he was, and the warmth creeping back into his body nearly lulled him to sleep. His growling stomach and pounding headache kept him awake. Yanka gave him a piece of flatbread and a chunk of dark yellow cheese. He started gnawing on the dry fare in between gulps from her waterskin. She took quick nibbles from her own food, seeming perfectly at ease in between curling roots. She had an almost dainty way of eating, he noticed, holding even a small piece of bread in both hands. Did squirrels eat like this? He fought an urge to giggle, and near choked on crumbs for his trouble. Clearing his throat, he asked:

"So you don't exactly know where this town you're looking for is. Any clues?"

"North of Krasnograd for certain." She hesitated.

"Are we going north? I can't tell, with the clouds and the trees and the mist."

"I'm sure," she nodded. "The forest gives clues on where north is. Or south really, so it's a matter of turning around."

"Uh-huh. So about this town? Does it have a name?"

"Volyansk," she said dreamily. "People whisper it's a place of freedom, away from the nobility's eyes."

The warmth from the blanket suddenly seemed an illusion. "You… have trouble with the nobility?"

She looked away, then nodded once. Stanislav shivered. He knew what he had to do. Throw the blanket off, leave this place, and… return to Krasnograd? His absence would have been noticed by now; uncomfortable questions would await his return. Press on? He had no idea where north was, even by way of turning around. Alone, he'd be wandering the forest until the cold or wild beasts took him. He felt like he'd swallowed an icicle.

"You're a danger to be around," he hissed. "The wardens will come for you."

"I know!" She exclaimed. "If only I could remember why! This man came to me last night, calling me Snowdrop, beckoning me to come with him."

"A burgher? In the middle of the night?" Stanislav asked, more panicked than he'd been alone in the forest.

"A noble," she said grimly. "No one else… looks like that. So… opulent. No one else has that stink."

The world flickered before his eyes. "You're really going to get me killed," he breathed.

"Not if we can find Volyansk. We'll be safe there."

"You don't even know where it is!"

"I'll ask!" She said defiantly, but her chin trembled. "Discretely. We'll find it."

"I would leave you behind if I could find my way through those gods-forsaken trees."

"Appreciate the honesty," she snapped, "but you're stuck with me for now if you don't want to be Owlbear dinner. Or snack, I suppose."

"Snack? Excuse you, you'll be the snack. I'm a full meal."

"Only with the blanket as seasoning, scrawny."

"At least I don't half-dissolve in the mist," Stanislav muttered.

"Neither do I, your cracked skull is making you see things."

"My skull is still as whole as they go, thank you very much."

"Could have fooled me," she grinned.

He sighed and rolled his eyes, which produced a flash of pain. Groaning in surprise, he pressed cold fingers to his forehead.

"I have something for pain," Yanka said, digging into her pack.

"Save it," he said. "I'll try to sleep, it might help."

"As you wish. I can keep watch a while. I hope you don't snore."

"I hope you don't snore," he muttered and curled up.

Despite the hard stone below the bedroll, despite the cold and his hunger and headache, Stanislav fell asleep immediately.

Yanka should have been terrified. Chased by the nobility, slowed down by an injured companion, and still unable to find her lost memories, she should have been half-mad with fear. She was not. She had travelled a good amount throughout Strazhland before and she was no stranger to the cold, but it was her first time cross-country in the Krasnyles. When she'd passed through a few years prior, she had kept her eyes on the road and walked as far as she could. Now, she saw the forest. She breathed in the delicate, chilly scent of snow. It twined with a faint smell of rotting leaves, of damp soil, of wet stone. She'd always thought of herself as a city girl, but these smells were home somehow. She felt much safer than she had in Krasnograd.

She leaned against the roots lining the cave wall and crossed her legs. She had never felt the need to lie down and be senseless for hours on end like other people did. She needed rest of course, but unlike humans she could spend some time sitting still and letting her thoughts drift. She did lay in beds when the opportunity was provided, if the bed was clean and somewhat comfortable. It was more relaxing than sitting. Was it an elf thing? She wasn't sure. The cave beckoned her to rest; the ground was almost soft where she'd sat, and the roots curled comfortably around her back. She kept an eye on the simmering stew, listening to Stanislav sleeping. He did snore, but not terribly loud. All the same, she hoped it wouldn't be heard outside their hiding place. That would be one way for their adventure to end…

Inevitably, her thoughts turned to the silk-stinking man. The trimmed beard, the forest-green shine in his hair, the caressing voice. He had all but promised to restore her memories, not so much as a boon or a bribe but just… a fact. A minor inconvenience he would soon fix. His clothes spoke of wealth and his voice spoke of authority, but even dressed in rags and silenced he would exude overwhelming power. She knew the rumours about the nobility, of course. Everyone did, and everyone agreed to not speak of it, at least not publicly. It had become natural for her thoughts to skirt around this topic so she had to make a conscious effort to alter their flow and think on it, really think on the rumours. Yanka had once stayed a few weeks with a widow who had frequently gathered her "knitting circle"; in truth half the grandmothers in the village. The elf had been recovering from a nasty cold, and had the kindly old lady not treated her, she was not sure she'd be here to remember their gossiping.

"Why do you suppose the aristocrats are all young and beautiful?" One asked, her eyes on the sock she was darning.

"Of course they aren't all young and beautiful," a wrinkled crone retorted. "No one is. The ugly ones stay hidden. They're people like us, just rich."

"You would not say so if you had met one is person," Yanka's host said, waving her finger. "Oh, my Gaspar's memory forgive me, but the one I met was a dream in velvets and fur, perfect calves and smooth hands, and eyes that made the crimson forest seem drab. He looked at me and I wished I was young and beautiful too, and he would make me a servant in his castle. I would serve tea and buttered buns to him all day."

Another one shook her head as she worked out a tangle in her yarn. "You're this old, and silly as a maid still. They don't make pretty people servants. They kill them for being too pretty. The aristocrats are a jealous bunch, and make no mistake."

"How dare you! They saved my children, when the Peryton flock attacked twenty-five winters ago, and Lady Tarasovna didn't do a thing! Now my daughter has a child of her own, and it's thanks to the nobles. They're blessed by the gods with beauty and strength, and magic that don't blow up in their faces."

"That's impossible," another snorted in between two sips of ungodly strong tea. "Magic do blow up in everyone's face."

"Listen to the wizard speaking," her friend giggled. "There's no magic to them. They're elves with short ears, that's all. Elves don't get old and wrinkly either. They do have the ears though, I saw them when I was still a waitress down in the docks in Krasnograd, before I married Valerian. The aristocrats just don't have the ears. They're elves."

"I heard a rumour," said a dwarven lady who was speaking up for the first time. "My sons bring supplies to Castle Krasnograd. They say the deliveries are all wrong. The food shipments just aren't enough for the whole castle, and not fancy enough for all this nobility."

"Well maybe they just eat the same potatoes as us then!"

"You're not listening," the dwarf whispered. "They don't eat potatoes like us all. Why do you really think young people are disappearing?"

A hush descended over the room, and the dwarven lady waited for effect before delivering her theory: "They eat the memories of young people. Beautiful people have easier lives, they yield the sweetest memories."

"You cannot be serious," the tea-sipping grandmother snapped. "The aristocrats don't abduct anyone. The dwarves do, and turn them into statues."

The dwarven lady paused in her work and shot a withering glare at her friend. Absorbed in her tea, the other woman did not notice.

"And they're not elves," she continued between sips, in a tone dripping with superiority. "They're dwarves. Taller than the mountainfolk, and they shave their beards to be prettier. That's why the bearded dwarves take the beautiful ones. It's a war between them."

"You ever wonder," Yanka's host cut in, "why they throw parties when they get married or win a battle, but never when a child is born?"

This caused another silence, eventually broken by the now much grumpier dwarven lady: "They keep their children hidden, because… because…"

"You have no idea," another snorted. "They obviously stay indoors way too much, and die young. All the nobles do. You think I would have grown so old if I didn't walk the five miles uphill to the lake every morning? And baked the bread myself? They have others bake their bread, and they die young."

"You only got old because you're ugly."

"Who said that?!"

"They don't die young," the dwarf insisted, weighing every word. "They have powerful magic from eating sweet memories. They eat memories so they may never age, and wield magic that can kill with a thought. They're not like us, mark my words."

The conversation devolved into squabbles, eventually shifting to safer topics. Yanka had fallen asleep then, despite being "treated" to the bitter tea. She was not sure how much belief she could lend to the knitting circle's tales; some rumours were definitely impossible. Magic that killed with a thought? Come on. But it was clear the aristocracy was of a different flesh, sibylline and distant. Another race certainly, though it did not need to mean a lot. Yanka herself was not human, and she was far from exceptional. Though one particular noble seemed to disagree with this, she thought bitterly. One of the rumours haunted her mind.

They eat memories so they may never age. Yanka half-heartedly felt for her missing memories, like fumbling in complete darkness. Of course she found nothing but a hollow filled with mist, aching sensations of familiarity, and a stab of loss. Had her memories been consumed, never to be returned again? Had the man effortlessly lied to her? It made too much sense. She felt suddenly ill, violated. She… she had to get to the bottom of this. She had to find out the truth. She felt at her head as if looking for a groove, her stomach churning in revulsion. If this was true… if the silk-stinking man had stolen her memories forever… oh, cost what it will, she would make him pay.

For hours she was lost in dark thoughts, until her companion stirred and sat up.

"What time is it?" He said sleepily.

"Time to be gone," she muttered. "We eat, then we leave."

"Did you sleep?"

"I rested."

He looked unconvinced, but didn't pry. The stew had turned into a mushy soup and it was burnt at the bottom, so they ate what they could without scraping too much. Yanka cleaned the pot in the stream, boiled water to refill her waterskin, and packed her supplies. Stanislav stood wrapped up in his cloak, either still drowsy or merely lost in thought. They set off, and even Yanka had trouble gauging the hour. It was past midday, she decided. She remembered a village not far from here, small but they had an inn. It was home to farmers, easy to miss. Spending the night there should not get them noticed, and Stanislav looked like he could use a real bed. If she could find the north road, it would not be difficult to get to the settlement. She looked around for signs of passage and found none, but the trees seemed thinner in the east. How she knew this direction was east, with the diffuse light trickling through the clouds and mist, she wasn't sure. Yanka wasn't about to turn her nose up at a clue, however shrouded its origin.

They walked in muffled silence, mist swirling around their legs and snow crunching under their boots. Even Yanka was getting too warm for comfort when she all but stumbled on a dirt path. She motioned Stanislav to stop and hide as she crept forward to scout. It was not the north road, for sure. An offshoot of it? She hoped the village was nearby. She crept through the shrubbery until she spotted fields in the distance. Rushing back to Stanislav who was resting his back against a tree, she reported on her findings.

"Not too far to these fields, we should be able to sleep in a bed tonight."

"I wouldn't mind that too much," he muttered, rubbing his temples.

"Does it still hurt?"

"Not as much. But using magic is troublesome. It's probably nothing a little rest can't fix," he hastened to add. "I did hit my head pretty hard."

They set off down the dirt path, where only a thin layer of snow covered the hard-packed soil. After walking in deep snow for hours, Yanka felt lighter on her feet than ever. The odd sensation from earlier returned; eagerness, excitement, light-headed joy. A feeling of returning home after being away for far too long. She glanced at her companion, wondering if he shared her strange elation. Stanislav was using his staff for support despite the flat ground, but a smile tugged at the corner of his mouth.

"You seem happy," she said.

"Happy? I don't know. More impatient, or eager I suppose. I'd never left Krasnograd before."

"Does it not worry you, then? You're leaving your entire life behind."

"It wasn't a very fulfilling life," he admitted. "I was… surviving. One job after the next, just to see another day. Always keeping my head down. Hiding. Now I have a chance to walk in the open."

"It's not any less dangerous," she warned. "We've been lucky so far, but even this close to the city, the woods are full of hungry beasts."

"That's not really what I mean," he said, looking at the darkening sky. "You wanted me as a companion because I can use magic. Not in spite of it. Usually people are afraid of it; when they learn I'm a mage, they back off. Not you."

She shrugged. "Magic is dangerous to everyone. Even the tiny spells I can work have blown up in my face before. It's life. And besides… when we're chased by a pack of wolves, we don't care much about running through thorny bushes, right?"

"I suppose so."

"So there's my reason. Your magic is a lesser evil I'm all too happy to contend with, if it can save me from the aristocrat chasing me. Or if it could help me remember."

"You have gaps in your memory?" He asked.

"Yes." She shook her head. "From years ago. I just remember fleeting sensations, bits and pieces. It's like my memories are choked with fog."

They walked in silence for a moment, Stanislav looking down as he processed the information. As the forest gave way to fields, the light faded to the treacherous gloom preceding sundown.

"I tried working healing spells before," he said, "but no luck somehow. I'll keep it in mind, but it's better if we find someone who knows what they're doing."

"I'd like that too," she said. "Appreciate the intention, though."

"You're my boss now," he said absentmindedly. "You die, I get no pay."

"How pragmatic."

He shrugged. Sighing, Yanka looked around hoping to spot the village's palisade. The darkness didn't hinder her sight, but it was dreary and she longed for a bath. It wasn't yet full dark but the fields were deserted. Lonely scarecrows dotted rows of turned earth. What could grow in the deepening cold, she wondered. She wasn't curious enough to ask the locals; that would be noticed.

"Yanka?" Stanislav said in a thin voice. "Hurry."

"Why? Did you see something?" She searched their surroundings, but nothing so much as rustled. The fields were dead silent under a blanket of mist.

"I don't like this place," he said and quickened his step.

He was all but running and her legs were just that much shorter so she kept up at a trot, glancing on either side of the path. At this pace they quickly reached the village, which was surrounded by a deep trench. A thick wall topped with a walkway and palisade rose from just behind the trench, which was crossed by a mouldering bridge. They were stopped at the gate before the bridge by two nervous guards.

"Travelling this late at night? Where from? Where to?" The one asked.

"I'm going to see my sister in the country," Yanka replied smoothly. "From Krasnograd."

From the corner of her eye, she saw Stanislav shift his weight. She prayed he would catch on the tense atmosphere and remain quiet; this was no time to attract attention.

"Dangerous here at night," the other guard said. "Don't be out this late. Bears and wolves. Boars are upset these days, one of the woodmen was gored last week. Ice spiders prowl."

"We made a push for this village," Yanka said. "Didn't mean to be out this late. We're just passing through and leaving tomorrow."

"See that you do. We don't want trouble here. Welcome to Kratkedny."

She bowed her head, and they were let in. Even for nightfall, the village was quiet. The main street was lit somewhat, but with the lamps few and far between, the houses were steeped in ghostly gloom. They found a hulking building with a sign hanging on creaking hinges, painted with a single, majestic turnip. Golden light seeped from under the door.

"Real beds, here we come," Yanka said happily.

She was hoping to cheer up her companion, but with a grim expression he pushed open the door and strode in. A hush fell over the common room as they entered, giving Yanka an unpleasant shiver. She felt like she'd been caught eavesdropping. A round innkeeper walked up to them, her grey hair tied with faded ribbons on either side of a motherly face. She was smiling, but Yanka saw a glimmer of unease in her eyes.

"Welcome to the Round Turnip, my darlings," she said. "It's late to be on the roads, I'd advise you avoid being out so late in the future. But you made it here safe and sound! Dinner is roasted roots, dandelion salad, and freshly smoked sausages. I have rooms with separate beds if you want to share… or one bigger bed if you are a couple."

The innkeeper winked. Heat crept up Yanka's neck as she felt painfully aware of Stanislav standing right beside her.

"Separate beds, please," he said. "We're just travelling together. And she drools in her sleep."

She shot him a glare, but he didn't notice. He elbowed her until she took out her coin pouch, fished out silver coins, and handed them to the innkeeper who bustled away gesturing at one of the serving girls. Yanka received a key, and they both went upstairs to leave their packs and cloaks. The room barely had enough space to walk between the narrow beds and the washbasin was chipped, but it was clean and didn't smell of mould. Yanka stretched, the fatigue of the day beginning to catch up with her.

"Dinner, bath, and sleep," she said, stifling a yawn.

"Did you notice people getting quiet when we arrived?" Stanislav said sombrely.

"Yes. It worries me, but what can we do about it now?"

"Not much. Something here… unsettles me. Keep an eye open."

"Sure will," she said. "We're not staying long anyway. We'll be gone at first light."

"I would prefer that, yes," he muttered. "And the earlier the better. Were people insisting about the late hour? It's really not that late."

"They get up bright and early to work the earth, I imagine," she said, but it sounded unconvinced even to her.

"I do hope you know what you're doing," he muttered

"I know we want to leave the Krasnyles behind," she said. "And leave no trace of our passage."

"Then I hope people didn't take as much notice as they seemed."

"They probably just turn in early too. Come on now, I could go for a proper meal."

"A meal you couldn't get a chance to burn," he said with a smirk.

"That was unnecessary," she grumbled.

"Am I wrong?"

She made a show of snorting and sulking, seeing him smirk out of the corner of her eye. Even better, as they returned to the common room for their dinner, people paid them no mind at all.
